#363SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine
Not to sound like a prick, but the fight should be fairly easy if everyone in the raid is getting a tremor totem. I've killed him both having and not having a tremor totem in my group, and honestly the difference in avoiding Doomfires is night and day. . . without a tremor totem I have to plan to be at least 30 yards away from any Doomfire when a fear is coming, whereas with a tremor totem I'm generally safe at least 15 yards away. Also, my DPS time increases dramatically with a tremor totem, you spend a lot less time feared.

If it's the same people who are actually dying first on each attempt, you need to deal with them however your guild deals with people who are wiping you. If you use SWS, it has a nifty log feature for everyone in the raid so you can see why they're dying. /SWL and it's pretty self-explanatory. If they can't fix their performance, you NEED to remove them from the raid. Tell them that you have to replace them if they can't improve their performance.

One thing that can help a lot is to have one of your more capable players watching the fear cooldown timer. 5 seconds before the cooldown is up, and then every 10-15 seconds, have him verbally remind the raid over vent that the fear is coming, the fear is coming, the fear is coming. For us at least, it helps the raid remember to focus on getting away from any and all Doomfires in their area.

Once your raid isn't dying to Doomfires, it should only be the relatively hard to control combos such as grip + burst that wipe you. Have the raid bring or your guild bank might be able to supply the raid with Purification Potions. People should save their potion cooldowns for survival potions, such as Purification Potions and health / protection potions, rather than use them on DPS pots like haste, destruction, and if they can avoid it, mana.

As far as skipping him, we skipped all of Hyjal this week to make sure we'd have time to get our first Illidan kill. Archimonde's loot table is all very good, though, he has the same ilvl as Illidan does, and nothing he drops will get sharded really. On the other hand, you can basically do all of BT/ Hyjal in Karazhan / crafted gear, so it's not like you really need the loot.
#364SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Zwink
We've killed Archimonde every week, except for the week we pushed to kill Illidan. I consider him on farm status somewhat, but he is definitely the encounter that takes us the longest to repeat week after week. It takes us a few hours every week to get it down. Sometimes it'll take no time and others we'll spend hours. Constantly throughout the fight I am telling people to be cautious; to be extremely cautious. My damage on that fight is next to nothing, barely more than our main tank sometimes. I could certainly do more, but melee dps does so much more damage to Archimonde that they practically win the fight for you if you can stay up for 7 minutes. We always have a group of 3 rogues, 1 feral druid, and 1 fear warded shaman. Every range dps class needs to realize that their damage is meaningless and the number one thing for them is survival. When the fear cool down is up no range should be anywhere near doom fires. If that means they can't dps for a solid 30 seconds, so be it.

Normally we bring 2-3 Shamans and 2 Fear Wards, but this week we only had 1 Shaman and 1 Fear Ward. Like others have said, the more shamans you bring the better off you are.
#365SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Snowy
I consider Archimonde solidly on farm. We probably would have one shot him this week if it wasn't for a Spirit of Redemption priest dying -- can't wait for that bug to be fixed. So we just killed him on the 2nd pull instead.

Keep in mind that we usually bring 5 shamans for this though. If you have a shaman in every group, and you have a pvp trinket as backup, there's really very little excuse anyone has for dying.

Understand something about Doomfire -- it will hit some people occasionally and it's hardly the end of the world. This is not a healing intensive fight otherwise. Otherwise, as Zwink said, ranged classes need to think survival first. DPS is something I do inbetween making sure I'm away from Doomfires. This is not the fight to try to squeeze in extra DPS or try to top the charts -- which is going to be melee anyways. Nobody is going to look at an Archimonde parse for DPS evaluations, so forget about it. If you do 600 DPS and never get hit by Doomfire, you're infinitely more valuable than someone who does 1000 DPS and gets hit all the time.
#366SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Stormheart
Originally Posted by Quigon
Do you have any evidence to support this theory? SR seemed to do nothing for us.
One of our holy priests definitely was able to resist the fear with resist, and he did have a talent i believe. No other healers were able to get a resist so we stopped trying resist. Our shadow priests resisted some fears and were dispelling them. That helped a decent bit at avoiding doomfire.



To Illundai:

Some advice

#1: Get people to stop cratering- thats basic, but obviously necessary

Beyond that: One way we found to help avoid deaths was to split groups north/south and then spread out. We had 2 decursers each side, 3 on one. With people well spread, and people not walking into fires, grip/burst will most likely NOT kill someone. Your decursers MUST learn to chase the guy when necessary along with a healer. I guess purification pots would help, but we just got used to chasing them down instead of relying on 33%.

#2: More healers is better

Take 10 if you have them, we had 10/3 shaman, the dps is so lightly required on this fight.

#3: Melee don't need a shaman.

The melee group is probably the safest group the entire fight. Rogues have so many ways to avoid dying, and druids can shift out and self-decurse or heal. Use that tremor on healers to keep them in one piece and so they can heal other people.

Just my 2 cents.

Also, don't get your tank airbursted. While its still possible to win(we did), its a lot easier when im not hitting tears and berserker rage at the same time. So tell people not to run thru ur tank at any time unless they are going to die.

Eventually it will happen, but humans make mistakes and this encounter has a very small allowance for them so mathematically your chances of beating it are quite low.

#370SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Stormheart

I would agree with many of you that the fight is somewhat random, but, I don't agree with the assessment that this takes 100 tries to get right every time. This fight is about 25 people knowing what can go wrong and how to correct for it. We didn't use a single purification potion, we had 3 shaman but I wouldn't call that stacking, and 5 decursers not counting feral. I'm not saying I expect a 1 shot, but I think probably 90% of the things that can go wrong are probably more player error than unavoidable. If you have fear ward, that makes the fight much easier, but we only wiped once because I missed fear(it just happened to be at 25%) in 3 days, so, I wouldn't worry too much about that. We also never really had aggro issues, despite the 1 minute fear holds, because people are focusing most of their time on evading doomfire.

You get 10 minutes to kill him, he doesn't have a lot of hp, so you might as well take advantage of that and focus on survival at all costs. If your pvp trinket is down, then just run away from the doomfires and hold up on damage.

I'm sure many of you are already doing that, but I just want to emphasize those things for those still working on him. This fight is not impossible at all. Just keep hammering at him.

#373SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ghando
Trohck, I wouldn't consider 4 of a given class "stacking" when that class has 3 raid-viable roles and is strong in all of them. 4 Priests is pretty common in raids these days with only 2 raid-viable roles. Especially as Horde, I don't think you can credibly fault a difficult encounter for rewarding extra Shamans in the raid. Archimonde is a difficult and unforgiving encounter that really demands good play from everyone in the raid. Seeing as his loot table is good and he's the final boss of a T6 instance, I don't think there's any compelling reason to make him much more forgiving. The 2.2 changes will reduce the luck component, and that's fine. The skill/execution should remain the same, they're not overwhelming now.
#374SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Evanwill
Edit - I'd also like to emphasize (I know you mentioned it Storm) that having priests dispelling fear after they break it / resist it / tremor totem / etc really saved a lot of people from getting feared into doomfire. My first priority after getting out of fear was to dispel people heading into fire and then healers as best I could and it really seemed to help.

Originally Posted by Stormheart
Our one priest was resisting a significant portion of the fears, probably about 2/3rds consistently with 240ish resist. I can't be certain of how the fear works, but its certain that without a resist talent resist gear does not help you.
From my understanding, from reading this

Formulas:Magical resistance - WoWWiki, the Warcraft wiki

and from experience in raids (ie MT on Ragnaros resisting knockback more with max fire resist) is that you can reach a 75% chance to resist a spell from a lvl 73 mob if you hit the resistance cap of 365 according to this formula from the above link:

Average Resistance = (Target's Resistance / (Caster's Level * 5)) * 0.75

Furthermore, there are two checks done on the target when the spell is cast. One is the above magical resistance check and the other is a check to see if the the spell missed. Another thing to note is the last section titled "Miss vs. resist in combat text" in the wiki as it confirms that there is some ambiguity in how combat text is shown to a player that doesn't allow you to tell if you resisted the fear bc of a miss or because of resistance.

What I'm not very sure about is how our talent Unbreakable Will (15% chance to resist stun, fear, and silence) works. I don't know if it works independently or in conjunction with these two checks. My guess would be that it is factored into the chance to miss check. I'm sure this has been discussed before but I just recently began reading these forums and couldn't find anything after doing some searching.
#375SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ manly
You've got it mostly right, but not quite. Spells are either binary or non-binary.

Binary spells: not resisted or fully resisted. ex: counterspell (ie: you can't 'half resist' counterspell)
Non-binary spells: not resisted or partially resisted. ex: fireball (ie: you hit for 100%, 75%, 50% or 25%. In theory you can reach 0% damage, but it seems in practice it cannot happen).

In short, since fear cannot be partially resisted, it is a binary spell. This means, both the 'miss' roll and the 'resist' roll are done at the same time, under a single roll. I am unsure about how miss rolls function in a monsters-vs-player context, but I will assume it caps at 1% on a 73 boss. (ie: 1% chance to miss). If you wear 365 SR, it should grant you 75% chance to fully resist the spell given the binary nature of the fear. However, I am unsure whether it is possible to get 76% resistance (75% + 1%) or if there is an extra cap specifically for binary spells.

But then again, the information about resists is rather scarce, even if you read all of wowwiki.
#376SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Eir
Originally Posted by Traek
Trohck, I wouldn't consider a kill if you feel so bad that you won't go back till the patch. If it was that messy you must have gotten lucky. Or maybe my guild is lucky (which we never are). There may be some inherent flaw in skill or strategy.

And yet we survived 4 Soul Charges on the kill, 2 of them being silences with one of the dot charges occuring 50 seconds into the fight, and still ended up with 20 people alive at the end.

#377SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Evanwill
Are you sure there are not two rolls done independently? One using the "miss" criteria and the other using "magic resistance" criteria? This would explain why you get mixed opinions and observations because there is no way to tell if you resisted the fear due to it "missing" you or due to you "resisting" it.

I guess what I was really trying to ask in my last post is if miss/resist rolls really work how I think they do and how the priest talent, Unbreakable Will, works.

Let me know if this is a discussion that should be moved out of the thread
#378SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Trohck
Originally Posted by Traek
Trohck, I wouldn't consider a kill if you feel so bad that you won't go back till the patch. If it was that messy you must have gotten lucky.
The improvement was gradual and over our 89 attempts. We had several below-50% attempts, but in the end, 20% is the same fight as 90%. When you take twenty-five people and ask them to do something difficult for 9 minutes, the odds are quite high that one will make a mistake during that time.

There are two sources of luck involved. The first is the occurrence of mistakes over a window of time. Given that our players will make mistakes at a certain (gradually improving) rate, you can probably chart our odds. We rolled the dice on people playing like pros for 9 consecutive minutes and we won. Certainly these players had all individually played perfectly for 5 minutes straight during various attempts, but in the end we need 25*9 = 225 minutes of combined (and consecutive) excellent play.

The second source is Archimonde's RNG choice of creating additional difficulty or penalizing us for mistakes.
- A hunter gets unnecessarily doomfired. That might be okay, or she might get air-burst and cursed 1 second before a fear.
- A druid steps into a doomfire because other healers were pushed away and the MT was dipping. That might be okay, or he might be feared into another doomfire and then air-bursted.
- Someone dies and we get silenced. The tank might dodge 3 attacks, or she might take 21,000 damage.
- A warlock gets airbursted. His internet might cough and increase latency by 750ms, or it might not.

We improved our awareness and our ability to react to nasty combinations. As you improve at a given encounter, you're increasing your odds of a perfect attempt, but luck is most certainly still involved. The randomness of Archimonde's abilities compared to other bosses cannot be denied. Many bosses have random abilities, but few have 4 pseudorandom abilities (5 if you count the use of soul charge) that can converge in the way Archimonde's can.

Different guilds are going to struggle with different encounters as raiders have personal strengths and weaknesses, but I can't think of an encounter that taxed situational awareness more so than Archimonde. From my perspective as a hunter playing the encounter, the excitement of the challenge quickly turned to boredom and frustration; I felt like I was taking free throws and waiting to make 10 in a row.
#379SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Ghando
A rule of thumb that I use in my head is "if you get silenced, you wiped." Depending on what else happens during that time, you might pull through just fine. But if the silencing Soul Charge goes off, you're pretty much at the mercy of the RNG. Our one wipe last night actually came on a double silence, since the guy who died had Spirit of Redemption...the first silence was survivable. Still, you can't really get through 4 Soul Charges and bag a "fluke" Archimonde kill. If you killed him under those conditions you can kill him under any conditions.

P.S. Trohck, how can you label the occurrence of individual mistakes as luck? That makes no sense. Yes, you can have a nearly-perfect run ruined at 20% by a stupid mistake and then wipe at 90% the next run to a bunch of stupid mistakes, but there's still a mistake. It might feel like you're just spinning the slots to get everything to line up, but at the individual level there's very little random chance.
Last edited by Ghando : 08/07/07 at 6:23 PM.
#380SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Trohck
Originally Posted by Ghando
P.S. Trohck, how can you label the occurrence of individual mistakes as luck? That makes no sense. Yes, you can have a nearly-perfect run ruined at 20% by a stupid mistake and then wipe at 90% the next run to a bunch of stupid mistakes, but there's still a mistake. It might feel like you're just spinning the slots to get everything to line up, but at the individual level there's very little random chance.
You're right that luck is not an accurate term for the occurrence of individual mistakes. All encounters require a level of skill and execution that if you don't pass, you wipe. In Archimonde's case, individual mistakes by any member of the raid are incredibly meaningful.

While it belies a lack of skill that mistakes are made, in my experience the mistakes are relatively spread throughout our raiders, meaning I will go 30 attempts without making a mistake and then I will make one, wiping us. What I feel like is that I have a certain amount of skill, so for example I will make a mistake 1 out of 30 times. A less skilled person might do it 1 in 20, and a greater skilled 1 in 100. What I'm referring to as "luck" is the fact that these mistakes are very isolated from one another. What are the odds of: 25 people, 0 mistakes, 9 minutes given our skill matrix? While this is the same concept as any encounter, the length of the encounter and the meaning of the mistakes are what set it apart. No other encounter makes every single person simultaneously accountable and penalizes you as severely when anyone messes up. So it ends up feeling like a dice roll.

Our one wipe last night actually came on a double silence, since the guy who died had Spirit of Redemption...the first silence was survivable. Still, you can't really get through 4 Soul Charges and bag a "fluke" Archimonde kill. If you killed him under those conditions you can kill him under any conditions.
I actually disagree with both Eir and Trohck and think our Archimonde kill will end up being much more repeatable than they do. I think we turned a bit of a corner when we stopped worrying quite so much on being perfect and focused a little more on being able to recover when someone inevitably made a mistake. Having the server pick that night to decide to throw random server latency in the mix just made things that much more interesting as several people crashed and burned from tear lag.

Just a comment about your quote, one of our 4 soul charges was a priest with Improved Death who clicked off the buff as soon as he died. We were only actually were hit with one soul charge from him. It kind of seemed to me that Archimonde has a short internal cooldown on Soul charge. We've also had 2 people die at virtually the same moment and it seemed like we only got one of those soul charges as well. Am I just crazy or have other people noticed this as well?

#394SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Digo
We tank him right where he stands and still had people getting feared through the world. What really disappoints me about this fight is fear. It's such a lame mechanic for what's supposed to be one of the most epic battles in the game. I would have hoped that they could come up with something more original that:

a) Didn't involve such a large degree of luck
b) Fearward/1s stance dancing

Even with a more reliable timer in 2.3 so that people can accurately gauge the stance dancing, it's still not a fun mechanic. Sure, there are ways to minimize its impact (stacking any class is dumb, btw) but I maintain that they can do better. There are plenty of other creative fights in the endgame that proves they can.
#395SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Praetorian
I suppose I take it for granted that everyone has the 2min PvP trinket. With that, you really don't need to class stack. If people use it intelligently (use it only if you are a moment away from running headlong into fire, or if you need to heal/decurse someone who likely will die if you don't), it really minimizes all of these issues on a raidwide level without needing shaman stacking -- though again, you really do want 2-3 shamans... if you do the fight with 1, you can't complain I don't think. Our experiences with the fight have probably been shaped by the fact that AV weekend in early July came right after our first Archimonde kill and most of the guild that didn't have their trinkets made a point of getting them that weekend.
#396SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Digo
Oh, I made it a point to ensure that everyone had a 2 minute trinket going into the fight. I've read all your posts, and I agree that people can learn to minimize risks. Still, why is fear in the game? I can picture the designer thinking "Hmm, this needs an extra element of randomness because I'm not sure it will be quite challenging enough as it stands. Bleh, we'll just throw in fear. Yeah, yeah, I know it's tired, but we're on crunch and we need to get this out the door."

For example, they could have thrown in the Infinite dragonflight, which never manifests itself in the whole instance. Not once. There is no indication that the flight has anything to do with the zone other than the fact that it's in Caverns of Time. Instead of fear, you could deal with drakes or dragonkin or anything at all that necessitates an extra layer of control. Kael'thas proved (in my view anyway) that control fights make for the best encounters. Archimonde is just frustrating and demoralizing for the people trying to learn it.
#397SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Praetorian
Hyjal clearly was not as polished as it could be. I mean, it was buggier and less polished/tuned than BT on the 2.1 PTR and in theory Hyjal was "in game" at release! The vast expanse of NPCs at the night-elf "camp" and unused space in the zone reinforces that idea, I think. It really just wasn't finished, and it seems like they've mostly decided to move on to other things.

I was wondering if anyone at BlizzCon would ask Metzen or Kaplan about the Infinite Dragonflight's absence in Hyjal. I would've myself, but didn't feel like elbowing my way past two dozen ret paladins lining up for every Q&A.

At the end of the day, though, while I appreciate the objective criticisms, I do enjoy the zone when we do it every week, just as much as I enjoy BT. The first four bosses are 100% predictable and unless you have some catastrophe, you should one-shot them every time, every week, once you've learned them. That means it's a 2hr clear to Archimonde with really nice loot along the way. Archimonde has no trash but is more "random" and obviously has a different feel to it than the other fights in the zone, but he's also an Illidan-tier boss in theory. This is entirely subjective, I realize, but I have fun throughout Hyjal, unlike Shahraz or pre-2.1 SSC/TK trash.

#399SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Trohck
Originally Posted by Clandestine
Most of the time, Fear -> Doomfire is the player's fault. Put more emphasis on staying far far away from Doomfires when the fear cooldown is up.
30s cooldown, and the fear itself is 8s. So without stacking shaman, some of your DPS is going to have 22s maximum time where they don't need to "stay far far away".

And staying far away enough to be safe is nearly impossible. The fear doesn't have any direction changing limitations or max distance. I've been feared into a straight line for 8s, hitting a doomfire around 7s that was ~40 yards away from my original position. And yes, my 2 minute pvp trinket (absolutely ludicrous requirement for a PvE fight) was down.

The time when DPS isn't in danger of being feared into a doomfire or running from doomfire is very, very minimal. If you really want to be safe, you need to be 8s' worth of run speed away from any doomfire when the fear cooldown is up. This is in addition to dodging doomfires normally. I would be surprised if you spent more than 10s out of 30 DPS'ing and not running from doomfires with this approach.

It's mitigatable by stacking shamans of course, or having dispellers break their fears with cooldowns and put themselves at risk instead of you. Both are poor solutions to a poor mechanic.
Last edited by Trohck : 08/09/07 at 2:00 PM.

#404SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Melador
Originally Posted by Trohck
And staying far away enough to be safe is nearly impossible. The fear doesn't have any direction changing limitations or max distance. I've been feared into a straight line for 8s, hitting a doomfire around 7s that was ~40 yards away from my original position. And yes, my 2 minute pvp trinket (absolutely ludicrous requirement for a PvE fight) was down.
That should be really, really rare. Yeah, sometimes you take that beeline sprint towards the (originally) distant doomfire, but that's what your PVP trinket is for. Having that happen twice in two minutes should be vanishingly rare.

And really, if you only spend 20% of your time dpsing but stay alive, then fine -- if you start wiping to enrage then you can address it. But I doubt that'll happen. :-)

For reference, I probably get doomfired one out every ten or so pulls, and usually that's because I was looking out for someone else and used my (5-minute, 'cause I suck) PvP trinket to decurse or NS+HT. I'm usually fairly in the middle of the action; close enough to be decursing folks and keeping all the HoTs I can up on the MT. That's not to say that I'm ultra-pro at this fight, but if you really focus on safety, you can definitely avoid enough doomfires to comfortably get a kill.

And, for what it's worth, even with the frustrations, Archimonde is my favorite fight in TBC. It can suck to wipe over and over, but the second-to-second gameplay (at least for a druid) just can't be beat.
#405SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Trohck
Originally Posted by Melador
Yeah, sometimes you take that beeline sprint towards the (originally) distant doomfire, but that's what your PVP trinket is for. Having that happen twice in two minutes should be vanishingly rare.
In my experience, it is rare. But if you combine it with getting feared into doomfires that spawn just before or during the fear or doomfires that spread towards you during a fear, 2 minutes is not enough without simply dropping your DPS to 0. You end up having to take risks.

You'll eventually get doomfired - if it's happening to you 1 in 10 attempts it is happening to your raid 2.5 times per attempt. Healers could handle that sometimes, except you can also get gripped and/or airbursted in the same second that the doomfire applies. That's what makes the fight excruciating.

Druids in our guild also seem to enjoy it more than most, probably because their role is different than "run around hoping not to be killed by the RNG".
#406SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine
Originally Posted by Trohck
30s cooldown, and the fear itself is 8s. So without stacking shaman, some of your DPS is going to have 22s maximum time where they don't need to "stay far far away".

And staying far away enough to be safe is nearly impossible. The fear doesn't have any direction changing limitations or max distance. I've been feared into a straight line for 8s, hitting a doomfire around 7s that was ~40 yards away from my original position. And yes, my 2 minute pvp trinket (absolutely ludicrous requirement for a PvE fight) was down.

The time when DPS isn't in danger of being feared into a doomfire or running from doomfire is very, very minimal. If you really want to be safe, you need to be 8s' worth of run speed away from any doomfire when the fear cooldown is up. This is in addition to dodging doomfires normally. I would be surprised if you spent more than 10s out of 30 DPS'ing and not running from doomfires with this approach.

It's mitigatable by stacking shamans of course, or having dispellers break their fears with cooldowns and put themselves at risk instead of you. Both are poor solutions to a poor mechanic.
Yes, most of the time your DPS is going to be moving and not DPSing. What's your point? If your DPS spends 1/3rd of their time doing nothing in order to insure they don't take more than minimal damage, you're still going to kill him. If your DPS is going all out on Archimonde and rushing to kill Archimonde as quickly as possible, and hence taking extra damage, a wipe is much more likely.

Obviously sometimes you can do everything right and get feared right into a Doomfire (without a shaman ~_~ I don't give myself one for this fight and it looks so much easier for the people who get a tremor), in which case you just heal through it. After all, one or two Doomfires aren't going to kill anyone. However, the majority of the time, it is definitely the player's fault, and when like 5 people in the raid are Doomfired at any given time, you're probably doing something wrong.

This is probably why you're having so much trouble with the fight. You can do next to nothing for 10 minutes and still kill Archimonde as long as no one dies.

There's really no justifiable reason for you to call the mechanic 'poor.' It's obviously a very defeatable encounter. Is it hard? Definitely. Is it broken or anything? Not really, except for the fact that the cooldown on the fear is actually 27 seconds from the start of the last fear's cast, so 26 seconds, and if it comes as soon as it's off cooldown, he's going to run off and kill someone. That's pretty cool. (We sometimes have a fear ward, but it always goes to a healer when we have it. It's stupid to give fear ward to a member of the raid who is already perfectly capable of breaking his own fears.)
#407SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Snowy
Originally Posted by Trohck
You'll eventually get doomfired - if it's happening to you 1 in 10 attempts it is happening to your raid 2.5 times per attempt. Healers could handle that sometimes.
How many healers and decursers are you bringing? A typical Archimonde for us sees us with 9 healers. It surely doesn't take 9 healers to keep up the MT and Doomfire isn't THAT bad to heal for a few people. Decurses should be happening close to instantly so there shouldn't be much damage being taken from Grip.

Our kill this week wasn't exactly flawless, as we had a shaman die, ankh, and die immediately -- so we had to deal with 2 Soul Charges to boot, but to give you an idea -- we had 15 people hit by Doomfire, which was fairly similiar to last weeks kill. The point being, people are going to take Doomfire damage, that's inevitable, so it sounds like to me that you need to distribute your healers better.

This is very much a positionial awareness fight, both as an individual, a group, and a raid. I'll be honest, the first time we killed him, and even the second, I thought to myself "I can't ever see this be repeatable in a reasonable time span." I was wrong, it's just it requires almost everyone to maintain total focus for the entire fight. When you wipe, you really have to drill down and figure out what the cause was. Was it because of no decurse? Where were the decursers? Did they die due to no heals? Where were all the healers? Did you have healers assigned to that area/quadrant? Where were they? If they weren't there, why weren't they? And so on.

You very much want to stay a healthy distance away from Doomfires when the fear cooldown is up, but it's even more important to know what to do if you get hit by it. For me, that's healthstone + shield, with a finger ready to hit a health pot too if there aren't any heals incoming by then. If your healers aren't using Grid or if they are and don't have the Doomfire debuff set to display -- that's a small problem right there. Same thing for Grip of the Legion.

I know I'm distinctly in the minority but I love the complete concentration it takes from your raid. There's really no time where you can take a deep breath and relax like Illidan for example, or pretty much any other fight. You always have to have a plan already in place for what you're going to do should something happen to you. What if Archimonde were to cast a Doomfire right in front of you, are you concentrating enough to immediately turn around and run directly away from him? When I get Air Bursted for example, I'm completely ready to shield + healthstone + pot -- I'm assuming I'm going to get Gripped as I'm flying through the air. Everyone needs to have that mentality. Then you don't have to stress over 2.5 people getting Doomfire each attempt because that's just not realistic. There's going to be damage thrown around, and your healers will have to deal with it and you'll have to help them a little bit sometimes.

Every week we go back, it's interesting.. because you can just see on the first pull we still don't quite make the paradigm shift in thinking of survival first. Damage goes way up as a result and we wipe. Then we remember "Oh, hey, maybe we should worry about DPS second, and staying alive first" and it goes a lot more smoothly. That paradigm shift is what I think makes Archimonde a unique boss fight. It's just the designer saying "Hey, we're going to throw some random shit at you, and if you're smart/good enough to avoid most of it, you'll win because we made the DPS requirement extremely easy."

Obviously this doesn't address issues such as being feared through the world, or the wonderful Spirit of Redemption you lose feature, but I'm addressing things that are controllable.
#408SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Trohck
Originally Posted by Clandestine
You can do next to nothing for 10 minutes and still kill Archimonde as long as no one dies. ...
Is it hard? Definitely.
Quoted for amusement purposes.

I think the combinatorial nature of his abilities is a very poor mechanic. Not only do many people on this thread agree, Blizzard also does as evidenced by their changes to the encounter in 2.2. The long fear is also a poor mechanic because it greatly rewards class stacking.

But ultimately, my justification for calling the mechanic poor is that the fight is not fun for me. Is it because myself or my raid group just don't have the skill to handle it consistently? That is your suggestion, but the end result is the same.

Re: Siawyn. Thanks for the helpful suggestions. Fielding 9 healers is difficult for us since most fights require 6-7. We do it when we can, and yes they're all using Grid with Doomfire and curse enabled, etc. The problem is pretty clear to me: We need 25 people to make no mistakes for 9 minutes that the RNG chooses to favor us. Empirically speaking, this happens 1 out of 89 tries.

#409SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ghando
6-7 healers doesn't cut it on any content past RoS and Azgalor. That's an organizational problem on your end. The end-T6 fights just throw so much damage around that having 8-9 healers with 2-3 Resto Shamans (on top of your DPS Shamans, of which you should probably have 1-2) is just a huge benefit.

#412SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Digo

We rarely have more than 7 healers online, and only 1 resto shaman in the guild. Trying to recruit a competent resto shaman as Alliance is like hunting snipe.

Also, I wouldn't be so quick to claim it's an organizational problem if a guild can't field X of Y class, or even X of Z archetype. Kaplan admitted as much during the Blizzcon panels that they try to be extremely conscious of class balance when designing encounters. It seems to me that the difference in difficulty between having 7 healers and 9 healers on some of these fights is far greater than it ought to be, at least from reading other people's posts.

Honestly, I wouldn't know if it does get much easier, so I'm just basing it on what you guys are saying. We've never had more than 8 healers in a TBC raid and typically run with 6-7 because that's all we can field.
#413SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Eir
Originally Posted by Clandestine
If you want to quote me out of context, I'm sure you can make amusing statements. I was merely pointing out that your DPS can sit around with their thumbs up their ass for 10 minutes and Archimonde will still die. The difficulty in this fight is staying alive for 10 minutes.

Then that sounds like a horrific design for a fight.

Any fight where the DPS can sit around for 10 minutes not really doing DPS is poorly designed.


There are several arguments floating all through this thread:

1.) Is it too hard? - Many people who have beaten the fight have argued that the fight is over the top. Obviously Blizzard thought it was too hard and the nerf is incoming.

2.) Is it fun? - Some people certainly enjoy it. But this is the second most detested fight in all of tier 6 content right now. In the end it's a matter of personal opinion.

3.) Is it well designed? - 8 second fears? Ranged DPS not contributing much beyond "don't fuck up"? I understand people who think it's fun, or not that hard, but I have a problem accepting that it's a well designed fight. 8 second fear on a 30 second cooldown. I mean, come on!
#414SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Renew
It's not a hard fight unless you have people who do not understand the concept of the fight and can overcome the urge to treat it like every other fight. The nerfs it is getting are due to the random bad luck scenarios that can be 99% unpreventable.

Is the fight fun? Probably not for those who do not enjoy spamming decurse. DoT classes do well, Rogues and other Melee classes dominate, so Hunters and meter whore Mages are probably a bit frustrated.

It's a cool fight in concept, but might not have worked out right as people got there (especially if they are light on Shaman with impatient people).
#415SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ghando
Originally Posted by Digo
Kaplan admitted as much during the Blizzcon panels that they try to be extremely conscious of class balance when designing encounters. It seems to me that the difference in difficulty between having 7 healers and 9 healers on some of these fights is far greater than it ought to be, at least from reading other people's posts.
You may be right about the ideal way to design raid encounters, but at a certain point I think tuning gets hampered by that idea. It would be very difficult to properly test and tune an encounter with the expectation that it be of roughly equal difficulty regardless of class composition, or even something broader like role composition (healers/tanks/dps). Furthermore, I think there's a transition that many guilds go through at a certain point in TBC progression.

Basically, in Tier 4/5 content you're rewarded for your DPS. This continues through some of Tier 6. At the end of Tier 6 though, there's a big (and probably too-sudden) change. Instead of healers being limited by mana (highly negotiable), they are limited by time. Raid damage is suddenly so heavy, bursty and unpredictable that you just can't handle it with too few healers. Having attempted Illidari Council with 7 versus 8 healers (while learning), it's night and day. For Shahraz, Archimonde, Illidari Council and Illidan there's just a certain critical mass of healers that can really keep things stable no matter what. Less than that is doable but 6-7 healers just isn't something I'd recommend for some of these fights while you're learning them.
#416SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Stigmata
Originally Posted by Ghando
Basically, in Tier 4/5 content you're rewarded for your DPS. This continues through some of Tier 6. At the end of Tier 6 though, there's a big (and probably too-sudden) change. Instead of healers being limited by mana (highly negotiable), they are limited by time. Raid damage is suddenly so heavy, bursty and unpredictable that you just can't handle it with too few healers. Having attempted Illidari Council with 7 versus 8 healers (while learning), it's night and day. For Shahraz, Archimonde, Illidari Council and Illidan there's just a certain critical mass of healers that can really keep things stable no matter what. Less than that is doable but 6-7 healers just isn't something I'd recommend for some of these fights while you're learning them.
I like this way of balancing personally, If every fight was a DPS race, the game would be stale.

Forcing your healers to excel and needing more of them to cover is not a bad thing.
#417SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3MatsT
Originally Posted by Digo
We've never had more than 8 healers in a TBC raid and typically run with 6-7 because that's all we can field.
Sure, most fights is possible with 8 healers, but many are easier with 9. I find it hard to believe that many guilds have so active members that they can not afford to have a few extra people for each role rotating spots or for use in some fights. I wouldn't mind to always have 5 tanks, 10 healers and 15 dps online just to have some room for optimizing.
#418SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Natural
Hybrids shine on Archimonde. Our retadin and feral have always healed on Archimonde and it quickly brings our healer pool from 6/7 to 8/9.

Gurtogg is a lot easier with more healers, but shadowpriests can bear a lot of the healing burden for the Bloodboil groups.
#419SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ghando
Originally Posted by Stigmata
I like this way of balancing personally, If every fight was a DPS race, the game would be stale.

Forcing your healers to excel and needing more of them to cover is not a bad thing.
As a healer, I concur :P
I do think that the transition is a little too sudden. You can rock Gurtogg/Reliquary/Azgalor with 6-7 healers, but every fight from there on out really rewards bringing more (8-ish). I think we'll see a lot of guilds recruiting healers when they reach this plateau, much the way most guilds had to open Warrior recruitment for the Four Horsemen (though the Horsemen required legitimate raid-stacking, unlike the T6 content).
#420SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â—Š Praetorian
Ehh, we've done Gurtogg with 7, but I really, really wouldn't want to bring 6 to Gurtogg.

6 on Teron is also a recipe for trouble if you get all your Shadows on healers.

6 is also kinda rough on Naj'entus. 6 is probably good for Supremus, Akama, and RoS though; and of course 6 is fine or even optimal for almost all t5 content if you have a couple of spriests to support your healers.

Honestly, fights are generally less healing-intensive than they used to be. If you think about it, I'd say 15 healers (30%) was pretty standard for 40-man raids, and people would stack 16-17 for something like Patchwerk or even 18-19 for Sapphiron when learning the fight. 30% of a 25-man raid is 7.5 healers, and I don't think there's a fight in the game that can't be done with 8. Just like you wouldn't really do Sapphiron or Patchwerk with 13 healers (at least not until you were overgeared in mostly t3 loot) I don't think it's unreasonable that bringing 6-7 healers to Shahraz or Archimonde is a disadvantage.
#421SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		â—Š Quigon
Your math is a little off. 30% of 40 is 12.

If you simply go 16 healers, and take 16*25/40 you get 10 healers.

I initially thought we would be using 11 healers in TBC raids before we ever did Gruul. We used 11 or 12 on Maulgar and it worked really well. I assumed it would scale. With the extra healing class this would make sense, especially as 4/9ths of the raid classes are healers.

The 40 man equivalence of 6 healers is 9.6 healers, which is absolutely ridiculous to think about. 7 is 11.2, 8 is 12.8, 9 is 14.4, 10 is 16, 11 is 17.6.

I didn't make this post however to nitpick yours Praetorian.

I just was posting that the nerfs/hotfixes are live on archimonde.
We'll be trying him sunday or monday of this week - and let people know how it goes. I'd be curious also with any reports of people who have tried him with the changes in place. I believe these changes truly remove the "you lose" categories - by removing collusive abilities, and perhaps stopping the silence from being a wipe 75% of the time.

I know it is a lot (lot) easier to post how this fight is doable and "our awesome guild" killed it in just "X amount" of tries. But the sheer number of messages I've received in private on this fight and the frustrating mechanics of it is probably larger than this thread by itself. I think these changes will be mostly welcome by most raiders for repeatability, and certainly for new guilds trying him out and not becoming frustrated. It is still a little sad the types of mechanics that are used to make this boss seem "hard" - but hotfixing to stop utilizing level 40 potions to overcome retarded circumstances has been happening since Gruul 1.0. I'm not sure why people think popping purification potions in mid air is "strategy" or a good idea.

And a bit more on topic - this fight is clearly easier with more healers, and more shamans. In fact each shaman makes this fight significantly easier (intensely so). But this has all been said already. We plan to box or have 5 shamans on for archimonde kills - even if it is a 1 shot, it is only as such due to this stacking and planning.
Last edited by Quigon : 08/11/07 at 2:37 AM.
#422SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â—Š Praetorian
How the fuck did I multiply 40 * 0.3 and get 15? Ugh. Anyway, yeah, that just makes my point more valid!
#423SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Wueste
WoW Forums -> Archimonde Hotfixes

In an effort to apply some of our upcoming 2.2 changes in a more expedited manner, we're hotfixing some elements of the Archimonde encounter. Not every planned change to Archimonde could be hotfixed, the other announced changes will occur with the release of patch 2.2.

The following hotfix changes are now live:

* Archimonde now casts fear in a bit more consistent manner, roughly every 40 seconds.
* Fear's cast time is now 1.5 seconds.
* Grip of the Legion now has only a 60 yard range.
* Red Soul Charge now only silences players for 4 seconds.


The planned changes for Mother Shahraz could not be hotfixed, but we are working to resolve via hotfix the timing issue with Essence of Desire's Rune Shield and Spirit Shock. Working on that fix, we discovered that Rune Shield wasn't actually absorbing any damage. We're also working to fix that error. Since the Rune Shield is normally removed quickly, Essence of Desire still won't get much benefit out of the effect. Mages who Spell Steal the effect will be quite a bit happier, however.
#424SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Russta
Really glad they put this in as a hotfix. We'll be doing the fight again tomorrow so I'll post any findings if nobody else has by then. It's a shame they couldn't hotfix in the change to being gripped in the air but at least that can be solved with lots of Plaguebloom and Icecap.
#425SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dawme
Anyways, even with these changes, Archimonde will still be the most disappointing end boss I ever saw in wow. Only 1 phase, very old mechanics (oh ae fear, did we really miss you ?), the fight is not horrible since well, it's fun and all, and will be prolly even more after fixes, but it's still way under my expectations for a end boss, and especially for a charismatic character like Archimonde. It's really far from Kael or Illidan level.
#426SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Playered
Well the encounter has the epic feeling that... its BIG... even without much there in terms of doodads and such, the sheer size of the 'playground' seems to work well as a good setting.

Its just a shame that the boss really only has 2 abilities of significance, Doomfire and AoE fear.
As said before however the fact he only has one phase... as with all bosses with it generally... its very dull and unimpressive.

Take Finger of Death for example, its a key ability that he has, it could be used in some really significant way which requires half the raid to focus on something to adapt to it. It could be really 'epic' and make people build up, endure it, then 'phew' we survived it, and instead its just a 'clean up' ability to make wiping go faster.

It's really far from Kael or Illidan level.
I think Archimonde is a lot better than Vashj, before and after the changes. It's just a shame that what made the encounter difficult were completely ridiculous things that shouldn't have existed in the first place; I'd much rather they rework the fight in some way to keep it challenging, but not so random that you feel like hurting something.
#428SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3david0925
For a zone's end boss, Archimonde is a horribly designed fight.

I don't mean that in perspective of difficulty or luck. I mean that for every end boss for a raiding Zone (heck even magtheridon), there are two or more phases involved. For a boss that has zero trash clearing and as a lore-rich end boss of current end game zone, Archimonde is almost stupidly simply designed, and involves pretty much just one phase (if you include the lolwisp phase i guess its two)

I hope for a redesign, but with Sunwell (rumor) hitting in like 2-3 months, I guess i don't really care that much anymore
#429SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dawme
Originally Posted by Zalera
I think Archimonde is a lot better than Vashj, before and after the changes. It's just a shame that what made the encounter difficult were completely ridiculous things that shouldn't have existed in the first place; I'd much rather they rework the fight in some way to keep it challenging, but not so random that you feel like hurting something.
Vashj has been nerfed to oblivion but the design in itself is way more interesting than archimonde's one in my opinion. There are multiple phases, adds, something unique to the fight (tainted core), all in all it's a "real" end boss which I will remember. Off course, it's way too easy since 2.1 patch, especially compared to how kael is vs other tk bosses but well, I still enjoyed killing her the first few times.
On the other hand, you have seen everything about archimonde after 3 pulls, there's little if any sense of progress. I enjoyed discovering the different vashj/kael/illidan phases, I took screenshots when I first saw demon illidan, striders, kael's weapons... I took 0 screenshots of archimonde. I was indeed satisfied to kill him, especially since we killed him in the top 20 world but well, 5 mins later I was like "ok, we avoided some fears and fires, we got epics, that's cool" and I went to bed. Guild chat was much more filled with satisfaction feelings when we killed Kael, Illi or even C'thun or nef. I can explain the archimonde strat in 3 lines (even 1 : don't die.). I can write 3 pages about illidan or kael's strategy.
Ah well, what's done is done, and it's still a fun fight, but like I said, it's below the requirements of a "cool end boss" for me. Can't wait for arthas =)
#430SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ghando
I like Archimonde because I know every single week I have to play at the top of my game to bring him down. It's a legitimately difficult fight to execute and it really rewards skilled play. Yeah, it's a fairly simple fight and if you're grading bosses on how many phases they have, Archimonde seems unimpressive. I honestly look forward to him every week, though we are fortunate enough to have 4-5 Shamans at every kill.

Having been on the receiving end of "GG" combinations, I don't recall a single instance where I simply could not have survived. As a healer I suppose I have more control over my fate than most people, but even with this week's feared-into-doomfire-then-bursted-then-gripped combination I could have survived using all my timers. I DIDN'T survive because I panicked and hit my Tear too early, and ended up cratering. Bad luck demanded that I handle the situation perfectly, and I didn't. Now, that's probably unreasonable to expect from every player in every guild that sees Archimonde. I support Blizzard's upcoming changes to the encounter. I just think that it's a pretty good design overall (a straight-up raid-wide skill check, easy to learn but difficult to master) and it gets a bad rap.

People got much better about surviving but I think our biggest problem still is we get too many people getting with doomfires. Also, I think reaction is slow sometimes. 1 person will need heals and they don't get any for some reason because of range issues or what not.

At least it will be easier for our MT to stance dance (wiped at 29% or something cause he missed a fear :/)

As a healer I suppose I have more control over my fate than most people, but even with this week's feared-into-doomfire-then-bursted-then-gripped combination I could have survived using all my timers. I DIDN'T survive because I panicked and hit my Tear too early, and ended up cratering. Bad luck demanded that I handle the situation perfectly, and I didn't. Now, that's probably unreasonable to expect from every player in every guild that sees Archimonde. I support Blizzard's upcoming changes to the encounter. I just think that it's a pretty good design overall (a straight-up raid-wide skill check, easy to learn but difficult to master) and it gets a bad rap.
I completely agree with this, there is a place in WoW for pure skill checks like Archimonde, like there is a place for pure gear checks (patchwerk), resist check (shahraz) ... I just think this place is not the end boss one. I'm happy that a fight like Archimonde exists in the game, but I would have expect him to be a boss in the instance, not the end boss because with 2+ years of wow raiding experience, I expect from end bosses to be very complex (in termes of strategy), multi phases encounters. Archimonde is hard, very hard, but not complex at all. This added to the fact that he really promotes raid stacking (shamans in particular) is a bit "meh". But well, like I said, that's just a personal opinion and at the end, I very much liked BC, including whole Hyjal.

In 2.2 airburst->grip combo wont be possible but grip->airburst will work.
Yep, but that's very different :

airburst grip means :
t=0: airburst
t=0.5 : grip
t=1.0 : out of decurse range because of the airburst's kb
t=5.0 : you die (maybe.)

grip airburst is :
t=0 grip
t=0.5 : airburst
t=1.5 : out of decurse range

In the first case you have 0.5 sec to decurse (= you can't decurse). In the second you have 1.5 sec (= you can decurse).
#435SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Igniter

Purification potions are also worth it.

#437SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dawme
Honnestly, I don't remember exactly what was changed, but my guild had some tries on vashj before 2.1 (killed leotheras in april) and phase 2 seemed much harder than it felt post 2.1. We never tried it fully flask + pot though, since we were aware of the almost impossible p3. I do think every spawn had more hp, I also remember that the tainted element took 1 min to respawn if you missed the kill instead of insta respawning like it is now, so a tainted missed was pretty much a wipe since adds dps was very hard to sustain. Obviously, 1 more month of gear farming before 2.1 helped this too.
Oh and also, I heard poison in p3 used to tick on hit. Now it only ticks after a few secs, which means you can take 0 dmg by constant moving and the fight can goes on even after enrage hits, at least for 1-2 mins. Post 2.1, you took 2-3k dmg or so on hit so you died very fast after enrage.
By the way, the fact that she was nerfed (too much in my opinion) doesn't mean I think situation pre 2.1 was nice. It was stupid, like almost all the raid game pre 2.1 was, and changes were welcomed. But vashj 2.1 is, in my opinion, tuned a little bit too easy. I still think nowadays that hydross or leotheras are harder than vashj, which is not normal. Or kael is tuned way too hard. As you wish.
#438SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ghando

#439SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dawme

Making the fight doable is a thing (and it was done by removing mind control which is already a pretty major nerf, they could have let the mc and let us being able to CC people or removing the dmg/heal buff and make tanks immune but whatever, that was a fix.), making the fight easier is another thing, and it has been done on vashj (like I said, insta tainted elemental respawn and poison not ticking on hits are the 2 things I remember, there probably were other changes).

#449SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Playered
I believe the hotfix is also somewhat of a placebo effect;

Before people are moderatly 'afraid'? for lack of a better word, on this encounter of RNG combination gibs that are almost completly unavoidable.

Today people (who didn't actually understand it properly) are like "oh... hes been nerfed lol no more randomness" and its a little bit of a confidence boost which stops them getting in a panic when the non easy situations happen.

I can't really gauge how the change has effected us, we didn't really prepare against the fears when we knew they were coming, we had a couple of stupid wipes and then a kill after someone died at the start, pretty much the same as our previous kill.

#451SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Amorpheus

"You are better than I am," Inigo admitted.
"So it seems. But if that is true, then why are you smiling?"
"Because," Inigo answered, "I know something you don't know."
"And what is that?" asked the man in black.
"I'm not left-handed."

#454SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Vanstrider
Originally Posted by Trouble

I have a theory to why Archimonde is easier then 2.0 (didn't see 1.0) but because we killed him on our first attempt, I would just be talking out of my ass. But I will just present it anyways, I found that Doomfires to be less intense/frequent for the very reason that his fear is on a more consistent timer, if he is casting fear (I think) he isn't casting doomfires constantly.

I don't know I need to see it more, but something was different other than the hotfixes, a by-product of them for that matter.
#455SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		â™¦ Quigon
The changes to Archimonde are really, really good.

The new fear allows me as the MT to basically unload on aggro and never get "Feared" - even if before you could change stances, we've had people die from me mashing it as quick as possible on a late global hit (this was already discussed in length).

It is basically much more reasonable as a tank due to the cast time.

Further, the fears are about 40-50 seconds apart, with relatively precise gaps.

This is really the biggest change. What it lets you do is essentially stand in "danger zones" a bit longer (nearly twice as long), and then move when the fear is actually imminent. You can actually brace for the fear, and it comes less frequently. Making the fear less significant obviously is better for the fight design, but the fight is now certainly easier.

The grip change seems good - but obviously even the upcoming? final version of grip+air burst you can be gripped before air bursted (unless it provided immunity) - but this is less common now, but has to be dealt with.

The fight is definitely much better now - but I can't help but thinking it is simply because fear is less of a factor. The fear is perhaps what makes this fight suck. Its hard to see how they could make the fight more difficult however without having the fear - sort of silly to rely on fear to artificially increase the difficulty of an encounter. Yech.
Because the fear is less common now, you can pvp trinket almost every other one.

The fight is certainly more enjoyable now - but you've still got issues of stacking. Also the change to the silence is good - its no longer an 80% chance of a wipe when a priest dies.

It seems like they could still tune a few things here and there:
You can still be feared under the world.
I believe we got a soul charge from a Spirit of redemption death.
Grip plus air burst still exists - and is kinda silly, should be removed. (and these 3 things apparently will be fixed in 2.2).
The fight still hugely favors stacking regardless of these changes, or how you can do it with XY and Z guild... doesn't mean its better or even smart to do it that way.
The doomfire itself can lead to a particularly nasty death where you get air bursted, land in a doomfire way behind the raid, and get feared away from your healers. I guess this is okay now since grip can't join the fray, but it would seem better if doomfire didn't stack on you beyond 80 yards from the boss. I would guess though, that this would be impossible to code.

Is it harder than Archimonde 1.0? Yes. Archimonde 2.0 makes you wonder how you ever got hit by doomfires in 1.0. Further, you could go entire kills on 1.0 without ever having a doomfire near your raid. Both 1.0 and 2.0 sucked though because of the fear and inconsistencies with doomfire. You could have back to back pulls that varied 10 fold in difficulty, and for that this fight is far more consistent and even now.
Last edited by Quigon : 08/13/07 at 4:30 AM.
#456SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3LiteSabre
I never would've imagined that 0.5 and 2 seconds respectively could have such an impact on the way I look at an encounter.

From a non-tanking point of view, the added 0.5 second casting time to Fear gives me an instant longer to look around once Fear is being cast, letting me plan what I'll do once Fear hits and I'm sent running off in X direction. I don't know if I'm really getting myself across here, but the small difference kept me from blowing unnecessary CDs (WotF and trinket, mostly) more than once.

The one time a Silence soul charge class died, we all kind of braced for impact and most of us (probably all of us) thought that it was wipe time, but the silence passed incredibly quick and we picked up for a kill.

We DID wipe more than once, but with the exception of one incident which I truly believe was a GG situation (rogue with all CDs down gets Grip+Burst, runs back, is decursed and immediately recursed + Burst again, this time into a doomfire) it was all due to player error, including several people who should've known better cratering for unknown reasons.
#457SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Kuai
Grip of the Legion should make you immune to Air Burst. Does anyone else see this as a logical and simple fix? I almost want to go as far and say it should have a snare component but I can see a bunch of death scenarios with that.
#458SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Illundai
It's kind of a dead horse right now, Grip + Air Burst is getting fixed next patch anyway.
But, what we did to counter those "Oh shit, I got Grip in the air"-moments, we formed groups around Archimonde.


1         A         2
          3


          4
Every single one of these groups had a decurser + a few healers in it. Our idea was not to spread out on Air Burst, we aimed to have everyone in the group to get hit by it. Yes, this does crowd control a lot of your raid, but that's no problem. The best thing about this is a decurser will always be sent flying with you and he can decurse you in midair. There is very little that can kill you in mid air, this way. We also had a Shaman in each group more or less, so that did help with the fears, of course.
I coordinated on ventrilo, keeping a close eye on doomfires. If I knew I could heal someone , I said on ventrilo "I'm healing X, Y heal Z!".
And if I saw someone was gonna get air bursted while having a doomfire dot, I told them to keep their head cool, tried to top them off before they were sent flying and basicly to stay alive. Everyone has a lot of tricks to stay alive and what did help was the threat of me saying "We can check on WWS if you didn't bother trying to stay alive after!" :P

#460SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine
I don't see why people are saying having Grip should make you immune to the Air Burst. The gib combo is only if you get Air Bursted THEN Gripped after you're in the air. If you get Gripped and your decursers are picking their ass long enough for you to get Air Bursted out of range, it's pretty obvious that someone screwed up. HINT: Air Burst has a cast time.
#461SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3TheDooft
We killed him yesterday pretty faster than before the fix, but it seems that there is another hiden fix : our melee took very few air burst, like 2 in whole fight. Perhaps it's just luck, and we had too few attemps to have a real proof about that.
It helps a lot cos usually melee are grouped (avoid doomfire and being parried) and air burst are pretty nasty on them.
#462SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Yaltus
I'm going to be very curious to check this fight out again next week, as our only kill came this reset before the fixes. Tentatively I'm inclined to agree with the guy who said these are mostly a placebo; I definitely feel that way about the Grip changes. We had way more deaths to doomfires, usually in conjunction with an air burst. The few Grip deaths I recall were generally, "I didn't get decursed for 5 ticks, wtf, I'm standing right next to you" and the mages/druids saying decursive showed them as OOR, not "I got Gripped in mid air".

The fear change is probably a more substantive change to the difficulty of the fight, although I can only think of a few times we wiped because of a missed fear break. More consistency will definitely help ranged dps, both in not taking doomfires and in actually doing damage.

#465SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Klorox
Originally Posted by Jamor
I have never really played with modifying BigWigs files. Can you tell me what edits you made?
Big wigs hasn't updated yet?
If they haven't, I'm assuming he changed the following lines in Bigwigs/Hyjal/Archimonde.lua

In the localization part:
fear_message = "Fear, next in ~30sec!",
to
fear_message = "Fear, next in 40sec!",
In the event handler part:
	elseif sync == "ArchFear" and self.db.profile.fear then
		self:Bar(L["fear_bar"], 30, "Spell_Shadow_DeathScream")
		self:Message(L["fear_message"], "Important")
		self:DelayedMessage(25, L["fear_warning"], "Urgent")
to
	elseif sync == "ArchFear" and self.db.profile.fear then
		self:Bar(L["fear_bar"], 40, "Spell_Shadow_DeathScream")
		self:Message(L["fear_message"], "Important")
		self:DelayedMessage(35, L["fear_warning"], "Urgent")
 		if self.db.profile.fear then
			self:Bar(L["fear_bar"], 30, "Spell_Shadow_DeathScream")
			self:DelayedMessage(25, L["fear_warning"], "Urgent")
to
 		if self.db.profile.fear then
			self:Bar(L["fear_bar"], 40, "Spell_Shadow_DeathScream")
			self:DelayedMessage(35, L["fear_warning"], "Urgent")
Haven't seen the encounter this week (we killed him before they hotfixed so assuming the fear is 40 seconds in between), but the code above changes the warning after fear to say "Next fear in 40sec". The other code changes the bar to display 40 seconds instead of 30, and the warning "Fear soon" @ 35 seconds. Make sure you don't edit the code after that. Starts with elseif and has ArchBurst in the same line. As a side note, I've never been good at coding, so I take no responsibility if the code above is wrong, but all that was changed were the timers by 10 seconds.
Last edited by Klorox : 08/13/07 at 9:31 PM.
#466SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Jamor
It's updated today --- thanks for the post -- I'll take a look shortly and review it.

Good to know going forward.
#467SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Russta
What Klorox posted is exactly what I did. I honestly had no clue what I was doing, I just opened the lua file for Archimonde, searched for the number 30 and changed all the ones that made it look like they make sense to 40. Thankfully it worked and was a lot more accurate and better for hate than roughly counting to 10 after every BigWigs timer.
#468SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3dr_AllCOM3

#469SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Amorpheus
Originally Posted by dr_AllCOM3
Is it just me or is standing behind him and eating unlucky Doomfires better than running to the water? I always did better when just standing there and running, like my group wanted me to do so badly, was every time a greater risk.
Doomfire ticks shrink over time, so when you actually get to the water much (if not most) of the damage will already have been done. All that time you lose health from the debuff and risk going OOR from healers and decursers.

"And what is that?" asked the man in black.

#473SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3LiteSabre

I don't know; there's nothing that really should be easier than usual since all that was changed were the fear CD and casting time, and grip range, but it all felt so much more controllable.

I chalk it up to everyone 'feeling' that the fight was easier, letting them keep their heads instead of panicing and giving up when someone died.

#477SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Natural
The changes definitely make it easier for the tank. Our MT was laughing at how easy it was to stance switch for fear. Telling the raid that "fear is coming in 5 seconds" is amazing for shaman who can time their tremor totems to pulse 1-2 seconds into the fear.

For kicks, I looked back at how many attempts Archimonde has taken us.

1.0: 12 wipe learning night, 18th attempt kill
2.0: 8 attempts
2.0: 5 attempts
2.0: 6 attempts
2.0: 1 attempt
2.0: 4 attempts
2.1: 1.5 attempt -- Tank dying in 2 seconds only counts as 1/2 an attempt =)

All kills except the first used 4 shaman. The fight can easily go wrong, but you should hopefully expect your guild to get better at it over time.
#478SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Renew
The key for us the last few kills has been warning people when a fear is coming so they can move away from Doomfires in the area. If someone says they died to Doomfire they obviously did not do their job, which is to live.

Seems that the new Archimonde is also a lot less painful when people die, though it might just be people adapting to the fight after many many painful attempts.

We did find more Shaman beneficial, but they are not required. The last few kills has been with 2 in the raid. I feel that the only need to bring Shaman now is for the healer group's Tremor Totem. Any more just helps out of groups who cannot help but play in the fire.

#490SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Praetorian
Obviously we've been doing the fight for almost two months now so it should seem easier, but for me the biggest part of the "nerf" is just how predictable fear is, which allows me to feel a sense of control over the fight. I can stand 5yd from an active Doomfire, merrily healing away, because I know I am not going to get feared into it, and that it should despawn before the next fear. When there are <5sec left on the Fear cooldown, I go into conservative hyper-cautious mode, but pre-nerf I used to spend almost the entire fight in that mode. As a result I basically never have to use my trinket to break fears, which lets me intentionally do things like stand in a middle of two Doomfires right near Archimonde, healing everyone, knowing that I'll just instantly trinket out of the fear.

In short, I feel like I can control where I want to stand instead of being completely at Archimonde's mercy, and that makes a huge difference. After several weeks of 2-shots and 3-shots we finally one-shotted him last night, which was nice.
#491SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ pinchet
We spent 6 hours this past Thursday and 2 hours on Monday on Archimonde before we got our first kill. After resets yesterday we decided to test our luck and head back to Hyjal to see if we could do it all in a day. We ended up one-shotting every boss up to Archimonde, and then three-shot him. Needless to say we were all pretty damn stoked at how quick the repeat kill was. Personally, I was dreading it.

It's easy to see that the trick was getting it into peoples heads that keeping yourself alive is your #1 priority above all else. Many of our mistakes when learning came from healers staying around doomfires because they were worried about others dying so much that they weren't paying attention to (or just didn't care about) themselves.
#492SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Thezilch
Originally Posted by Praetorian
Obviously we've been doing the fight for almost two months now so it should seem easier, but for me the biggest part of the "nerf" is just how predictable fear is, which allows me to feel a sense of control over the fight. I can stand 5yd from an active Doomfire, merrily healing away, because I know I am not going to get feared into it, and that it should despawn before the next fear. When there are <5sec left on the Fear cooldown, I go into conservative hyper-cautious mode, but pre-nerf I used to spend almost the entire fight in that mode. As a result I basically never have to use my trinket to break fears, which lets me intentionally do things like stand in a middle of two Doomfires right near Archimonde, healing everyone, knowing that I'll just instantly trinket out of the fear.

In short, I feel like I can control where I want to stand instead of being completely at Archimonde's mercy, and that makes a huge difference. After several weeks of 2-shots and 3-shots we finally one-shotted him last night, which was nice.
Seconded.

As a member of one of our non-shaman groups, it's night and day with fear->doomfire awareness. Even for shaman groups, the DPS improvement offered by the fear change is nearly doubled. Being that we had previously been hyper-sensitive to never having the chance to be doomfired and then seeing a berserk timer, I can't fathom us being in that position again, unless we survive 8+ DPS soul charges.
#493SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Quigon
Yeah last week it was a 6 minute 2 shot (first attempt was something awesome like 95%). I don't consider us hugely better at the fight... fear consistency and the half second difference for tanking it make all the difference in the world. Perhaps a sad testament to how much of the difficulty of this fight was artificially brought on by a mechanic where you have nearly 0 control over your character.
