#495SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Hootiepoonie
we have been attempting him for 3 days now and i was wondering if our strat is abit flawed. We are doing the 180 degree strat and since the changes to arch are we hurting ourselves by not doing 360 degree? We tank him closer to the hill, and i was thinking that we up our chances of killing him by moving him out in the center more and have four groups surrounding him so doomfires are more predictable to where they go.
#496SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine
I love the fear change on this fight, the fight overall is so much easier and more predictable now. It was so annoying how you could spend 60 seconds running away from Doomfires waiting for the next fear, doing very little. Even though the fears are consistantly faster now, knowing that they'll come within 10-15 seconds of the cooldown coming up makes it a lot easier to keep yourself alive. For our kill this week I had no Shaman, did not have to PvP trinket a single time, and did not get Doomfired at all during the fight. Very very controllable fight now.

@Hootiepoonie definitely should be using all 360 degrees to spread out from the Doomfires.
#497SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Eir
I'm pretty sure the 180 degree strat was developed for Archi version 1.0. Once the doomfire changes went in, most people switched to a 360 strat since it gives you more room to spread out to avoid doomfires.

It's not really that the 360 degree strat makes doomfires more predictable, but you have much more room to move around if one side gets particularly bad.
#498SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Arvak-
Originally Posted by Eir
I'm pretty sure the 180 degree strat was developed for Archi version 1.0. Once the doomfire changes went in, most people switched to a 360 strat since it gives you more room to spread out to avoid doomfires.

It's not really that the 360 degree strat makes doomfires more predictable, but you have much more room to move around if one side gets particularly bad.

The problem with spreading out 360 degrees is that it becomes nigh impossible for healers and decursers to cross heal and that made the kill for us. There are still many random things in the fight that can make it go awry, which can eventually lead to healing and decursing being unable to hit their group for a significant period of time.

Unless you stack 10 healers, that positioning only seems to make the fight harder since we tried such a setup and ended up getting peaced out when a healer got launched away from their group as it scrambled to dodge doomfire. It wasn't until we began attempting it with a 180* plan that we started seeing progress.

The fear change was great in one aspect, since that made the boss a little less impossible to tank, however that still leaves us at the mercy of grip-burst combos and rampant doomfires that have more mood swings than a beaten Latina. One attempt, it's perfectly distributed, another it's okay, and then the next you have all three making a unified ring of death around the MT.

Can't wait for 2.2.
#499SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Praetorian
We still use a sort of 180-degree strat. We tank Archimonde in the middle of the meadow, and use a semicircle (with melee west at his back, the tank east, their respective healers behind them, and then other ranged groups NW/N/NE). This prevents people from being knocked too far away from the raid, but still gives plenty of room to maneuver on all sides.
#500SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Playered
We use (as only 2 shamans) 2 camps, either side of Archimonde (oposite sides), we then move as groups where possible, or atleast with a decurser around to avoid doomfire when it becomes rampant on one side.

We use the whole area to spread out, but generally as you tend to stick to your groups theres always 1-3 decursers in range, and atleast 3 healers should be in range of everyone (with the exception of melee/air burst).
#501SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Natural
We run with 5 groups: NW, NE, SW, SE, and melee center. Each ranged group has at least two healers and one decurser. Each group tries to stick together near their shaman and/or decurser. It's been pretty reliable for us.
#502SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Yilona
Originally Posted by Natural
We run with 5 groups: NW, NE, SW, SE, and melee center. Each ranged group has at least two healers and one decurser. Each group tries to stick together near their shaman and/or decurser. It's been pretty reliable for us.
I think the most important point of our strat is that each group is a "unit" that is responsible for it's own survival. The idea is that more than one or two units shouldn't be out of commission (Doomfire or Air Burst) at one time, so the MT should still have plenty of healing. If Doomfire is ubiquitous in any one quadrant, that group slides to the side a bit and other groups compensate, but the units should always stay together with some distance between each other. Sometimes, someone will call out to throw extra heals to so-and-so or decurse someone, so the other groups will help out, but for the most part, we're completely independant.

Of course, we also run with 4 shaman almost 100% of the time, so that helped a lot when fears were unpredictable. =b

It's worked very well for us, though now it's probably not completely necessary, since you can't be Gripped way far away (always getting Air Burst as a group means there's always healers and always a decurser to keep the group alive). The predictable fears now make it even easier, too. We usually 1- or 2-shot him every week with this strat, and have been for a while.

Also, remember that you can dispell the fear, if your group doesn't have a shaman and you see someone running towards fire. That helps a lot with unnecessary extra healing.
#503SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Trouble
We do this with four groups instead of five. This allows each group to have two healers and one decurser instead of spreading those tasks more thinly.
#504SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Natural
Originally Posted by Trouble
We do this with four groups instead of five. This allows each group to have two healers and one decurser instead of spreading those tasks more thinly.
Do you mean that you have 3 ranged groups + 1 melee group, and there are two healers and a decurser with the melee? It seems unnecessary to me to have those classes with the melee because the ranged groups are always within range of the melee to heal/decurse.
#505SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine

We run with 5 groups: NW, NE, SW, SE, and melee center. Each ranged group has at least two healers and one decurser. Each group tries to stick together near their shaman and/or decurser. It's been pretty reliable for us.
This is pretty much our strat, except without 4 Shamans :<. Wish there were more around for Alliance.

I'm sure this has been mentioned earlier in the thread, but put raid icons on your decursers. People who get gripped in an unusual area can call out and head towards the nearest icon this way.

#512SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine
I've heard that originally, Blizzard intended for the 3 haste rings and an unknown fourth item to be the quest reward from the Illidan drop (and I would bet the Blessed Medallion is the fourth item, so you would get the necklace and your choice of a ring.), but there was a failure in internal communications somewhere so the rings were added as trash drops instead. It would explain why the rings are ilvl 151, which only comes from Illidan or Archimonde, as opposed to 141 like everything else.

#521SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3RRVex
Our guild were trying this encounter for slightly less than 2 nights, using the 3 teams positioned in triangle around him. Got to around 36% after our first 10 attempts or so on the first day and pretty much always reaching 30-50% on our second day, but still haven't killed him yet. Everyone seem to perform at their best trying to avoid deaths, but "random" unavoidable stuff always seem to wipe us (like Airburst + Grip for example).

The thing that i'm wondering the most is how does your raid DPS meter look like on the actual kill?
We seem to have a huge problem with ranged dps classes being extremely low, unlike all other encounters. We fit in the 10 minute enrage timer perfectly, but the dmg difference between the melee and casters/ranged is insane. We got him to 34% on our last attempt yesterday and the meters looked something like : Whole melee group (2 warriors, 1 rogue, 1enh shaman, 1 feral druid) had around 10-13% raid dps each. The average dps for the melee group is around 1 - 1.3k each. The 6th on meters was a shadow priest with only 4.5%, the rest were even lower, some lower than MT. (noone died till ~36-37%).
We've gotten Doomfire on melee group only 3 times in 2 days (20-25 attempts each), so i'm wondering if it would be better to bring in another full melee dps group (assuming they spread in 2 camps around archimonde's mob square)? How would it effect the amount of Doomfire and Airburst on melee?

I'm pretty sure some guilds tried it so any feedback would be appreciated. As well as tips on how to improve ranged dps in this encounter.
#522SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Juli
Originally Posted by RRVex
The thing that i'm wondering the most is how does your raid DPS meter look like on the actual kill?
We seem to have a huge problem with ranged dps classes being extremely low, unlike all other encounters.

I'm pretty sure some guilds tried it so any feedback would be appreciated. As well as tips on how to improve ranged dps in this encounter.
Maybe your ranged are clumping up too much, causing air burst to decrease damage too much? What seemed to work for us was to tell ranged camps to spread out as much as possible within their section, centered around their shaman. The biggest thing I can think of other than that is to just be mindful of the fear timer. It's perfectly safe to stand right next to the tail of a doomfire right after a fear is over, and it will despawn before fear is up again for example.

I'd really like to see some changes made to this fight. I hate that you can, and should if possible, brute force him. Our two kills so far (1-nighted hyjal for our 2nd kill) have been with 5 shamans, 2 dwarf shadow priests, and 1 dwarf healing priest. I personally feel like we haven't mastered the fight, but fear warded shamans dropping instant tremor and the priests/paladins in their group dispelling any shamans that didn't get fear ward instantly so they can do the same just brings down the difficulty SO much. I also hate any fight that makes me chain-shift with shadowform or go without shadowform just because of fear ward.
#523SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Lymmel
I respecced to holy for this particular fight as I found dps'ing out of shadowform kinda impractical and subpar. Fear ward is always sort of a burden for me since I respecced shadow ever since Nightbane

Melee are usually on top, but if you stack too much melee you increase the likelyhood of bad things happening to all of them at once. Some of your casters will be running from a doomfire at any given point. I have not had an Archimonde attempt yet when I did not spend at least 20 seconds of every minute making sure doomfire did not kill me.

#526SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Juli
Originally Posted by Lymmel
I respecced to holy for this particular fight as I found dps'ing out of shadowform kinda impractical and subpar. Fear ward is always sort of a burden for me since I respecced shadow ever since Nightbane
I actually shift back into shadowform a fair amount on this fight. I have a resto shaman and I have to chug a lot of potions to keep up with shifting on a fight that would otherwise be easy on my mana, but it can be done. Generally I will shift into shadowform right after warding a shaman, but only if the area my group is in is relatively clear of doomfires and a fear isn't about to go off; there's really no point in shifting into shadowform if I'm going to spend 20 of the next 30 seconds of the fear ward cooldown running away from fires or chasing after some shaman trying to dispel his fear.

I considered respecing for the fight, but I'm already blowing 100g/week respecing for arena healing and my healing gear consists of primal mooncloth which I can't equip without paying 175g to respec tailoring each way (and then 175 more to spec back), random unenchanted/ungemmed karazhan and SSC non-set pieces, and full season 2 arena/honor gear, which I suppose is decent for archimonde. I don't think I'd be THAT much more effective, and 200g/week on respecs is kinda pushing it (I'm sure soon I'll be wanting to respec for Shahraz too since we're pushing for her this week, but I'll probably end up holding myself back on doing that too unless we really need it).
#527SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3RRVex
Originally Posted by Juli
Maybe your ranged are clumping up too much, causing air burst to decrease damage too much? What seemed to work for us was to tell ranged camps to spread out as much as possible within their section, centered around their shaman. The biggest thing I can think of other than that is to just be mindful of the fear timer. It's perfectly safe to stand right next to the tail of a doomfire right after a fear is over, and it will despawn before fear is up again for example.
We're using 3 camps of 5-6 casters in each, the 3 marked mages (decursers) position themselves in a triangle, with archimonde being in the middle. Everyone else spreads approx 30 yards away from them to be in decurse range. We also have 2 more resto druids and 1 mage as decursers, who are spread inbetween the main 3 decursers, this way we have whole area around the boss covered. So in overal, whole raid is fairly spread and we don't have Airburts hitting more than 2-3 people.

As for using shamans as "marks", we got only 3 in guild who are not always available for raiding. So we can only have 2 groups with the totem in them at best. ... Low population RP realm... been around 4 months since last decent shaman applied to us. :<
#528SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Lymmel
We are currently at the 3rd night of attempts on him and we had a few heartbreaking 20%ish wipes (and a 15% one) so we are getting there I guess. I just wanted to express my dissatisfaction about how unfun this boss is. I have never been more annoyed to wipe at a boss really. There is no luck component ofcourse, but the margin for error is terribly low at some points. I guess it's a matter of practice for our entire raid force, but the most annoying thing is that every time there's a different person dying so you can't pin it down on someone and replace him. You just have to spend hours wiping hoping this is the fight everything clicks.

Beyond the obvious grip+air burst combination, it's almost inevitable sometimes that a few people will get doomfired, at which point them getting burst or grip has a large chance to wipe us. It's easy to avoid yes, but it's extremely punishing. Essentially it's a 10 minute fight where you really need every last guy to not lose focus for even 5 seconds or he might die and the raid will wipe.

I think the soul charge mechanic is what makes this fight so unfun. I would rather it was a bit more forgiving for 1 death. I did read about guilds getting away with 7 deaths or so and hats off to them, but while learning him we have only gotten away with 2 deaths once (which led to an attrition wipe) and it's mostly a wipe when someone dies. I would rather it scaled like it was only the special effect (mana burn, silence etc) on the first soul charge, 3k damage+effect on second, 6k damage+effect on third and a certain wipe at 4th. It's extremely unforgiving now and for raid groups which have a few decent but not amazing people it hurts a lot to do this encounter, waiting for them to catch up on what you got a few days ago. Let's not even mention how terrible getting someone disconnected while you have him at 50% is and he dies ofcourse. Perhaps I am a bit bitter because I wiped at him recently, but generally I have had much fun wiping in most encounters in tbc with Kael giving me the best memories, but Archimonde is so unfun for me that I am thinking of taking a day off because I will face burnout if I do him again.
#529SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Kettle
Originally Posted by RRVex
We're using 3 camps of 5-6 casters in each, the 3 marked mages (decursers) position themselves in a triangle, with archimonde being in the middle. Everyone else spreads approx 30 yards away from them to be in decurse range. We also have 2 more resto druids and 1 mage as decursers, who are spread inbetween the main 3 decursers, this way we have whole area around the boss covered. So in overal, whole raid is fairly spread and we don't have Airburts hitting more than 2-3 people.
Sounds like you're on absolutely the right track, Vex. I wouldn't worry too much about the range/melee dps balance. There's certainly no need to stack. As you've already noticed, the dps requirement isn't all that high. Your ranged might fall a little short, but if they aren't getting themselves killed, then that's half the battle and you're almost there.

In my experience, the entire fight just hangs on people not taking daft risks and not taking unecessary Doomfires. A bit of clear communication on the healers part if they get cut off for a few seconds or if decursers get caught out of range, don't spaz up the Tears and that's really all there is to it.
#530SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Phantasie
just a sidenote. Sometimes if archimonde takes his sweet time to use a soul charge you can actually knock it off the debuff table by loading him up. Can't rely on it but its nice when it happens.

#539SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Renato
Id say that a BM hunter would actually output more DPS on Archimonde than any other hunter spec, specifically because of their ability to chain-immune his fears now that they are on a reliable timer.

Assuming of course that you have good decursers who know how to decurse a pet, and that you are aware of your pets position as well as you own so he doesn't get Doomfired.
#540SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Russta
Originally Posted by Sinzar
This fight would be so perfect if they would just remove soul charges completely and lower the enrage timer to prevent wins after mass casualties. Our guild has been stuck on Archimonde for a few weeks, and I'm so completely fed up with constantly wiping because one person touches a doomfire before an airburst (or any of the other 10 ways to die -- thus causing a charge and cascade effect).
Honestly, once you get that first kill it just gets easier and easier. When we first started we were of the opinion that a Soul Charge was always a wipe due to the domino effect. After more and more attempts you won't even think about it. Sure, there's still a lot of ways to die on the fight but you'll eventually get to a point where one death isn't a wipe more often than not. Make sure as soon as someone dies everyone gets topped off, everyone is aware Doomfire = Thaladrad, aware of when Fear is coming, everyone in the raid has a few Purification Potions and, most of all, everyone is relaxed. These are the things that worked for us.

Our time frame for our kill has gotten smaller and smaller and tonight we wiped at 16% on our first attempt and killed it on the second.

Stick with it, I know it's a horrible fight but it honestly gets easier and even fun.

AggroCrag/Stormstrikes/Crittle/Sean need Might/Kings

#549SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Uldreth

#550SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3shorto85
We got our first Archimonde kill on Sunday. One thing that helped a lot was constantly calling out the fear timer cooldown over vent. We went from 4-5 people getting hit by doomfire every fear to 1-2. We only ran 8 healers for Archimonde so people staying out of fire kept healing from being spread too thin.

Also its not much of a dps fight. Once our casters started cancelling their casts when they saw a a doomfire coming at them it helped a lot.

Video from our first kill, rogue pov. I loled @ how many times he got air bursted.

#552SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Sinzar
Just out of curiosity, do any guilds still do 180 degrees?
We do.

My guild was stuck on Archimonde for over a month. Over and over we would constantly have wipes for misc reasons, using 1-2 shamans. Thursday we went with 3 shamans (got a new app) and killed him that night.

The insanely dramatic effect shamans can have on this encounter is just...... World of difference when ~80% of your raid (3 groups with tremor totem, warriors, fear ward) can for the most part negate the fear. This fight really needs to be re-designed (even though I know it won't be).
#553SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3xyruul
Any guilds out there specifically trying to minimize the amount of decursers they use? On our first kill we had exactly two, a mage and myself and the mage died around 75% leaving just me to solo decurse the entire raid (I stand in melee range to proc OOC and to have range on everyone). It worked fine until we had a number of deaths at 12% or so and powered to a kill before a wipe. Our kill last night we had the usual 3 mages and myself, all of them putting decursing as priority over dpsing and their dps fell from 1200-1400 in other fights to 500-800 for all 3.
As an example if we had all 3 of them ignore cursing our raid dps would increase roughly 15-20% which is significantly less time for bad things to happen. I was worried about doing it with only 3 decursers originally but soloing it relatively easily makes me think we are just wasting time with 3+ and exposing ourselves to bad luck and lag-in-the-air syndrome.

Oddly the past couple weeks we have had a couple nights were exactly 3 people from all over the world would randomly get dced over and over again all night. Two of us were in the air on the last dc last Archimonde but luckily he was already at 11%.

Anyway, just wondering what the 'sweet spot' was for other guilds as far as number of decursers.
#554SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Clandestine
Shamans are really not nearly as necessary after they made the fear more predictable, and the fight overall is really not very random anymore. Emphasize survival over all else, warn frequently for fears, and for the love of god stay away from doomfires.
#555SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3woo-haa
I couldn't imagine doing Archimonde with only one decurser. Didn't fear, doomfires and air burst cause OoR problems? Personally, I like at the very minimum 4 decurses; one in each group. Even then I still hand out purification potions to every non-decurser.
#556SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3delling
Hi there.

We had our first kill yesterday - was about our 30th try in total I think (4th hour of wipes).

Just echoing what some people have already stated here - calling out the fear timer, and just simply spamming on voice coms to 'move away from the fire' will do wonders for your raid group's survivability.

We went with 3 mages and 3 druids (2 ferals) decursing. 3 shaman too, but we moved around so much that the tremor totems didn't do a whole lot. 3 priests and 1 paladin, to bring it up to 8 healers (plus the two ferals, but I think they were even in feral gear, decursing).

We started off with the whole '3 groups, and a decurser behind to catch the rogues' positioning, but by the end we were just moving as a raid to the side that had the least fire.

Really, it got to the stage where we just had to heal the MT and 1 (sometimes 2) people with Doomfire.

Very cool, calm, and not as random as I expected (once we got past the 'random' deaths from not having Tears, trees sneaking up on people, 'lag'...)

I didn't notice any nasty mid-air combos, but I did make sure that most classes had purification potions for those 'oh shit' moments.

Nothing special to report on the fears really - we had 3 priests, so between our talent points we broke 50% of the fears, and we're all undead, with 2 minute trinkets (so that probably helped a lot).

But yeah, can't emphasise the 'stay away from the fires' bit enough. Stay away from the fires (waaaaay away), and you should secure a kill on this guy pretty quickly.

We even had an airburst on our MT at 15%! That was funny... ha... ha...

I sure hope he's repeatable next week.
#557SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Zifna
Just got him down last night! In light of that I thought I would share some doomfire diagram/comiccy things I made for my guild. At best, they may be a clear way to illustrate what is bad to members of your guild... and at least I hope they may provide some amusement. ^_^;













#558SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3xyruul
Originally Posted by woo-haa
I couldn't imagine doing Archimonde with only one decurser. Didn't fear, doomfires and air burst cause OoR problems? Personally, I like at the very minimum 4 decurses; one in each group. Even then I still hand out purification potions to every non-decurser.
Well, I'm feral spec and usually tanking so I have the feral talent to resist fears (which does work unlike SR on his fears), and I also have full gladiator resto gear from s1/2 so my unbuffed hp is something like 12k+ in my resto set. Between tremors+resists+trinket I am never feared at the wrong time, and in the event of a doomfire being in the way between me and a guy with decurse I just run right through it without caring at all throwing up barksin and some hots after I get to the guy.
Using pitbull and agro monitor, I can decurse anyone in range before they take a single tick, and also lifebloom the target of the air burst and maybe 1 guy next to him before it even hits them.

It's really rather easy with mouse over decurse macros, an agro-alert setup in your ui and a lot of hp. I'm also really situationally aware and know where most everyone is, so on the off chance someone does get grib+burst (when the burst didn't target them and they were out of range for the decurse which is rare) I just travel form towards them and handle it.
We also make everyone have purification pots just in case, but we've only needed to use one once. We tell people who are far away to run towards the middle should they get cursed to fix most range issues.

So, as you can see I have a lot of things going for me that a typical mage doesn't, including the fact that I'm in the middle in melee range with range on everyone (usually the opposite side of the melee to avoid getting bursts myself). I'm a little hesitant to solely rely on just myself to decurse, but I definitely think 3 mages on top of that is a total waste. I'll probably try just one next week.
#559SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Whiteknight
Originally Posted by xyruul
Any guilds out there specifically trying to minimize the amount of decursers they use?
I think you got lucky having only 1 decurser - that and your dps must be a lot closer in to the boss than our setup.
A lot of our ranged dps stands close to max dps range because it creates a lot more room for stepping away from doomfires. A quarter arc around the circle away from doomfire at 40 yards out is a very big distance. The same arc close in is too close.
That said, for us the sweet spot is more based on the fact that we have 4 raiding mages, and 3 raiding resto druids. So having an abundance of decursing isn't really a sacrifice - we're simply taking some dps and healers - and they happen to be able to decurse too.



Originally Posted by Sunchips
Just out of curiosity, do any guilds still do 180 degrees?
I'm not sure we use a conventional 180 or 360 strat at all. We divide our raid into 3 - melee, and 2 ranged camps. The ranged camps are dps/heals/decursing together - usually a little under ~2 groups each.
They rotate independently around the boss like the hands of a clock in order to position away from the doomfire.
Perhaps this is what is understood by the 360 strat.


Originally Posted by Clandestine
Shamans are really not nearly as necessary after they made the fear more predictable, and the fight overall is really not very random anymore. Emphasize survival over all else, warn frequently for fears, and for the love of god stay away from doomfires.
I have to say - while tons of shamans aren't necessary for a kill, more shamans means a lot more dps time on the boss. It's not surprising that the top 50 dps parses for archimonde have 3-4 shamans or more. A FW shaman in the melee group means your rogues get pretty close to 100% dps time on the boss, for example.



I did have one question about doomfires. Do folk actually still 'train' the doomfires? I hear a lot of folk talking about it, but we found it to be incredibly unreliable. We were able to 'control' maybe 20% of the doomfires. And the trainers were usually getting well out of position and gripped/dotted/airbursted really badly. The turning point for us was telling folk to *not* train the doomfires. Simply sidestep them and then get the hell away in preparation for the fear. This kept everyone comfortably in range of their decurser/healer while still being in range of the boss for better dps uptime.
Sometimes this causes insane lakes of fire on one side of the boss, but with a dynamic re-positioning strategy we simply put the entire raid on the other side of the boss whenever that happens.
#560SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Allendana
We downed him yesterday evening after approximately 50 attempts. I would like to thank this forum and all posters who contributed to this thread. Your experiences helped us a lot.
For statistic purposes, we used 3 shamans and 5 decursers, 9 healers in total.

#565SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Cadfael
There is a range restriction. If you tank him a bit towards the mountain where you walk along from where he starts and then run through him to the mountain area behind him, you'll no longer get feared. I don't know how far that is. Could be 100 could be more. But there is definitly a range restriction. I noticed that during our firstkill where I had to run away often due to not having a fear breaker Shaman in my group.

The range is huge but not infinite.

#569SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Intermission
I'm pretty sure the fear is not ~99 yards... unless the size of the encounter area deceives me. During a few /facepalm type learning attempts, I consistently out ranged the fear by running back when fear cooldown came up. It was a huge loss of dps and I certainly dont recommend it unless you get some huge lag spike.

As a BM hunter, 36 yard range, I would estimate I ran about twice my shoot range to OOR the fear. ~70 yards sounds about right. I am almost certain I could hunters mark while easily of fear range (100 yard range spell).


On the topic of fear, I was in a shaman group for the first time the other night... and WOW. Tremor totem is simply amazing.
#570SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Cevil
Our guild finally killed him last night, and I can't tell you the relief it gave me. I won't even tell you the number of attempts we put in.

The fight is maddening. The previous night to the killshot, it finally looked like we got the "concept" of the fight down. However, almost every single time we would wipe to something that simply cannot be called user error. Airburst + grip, Airburst into a doomfire (somewhat controllable with tear timing), Priests Spirit of Redemption causing double soul charge, double grip (we had someone get grip back to back, ridiculous). It was everything I could do to keep my guild motivated to do this. We'd be perfect up until ~35%, then it'd hit the fan.

I know my guild is good enough to kill him weekly, but I feel like our killshot was a "stars aligned" kind of kill. No grip + airburst, doomfires that appeared to be spread out and manageable. Tank healing smooth. It was a perfect kill, no deaths at all, but it felt like everything had to align for that to happen. Bad fight design, imo. Hopefully 2.2 will change things.

Our group makeup was stacked for learning. 2 shamans; resto and enh (a good enh shaman can be amazing in this fight. Tremor totem near the tank and melee gives a healer a real good shot at keeping up the tank during fears without using any cooldowns.) Druid tank, because we have fear ward. Our druid tank took significantly less damage than our warrior tank did. We had, I believe 5 decursers. 4 resto druids and a mage (we respecced some of our other feral tanks, we love druids in our guild.) Decursing was not a problem, but for those who it is, we had a rule that if you got curse, you had to run towards archi, as he was the common point amongst decursers. We'd start the fight with raid icons over heads, but those got erased as they got airbursted. Also, we found that starting in a semicircle worked well, but ending in a large cluster that was equidistant from the two closest doomfires was most effective. Positioning was completely dictated by fire positioning.

Overall, I'm proud of my guild, but I do feel the death is 1-2 days overdue just due to poor luck.
#571SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Praetorian
Originally Posted by Cevil
Our group makeup was stacked for learning. 2 shamans; resto and enh (a good enh shaman can be amazing in this fight. Tremor totem near the tank and melee gives a healer a real good shot at keeping up the tank during fears without using any cooldowns.) Druid tank, because we have fear ward.
How in the world is 2 shamans "stacked"? We bring 5 shamans to Archimonde pretty much every week. 4 if we must. A couple of times we even brought 6.
#572SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Nite_Moogle
Originally Posted by Intermission
As a BM hunter, 36 yard range, I would estimate I ran about twice my shoot range to OOR the fear. ~70 yards sounds about right. I am almost certain I could hunters mark while easily of fear range (100 yard range spell).
This is a bounding box issue. The fear's range is calculated from the center of Archimonde (who is naturally huge) while your hit range is calculated from your character to the edge of Archimonde's hit box. There's a few yards lost from the center to the edge of his model, which is why you can use a 100 yard range ability on him and not be hit by a 99 yard ability. You are almost certainly running 99 yards away from the center of Archimonde's model.
#573SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3EllTrain
Originally Posted by Praetorian
How in the world is 2 shamans "stacked"? We bring 5 shamans to Archimonde pretty much every week. 4 if we must. A couple of times we even brought 6.
Wow. How often are people doomfired with that setup?

We learned/killed him with 1-2 shaman, and the incoming damage to the raid is pretty intense. We typically have somewhere between 60 and 70 doomfires hit people over the course of the fight, with no less than 4 people usually running around with the dot.
#574SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Nurru
For our first Arch kill we had 5 shaman and me running around like a crazy person fear warding as many as I could between each fear (The magic number is 2). For our second kill I think we may have had 3, possibly 2. For us it didn't seem to make a big difference, though we likely bring more healers than most guilds for the fight. If I recall we had 9 healers plus me healing as shadow because I didn't want to bother dpsing while going in and out of shadowform every 25 seconds. For both kills we've survived 2-3 Soul Charges, though those stun charges right when you get feared towards fire are fairly terrifying.

#577SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Digo
Incredibly, we seem to have fewer problems with Mother than Archimonde, and we killed Archimonde over a month ago. Maybe we're just doing something terribly wrong (3-4 shamans, 5-6 decursers, 7-8 healers) but I completely detest this fight. Granted, we've only killed Mother twice now, but it took less time for a repeat kill than our weekly "throw-our-faces-into-Archimonde" debacle.
#578SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Lymmel
We finally killed him in a day we had 2 shamans while we kept wiping for 2 weeks (4-5 sessions) with 4-5 shamans. In the end we killed him with 2 shamans, 4 decursers and by using more melee than before. Ironic as it sounds, I think bringing melee is not only good because of their superior dps, but because you can control the fight better by using them. They are all usually pretty clustered up close to him no matter what, so healers and decursers can reach them much easier than some hunter who just got grip and doomfire has cut him off to some awfully weird place. Every healer has quick access to melee because he is standing at the edge of a circle and they are in the circle's middle, while ranged could be at the circle's other edge and it relies only on the healers there to figure out if they are in range quickly. In a funny way it is the opposite problem of the original gruul where having people in the middle of the circle was problematic :P

Apart from the unlucky burst+mid air grip combo that I can't figure what to do against apart from shadow resist/purification pots, stacking melee up to a degree (we brought 8 or 9, 2 dps warriors, 3 rogues, 2 ferals, 1-2 enh shamans) seems to me the best solution for this fight.

Also, I would suggest making fr/sr cauldrons for a first kill. We had 2 people at 15% who got bursted with a doomfire on them on our first kill and they survived solely by taking the fr pot we gave them earlier until they got back to the camp.

As a final note, I haven't done shahraz, but doing archimonde for our guild at least felt more difficult than doing kael. We got kael in 4 nights or so, but each night we saw distinct progress (usually a different phase) while we got archimonde to 15% the second day, 24% a few tries later then spent a couple of days more wiping to him between 50-70%. Our approach to the encounter at the first couple of days was kinda shit (used ferals as decursers, spriests out of form for fearward in an effort to control the fight which only prolonged it too much and failed) but still, I have not seen another fight where momentary loss of focus at any point during the fight has such a chance to lead to a wipe. It's a really demoralising fight and totally unfun in my opinion. I am willing to predict that if the bulk of guilds stuck at kael now reach archimonde, there will be an uproar about the encounter. It's really the only encounter I have seen so far that you really need every last guy to reach top performance, it's a really hard fight to execute even if it seems relatively simple.
#579SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3woo-haa
Originally Posted by Cevil
The fight is maddening. The previous night to the killshot, it finally looked like we got the "concept" of the fight down. However, almost every single time we would wipe to something that simply cannot be called user error. Airburst + grip, Airburst into a doomfire (somewhat controllable with tear timing), Priests Spirit of Redemption causing double soul charge, double grip (we had someone get grip back to back, ridiculous).
Of these I would say only the Airburst + Grip combination remains somewhat uncontrollable reason of death you should have. Even then you have purification potion with ~60% success rate.

For us the most important thing was to tell everybody to call out on VT whenever they got knocked, gripped or doomfired.

#581SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Lupison

#582SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Praanz
The major break on this fight for us - and probably any guild that does him is:

Wichever position you use or how you stack your raid - focus primaly on survival and let everything else be secondary.

This fight doesn't require top-notch "Theorycrafted2000X-DPS", 9 decursers with Parachute Cloak or a main tank using Deviate Fish to hide underneath a Shrubbery(tm).

It doesn't require anything more crazy than SURVIVAL - I wrote that again capitalized because it had to be shouted alot in chat/vent before it sunk in.

I can honestly say this is the only fight in WoW ever(!) that I don't really care too much how I end up on the damage-meter. Sometimes I take extra long routes walking this or that way staying extra clear from Doomfires. I interrupt a late three second Fireball just to decurse someone. I decurse pets! I don't use mana-gems or mana pots for the sake of HP-pots and HP-stones. When there's risk of a fear I move far from any Doomfire instead of risking it for the sake of DPS'ing.

It's actually that simple - make sure your raid members focus on careing about their personal health and you'll see progress.


Edit - About Grip + Burst. We have often used a icon on all decursers. This makes it easy to call out your nearest decurser on vent so you can 'hook' up half way. This is just another example of not caring so much about DPS but blinking 20 yards away from the boss to save a friend (and the raid).
Last edited by Praanz : 09/21/07 at 5:48 PM.
#583SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Bazazu
Originally Posted by Praanz
The major break on this fight for us - and probably any guild that does him is:

Wichever position you use or how you stack your raid - focus primaly on survival and let everything else be secondary.

It doesn't require anything more crazy than SURVIVAL - I wrote that again capitalized because it had to be shouted alot in chat/vent before it sunk in.

I can honestly say this is the only fight in WoW ever(!) that I don't really care too much how I end up on the damage-meter. Sometimes I take extra long routes walking this or that way staying extra clear from Doomfires. I interrupt a late three second Fireball just to decurse someone. I decurse pets! I don't use mana-gems or mana pots for the sake of HP-pots and HP-stones. When there's risk of a fear I move far from any Doomfire instead of risking it for the sake of DPS'ing.

It's actually that simple - make sure your raid members focus on careing about their personal health and you'll see progress.


Edit - About Grip + Burst. We have often use a icon on all decursers. This makes it easy to call out your nearest decurser on vent so you can 'hook' up half way. Another example of not caring so much about DPS but blinking 20 yards away from the boss to save a friend (and the raid).

I'm gonna quote this for emphasis. This is the *key* to the entire fight. And a "sub" key, is Doomfire.

Grip is fine. Airburst is fine. But Doomfire will wreck you. 90% of our deaths on archimonde involve doomfire. Tell people to avoid it at *all* costs. I don't care if you don't dps for af ull minute or 2. You dying is a bigger detriment to the raid. Save yourself, avoid doomfire.
#584SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		xyruul
Well, we've had two kills that would have been wipes if we had only 1% less dps then we do. Sometimes, really unlucky things happen, like airburst into a doomfire, immediately airbursted when you get back, strait into another doomfire and then feared 2.9s into a heal and then gripped while you are out of tremor range and just used your trinket on the last fear. Even with 14-15k hp as a druid hotting myself and using barkskin I was unable to survive that, and I even got a couple heals from others.
My motto is to maximize dps while staying alive. Obviously staying alive takes precedence, but the more dps the less time for silly things to happen. When you say stuff like "ignore dps and just survive" you would be amazed just how much a lot of people actually listen to you. Mages are more then capable of doing at least 800dps while canceling every spell to decurse, yet lots of logs have them doing 300. I guess it just comes with practice, but I think your best chance of repeated success is to focus on all aspects of the fight including dps rather then simply surviving at all costs.
Last edited by xyruul : 09/21/07 at 6:49 PM.
#585SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ribeye
Originally Posted by Bazazu
I'm gonna quote this for emphasis. This is the *key* to the entire fight. And a "sub" key, is Doomfire.

Grip is fine. Airburst is fine. But Doomfire will wreck you. 90% of our deaths on archimonde involve doomfire. Tell people to avoid it at *all* costs. I don't care if you don't dps for af ull minute or 2. You dying is a bigger detriment to the raid. Save yourself, avoid doomfire.
Doomfire isnt that bad. I'm not saying your dps should aim for them or anything but they also shouldn't avoid dpsing or healing for 2 minutes because of them. Tell your druids to set their raid frames to show who has it and then just pop a high ranked rejuve on them, swiftmend it if they're too low. We use 3 camps a couple healers to each side and I tell the healers with me to concentrate on the tank and I'll concentrate on them and the doomfires, works great. But don't read this and think we don't wipe, we do :P We just aren't frightened of doomfires.
#586SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Shelendil
Some people need to be more cautious; others are playing more cautious than they need to be (making attempts take longer if they're dps, or risking tank death by being out of healing range longer than necessary if they're healers). Best way to figure this out is parse your wws in a very detailed way over many attempts: then you can actually target your advice and improve the raid. Blanket advice is not going to work as well. It takes a lot of individual adjustment, and what may work for one attempt won't work for the next attempt, depending on how much you're individually targeted for abilities.

I'd say the only absolute is that you shouldn't crater.
#587SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Intermission
Originally Posted by Nite_Moogle
This is a bounding box issue. The fear's range is calculated from the center of Archimonde (who is naturally huge) while your hit range is calculated from your character to the edge of Archimonde's hit box. There's a few yards lost from the center to the edge of his model, which is why you can use a 100 yard range ability on him and not be hit by a 99 yard ability. You are almost certainly running 99 yards away from the center of Archimonde's model.
Ah, makes sense.

Similar to Azgalor RoF I guess. We only had 6 healers for him one night so we just cheesed it up and used melee on the adds, the raid ~35 yards away and tank getting chain fired. Made a few people laugh who havent heard of that method before!
#588SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Praanz
Originally Posted by xyruul
Well, we've had two kills that would have been wipes if we had only 1% less dps then we do. Sometimes, really unlucky things happen, like airburst into a doomfire, immediately airbursted when you get back, strait into another doomfire and then feared 2.9s into a heal and then gripped while you are out of tremor range and just used your trinket on the last fear. Even with 14-15k hp as a druid hotting myself and using barkskin I was unable to survive that, and I even got a couple heals from others.
My motto is to maximize dps while staying alive. Obviously staying alive takes precedence, but the more dps the less time for silly things to happen. When you say stuff like "ignore dps and just survive" you would be amazed just how much a lot of people actually listen to you. Mages are more then capable of doing at least 800dps while canceling every spell to decurse, yet lots of logs have them doing 300. I guess it just comes with practice, but I think your best chance of repeated success is to focus on all aspects of the fight including dps rather then simply surviving at all costs.
First - "ignore dps and just survive" isn't something I wrote - you might actually want to read what's written. I'll quote myself "focus primaly on survival and let everything else be secondary". That means from your perspective "focus primaly on survival and let DPS be secondary".

The example you'r pulling - is nothing short of a description of "worst luck ever". Sometimes the Worst Of Luck beats Skill silly. I also know that most "unlucky" situations can countered with skillfull playing and understanding the encounter. This is so true especially for Archimonde since skill in this encounter is to survive and the actions/reactions are all connected like Domino-pads. I'll 'counter' some of your happenings by throwing a few things from the book of survival:

Gripped out of tremor range- can be countered by having more than 1 decurser in the raid I know we usually run with 2-3 mages and 2 resto druids thats alot of overlapping. Bringing decursing consumables.
Trinket on CD - If you position yourself carefully there are not many times you actually need to use the trinket. Why use the trinket just to gain some more DPS. I find myself saving it for a o-shit moment. If I position myself correctly well in time before a fear - the o-shit moment are unlikely to happen. When trinket is on CD I'm also extra carefull when the next fear is incoming.
Airbursts-upon-Airburst-upon-etc - I've esacpe numerous airburst by thinking and adding awareness to other thing than my normal stopcast-bar. Archimonde always targets his Air Burst-victim - for me atleast - this is enough time to read the name on ToT-frame and remember if it's one of the persons who stands near me. If it is - then I just move from him. If it's me -I pull back trying to save some nearby friends of the hassel. Just spend some time during raid thinking of who runs in and out of your close vincinity. It does wonders.
Call for help - A few times I've been shit out of luck. When your all out of cards to play or know that your might get out on deep water shortly - call it out on vent.

Nice example would be my raid yesterday. Probably the most irritating and anoying downing of Archimonde I've done so far. Impressing series of Doomfires (100k fire-dmg on me) and I was quite near dying a good amount of times. Calling out on vent, spending mana on shields, hp-pots, hp-stones and so on made me survive. I didn't really get much done that fight but leading Doomfires away from the raid, take damage, decurse abit and deal some damage. But hey ho - eventually I was standing there with everything on cd wanding Archimondes last 10% - down he went.

I'm 100% sure that we would have wiped that downing if I had been less focused on survival but more trying to max-DPS that raid. I still claim that Archimonde isn't a fight that scales down in difficulty, if you reduce the length of the encounter, the same way it does on a luck based fight like Mother Shahraz or a DPS-race like Gruul. Archimonde is a slow and controlled chaos steadily bringin his HP down. Most of the chaotic things can be controlled - heck even Doomfires can we lead away from the raid by smart raiders instead of creating a maze around the raid.

I'm not trying to imply throwing candy at Archimond will do the trick - some level of DPS is still needed.

One fact is sure for us - when everyone focus on surviving we 1-shot him. The times we've gone in DPS-racing - those are also the times we've wiped the most.
Last edited by Praanz : 09/22/07 at 9:07 PM.

#598SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Melador
The fear still needs to go. Its just fucking stupid that in this day and age we're seeing that trash in an "end game" encounter.
Faction imbalances regarding fear ward notwithstanding, I see nothing wrong with using fear as a mechanic. Knowing that you're going to be running around an out of control of your character makes sure that people can prepare for the future rather than just reacting to the present. It makes sure you get yourself in a safe position, get some hots/sheild on the MT or anyone who's recently been doomfired, manage your cooldowns so you don't pop something right before you get feared, etc.

In fact, I sort of like it because it adds some unpredictability to endgame encounters that after a while get very "by the book".
#599SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Nurru
Originally Posted by Melador
Faction imbalances regarding fear ward notwithstanding, I see nothing wrong with using fear as a mechanic. Knowing that you're going to be running around an out of control of your character makes sure that people can prepare for the future rather than just reacting to the present. It makes sure you get yourself in a safe position, get some hots/sheild on the MT or anyone who's recently been doomfired, manage your cooldowns so you don't pop something right before you get feared, etc.

In fact, I sort of like it because it adds some unpredictability to endgame encounters that after a while get very "by the book".
I'm surprised anyone can justify something as inconsistent as fear's current implementation. It might fear you straight into a fire 40 yards away, it might make you run just out of range of a decurser, it might resist, it might simply run you as far as possible away from the fight so it takes you a chunk of time just to run back. That sort of unpredictability should not exist and the fact that they keep using it encounter after encounter simply shows that they're too uncreative (or lazy?) to come up with new encounter mechanics for raid wide effects.

#601SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Playered
They could do a disorientate (non MT) rather than a fear of which no amount of shamans, undeads, dwarfs of draenei's will help you - not to mention you will be out of control and not move too much from your current position.

Fear and MC are two mechanics I find dull, over-used and non-inventive, atleast Chromaggus' version was controllable and more fitting than "oh and he MCs you".

The pure fact of how Shamans alone can effect this fight significantly just show how flawed it is as a mechanic, if any class had a way to make people immune to MC you can bet your raid would end up loaded with them on encounters that have it.

They need to make these 'ultra boss abilities' uncounterable by means of outside-event items, racials or class specific benefits, but with a way inside the encounter to control it somewhat.

This is again one reason why Kael is quite good (exception of MC/fear), you have quite alot of abilities (pyro, disorientate, conflag, fireballs), of which you counter with use of the mechanics of the fight
#602SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Nurru
Originally Posted by Dots
It is equally surprising how you just ignore that some people might like the concept. Randomness can add a challenge, it's a matter of preference whether you like it or not. But that has already been discussed to no end in this thread.
Some randomness (Crits, tank crushings, etc) add "challenge", other randomness (See running 100 yards away from a healer through fire uncontrollably, Mother Shahraz) just adds a luck and bullshit factor to an encounter. When you down a boss do you prefer to think you did it because you mastered the encounter or because you simply had a good run with the RNG? Fear could be used in the former situation, but most of Blizzard's use of it leans towards the latter. Think back to Magmadar when fear could be out of ranged before it went off. That added some random challenge of fears going into fire, but it was controllable because you could choose to not be in range of the fear at all. Archimonde is a totally different story due to the nature of the Doomfires and the duration of the fears.
#603SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dots
I prefer to think I did it because I played well every week, not because I managed to stay awake on a boring farm encounter that never changes.

For what it's worth, I've never died during our Archimonde kills yet I still can't commend the random design of the encounter (at least you can see fear coming now).

#606SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Nurru
Originally Posted by Dots
Your reply makes no sense. These single incidents don't wipe the entire raid.
Soul charge cascades from a single death can very much wipe the raid if it's at a bad time. It doesn't happen often, but when you get a death because of a random factor such as where fear sends you it's frustrating. I'll agree there are a lot of ways you can improve the odds of this never happening, but sometimes you're just screwed. That aspect of it is something I think they need to eliminate from encounters and tweaking fear or just not using its mechanic over and over would go a long way towards helping that.
#607SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dots
Sure, you got feared into a fire even though it was 40 yards away because everything was on cooldown. Your healers were all sleeping so they couldn't do anything about it either. That resulted in a Soul Charge which you couldn't manage, wiping the entire raid. 100% RNG.

Edit after your edit: yes it can sometimes screw you. But it's not nearly as often as some people think. Myself, I'll rarely take a wipe to randomness if it makes the fight more interesting overall. I can see how that is not everyones cup of tea though.
#608SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Praetorian
Yeah, the point is that while fear is not controllable, your raid's positioning relative to Doomfire is.

People will get feared into Doomfires, but it shouldn't be more than a couple, and it shouldn't be more than your healers can handle if people play it right. You can use PvP trinkets to mitigate the situations where you absolutely cannot afford to be feared or you will wipe the raid, and you can provide tremor totems to further stabilize the couple of groups that really need to be fairly clumped and near Archimonde (melee and a healer/decurser group, if nothing else). If you have a bunch of people standing 15yd from an active Doomfire, who really don't need to be there, and they get feared into it, that's poor tactical execution on their part, not poor "luck."

Personally I agree -- the Fear mechanic on an individual level can be frustrating, but it keeps the encounter dangerous, unpredictable, and uncontrollable. When we wipe, 100% of the time, it's because some people made mistakes. I really enjoy the fight still, every week, three months after our first kill.
#609SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		â™¦ Quigon
Good ol' Dots. This isn't about wiping or not wiping. It isn't about blaming the RNG for your deaths. It's about losing control of your character. It is about poor encounter design.

Fear is just dumb. It is like Mind control on razuvious. It is like BWL loot tables. It is like Archimonde 1.0 sitting there wondering if you'll get a doomfire in the raid on your kill, making it 100 times easier. In one sense fear is added as a terrible patch-job by devs to increase difficulty when development is too inane to come up with something better, and in another sense it is to add randomness to the encounter.

Why do you need to have a fear? You can add another RNG item like an AE that is jukeable that is also "dangerous and unpredictable". I just don't see how "uncontrollable" is fun - even if its on a trivial fight. I keep watching this demo of flight simulator and I'm blown away by how "fun" watching a demo is...

What about Loatheb, or Solarian - these fights employ abilities that make the fight suck, yet you're going to 1 shot these every time. Consumable and group stacking, AE abilities that make sense for design, but lack in quality in implementation. Yet they're not RNG based, they just suck. Is this now another story because its not RNG or "difficult"? Are mark of solarian and impending doom different issues than fear?

Encounter design is something that goes beyond difficulty. It should be innovative, fun, challenging, and engaging. These issues are rarely seen in TBC bosses to the extent they have been in the past. Kael'thas is an example of how to do an end-boss. Illidan and Vashj are examples of how to do an end-boss. Archimonde is an example of a boss that was never well tuned, and is a hodgepodge of 1 stage abilities, some of which are uncontrollable, that are thrown at you to give you some semblance of difficulty. Yet tweak one number too far left or right, and it goes from overly difficult to far too simple (as it is today). Reminds me of another shitty fight that is about to make the same transition.

Archimonde could be so much better than the fight it is today (I actually enjoy the encounter, my problem is with the fear component). I'm sure you can look at this fight and see ways to improve upon it. Surely we're not all sitting here eating Blizzard's shit and thinking "hey, thats as good as it gets kids." Sapphiron's all around, cheers!

Just some ideas that would be far better than "fear" (imo):
-Add falling debris that instagib (and do it right, not the magtheridon nonsense).
-Add a 1 pulse random direction earthquake that breaks positioning and casts.
-Add a targeted AE like a void zone (don't make it like Az'galor's RoF).
-Have a phase 2 where adds need to be dealt with while managing existing doomfires - 1 range tank 1 melee tank, range tank mob has a fear (appropriate use of a fear would be the panic on vashj's adds - an avoidable fear with penalty, unless you're a tauren - you get cooked because you were dumb, not because your tremor totem didn't pulse as a doomfire spawned)
-Have some sort of uber move you need to survive every 25% - perhaps a forced soul charge.

This game needs more skill elements and less stupid abilities like fear. Less things like ironshields and mana pots, and more items like swiftness and rage pots.

My experience with fear on our last kill was basically seeing 4 or 5 total fears, and none of them affected the fight in the slightest because we had shamans, and stood a long ways from the doomfires. Before the hotfix the fast fear changed my tanking style and created a havoc of problems for positioning and groups (coupled with gripped people being at 60+ yards out). The fear could come every 30 seconds and last 7 or 8 seconds? It was just dumb - frustrating comes to mind... not "fun". The fear now is a joke, and just is a remnant of an older encounter practically.

What is wrong with the idea of making Archimonde very difficult, while not relying on fear to do it?
Last edited by Quigon : 09/22/07 at 11:40 PM.
#610SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Ribeye
I like Archimonde as a fight, and I'm unsure why you think a raid wide fear is some sort of copout design element by Blizzard. Certainly it could be a completely different fight alltogether, but it isn't. It is what it is, and when its all said and done, for all its random elements it isn't the sort of beatdown that both Kael and Mother are to learn. In its current state most people report having an easier time with it every week and yet it's still an encounter where everyone has to pay 100% attention the entire fight if you want to win. Fear takes away control of your character and sends you on a walk for a couple seconds and while I will agree that it has been used before, I hardly think thats reason enough to never use it again.

Which brings me to a different point regarding "random elements." Why is it that the very thing people love so much about PvP is the one thing they hate to find in PvE? I hear all the time that the greatest rush of arena is the not knowing what your opponent will do and having to react to a constant flow of random elements that no Computer A.I. could ever simulate. Toss one random element into a PvE encounter that noone can control and people become upset.

Perhaps we carry too many assumptions about raiding to ever deserve truly innovative content. We *expect* content to get easier everytime we succeed at it. We *expect* boss fights to get harder as we progress through the zone and loot to become better for each successive boss. We *expect* all elements of a fight to be controllable if we understand all the variables. We *expect* every boss in the game to be beatable if we bang our heads against it long enough.

I'm as guilty of these assumptions as anyone else, but I'm willing to admit that as we become better and better raiders, the game is going to have to start challenging our assumptions about raiding more and more. The game is training us to be shrewd and skilled opponents and we may see the day where the only way a boss offers any sort of challenge is through uncontrollable random elements.
#611SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		â€¢ Falk
We had a small discussion some time back on how Archimonde may have been so much more engaging, if he'd been tuned for ~15-18 people, and instead have waves of increasingly tough undead storm the Night Elf camp.

You'd have to basically kill Archimonde before the entire camp is overrun, and there would be some leeway in the strategy/division - you could either put more people at the camp to sustain the fight longer (if you have fewer people in the raid able to succesfully click the Tear/dodge doomfires) or put less and rape Archimonde in fewer waves.

Would have been hell to tune correctly, but it may have given options for guilds with more than a few brain-dead people. Not to mention making the fight less one-dimensional. Taurens and their beatsticks were an amazing experience - now why not have Ancients joining the fray along with bear cavalry and friendly flying NPCs (!!!) raining down death from above?

Edit: Speeling
Last edited by Falk : 09/23/07 at 12:01 AM.
#612SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		â€¢ Playered
The odd thing is simply how Archimonde managed to stealth past the entire night-elf base and start sapping the World Tree without them noticing.
Every other base got ravaged by the Burning Legion in order to get access there, but aparently it wasn't needed.

Archimonde currently is an "enjoyable" fight because he is an easy fight, a walkover in comparison to Kael and you only need to have half a brain in order to repeat the kill on him, not to mention there is 0 trash.

He was and still is implemented poorly, if what Blizz said about them wanting us to get purples was the methology behind this fight, then they should of had a couple of sign-posts along the 'road' of MH like you would on the side of a motorway.


They could of simply added a P1 like on Nef which involved some crappy adds for 5mins to give you the feeling that there is something happening and your involved in the actual event.

You talk to Tyrande Whisperwind, she starts the small event (like in the previous bases), you defend vs a couple of waves and then she shouts something like:
"Heros! we've been tricked! Archimonde has bypassed us and even now draws power from the World Tree, quick you must stop him before it is too late!"
"We will hold back the hordes of the Burning Legion while deal with Archimonde, may Elune be with you".

It would basicly turn the fight into Nef v2, but it would add alot more impact into the feeling of the fight, even if you changed nothing about Archimonde himself.

You could even then have the enrage-timer being related to the survival of the NE base rather than simply after 10mins he decides to finger your entire raid because he has a short form of ADD and wants to do something else.

There was just so much potential about this cool boss, so many ways you could involve people within the story and it all got wasted.


If they wanted people to see the 'history zone' and get some purplez along the way, they could of simply opened up the real Hyjal and added a couple of DM arena type events passing players could do every couple of hours and at the end there would be a chest at the World Tree like in the STV arena.


Originally Posted by Quigon
G
Just some ideas that would be far better than "fear" (imo):
-Add falling debris that instagib (and do it right, not the magtheridon nonsense).
-Add a 1 pulse random direction earthquake that breaks positioning and casts.
-Add a targeted AE like a void zone (don't make it like Az'galor's RoF).
-Have a phase 2 where adds need to be dealt with while managing existing doomfires - 1 range tank 1 melee tank, range tank mob has a fear (appropriate use of a fear would be the panic on vashj's adds - an avoidable fear with penalty, unless you're a tauren - you get cooked because you were dumb, not because your tremor totem didn't pulse as a doomfire spawned)
-Have some sort of uber move you need to survive every 25% - perhaps a forced soul charge.
They could of used erm.. Finger of Death? an ability everyone knows and loves about Archimonde before WoW. It seems quite stupid that he has 2 'clean-up' abilities to wipe the raid quicker when you let your MT die.

Ways you could have it?

He starts to cast (as in 3-5sec) it on a player, much like Infernal on Anetheron, and it does a meteor-esk damage, so people need to group up on the player to stop it being an insta-gib.

He could use it as a channeled ability, he stops hitting the MT and casts it on any random player in the raid, and that person needs to be healed through 2500 damage/second for 5 seconds.

You could also have it as a 'phase', where every 25% he yells "Enough with you all, feel the might of the Burning Legion", you get a few seconds as grace time untill he starts spamming Finger of Death on random people in the raid for 8k damage around 10 times.


I mean theres no need to go finding hugely exotic ways to make the encounter hard, he has built-in abilities you could do great things with and keep him feeling like the Archimonde we know and love from Warcraft 3...
Last edited by Playered : 09/23/07 at 12:58 AM.
#613SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Melador
-Add falling debris that instagib (and do it right, not the magtheridon nonsense).
-Add a 1 pulse random direction earthquake that breaks positioning and casts.
-Add a targeted AE like a void zone (don't make it like Az'galor's RoF).
-Have a phase 2 where adds need to be dealt with while managing existing doomfires - 1 range tank 1 melee tank, range tank mob has a fear (appropriate use of a fear would be the panic on vashj's adds - an avoidable fear with penalty, unless you're a tauren - you get cooked because you were dumb, not because your tremor totem didn't pulse as a doomfire spawned)
-Have some sort of uber move you need to survive every 25% - perhaps a forced soul charge.
Personally I find "instagib" mechanics annoying, because there's no recovery -- oops, you weren't paying attention for a second there, boom you're dead. I'd much prefer a penalty that through subsequent skilled play you can recover from. Doomfire is a good example.

Cast-breaking movement is sort of a annoying and not that tactically interesting. Oops, my cast got disrupted, guess I'll just start it again. You wouldn't prep for that the way you do a fear. Plus it doesn't hurt melee that much. Or druids for that matter, 95% of my casts that fight are instant.

I don't think we need Yet Another AoE Damage, especially when the melee classes need to group up. And by the time we're at Archimode I've had my fill of waves of adds, thanks.

Fundamentally I just don't understand the hatred of the fear mechanic. It's just one of the many things that bosses can do. It's a mechanic that has a bunch of interesting tactical implications -- the need to get hots on the MT and others taking damage so that they survive it, the need to position yourself so that you're unlikely to get doomfired, the need to get back into position post-fear while maintaining your other duties, etc. All in all, I think it's one of the more interesting mechanics Blizzard has at their disposal. But like I said earlier, Archimonde is my favorite fight in TBC, even in its currently slightly too-easy state.
#614SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Nurru
That feeling when you reach 10% for the first time outweighs any hatred of the fear mechanic.
#615SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Zifna
Originally Posted by Melador
Personally I find "instagib" mechanics annoying, because there's no recovery -- oops, you weren't paying attention for a second there, boom you're dead. I'd much prefer a penalty that through subsequent skilled play you can recover from. Doomfire is a good example.

Cast-breaking movement is sort of a annoying and not that tactically interesting. Oops, my cast got disrupted, guess I'll just start it again. You wouldn't prep for that the way you do a fear. Plus it doesn't hurt melee that much. Or druids for that matter, 95% of my casts that fight are instant.

I don't think we need Yet Another AoE Damage, especially when the melee classes need to group up. And by the time we're at Archimode I've had my fill of waves of adds, thanks.

Fundamentally I just don't understand the hatred of the fear mechanic. It's just one of the many things that bosses can do. It's a mechanic that has a bunch of interesting tactical implications -- the need to get hots on the MT and others taking damage so that they survive it, the need to position yourself so that you're unlikely to get doomfired, the need to get back into position post-fear while maintaining your other duties, etc. All in all, I think it's one of the more interesting mechanics Blizzard has at their disposal. But like I said earlier, Archimonde is my favorite fight in TBC, even in its currently slightly too-easy state.
If any Blizzard posters are reading this, by the way, thanks for balancing the fight with such a long duration fear. It's the first fight, in, well, my memory where I've felt really happy about having Tremor, and felt like it was really useful. Yeah, there've been tons of other fear bosses, but their fear durations are short enough anyway that Tremor can easily do -nothing- so my thoughts are more like "Well, I'll drop Tremor, can't hurt."
#616SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Juli
Originally Posted by Nurru
I'll keep that in mind next Hyjal clear when I have no fire within 40 yards of me on every side but get feared into one because I don't play well enough.
Let's see:
  • Your pvp trinket was down
  • You weren't in a shaman group
  • You had 0 priests/paladins in a shaman group or with WOTF or fear ward or divine shield in range of you
  • You had 0 priests/paladins with a pvp trinket that wasn't on cooldown in range
  • Every priest/paladin that was in range and had one of the above spilled coffee in their lap and couldn't find their cleanse/dispel keys or couldn't click on you as you slowly pathed into the doomfire
I'm also kind of surprised I haven't seen anyone suggest the use of mass dispel when you lack shamans (although I may have just missed it; the thread is pretty long now). We only had 2 shamans on our last kill and I found it to be very effective to fear ward myself if I had time after the shaman I was warding, then mass dispel clumps of people so that the MD landed the exact time, or very close after, the fear landed. It was especially effective to get healers and decursers, even if they're not near doomfire. I'd then run around dispelling individuals headed toward doomfire until everyone was safe or the fear expired.

Horde could do the same with undead priests using WOTF and pvp trinkets, and speccing into .5s mass dispel would actually be pretty beneficial for either faction using MD. MD wouldn't be as useful if you had 3-5 shamans since most people would break quickly anyway, but breaking your own fear and single dispelling people at risk of fire is always great. If you're worried about the mana cost, which costs more: healing through a doomfire debuff on even a single person, or mass dispelling? Add in the mana cost of a soul charge or preventing doomfire from hitting more than 1 person with a MD, or breaking a healer's/decurser's fear so they can prevent another person's death and it's a no-brainer.
#617SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Nurru
You seem to be making a link between touching fire at all and wiping the raid. I don't believe I ever claimed that. Besides that, Dots already pulled the "you suck" card so I don't feel the need to go back into that. I still believe adding difficulty to encounters should consist of more than just "Well, it's too easy. Lets add Fear or MC". Taking control away from the players is a cop-out in my eyes. It's not like they can't come up with other methods of adding difficulty as was posted above. Teron Gorefiend is an excellent example of a fight that was basically tank and spank but with a unique difficulty element that made the encounter refreshing in a way.
#618SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Juli
Well my intent was more to inform, and point out the numerous counters to fear, as some of them are often forgotten (you personally may have not been able to do anything more, but someone in your raid could). It's in my nature to be an ass when I offer criticism, constructive as it may be.

On a slightly different note, after having done the fight more (and shahraz a good number of times, both of which are touted as highly random), it seems that the difficulty stems mostly from the average raider's ability to react and cope with random elements, not from the random elements themselves being difficult. As Ribeye was getting at in post #610, it takes a better player to react to a dynamic situation than to be given "A->B->C->D->Loot" instructions to execute. As players get better at reacting on the fly, the encounter becomes noticeably easier; it's not just a dice roll every time. If it continues to feel like a dice roll, it's likely some of your players aren't improving their play ability.
Last edited by Juli : 09/23/07 at 2:37 PM.
#619SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Dots

The point is, while the fear is totally random on an individual basis, it is very much possible to deal with it as a raid entity. But Praetorian, Ribeye and some others already put it much better than I could.

#621SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Lymmel
I don't see how a trivial introduction phase would add thrill to the encounter. If it's not trivial I would have to disagree, the fight is hard enough already as it is. It depends on your guild, but I found archimonde to be much harder than kael for us. Adapting to tactics, learning about new abilities, burning down the weapons before advisors and the then advisors before kael, sure. The crucial kael phases (2+3) last for 5 minutes total and the biggest danger is really some mob instagibbing people who moves a lot slower than doomfires do. And if someone dies to him, that's fully recoverable. Archimonde is not at all like that, a fight which requires absolute focus for 10-12 minutes for every single second of it is a hard fight to execute in my book.

I don't think fear is what makes archimonde annoying, I have seen fear in lots of encounters before and I always liked it, because it really gave you the impression that you were fighting against a much more powerful entity that had power to destroy your raid's planning. I think the problem lies in soul charge. In a fight that takes that long, a mechanic that has a large chance to wipe you in the case only 1 of your raid members loses focus for a few seconds or disconnects or gets grip midair or whatever is just too unforgiving. Sure you can survive it, but from the moment someone dies and soul charge will go off, it's a gamble more or less. In a perfect scenario noone would take damage from grip or doomfire but I am willing to be it happens in every archimonde fight for every guild and that if you get soul charge on a bad moment, wiping potential goes up by tons.

I think soul charge should be 'stacking' in sorts, like do no damage and just cast the side effect first time you get it, do a 3k aoe without knockback second time, do the current one at 3rd death and just instagib the raid at 4th one. Or maybe do the same 1 death sooner, 3 deaths shouldn't be allowed either I guess, would propably be too easy. Having such a high chance to wipe when something happens to only 1 of your raid members seems like a nice concept but it's totally unfun in practice. It's rewarding when you get him, but when you look back at your tries, you only remember being stressed and on the edge all the time.
#622SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â€¢ Playered
Originally Posted by Lymmel
