It depends on your guild, but I found archimonde to be much harder than kael for us. Adapting to tactics, learning about new abilities, burning down the weapons before advisors and the then advisors before kael, sure. The crucial kael phases (2+3) last for 5 minutes total and the biggest danger is really some mob instagibbing people who moves a lot slower than doomfires do. And if someone dies to him, that's fully recoverable. 10-12mins of focus eh? Well to be fair it must require a DAMN huge amount of focus to survive upto 2mins of his enrage (which is 10mins).

The fight is between 5-8mins for the most part, once you have the survival part sorted on your raid you can put more emphasis on DPS to bring the kill faster.

Kael is far more complex, Archimonde is Fear, Doomfire, Airburst and nothing else really, if someone dies it tends to be a wipe untill you get moderatly good at it so you dont really have to learn how to deal with soulcharges much, if you get one, you put everything on hold and try to survive its inital damage and the silence if its there and then you continue as normal.
#623SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Renew
Getting feared into a fire from 40 yards out means that by the time you touch the fire the fear ends. So you will get heals. It will also be very rare this happens because 40 yards is a long distance to cover, usually I have people in my guild move 20 yards out when the fear cooldown is up.

The fear mechanic in this fight isn't really an issue with boss mods, you can do stuff to stay alive (ie move far away from fire). The area is large.

Kael has a ton more abilities but on their own they are a lot less deadly and a lot easier to avoid and even if someone falls victim to them they are far more recoverable. We spent 15 hours including trash reclears at kael, we spent 25 hours before we killed archimonde. #625SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3
Edited onPatch 2.1.3		Aciara
After we've now downed him twice I must say that after the first few stupidity wipes (fall damage), I really really like this fight. As a lifebloom Druid Doomfire is just so much damage that I only have to put up 1 lifebloom every 7 seconds to outheal it so effectivly I could heal my whole group if we all had a Doomfire dot running for some reason.

We're a Horde guild so we don't have a Druid tank, but on both our kill tries we had 3 Shamans and 9 Healers (once 1 lb Druide once 2) in the Raid and due to tremor totem I only had to use my PvP insignia twice. As I tried to point out above if someone in my range (we use a 3 camp+Melee camp setup) gets Doomfire I can let my lifeblooms really shine, as Doomfire feels like it has been built in extra for us Druids (long Duration, low damage).

The only things about this fight that I might say isn't as it should be is the big difference betwen Horde and Alliance. Fearward really makes this fight alot easier (Feral tank vs Warrior tank). The other thing that one might not see as such a good idea is the needed Shaman stacking (less than 3 and you're asking for trouble), but this is afaik the first fight where a tremor totem is needed (yes on some fights it was nice in pre TBC but it was never "needed") which isn't to bad.

Overall I'd just like to reinforce my point that I really like this fight alot more than any other one in Mt Hyjal. This is partly due to it being the only fight without stupid trash but also partly because as a Druid I like being able to heal and decurse while having to look out to what is happening to everyone else (i.e. if someone just got grip and is now flying I can travelform after him and save him! Yay! )


/edit that's what I get for not refreshing before posting :&

For us Kael'thas was alot worse simply because the fight goes on for so long (and because I think our phoenix workout is wrong but that's beside the point). We wiped for ages vs Kael for our first kill, about 5-6 Raiddays for our second kill and the same time again for the third time. Archimonde was a totaly different matter we had our first set of tries the week before last with 3 Shamans and only 8 healers with our best try being 37% (which was more luck than anything else imho). Then last week we had Monday and Tuesday with tries against him and on Tuesday everything just clicked (9 healers, 3 or 4 Shamans) on our second try that Day he was down. Wednesday hit and with that a fresh Mt Hyjal id and again our third try of the night landed us a Archimonde kill. I think this has alot to do with our attention span and/or our ability to concentrate for long periods of time (Kael was a ~25-30 min fight with a fresh trash clear every 2 hours). Maybe this is also part of why I like Archi so much

#626SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Lupison
The only design flaw of this fight is the 2 things they're addressing in the patch:
curse + thrown and soul charges being an insta raid wipe.

And the soul charges part isnt being nerfed enough imo. Sure you can have it so he sucks your soul and causes some minor bad thing to happen, but make it so one guy dying is an insta wipe just seems flawed to me.

Everything else about this fight seems well designed to me.
#627SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Russta
It's brutal for learning the encounter but once you get used to it, Soul Charges aren't always a guaranteed wipe if you're playing well. Sure, everyone taking 4500 damage is going to wipe you if half your raid sucks at avoiding Doomfire or decursing but they can be avoided and resisted. A well geared tank will have the means to survive most of them if everyone else can.
#628SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3â™¦ Nurru
I'd argue against soul charges being nerfed. Without them there isn't really any penalty to your raid not being able to handle grip/doomfire and the fight already isn't much of a dps race considering you have 10 minutes and only need to survive till 10% or so.
#629SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Aciara
Originally Posted by Russta
It's brutal for learning the encounter but once you get used to it, Soul Charges aren't always a guaranteed wipe if you're playing well. Sure, everyone taking 4500 damage is going to wipe you if half your raid sucks at avoiding Doomfire or decursing but they can be avoided and resisted. A well geared tank will have the means to survive most of them if everyone else can.

The Hunter/Druid/Whatnot one is very easily healed through (4800 damage over 8 seconds or so) and if nothing bad is happening the +50% damage one isn't bad either. We've also healed through the silence a few times (notice: the duration of the silence isn't always the same, sometimes it's 1-2 seconds and sometimes 5-8 seconds). With enough healers (we bring 9) healing through soul charges isn't such a pain if everyone else is doing everything right (but atleast for us if someone screws up, concentration is lost and someone else will probably die soon).

Once someone dies we're pretty good at toping everyone off, or anyone low immediately uses a consumable before the charge is used. We can usually live through one death if enough of us resist the silence and/or stun. But it's always hte stun/silence part that's the wiper.

#635SourcePosted on Patch 2.1.3Russta

#636SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Fafhrd
Archimonde is a perfect encounter, in my opinion. These are my criteria for a fun and well designed boss-fight: Engaging, unique, challenging, rewarding, not tedious.

- Engaging; all player need to be on their toes. I hate fights where the usual suspects can stand in a corner and press one button while watching anime.
- Unique; there are mechanics we haven't seen before, like the Air Burst/Tears.
- Challenging; a flawless player will NOT die on Archimonde (except if in the unlikely event you get Grip/Burst/Purification Pot on cd). Several of my guildmates has never died "first" there. Don't we all love an encounter that separates the wheat from the chaff?
- Quick recovery; no trash, short run
- Rewarding; besides nice loot, you get a good sense of accomplishement to down him after 30-40 tries.

The only problem with it is that the last 10% is too easy. And longer fears please, make the dispellers work more!
#637SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0PsiVen
While I think it's certainly a fun encounter if you haven't been wiping on it for hours that night, I wouldn't call it perfect. The erratic behavior of Doomfires and their penchant for making figure-8s on the melee gets old.

Longer fears, Fafhrd? I don't think we need to require guilds to stack 5 shamans...
#638SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Dawme
Archimonde is way too subject to raid stacking to be perfect imho. I enjoy the fight every week, but honnestly, Archimonde with 1 shaman and Archimonde with 3-5 shamans are 2 _very_ different fights. The latter is enjoyable and fun, the former can be really frustrating.
#639SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Lymmel
As I said, soul charge's effect should be scaling with deaths and have a wider effect each time, making it an instant wipe at the 3rd or 4th death, a challenging recovery at the 2nd death and a minor inconvinience for 1 death. 1 death should just not be punished so much even if the focus of the fight is survival. I agree that if soul charge was just nerfed the encounter would be ridiculously easy for a t6 endboss.

Other than that I agree that the fight has some nice unique elements, but they are combined with some overused ones (decurse/fear) to make for a mediocre experience. He is also kinda anticlimatic compared to the final mission of wc3. I really expected something totally different.

I personally prefer encounters that you only rely on a specific part of the raid, like you rely on rogues/warriors for RoS, like you rely on mages/hunters for maulgar, like you relied on priests for razuvius (apart from the stupid resist/break chance). I think relying so much on the whole raid is a flawed design because very few guilds can field raids with that quality of players. Also, people tend to lose focus after a certain number of wipes, which is necessary for this encounter.
#640SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Aciara
You're making it sound like you can't heal through Doomfire? Because apart from that and our MT dieing we didn't have that many problems (after the fall damage deaths stopped happening). From a Raidgrp coordination perspective I finde Kael'thas alot worse because you didn't only have to do it right, you had to push out certain amounts of dps whilst doing it right. While fighting Archimonde you can just "stack" (I wouldn't call taking 9 healers stacking but some might) healers and you're golden, as long as you have 3 Shamans with you otherwise fear might be too punishing if the fight drags on for a long time.
#641SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Lymmel
You can easily heal through doomfire, problem is when someone gets bursted with doomfire ticking or someone hitting a newly spawned doomfire while running back to camp. The odds of getting a doomfire+burst, a grip+burst or doomfire+soul charge stack up to be high. And you only need it to happen to 1 person to get a wipe. Ranged dps were the problem for us and the usual death victims about 80% of the time, because they would have a limited amount of decursers/healers to take care of them in case anything went wrong. If they got cut off in a weird place by doomfire or bursted with one they would typically die.

We got the kill by using more melee than usual (8-9 instead of 5-6, 1 of them an enh shaman), 8 healers (1 shaman healer) and 8 ranged dps standing spread out in one area behind him to synchronise their movement. We abandoned any idea of trying to control the fight through stacking shamans or having people out of form fear warding and finally got it in a 7-7:30 minute kill by trying to just burn him as fast as possible. Hectic, but worked.

#654SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Cevil
Since 2.2, has anyone a new undocumented change on Archimonde? It seems if a fire path loops back in on itself, and reaches Archimonde, the entire flame path despawns instantly.

We killed him for our second time last night, and while we've been told it gets easier the more you do it, it felt a whole heckuva lot easier last night than our first kill. We never had problems avoiding the fire (if you can believe it, idiots falling was still wiping us after ~60 attempts), but the fires last night seemed a LOT less problematic, which in turn increased DPS, making fight shorter, etc. etc.

The fires last night just seemed to be easier. Anyone else notice it?

Also, you can survive soul charges, and keep going without a problem, so long as no one dies to the soul charge. When someone dies, I'll call out on vent "soul charge incoming," and it's the guild's cue to be ready to bandage immediately. It's definitely recoverable.

Also, we run 3 shamans now (1 enh, 2 resto) and it makes this fight MUCH better. Tremor Totem really shines here.
#655SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0â™¦ Nurru
Doomfire deep breaths more. We didn't notice any changes last night, except that one of our hunters playing one of our shaman had an almost magnetic attraction to doomfire.
#656SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Russta
For people that have done the fight post-patch, do you feel it's still worth everyone having Purification Potions for air grips? I know burst>grip can't happen anymore but is it still a good precaution to have them for grip>burst?
#657SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0PsiVen
Personally, I've never had the occasion to use one of my Purification pots. As a paladin I don't even bring them anymore, but I would recommend that DPS still have them in case they need to decurse themselves. I'm not sure I've ever seen a burst+grip death in ~80 Archimonde attempts but I've seen many instances where people got grip and nobody was around to dispel it for several ticks.
#658SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Illundai
Originally Posted by Cevil
Since 2.2, has anyone a new undocumented change on Archimonde? It seems if a fire path loops back in on itself, and reaches Archimonde, the entire flame path despawns instantly.
I definitely saw this happening on our kill on Wednesday. Only saw it once though, but what happened was that a Doomfire spawned, which I dodged, then it went all the way behind the melee, only to come back at the front of Archimonde and approximately path of the spot it spawned. It despawned instantly, the entire trail, not the start of the trail like before - it was completely gone the moment it ended. Very odd.
#659SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0â™¦ Elendril

#660SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Sorcerer
We are still learning the fight (sigh ppl who die from doomfires) but is there way of actually controlling doomfires at least now after patch?

They are really unpredictable for us, sometimes making circle around the people etc.

And question, is spreading around archimonde rather good or not becouse i have some doubts. Dispelling is fine for us with ppl spread all the way around archimonde but is there other reason why not to spread around just stick behind?
#661SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Intermission
Originally Posted by Sorcerer
We are still learning the fight (sigh ppl who die from doomfires) but is there way of actually controlling doomfires at least now after patch?

They are really unpredictable for us, sometimes making circle around the people etc.

And question, is spreading around archimonde rather good or not becouse i have some doubts. Dispelling is fine for us with ppl spread all the way around archimonde but is there other reason why not to spread around just stick behind?
[edit: havent done archi post-patch]

Spreading out does two things:

Air Burst is an AoE, so more spread = less burst.

Spreading out means less people in any given area. So if a Doomfire comes to a group 10 people, it's going to be worse than coming to a group of 3.


The only downside of spreading out is possible OOR decursers. Not usually an issue though.



As for the Doomfire, it noticably 'latches' onto and follows people. Not always for its full duration, and may simply drop off you too. It also seems possible to 'break' the latch by dodging it as if you were dodging a rolling boulder, stepping sideways quickly as it approaches. However this is NOT a good thing to do. If you Doomfire is near you, the best thing to do is run it AWAY from the boss in a straight line if possible. Yes you look like an idiot for not simply side-stepping it, but if you side-step it there is the possibility it will loop around and encircle a group of healers / melee / slow people.

I estimate that the vast majority of wipes could be avoided if people simply handled Doomfire correctly. I dont mean positioning during fears or that sorta stuff, I mean what *you* do as the Doomfire spawns in your vicinity.
#662SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Sorcerer
Ok archimonde died today after 5 tries, thats whole of 2.5 night of tries post patch but anyway back to meritum.

I cracked my head a lot during the fight especially about doomfires.

We tried 2 things about positioning archimonde, killed with 360o degree tactic.
-360 degree spreading , archi near choped wood
-180 degree spreading in moon shape behind archi which was tanked at the mountain.

Both had pros and negatives but they are RELATIVE how people handle with doomfire...
If your raid is very good at running doomfire in straight line 180 degree tac is clearly superior.

How i see doomfire mechanics.
People who are in front of spawning doomfire shall NEVER EVER strafe run but run backwards or else doomfire loops like crazy. U can strafe back into the fight once its quite far so once it loop it wont even reach ranged ppl.
BUT... when we used 180degree tactic few times doomfire was running at the top of the mountain in straight line where nobody ever was so...

I think there is something other gimmick about doomfire and its not only following people. Key could be analyzing positioning and raid moving when it spawns and from what i've saw it never spawns more than ~15yards from archi, its like doomfire has outer ring running out of archi were it spawns.
#663SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Cadfael
Got our second kill of Archimonde today. In the third attempt. The first two we wiped because a new shaman we just attuned today with Kael and brought along cratered us two times. Third attempt he went down way easy. We had for the first time 4 shamans and boy was that a big difference. With the Airburst + Grip combo gone, he was easier by a tremendous amount. People were feared for about 2 seconds max.

I can only second the notion, that with enough fear breakers, the fight is entirely different.
#664SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0Gryff
Easyish fight, cleared thursday after lagfest wednesday meant we didnt even down azgalor.

Just positioned into three camps, decurses+healers at each, all decursers raid iconed up.

Initial positioning isnt that important as its fluid, the key is moving around well and staying close to one of your decursers as dps/healer.

With good decursing, the only real issue with the fight is avoiding doomfire+fear combo, we make sure fear CD is announced and people move away from fires, we only had 2 shamans and the only issue we had was the first attempt the guildmaster >.> tried escaping from doomfire...across me ( MT ) and getting me airbursted and consequently finger of deathing people.

Second attempt was a good clean kill and our guild second ( first was post patch ).

Can't express how much easier the fight felt this week.
#665SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.0
Edited onPatch 2.2.0		ainav
Considering you only have 1 shaman I think I can give you a hint how to possition your groups so it make it a little bit easier for you.

4-----------------------1


melee Boss MT


3-----------------------2
What you can do here is basicly split the raid into 5 self sufficient groups each having a decurser + 2 healers + 2dps'ers excluding (melee group which should only consist 1 shaman for tremor totem for the rogues).

Now lets focus on the ranged groups that we have (1-2-3-4) almost full time you will have fire walls that threaten 2 of those groups by heading to their direction and you have more or less correct timer for the fear.
What you can do is tell to the groups that are on the sides where the fire wall is to move far away exactly before the next fear happens that way you will still have atleast 4 healers + hots on the MT and ofcourse you can make a rotation for (trinket bubble etc.) depending on which groups need to move(good voice comunication will help a lot here).
Talking about cursed ppl it shouldnt be a problem because :
1st every group has its own decurser and melee are decursed by everyone in range
2nd even if someone gets curse + burst (which shouldnt happen now with the patch iirc) he is flying exactly behind the back of his own group which should make it easy for his group decurser to simply turn back run 20 yards in the dirrection of the cursed player and decurse him before he dies.

The most important thing in this tactic is that people should always move away from the fire before fear happens and you shouldnt be afraid because there are groups that do not have on their side and the healers in those groups can heal the MT without problem.
Last edited by ainav : 10/01/07 at 12:22 AM. Reason: problems with making the possitioning picture
#666SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.2Machia
We did Archimonde for our first time last night. We ran with 3 shamans, and about 7 decursers (we run druid heavy raids). We never had much of a problem with decursing but even with tremor totem the fear is difficult to control. We'd get air burst into flames a few times and have the unlucky addition of grip getting on someone who just got hit by flames and then air burst. Towards the end of the night we were learning to control things a bit better and we were able to consistently push him to 50% before we were hit with the bad luck monster. Our DPS was pretty bad on him (we would've still made the enrage timer) but pretty much everyone was playing a more cautious role with DPS being secondary. It helps to make sure that your raid knows that the fear is dispellable and to hopefully get it off as many people as possible. We're hoping our next go at him will yield a kill shot.
#667SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.2Zindel
Ever since the first pull we told the raid that reaching the enrage is a good thing, and that we'll kill him the pull after reaching enrage.

We hit the enrage with 25 people up, we killed him the very next pull. The simple fact that you made the enrage timer gives the raid a whole lot of confidence that yeah, this group of players can kill him. Suddenly dps jumps up and you got yourself an Archimonde kill.
#668SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.2â™¦ Jamor
Originally Posted by Machia
We did Archimonde for our first time last night. We ran with 3 shamans, and about 7 decursers (we run druid heavy raids). We never had much of a problem with decursing but even with tremor totem the fear is difficult to control. We'd get air burst into flames a few times and have the unlucky addition of grip getting on someone who just got hit by flames and then air burst. Towards the end of the night we were learning to control things a bit better and we were able to consistently push him to 50% before we were hit with the bad luck monster. Our DPS was pretty bad on him (we would've still made the enrage timer) but pretty much everyone was playing a more cautious role with DPS being secondary. It helps to make sure that your raid knows that the fear is dispellable and to hopefully get it off as many people as possible. We're hoping our next go at him will yield a kill shot.
Similar to the previous poster, we stress staying alive MUCH more than anything else -- including DPS. We had a kill stopped by the enrage timer, and I was actually very happy with the outcome. DPS will come as people get more comfortable staying alive.

One of the things we do for this fight is just to let the melee bring the kill home for us. We chain heroism in to that group, and give that shaman our fear ward (if that priest is online). Melee getting a doomfire will suck up more healing than anything else (especially with the change to the water). The side benefit is that they do a crapton of damage as well.
#669SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.2Latito
Same as the above poster, nearly every fight the top 5 spots on dmg meters are 4+ melee. Just make sure people stay alive - if all of your fear breaks are on cooldown, run away from doomfires 5-8 seconds before fear starts. Simple as that. Not only do you do no dmg when dead, but you've got a strong shot at wiping the raid just for that extra 5 seconds of dmg - was it really worth it?
#670SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.2Giske
This fight is so unforgiving, 50+ attempts on him and we still have idiot ranged dying on doomfires. So tired of him, hes the new Vashj.
#671SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.2Herm
Originally Posted by Giske
This fight is so unforgiving, 50+ attempts on him and we still have idiot ranged dying on doomfires. So tired of him, hes the new Vashj.
Vashj is forgiving provided you can think on your feet. Nothing that can go wrong really has the ability to wipe the raid on it's own. Archimonde can be unforgiving if you are unlucky enough to have a soul charge hit the raid right before a fear, leaving no ability to react or recover, and can wipe the raid if multiple people die as a result of it.

#675SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Cadfael
Yeah if you learn this fight, the first thing that kills you is probably either airburst, curse or tank taking a spike.

As soon as you got airburst under control and the curse is being dispelled properly, it may switch to doomfire problems - and that is where it probably remains for the rest until the firstkill. Really drill it into the people, that avoiding fires is paramount to everything else.

No ranged DD should EVER hit the fire. Ever. A MT healer, that's understandable, but never a ranged DD. Should there be no fear breaker for some ranged DDs, have them run all the way out each time a fire is somewhere near and a fear is coming up. Even if that means that the player is 40 seconds in total not doing any damage at all. Damage for everything not melee is irrelevant, Archimonde requires about 6800 raiddps. You're most likely spiking 17K right at the start. If you don't loop the fires back in circles at the melee, because you're thinking you need to get back for some DPS time, your melee will kill him just fine for you.

I've probably wiped around 80 times at Archimonde and killed him 3 times. I have never seen the enrage. Damage is irrelevant, survival is all.

On the first kill, I had no fear breaker. My grand contribution to the fight amounts to something around 400dps.
#676SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Vazu
Doomfire is actually very manageable for me. In the rare situations where I've eaten that debuff, a Greater Fire Protection Potion + Healthstone works wonders to mitigate the initial large amounts of damage. A couple of HOTs on me was all I needed + Drain Life and I was fine. Some of our Priests on the other hand, get owned. We've started having them wear PVP gear. Sitting at 9100 health for Archimonde as a healer is just not a good idea.

Has it been a "we learned, now we do it right" kind of thing or "we throw attempts at it till the stars align" kind of process for your guilds?

Vashj and kael are more execution based than Archimonde. You may find archimonde more difficult to repeat than the former due to random elements of doomfire and fear completely governing the difficulty of the fight - no two archimonde attempts are remotely similar, and for some people this is what they enjoy.

More Indiana Jones balls need to be rolled through these encounters is probably the thinking.

We've killed archimonde like hmm 11 times now I think and it is by far the hardest fight for us to repeat. I think most guilds will disagree with me on this, but most guilds don't do Archimonde with 1 shaman

The degree of repeatability is directly proportional to the amounts of shaman, fear wards, undead you have in your raid, aside from the fear there really isn't any challenging component to the fight, so the more ways you can remove it the easier he will be to farm.
#682SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3generalanders
If you're able to time the fears, then you can time your tremor totems. Tremor Ticks immediately when dropped and every 5 seconds after. So if you drop tremor 4 seconds before the fear starts, it will break your group out (assuming they're in range) after 1 second of fear.
#683SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3dukes
Originally Posted by generalanders
If you're able to time the fears, then you can time your tremor totems. Tremor Ticks immediately when dropped and every 5 seconds after. So if you drop tremor 4 seconds before the fear starts, it will break your group out (assuming they're in range) after 1 second of fear.
The fear has a minimum timer and a maximum timer. Within that window (about 15 seconds) it can be cast at any time. They've changed most "random" mechanics to work on this semi-random principle, because pure-timed abilities could be considered too easy to work around (as you said, if fear was always 45 seconds you could time it to tick exactly 0.5 seconds after the fear, breaking it semi-instantly).
#684SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Buiden
Even after the fear changes we've had him not use his fear in the upwards of 45 seconds after the cooldown comes up, not sure if anyone else has noticed this but it is still entirely possible.
#685SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Latito
Just to give you an idea of how repeatable the fight is.. my guild has killed him ~8 times now, we're currently working on Illidan. This week we 1-shot all of Hyjal except Archimonde, 1-shot Naj, Sup, Akama, Teron, Bloodboil and Mother. RoS we 2-shot after a double-resist by the felhunters on p2 bubble so I kicked a shield while Spirit Shock was busy shocking our MT. Next attempt went off without a hitch. Council was 2-shot, our second kill. Archimonde took ~7 attempts.

In our 2 months killing him, we've never failed to down him. Usually its on the first night of attempts (first few weeks we'd do Rage -> Azgalor night 1, Archi night 2.. now we do full Hyjal night 1 + some BT), occasionally it spills over to a second night of attempts. We've 1-shot him, we've taken 20+ attempts on him post-first-kill. Its a pretty random fight but nothing you CAN'T handle. Granted the MT taking 3x 9k+ hits in 2 seconds does suck. Just treat it the same every week - SURVIVE and ye shall get loot.
#686SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Nurru
Archimonde seems scary as far as repeating goes, but the fight is a lot more mechanical than given credit and as people get used to it week to week you start being comfortable handling the randomness.
#687SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Our guild tried archimonde tonight for the first time and killed him after ~3.5 hours or 15-20 total attempts, with a unlucky 11% wipe in the first part of the night. Ive been dying to do this fight myself for months and only had this thread as a resource to find out what other people think. So finally today I got my chance to experience it and my thoughts on the fight were:

- the fight itself is amazingly FUN and original! Concentration and communication required all the time!

- the fight would have been extraordinarily frustrating before the changes to airburst/fear and we're glad we got to him at a time where this was much less random

- doomfires were very controllable with good positioning and communcation

- we used 3 shamans and 5 decursers and a 4-point square formation for basic setup (4 mages in a square formation around archimonde at the centre, with all their group standing on them - and a resto druid standing in the middle of the square with the melee, responsible for melee decurse)

Fun sidenote is: most of our mage/caster dps were on ~300-600 dps and for the kill of 8.5 minutes I (also mage) did about the same damage as the main tank! Leave the real damage to your melee, wear good sta/pvp gear instead and forget about trying to do damage like normal fights.

I havent been this impressed with a raiding encounter since C'thun - totally in love with this fight and really commend blizzard with its design.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/11/07 at 11:29 PM.
#688SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Lymmel
It's nice that you are enthusiastic about your kill and congratulations for that, but I think you are overreacting. Apart from soul charge, nothing is really original about the fight. Also, you will have to do it someday without stacking the raid on decursers/wards/shamans so much and it won't be too enjoyable then propably. I dunno though, maybe I am bitter due to all the disconnect/midair grip wipes we have had. Even now that we usually kill him without much trouble I hate the fight with passion. C'thun and Kael and Illidan and RoS are very different, you can have tangible progress every attempt, while archimonde was just a dice roll every attempt, not because his abilities are random, but the focus and attention span of your raiders each different day is.

But I sincerely dislike a fight where your odds of defeating it are increasing by using arena gear, and taking strolls around the lake miles away from him. Illidan and Kael are much better and interesting encounters in almost every possible way, you can't overemphasize on any aspect of your gear and beat them.
#689SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Apart from soul charge, nothing is really original about the fight
But I sincerely dislike a fight where your odds of defeating it are increasing by using arena gear, and taking strolls around the lake miles away from him. Illidan and Kael are much better and interesting encounters in almost every possible way, you can't overemphasize on any aspect of your gear and beat them.
I would have to disagree entirely. Having an end boss of a zone where survivability is that important raid-wide and dps becomes almost meaningless in comparison - is very original in this implementation (a huge open field where your thrown around and having to run large distances from doomfire).

Ive never really had that feeling on Kael/Cthun/Ragnaros/Nefarian/Naxx/Vashj before as a mage. C'thun and Kael are both two very awesome other fights, but its just a nice refreshing change and id love to see similar themed fights (encouraging survivability over everything else) in future.

Even if some mechanics of the fight might not be new (eg: fear, running away from something bad) the way it all comes together in the fight is what does it. Having 3 shamans and 4-5 decursers (3 mage + 1resto and feral druid helping) isnt what id consider raid stacking. Its just a balanced raid comp - and I think requiring a balanced raid comp is fine.

We did a quick poll of 'What would you rate archimonde out of 10' to guildies after our kill - and no surprise that the melee and main tank rated him the lowest, whereas most of the ranged dps and healers rated him high.

It really is interesting to see how polarizing the 'Do you like the archimonde fight?" question is between different people/classes/guilds etc.

During the -10% zerg I took this very cool screenshot:

Last edited by Tyrian : 10/11/07 at 11:26 PM.
#690SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3nataku
The Soul Charges are significant and important new ability in a fight as it forces a successful kill to involve very few deaths from the raid. I guess this would be your basic raid awareness from each individual test taken to a whole new level of importance. It took my guild roughly three full nights and ~80 attempts before people fully understood how important staying alive for this fight is and we killed him last night.

We had 2 shamans, 4 decursers, and 2 dwarf shadow priests out of shadow form to deal with Archimonde's abilities, so our margins for error in positioning relative to Doomfire was fairly tight. I tried to dps on this fight, but seeing that we only had seven healers available last night, I swapped in more healing and pvp gear and tried to spot heal Doomfire people more than doing damage, while running around fear warding healers.

Not too sure how well we will be able to repeat the kill, but I think a large majority of the guild was starting to understand their roles a lot better for the fight by the end of the night.

#694SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Kill him 10+ times and we'll see just how much you still enjoy it. I for one thought it was an awesome fight after our first kill, after 5 or 6 I soon discovered it is debatably the worst fight they have ever "designed".
That just means the level of concentration, co-ordination and strong balanced raid comp (decursers, shamans, fear management techniques) is going to need to remain strong for every kill - unlike other farm bosses which just progressively get easier as your gear gets better, even if players get lazier and sloppy in performance and execution of the strat. I dont see how this is inherantly 'bad design'. Sure - it might be frustrating and annoying at times, but overall its nice to have one boss in the game like this.

Also, we're fairly melee light recently, I'd assume that makes a difference as well.
We only took 5 melee (excluding the main tank) to archimonde: 3 rogues + fury warrior + enhancement shaman (group tremor totem) in one group. On our kill those five melee did 51% of total damage to archimonde.

The other 50% came from the remaining 10 ranged dps. We just pushed the mentality to all ranged/casters that 'leave the dps to the melee, just focus on staying alive' Again this is nothing new, everyone else has said it previously in this thread - but its really what needs to be nailed into people.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/13/07 at 12:51 PM.

#696SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Cadfael
Originally Posted by Vazu

I think we'll finally get him down, but god killing him weekly is going to be rough.
It gets better really, once you had him people start to really believe in the "survival is all" thing and risk less, which leads to better survivability overall.

Like the poster above said, Archimonde becomes easier once your players become accustomed to focusing on survival, whereas Shahraz can be pain in the ass just because some things aren't controllable like how many mana burn beams you happen to get or bad attraction ports. Last reset on Shahraz on one try our healers we running OOM around 30% due to constant mana burn which of course meant that people started dying. Try or two later, when we got the kill we had better luck with beams so she died with only one player dead.

#699SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Shinja
Hi here, we're currently on Archimonde (and 5/9 in Black Temple) and after 30 try, we didn't really have a good one (best so far is 30%). We've only 2 shamans, so the fear is an issue... My Raid leader told us to "kite" the Doomfire, but I've no read in this thread that the Doomfire could be "kited". As I'm rogue, I can't really see the moving pattern of the Doomfire, any hint about it or it's totally random moving ?
#700SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Falk
The thread's gotten pretty bloated, but in a nutshell, it behaves somewhat like a heat seeking missilie. Running straight backwards if you think it's on you = good. Sidestepping and potentially curving the doomfire around into other people = bad.
#701SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Abradix
Doomfire more or less follows a person, so yes, it can most definitely be kited. Large problems arise when people who are being followed by doomfire, decide to move in an arc around Archimonde instead of just running backwards. This is a huge difference in how annoying the doomfire is, because doomfire cutting off half of your raid and going straight through the raid in general is alot more difficult to deal with then if people just "kite" the doomfires away from Archi in a straight line.
#702SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Heres a test picture I made before we killed archimonde, when we were discussing positioning. Every guild uses different strats for group setup and positioning, as u can see we opted for a 4 point square around archimonde (group 5 is the melee group). This is what worked best for us - it may or may not work for your guild.

The trick is:

- when doomfire spawns that whole group runs in a straight line away from the boss as far as possible until the doomfire stops following you. Dont stop, dont try to sidestep it - the entire group keeps running in a straight line away as far as you can.

- each group is a fully self-sufficient unit - with its own healers and a decurser with a symbol. You always stay together: therefore you all get airbusted together (so nobody is ever out of range of their healer/decurser) and you ALL move together when a doomfire comes towards your group, regardless of which person in the group its actually following. Standing with your group is very high priority, so after any fears or situations where your positions get forcibly changed - moving back to your group decurser symbol is top priority.

This means that, even if the doomfire turns around and comes back for melee, by the time its back it will almost be close to despawning because it has a large travel time to 'snake back' before it reaches the melee. With good vent communication you will be able to alert your melee well in advance if this is happening so they can run off.

It almost always spawns (in my observations) and heads immediately outwards towards the closest ranged/healers for 10-15 seconds before theres a chance it will 'loop around' and chase melee. That 10-15 seconds is crucial as its the time you want to get it to move as far away (in that straight line) from the boss as you can.

Last edited by Tyrian : 10/22/07 at 12:04 PM.
#703SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Latito

Maybe I'm just unaware, but I've never had to kite a Doomfire. The ranged in our guild do, but melee just tend to stand and dps. If a doomfire is headed to melee, we move step back or to the side a bit as it passes through. If we get bursted and can't get back, we wait. Nothing special really.

Any player can trigger a leash if they're too far from his "combat area" from what I've seen, not just his primary aggro target. Could just be a global flag or related to when he tries to target people for Grips; but one time I tanked him a bit too close to the corner of his area and someone got launched causing an immediate finger on the raid.
#706SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Aslin

It was never even timed with punts or grips or anything, and was definitely not from pulling aggro (at least in that case).

Something interesting to note is that we had a GM watch us on our last attempt of the night so that he could see if it was a bug. Granted we ended up wiping, but during the wipe Archimonde fingered a random caster in the raid even though the tank and all melee dps were still on him. The GM's first response was, whoa that's not supposed to happen.

#707SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Cardynal
Has anyone ever tried having the majority of people stand in melee range for this fight?

My guild had about 4 hours on him last night and we only really got him to 59%. Most of the deaths were from random screw-ups...such as someone not getting decursed, falling from the air burst, ranged dps getting hit by the fire...etc...etc.

From what we noticed, the doomfire hardly ever went into the melee group as long as the ranged people around them only ran backwards. We even started sticking a few MT healers in with the melee, and it worked pretty well. It also seemed that the ranged people behind the melee (we were using the 4 groups method) would get the majority of the doomfires on their side.

I was thinking of everyone stack in 2 groups in melee range except for the mages that would stand at their max range. The mages could decurse themselves and run away from the fire when it came to them.

This strat would cause airburst to be a much bigger issue, but i'm wondering if it could be used to mitigate the doomfire...which seems to be our biggest problem when we actually have a good attempt.

Any thoughts?
#708SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Caligula
Originally Posted by Cardynal
Some stuff here

Any thoughts?
My thoughts are, it sounds like a terrible idea, but it might work for you

That's a "put all your eggs in 1 basket" strategy. One bad doomfire and you lose. Making everyone take an air burst every single time seems excessive and will probably result in your tank dying due to your healers flying away.

If people are dying to falling and not being decursed then it just sounds like everyone in your group isn't quite comfortable with the fight. It took us over 60 attempts to kill him once. After that we haven't taken more than 5 I think. Eventually it will all just click for everyone. It's not a DPS race, it's a survival fight. Don't die>You win. It's pretty much that simple. If that means your shadow priests with doomfire shift out of shadowform and heal themselves, so be it. If that means your OOM caster pops a health pot instead of a mana pot to stay alive, so be it. If that means one of your healers runs the entire way to the well and jumps in to avoid doomfire, so be it. That's really all there is to it.
#709SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Cardynal
Originally Posted by Caligula
That's a "put all your eggs in 1 basket" strategy. One bad doomfire and you lose. Making everyone take an air burst every single time seems excessive and will probably result in your tank dying due to your healers flying away.
Well it's more of a 2 baskest strategy =p

But that's assuming you can stand in melee range and be 13 yard away from both the MT and another melee group. We would split the healers between the 2 melee groups of course.
#710SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
That's a "put all your eggs in 1 basket" strategy.
Agreed, it might work for your guild - but it isnt a very good idea. If you go with the pic I posted a few posts up, each range group consists of: 2 healers + 1 decurser + 2 dps. Each group stands on top of each other so they all get airbusted together and forms a fully self-contained unit which can keep itself alive.

The points I stressed the hardest besides the obvious one (survival) to the raid on our learning attempts were:

- Always stand on, and follow if necessary, your group decurser

- If a doomfire spawns in front of your group, stop immediately and run. Dont stand there and hope it might go in another direction - run first - and look back later to see if its safe to return.

Raid leaders will notice alot of good healers and dps have a 'must get top healing/damage' mentality and it really needs to be put aside for this fight as people might take dangerous risks to achieve this.

Risks like 'Ill finish off that last bomb heal before I move from that doomfire heading my way' , or 'ill finish off that fireball when theres a fear in 5 seconds and that doomfire is only 15 yards away', or 'ill just stand here by myself, away from my decurser , so I can dps/heal more'. Those risks are what kill people and will wipe raids.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/16/07 at 12:20 PM.
#711SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Cardynal
We're using your strat almost exactly tyrian. The ranged dps is split to the north and south sides, the melee fights on the west side, and the tank is on the east side. We have healers on all 4 sides as well.

I think another one of our biggest problems is that when 1 person went down, I think everyone felt like it was a wipe and I'm not sure they tried to recover. I know some of them are pretty nasty to recover from, but completly doable as long as 2 people don't die back to back. How many people go down on a normal kill? I saw some posts saying up to 7...1 even said 19 on one kill.
#712SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
It is also a good idea to use a single resto druid standing on the melee , in the centre of the star formation. I did that and was happy with the result. This druid is primarily responsible for decursing MT/melee (because mages often have to run off and are too far from melee to save them) and hotting up everything hes in range of - raid and MT - since hes at the centre of the star. He will also get airbusted with melee every time and can heal them up through that damage.

Because your resto druid is probably not in the melee group (and might not have access to the shaman tremor totem) , we gave ours a fear ward for the entire night. Doomfires surround the melee most of the fight and the FW/tremor totem is very helpful. To relate this back to my pic, we use 9 pure healers. Two are on each of the 4 points of the star and the 9th one is the druid in the middle.

I think another one of our biggest problems is that when 1 person went down, I think everyone felt like it was a wipe and I'm not sure they tried to recover.
If you use vent, the moment someone dies the most important thing is: everyone needs to STFU and relax.

The raid leader can then calmy tell everyone 'A soul charge is incoming, top everyone up, DPS prepare to healthstone/bandage/pot'. Although each soul charge has a high chance of killing someone new (and thus causing a wipe chain), raid members still have a responsibility to try minimise the after-effects, through healthstones and pots/bandages, to reduce the massive strain on the healers.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/16/07 at 12:48 PM.

Originally Posted by Aslin

Has anyone had any problems with Archimonde randomly finger of death'ing people for no apparent reason? We've had it happen a few times when our MT (warrior) was in, but more noticeably tonight the last two attempts in a row (beartank) he's finger of deathed at random times -- once at 70% and the next attempt at like 98%. A few weeks ago, we had a DPS Warrior lag out. When he logged back into the fight (hadn't died), Archimonde did a Finger of Death on a Paladin. Same situation, tank was in melee range, nothing special going on. We figured it was from the lag out and just forbid people from logging back in and haven't seen it since. It could just as easily be a coincidence.
#715SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3spiderella
Originally Posted by Tyrian
The trick is: when doomfire spawns that whole group runs in a straight line away from the boss as far as possible until the doomfire stops following you. Dont stop, dont try to sidestep it - the entire group keeps running in a straight line away as far as you can.
We had killed Archimonde once with a triangular configuration but had way too many deaths from doomfires. We moved to this configuration and what happened was more running _away_ because you could afford to have an entire group or two out of range if healers were spread out equally. Also, and I think this was really key, is it makes it possible for groups to police themselves as opposed to letting people get by doing stupid things and get by with it because no one was really watching them. As a raid leader it was possible to just ask people in group if someone was eating a dubious number of doomfires, if they were playing poorly, and then ask people to reinforce good decision making on Archimonde. The doomfires/attempts ratio per person in raid went down a stunning amount.

So it was like 1-50 kill/wipe with me trying to call out when someone was doing something dumb in a triangular configuration to now we're at 2-12.

I really didn't like learning Archimonde as I felt like it forced leadership into a more disciplinarian kind of role that, even though I know it's what's required on this fight and I wasn't calling people out on trivial things, still made me feel like an ass. So I'm much more a fan of a group-based approach to solving that problem.

#719SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Virtue

#720SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
but I really don't like the luck aspect. I know they nerfed it a bit but it is still annoying for someone out of range of decurse to get gripped.
Sorry - but this is wrong. There is no 'luck' involved if somebody is out of range of a decurse - its your strategy at fault. Its a weakness of the 'everyone just spread out around archimonde' strategy.

The only way ive seen people die to Grip in our proper attempts is when they break our number 1 rule. That rule is: stay with your decurser!. Our decursers are the 'leaders' of each group. They have a symbol and control the movement and direction you will run from doomfires - and you must always follow them - so if theres an airbust, you will get airbusted with them - so range should never be an issue.

promoting your decursers so they can put/refresh their raid icons
Deadlybossmods by default puts a Skull symbol on people who get airbust - and unfortunately this overwrites any current symbols the raid has placed on that person. However there is an option to turn it off . Turn that option off and set symbols on mages/druids and they shouldnt get over-written again.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/18/07 at 12:29 PM.
#721SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Grelif
Originally Posted by Tyrian
The only way ive seen people die to Grip in our attempts is when they break our number 1 rule. That rule is: stay with your decurser!. Our decursers are the 'leaders' of each group. They control the movement and direction you will run from doomfires - and you must always follow them - and if theres an airbust, you will get airbusted with them. There should never be any decurse-range issues, ever.
While I agree staying with your decurser should be a priority for the ranged, I don't believe that you should have groups getting airbursted together. That's a lot of unnecessary damage and a little bit of proper preparation in having plenty of HP for the fight as well as a few fire protection and purification potions can mitigate unfortunate combos or poor circumstances.
#722SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
While I agree staying with your decurser should be a priority for the ranged, I don't believe that you should have groups getting airbursted together. That's a lot of unnecessary damage and a little bit of proper preparation in having plenty of HP for the fight as well as a few fire protection and purification potions can mitigate unfortunate combos or poor circumstances.
I disagree. Way I see it is this:

Staying with group and getting airbusted together pros
- Always in range of group decurser
- Always in range of group healer
- Players focus on their group only (5 people)

cons
- A couple more people take 3k damage oin the airbust

Spreading entire raid out pros
- less people take air bust damage

cons
- Potential for people to get airbusted out of range of healers
- Potential for people to get airbusted out of range of decursers
- Players need to watch more of the raid (at the expense of focusing on your surival and that of your group only), since alot of decursing/healing might be required out-of-group.

---

Its personal preference as both strategy's can work just fine - however I think several small groups is superior. I would gladly have a few extra people take a negligable 3k airbust damage than risk having players get separated from healers/decursers.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/18/07 at 12:48 PM.
#723SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Machia
We've killed him 3 times now and have always used the triangular approach. With this method we've found that the greatest success comes from having each group back up if any fire comes near them and clear the area until the flames are gone. Usually what would end up happening is if the fire converged on either of the sides (sometimes both) the 2 groups on either side would merge into the middle group and everyone would be stacked. Then if a fire got in the middle multiple people would be hit, as well as having a ton of people getting air burst at once. So having that group back up and just relax for a moment definately helps cut down on crowding. We still end up getting Archimonde to 10% with 4 minutes left on the enrage timer. We run with 4-5 shamans, 4-5 decursers as well as 7-8 healers depending on the day. Yesterday we had 3 dwarf priests in the group and had the entire raid fear warded for the first fear.. was pretty hax.

I agree with one of the posters that you definately have to do a lot of yelling during this raid. Mainly to point out mistakes and make sure that other people don't repeat the same ones. Even though I really hate this fight on a personal level, I like that it really causes everyone to focus and bring their A game. No matter what we do after Archimonde that day it always seems so much easier. That fight is a great way to train people to communicate, improve situational awareness and focuses on individual performance.
#724SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Zurick
Curious Question
My guild has just recently began doing Archimonde, and with around 17 Attempts, our best was 73%, our Primary issue seems to be Doomfire with us. I've been reading that most guilds set up groups, and upon Doomfire targeting, tend to run in a straight line away from Archimonde so it does not loop back to melee.

My main question is actually a group positioning question. I've read on the Triangular, Half Circle, and Four Corners techniques... To me, I am interested in using the Four Corners as my guild tends to do quite well in small groups with their own tasks, but before I commit to a decision, as if I try this, I would like to just stick with it for a bit; I was attempting to find what you find to be the key differences, as well as pros and cons of these three seemingly popular techniques.
#725SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kink
Originally Posted by Zurick
My guild has just recently began doing Archimonde, and with around 17 Attempts, our best was 73%, our Primary issue seems to be Doomfire with us. I've been reading that most guilds set up groups, and upon Doomfire targeting, tend to run in a straight line away from Archimonde so it does not loop back to melee.

My main question is actually a group positioning question. I've read on the Triangular, Half Circle, and Four Corners techniques... To me, I am interested in using the Four Corners as my guild tends to do quite well in small groups with their own tasks, but before I commit to a decision, as if I try this, I would like to just stick with it for a bit; I was attempting to find what you find to be the key differences, as well as pros and cons of these three seemingly popular techniques.
We use the 4 corners + melee group technique and have had maybe 20 attempts (NOT including things like 100% wipes on the pull etc =), we only had 5-6hrs on him so far. Our best was 13%, 2 other pulls were sub 25% and 2 more were sub 35%.

However we learned that progress on this fight is NOT measured by each pull getting him lower and lower in hp. Simply due to the randomness that you can counteract to only SOME degree, your 20% wipe could easily be followed by a 65% wipe then to get a 15% wipe and then a 70% wipe.

Wipes were almost always caused by doomfire spawning and immediately arcing into the melee group, causing too much stress for healers. Our best attempts have been when people have remained completely calm, even if a soulcharge goes off. Our 13% wipe included 2 soul charges.

If you are struggling with 3 groups, split it into 4 + melee and see how it goes, we raid mark all our decursers and put 1 in each group, then everyone in that group knows they must always try to be next to their groups raid mark. Also, I as a feral druid Decurse as much as I am able to. I recently got Decursive, which I found to be great for this, just left click on a box that shows a cursed player in range and they are decursed. Very simple to use.

This fight is 100% about survival, if people can do something to help, they should help. Decursing a person 1 second faster than a mage means that person might take a bit less damage and that can make a huge difference in the long run. As a feral I shift, decurse, and instant regrowth, it means I chug mana pots, but survival is key here, people need to do what they can.

Also, do not forget the fight doesn't really change until he is dead (or 10% from what I have read, but thats as good as dead =). There is next to no difference between the fight at 70% than the fight at 20%. People just need to get used to what to do and to survive as best they can, as long as they can.
#726SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Cardynal
Does anyone have a blank map of the area around archimonde? I can't seem to find one.
#727SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
I was attempting to find what you find to be the key differences, as well as pros and cons of these three seemingly popular techniques
Ultimately its personal preference - and dependant on what your guilds players are better suited for.

As another posted already said: a key benefit of 4-corner setup is you can introduce a very strict 'keep your group alive' mentality - and hold people acccountable to that. Group healers and decursers know that if someone in their group is cursed/damaged, they must handle it - or answer to the raid leader what went wrong if they die.

If you ask players to just focus on small group survival (as opposed to 'spread out around archimonde and watch the whole raid), people will end up noticing alot more of whats going on that concerns that group. Yes, its ironic that if you ask people to focus on less - they may actually notice more.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/22/07 at 1:59 PM.
#728SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kasi
One thing I wondered about the 4 corners thing is obviously all 8 healers are responsible for the MT. But my question is how many of the groups need to be in range of the MT and melee to specifically keep the MT up? Would one group and 2 healers be enough for a few seconds if doomfire forces the other 3 away? Or would 2 be needed? I think for many (especially healers) its instinctual to look after the safety of the MT instead of your own. Which means when fires come their way they are not too quick to get out of dodge and just run the hell away, which leads to people dying prematurely. I know Archi doesn't hit as hard as Azgalor, but I think 2 healers should be enough to keep him up for a few seconds.

Has anyone found out that having a group leader for each ranged group maybe with a macro hotkeyed saying something like "group 1 is retreating from doomfire and are OOR" would be useful for the raid as a whole, so other groups can step up to fill the responsibility?
#729SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kir
It's also very important that your 'group leader' (we symbol one person in each of the non-melee groups for everyone to follow) be very aware of each doomfire, where it's heading, how long it's been up, incoming fears etc.. Ideally, this person is also the group decurser, but it's better to have a player that can handle these tasks.

For example, using the 'run straight out' approach is fine in theory, but there are a few exceptions in terms of running back IN that you just can't teach. The doomfire is a random element that is vastly different from one attempt to another. The group leader needs to be able to go 'ok, that first one we ran away from looped away a little bit, but it could come back.. think we'll stay run back slightly a little longer... oh shit another doomfire on our side, run out.. run back near the 1st one since it's about to despawn' etc..

Running 'straight out' and running 'straight back' is a good base, but there's some exceptions to this. If people are TOO scared of the fire, and run TOO far back (once you are like 100yds out, you can start looping the fire around, since it won't make it back towards melee at that point anyways, just be careful not to cut yourselves off) then you can occasionally run into having too many decursers/healers out of range and some melee or the MT bites it.
#730SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Has anyone found out that having a group leader for each ranged group maybe with a macro hotkeyed saying something like "group 1 is retreating from doomfire and are OOR" would be useful for the raid as a whole, so other groups can step up to fill the responsibility?
If you attempted this your raid screen would be spammed with messages - people dont have time to read the amount of 'im coming' or 'we are moving' messages this would create - it would only serve as an un-necessary distraction in an otherwise busy fight. As long as healers realise that one second 8 healers might be on mt and a few seconds later only 3 (the rest suddenly might have to run from doomfire/airbust) it should be enough.


Agree with the above poster, the group leader of each group should be watching the doomfires intensely, as much of their groups survival depending on them. They should know which doomfires will despawn first and when its safe to move to any given position.

From memory a doomfire max travel distance, assuming it moves in a straight line, is roughly from where Archimonde stands to the well of eternity and maybe 1/3 the way back again. Id guess thats about 100-130 yards? So if you manage to pull the doomfire ~X yards away from Archimonde on the run-out, you can guess how far it will follow you on the run in, given that you know roughly what its max travel distance is.

So yea you could run ~70 yards out, turn around, and know it'll despawn by the time you return to your original position - but wouldnt suggest trying this while you learn the fight. Stick to the 'run out as far as possible' motto while you learn it.

I think 2 healers should be enough to keep him up for a few seconds.
After racking my brain, I struggle to think of any times where our MT died because of 'lack of healing' with the 4pt method over several dozen attempts. Tank deaths were almost always the result of parrys or soul charges from other people. It shouldnt really be a problem.

Now to get slightly off on a tangent.... The problem arises when lots of people get doomfire and too many heals have to be diverted off the MT to keeping the raid alive through the doomfire, which means....

MT healing is a group effort from the entire raid, even the nonhealers - because - the more proactive people are in avoiding doomfires, the more the healing can be focused solely on the MT - and the lower your chance of him dying will be. I repeated this on vent several times on our first learning night: "Every heal for someone with doomfire, is a heal thats not on the main tank." Thats really what it comes down to . I had some raid members comment how 'doomfire doesnt tick for much' as a justifcation for why its 'no big deal' if you get doomfire. Thats the wrong attitude - its not you that we're worried about, its the loss of healing from the MT thats of concern.

So I guess my point is, you cant really just talk about healers when it comes to 'Main tank healing on archimonde' . Thats only half the story: the other half is minimising healing lost off the MT to doomfires - and thats a raidwide responsibility. Both need to be considered and dps made aware they have a large part to play in the MTs survival too.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/22/07 at 7:44 PM.
#731SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Beren
We had something "interesting" happen on our Archi kill today:

We got him to 10%(he did the emote) but everyone died before the NPC could come do her thing, so we release and head back. Interestingly, he didnt despawn as normal, but was there waiting for us when we got back.

When buff up, and engage again, and right when we start the whisps show up, we get the NPC's buff, and 1 minute later he keels over dead at 90% health.

We petioned it, just to be safe, but meh, felt kinda cheap.
#732SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Giske
We finally downed him yesterday with the 4 group tactic, having tried every single tactic there is, I can heartily recommend this one. It made the fight much easier.

And that bug thing sounds like the 10% event doesnt stop properly if there are no players to cast the buff on, I wouldnt consider it cheap since all you do at 10% is finish him off while being invulnerable. Making it to 10% is the whole fight.
#733SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kink

And that bug thing sounds like the 10% event doesnt stop properly if there are no players to cast the buff on, I wouldnt consider it cheap since all you do at 10% is finish him off while being invulnerable. Making it to 10% is the whole fight.
Well, I would say that making it to 10% with enough DPS alive to be able to DPS him down in 1minute is the whole fight.

However it is not like they possibly could have done that on purpose, so yes, you cheaped that kill, but to get that far you will clearly be killing him the next reset legitimately, so I wouldn't lose any sleep over it at all =).

Myself, we still have trouble with Doomfire (and Azgalor =). The main problem is that it spawns, and immediately curves into melee giving them little to no time to react to it, invariably when this happens every non rogue gets the debuff which stresses healers greatly, and though we have recovered from this and wiped due to other reasons, it has definately been the single cause of most of our wipes.
#734SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Giske
If your doomfires keep curving it means your ranged dps and healers are sidestepping it instead of running away from it. Sidestepping doomfires makes it do loops.

And I believe that someone posted whisps blowing up Archimonde for them at 8% when they had like 5 people alive when they got the invulnerability buff? Sounds like you win when you hit 10% either way to me.
#735SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Giske
