#736SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
The main problem is that it spawns, and immediately curves into melee giving them little to no time to react to it
I have never seen this happen. Could you elaborate on your positioning for the raid? Where do range/healers stand? How many groups and where? Are you using semi-circle, 'spread out anywhere', triangular or 4-corners positioning techniques?

I still have only ever seen doomfires spawn and move outwards towards the closest range/healing groups for a while before there is a chance it'll start to change direction. I dont recall seeing a doomfire spawn and immediately head backwards to melee , without first heading outwards for some period. They most certainly can (and will) loop back around , but not for a while. Because im a mage and also my group decurser - I spend most of the fight carefully watching the movement of the doomfires - I find it a little strange ive never noticed what you describe, heres what I usually see:

X = Ranged/Healer group
O = Doomfire spawn points

X1------------X2
------------------
---O1-----O2---
-----BOSS------
---O3-----O4---
-----------------
X3-----------x4

In my experience a doomfire will almost always head outwards towards the closest X number first. For example: Ive never seen a 'O3' spawn-point doomfire head towards X2 upon spawning, it would head towards X3 first. It could also head towards X4 if they are too far left, or X1 if they move too far south. However, with correct positioning like in the diagram, all the doomfires seem to reliably move towards their corresponding numbered X when they spawn.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/23/07 at 7:36 AM.
#737SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Subject
Originally Posted by Tyrian
Deadlybossmods by default puts a Skull symbol on people who get airbust - and unfortunately this overwrites any current symbols the raid has placed on that person. However there is an option to turn it off . Turn that option off and set symbols on mages/druids and they shouldnt get over-written again.
You can simply make a macro as the raid leader or person with (a) to mark everyone at once. So if someone gets gripped that is a decurser; simply hit the macro and the mark will be reapplied.

I used a similar macro when doing Kael'thas to mark the weapons I was tanking.

/tar Decurser1
/script SetRaidTarget("target",1)
/tar Decurser2
/script SetRaidTarget("target",2)
/tar Decurser3
/script SetRaidTarget("target",3)
/tar Decurser4
/script SetRaidTarget("target",4)
/tar Decurser5
/script SetRaidTarget("target",5)
#738SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3KamPa
What if second doomfire spawns on the side that is already clear, since people ran away? Wouldn't it head back to melee?
#739SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Some people were asking me about possible ways to handle decursing/healing setup for a 4-point method and heres quick pic I made to visually show it:



You could indeed cut out the 9th healer in the middle and run with 8, but I think this creates an unnecessary risk.

You cant rely on the range groups to decurse the middle always, as theres a chance they might all be far away: running from doomfires/getting airbusted. The central druid , with permenant hots for the MT, swiftmend for emergencies, ability to decurse all melee/mt in the absence of mages who need to run off, and ability to heal multiple melee with doomfire with OP hots - is a nice way to play it safe.

Because your healing druid is in melee range with doomfires nearby, id recommend giving him fear wards first (if possible). Some guilds might not have those, so putting him in the tremor totem melee group might be another option.

I just dont like the idea of having all melee/mt helplessly sit there with the only decursers/healers standing 30+ yards away who might have to run/airbusted 100+yards any moment and unable to help them. You could say 'range groups watch melee' but I think the best results with the 4 point strat are when you know who is responsible for certain people and you can hold them accountable or they die. Assuming your healers and decursers are on the ball, its almost always the dead player who did something stupid. (eg: ran too far from their decurser and got Gripped, stood too close to a doomfire with a fear incoming)

If a melee dies - your first question should be to the central druid - because the druid was right next to them and should have seen/noticed exactly what happened. Asking 4 mages what happened, who might be 100 yards away or busy decursing their own group - might yield an answer like 'I didnt see' or 'I dont know'- and thats not good enough. Somebody always needs to see/know exactly what happened.

Its the same with every other aspect of the fight. If somebody dies from a curse - ask that groups decurser what happened. If a range dps dies from doomfire, ask that groups healer why they died. If a healer dies from doomfire, ask that groups DPS whether the healer was standing too close to it. There should always be someone to ask, 'How did XXX die' when something goes wrong that can give you a solid answer.

/tar Decurser1
/script SetRaidTarget("target",1)
/tar Decurser2
/script SetRaidTarget("target",2)
/tar Decurser3
/script SetRaidTarget("target",3)
/tar Decurser4
/script SetRaidTarget("target",4)
/tar Decurser5
/script SetRaidTarget("target",5)
Ooh thankyou, ive been looking for this type of macro for a while! Not to sound dumb, but im guessing the number in 'target,1' refers to a particular raid icon? I didnt know raid icons had set numbers assigned to them by the default UI, I thought you had to type 'skull' or 'cross' etc.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/23/07 at 8:52 AM.
#740SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Giske
We used this tactic except we had no decurser in melee, we just told one of our druids to try to stay within 30 yards (her only job was healing the MT) to decurse. Also everyone without the means to decurse themselves had purification potions and if that didnt work one of the mages would run close enough to decurse melee (frost mage so could IB if hit by doomfire).
#741SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kink
After watching our videos, I noticed that the cause of the doomfire in the melee is not positioning of the groups, but positioning of the boss. We tank him near the broken tree stumps. These do in fact block the doomfire so it just stays in one spot and burns (possibly creating a safe spot if LoS with the tank can be maintained, but blocking the doomfires?). After a while of burning, it just turns into the melee and catches them offguard.

I will suggest we pull him into a more central location so this tree stump problem doesn't occur. Still, at least we learned doomfire cannot go through it!
#742SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
These do in fact block the doomfire so it just stays in one spot and burns (possibly creating a safe spot if LoS with the tank can be maintained, but blocking the doomfires?). After a while of burning, it just turns into the melee and catches them offguard.
Good find. The time where the doomfire is 'stuck' and stationary is very bad - and could be responsible for the problems you describe.

Blocking a doomfire off only 20 yards from its spawn point at the stump (if the boss is tanked close to it), might mean it'll turn around to melee with 80+ yards left of travel distance before it will despawn - and just go through the entire raid wreaking havoc.

Ideally, the doomfire needs to head 50-70 yards directly outwards from Archimonde, unrestricted by terrain - before your melee can consider it 'safe' (aka Whereby it would despawn by the time it reached them if it turned around)
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/23/07 at 9:10 AM.
#743SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Maskirovka
Originally Posted by Tyrian
I have never seen this happen. Could you elaborate on your positioning for the raid? Where do range/healers stand? How many groups and where? Are you using semi-circle, 'spread out anywhere', triangular or 4-corners positioning techniques?

I still have only ever seen doomfires spawn and move outwards towards the closest range/healing groups for a while before there is a chance it'll start to change direction. I dont recall seeing a doomfire spawn and immediately head backwards to melee , without first heading outwards for some period. They most certainly can (and will) loop back around , but not for a while. Because im a mage and also my group decurser - I spend most of the fight carefully watching the movement of the doomfires - I find it a little strange ive never noticed what you describe, heres what I usually see:

X = Ranged/Healer group
O = Doomfire spawn points

X1------------X2
------------------
---O1-----O2---
-----BOSS------
---O3-----O4---
-----------------
X3-----------x4

In my experience a doomfire will almost always head outwards towards the closest X number first. For example: Ive never seen a 'O3' spawn-point doomfire head towards X2 upon spawning, it would head towards X3 first. It could also head towards X4 if they are too far left, or X1 if they move too far south. However, with correct positioning like in the diagram, all the doomfires seem to reliably move towards their corresponding numbered X when they spawn.
We had problems with this boss after 2 kills, and we switched to a similar positioning. The fires always move towards a group upon spawning, and that group runs away from the fire. I have no idea what the range is, but the fires never curve towards another group once you get them a certain distance from other people. The other benefit of this strat is that groups get air bursted together and can decurse and heal after landing with no problems.

In 5 attempts using this "have your group run straight away from the boss when fires spawn" strat, we only had someone die to doomfire twice, and one was just a stupid mistake and the other was a disconnect. Our other two wipes were due to the MT dying while more than one group was avoiding fires. We simply adjusted healing and got a kill.

Our raid leader looked at fraps, and the only times we had fires streaking through the middle was when someone ran in a stupid place while the fire was following them. The fires follow a player 100% of the time, so it's easily possible to control the fires.
#744SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3valeea
What saved my raid many hairs was the order of our raidleader to consequently try to "pull" the fires away from archimonde. Never go at any risk if a fire is heading towards you or seems to. we killed him with 3 shamans for the first time. Due to the "fire pulling" strategy we had some critical moments when decursers were dragging away their fires, but in the end it proved to be the best idea we had. whatever your job is (despite the tank), run in a straight line away from him if your in danger by fires. we needed about 40 trys until he went down the first time.
#745SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Subject

Yea the 1-5 = the icon. I believe 8 is the skull (which is used by DBM or BW) and I believe 0 removes the icon. Just replace "Decurser1" with the name of the player. Pretty sure you can only fit about 5 names in the space of the macro due to the character limit of 255.

#749SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Saabik
We use a 5-point strategy. Generally we run this fight with 4 shaman, and the 5th group (my group "stump hump") positions themselves near the stump. With the proper mentality of "group survival first", a little jumping experience, and some awareness this group becomes self sufficient and doesn't require a tremor. We still do moderate amount of healing/decursing for the rest of the raid, but always focus on the group first (the other groups can handle themselves just fine).

While I don't think we are the most effective group (in terms of killing the boss), this is one of the most entertaining groups to be in on any encounter. I'm ret for all of our raids, and genuinely enjoy swapping to heal gear for this fight.

If you're getting a little bored, I highly recommend this

STUMP HUMP!


Edit: For those confused, the stump offers some advantages during fear. However, it's also a huge risk if people don't understand the mechanics. The whole group can die in a few seconds if you don't know what you're doing. If you are short a shaman, I recommend this. Feel free to PM me if you are interested in learning more about stump hump.
#750SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
This is a very exciting picture of the stumps in the middle of the archimonde field:



Im guessing 'stump hump' refers to wedging yourself somewhere in the stump/branch on the right such that over half/threequarters direction of your movement is blocked if your feared? Thus you indirectly have some degree of control over which direction you will get feared.

I can definetely see the advantages of doing this, but like you said, it requires some degree of skill from the players of knowing when its safe to trap yourself like that. It could result in alot of very funny, stupid deaths too - lol.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/24/07 at 4:38 PM.
#751SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Saabik
Originally Posted by Tyrian
Im guessing 'stump hump' refers to wedging yourself somewhere in the stumpp/branch on the right such that over half/threequarters of your movement is blocked if your feared? Thus you indirectly have some degree of control over which direction you will/wont get feared?
You have the basic idea. The right stump (in you picture) will prevent you from moving off of the stump (there is no "path" off of it). Following simple fear mechanics, fear will never run you off a cliff or down/up a "path" that cannot be normally climbed up.

It's safe to stand on the stump when a fear is about to hit. For the most part we all stay on it during the entire fight. We get air burst together, we run back together, etc. The *very* dangerous part is when a doomfire comes very close and "touches" part of the stump. If a fear hits at this point anyone on the stump gets rapidly tosses in and out of the doomfire, instantly reapplying the 2400 fire damage. An entire group can die in a matter of seconds.

So, you just need to make sure the group is ready to abandon stump should a doomfire come in contact with the stump. Again, the graphic won't show, so you just have to watch the path of the fire. I'll try to make a fraps next week.

Our ventrilo is often spammed with messages like:

"Abandon stump!"
"Stump hump, reassemble!"
"Humpers, regroup!"

It makes it all the more exciting.


One conversation we avoid (if we all get caught on the stump during a doomfire...), Archimonde Soulcharge +5!!!

"What happened to G1?"
"We don't want to talk about it."


Certain objects are ignored during fear

"Humpers, regroup!"

#761SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kasi
Couple questions I have here about this fight.

We use the 4 corners method, but have had issues sustaining the fight past 3 minutes in our 2 nights of attempts. Seems dps is okay, since we get him to about 70% in that 3 minutes, but still usually someone dies and then it spirals out of control.

1) When dealing with doomfire, if a doomfire goes toward a group is it necessary for the whole group to run away? Or just part of it? This along with my next question is the tricky part of the encounter. I know when doomfire goes toward you that you're supposed to run. But then sometimes you go one way and it goes slightly another and the thing is is it safe to move back in yet? Issue with whole groups running away cause of doomfire has been our tank being killed due to things like 2 groups running away, 1 being air burst and the 4th couldn't do it alone.

2) When is it safe to move back in after doomfire? First night I did this I ran the hell away and stayed out til I knew it was safe to move back in. Obviously this killed my dps. Second night I mostly did that, but then I tried moving back in once on a doomfire I thought had latched on to someone else and passed me and I got hit from behind when it switched to me and looped back in upon me. This really ties into question 1 because I'm not sure if doomfire kiting should be done with individuals or with whole groups sticking together.
#762SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3aquasheep
Originally Posted by epiphenom
The fear cannot be resisted.
The fear can be resisted; I've resisted it with just normal gear and Cloak of Shadows all but guarantees a resist.

Whether stacking SR will do anything however, I don't know and honestly wouldn't bother.
#763SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Zaran

Whether stacking SR will do anything however, I don't know and honestly wouldn't bother.

#764SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ goss
I have found, however, talented fear resists (especially for healers) are a big help. Since speccing into Unyielding Faith, its rare that I don't go an Archimonde without resisting at least one fear, which of course gives my trinket time to come off cooldown should I have used it.
#765SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Beren
Originally Posted by aquasheep
The fear can be resisted; I've resisted it with just normal gear and Cloak of Shadows all but guarantees a resist.

Whether stacking SR will do anything however, I don't know and honestly wouldn't bother.

You can not "resist" the fear, you can be immune to it, but no resists.

You CAN, however, resist the yellow and green soul charges (fire/nature), as well as dodge/parry the purple one (physical).
-B
#766SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ goss
Originally Posted by Beren
You can not "resist" the fear, you can be immune to it, but no resists.
Yes, you can.

Wow Web Stats
#767SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3nataku
I think priests and paladins have talents that increases their chance to resist fears.

The question is whether or not shadow resist also allows you to resist Archimonde's fear. From testing by a couple of our healers, the consensus was shadow resistance did not help them resist more fears.
#768SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Tyrian
I was under the impression that gear has 0 effect on ability to resist Archimondes fears. Only talent based abilities (like those aforementioned) can. However thats hear say and I have no solid proof unfortunately.
#769SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3epiphenom
Well, to be more accurate about it, the fear can miss you (displaying a resist message like spell-misses by players on mobs) with the normal chance (modified by talents). But you can't resist it through SR.
#770SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
This along with my next question is the tricky part of the encounter. I know when doomfire goes toward you that you're supposed to run. But then sometimes you go one way and it goes slightly another and the thing is is it safe to move back in yet? Issue with whole groups running away cause of doomfire has been our tank being killed due to things like 2 groups running away, 1 being air burst and the 4th couldn't do it alone. When is it safe to move back in after doomfire?[/
This is part of the fight where you simply have to experience it and learn yourself. However there are essentially two types of doomfires in the strat. If you look at a doomfire you should be able to tell what type it is and whether its safe to return to your location immediately, whether you should wait a few seconds just in case - or whether you should wait until the doomfire despawns completely. Heres two examples:

Good Doomfires



A doomfire that spawns at archimonde and heads a long way (eg 80 yards) directly outwards. This is a safe doomfire . Even it decides to turn around it should be despawning by the time it reaches any other groups or your melee. Therefore if the doomfire stops following you at 80 yards away you can simply run back in to the boss and happily DPS - because you know that even if it changed direction to come for you - it will be despawning by the time it reaches you.

Bad Doomfires



A doomfire that spawns next to Archimonde and begins to turn around/arc after a short distance (eg 30 yards) is extremely dangerous and you need to watch its movement very closely - as theres over 100+ yards left of travel distance on it before it despawns.

In the above pic the arrow shows where this doomfire suddenly becomes dangerous. You dont know which direction it will go and its got alot of travel time left before it despawns. Even if it appears to go in another direction , its probably safer to just stay away until it despawns. Even if you stood 50 yards from it - it could easily reach you before it despawns.

This is a good example of a doomfire where you need to say on vent immediately 'Melee watch out , possible doomfire coming from behind'.

1) When dealing with doomfire, if a doomfire goes toward a group is it necessary for the whole group to run away? Or just part of it?
The whole group moves away immediately, irrespective of which actual person in the group its actually following. This is the key part of the 4-point group strat. If one person has to move - the whole group moves.

but then I tried moving back in once on a doomfire I thought had latched on to someone else and passed me and I got hit from behind when it switched to me and looped back in upon me.
Ill try to explain clearly why you made a terrible decision here.

1 - If you had stayed with your group and moved with them, that doomfire would still be heading directly outwards.

2 - If it was still heading outwards, it would be keep moving further from the rest of the raid (20 people) and become a safe doomfire like in an above picture. However because you chose to DPS you turned that doomfire around and suddenly it comes dangerously close to the raid again.

3 - Because the doomfire is now close to the raid/other groups (after turning around to follow you), you might force other groups/melee to have to move as it continues on its new path. Suddenly this one doomfire that originally just required 5 people in a group to move, might travel through the raid and cause 10-15 people total to have to move to avoid it. You effectively have turned what was originally 5 peoples problem into potentially 10-15 peoples problem, all in the name of 'a little extra dps' which wasnt even important to begin with.

All this happened because the player broke the number 1 rule. 'Stay with your group and always move together'. The extra dps or healing - is not worth it.

If all 5 people run directly outwards together - it can target any or all of them and it'll still be going in one direction = outwards. If one person sidesteps it, you can create the nightmare problems like you mentioned which vastly complicate the effort required to avoid them , not just for yourself , but the rest of the raid as well.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/30/07 at 8:29 PM.
#771SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Jelloshots
It's a small thing, but if you plan on doing the groups method, I think you benefit greatly from having a group leader, preferably a decurser, healer, or both, and putting a raid mark on them so it's absolutely clear where the group should be at all times.

You have the whole group basically stand on top of the leader for the group and thus stay very tightly packed? Sometimes I've noticed we have a tendency to kind of spread out as a group. Everyone takes a different path running away and then after the doomfire passes we kind of meander back to our original spot.

I am just wondering what the melee needs to do to avoid doomfires. I know a lot of it is ranged running back to keep them safe, but in the reading I've done I've not been able to really find out if a doomfire can spawn and then go straight into the melee.
#774SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Zindel

You should have tremors anyways because melee will have a shaman for windfury. Tremor and a 2 minute PvP trinket is all you need to control fears.
#775SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Tojara
From my experience doomfire can spawn very close to melee, but not exactly on top of us. It can and will loop around eventually, heading straight towards the melee camp before stopping.

The above leads me a few conclusions, some which may or may not be true

-Doomfire doesn't actually target anybody in the raid and just randomly moves until it stops
-Doomfire randomly targets someone other then melee and moves accordingly
-Doomfire locks onto a target every few seconds which causes its sometimes weird movement
-Doomfire performs like the above option, but can't target the melee until x amount of seconds have passed, preventing it from just staying on top of the melee camp the entire time

Now I really don't know how doomfire acts nor will I give any suggestions on how to deal with it. The basics behind dealing with it are always true regardless of how it truly acts. Stay away from it and give yourself a lot of room when fear is cooled down. Just when you think you've figured doomfire out it does something you don't think it would do. I am more inclined to believe that it constantly targets players outside of Archimondes hit box intially and after so many seconds can loop around targetting melee.
#776SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Sometimes I've noticed we have a tendency to kind of spread out as a group. Everyone takes a different path running away and then after the doomfire passes we kind of meander back to our original spot.
Like the above poster said, you'll find best results when you put a symbol on each group leader and make it mandatory for their group to follow them. If people dont stand on them within 15 yards at all times , give them two choices: either 1) Stand on them or 2) Get out of the raid. Being a mage/decurser and officer, I can just yell on vent at people to stand on me and demand answers why if people are out of range, but if your decurser is shy or not used to talking on vent and saying something like 'Why the hell are you over there - stand on me NOW' - make sure group members dont take that as an excuse to get slack.

-Doomfire randomly targets someone other then melee and moves accordingly
-Doomfire locks onto a target every few seconds which causes its sometimes weird movement
-Doomfire performs like the above option, but can't target the melee until x amount of seconds have passed, preventing it from just staying on top of the melee camp the entire time
I think these three conclusions sound accurate. I have seen doomfire spawn and immediately head over melee once towards another range group - and that was only because the other range groups were just airbursted 100 yards away or running from doomfires. Only ever seen that happen once in about 60 attempts. My guess is it works like this:

A - It spawns and locates the closest player that is at least X distance from the boss and begins to head outwards, either directly towards them or in that general area. This minimum distance could be something like , say, 10-20 yards (so all the melee/main tank are excluded from initial targetting)

B - If the closest person at the minimum distance is on the opposite side of Archimonde, it might head directly over melee to reach them. This situation would occur in the picture below:

1----------------------------------2

----------------------------BOSS
---------------------------melee
----------------------------FIRE

3----------------------------------------------------------5

In this pic, we could see that groups 1/3/5 are all far away (been airbusted or run off). The freshly spawned doomfire targets the closest person at least X yards from archimonde - usually this would be groups 3 or 5, but it happens to be group 2. Upon heading towards group 2, the fire would have to travel directly over the melee, and possible disaster follows.

This doesnt explain doomfire behaviour fully. Sometimes it just spawns and heads off in a direct line apparently chasing nobody until it despawns - cant explain that yet. But it gives a reasonable idea on why doomfires always seem to spawn and head outwards at first, except in rare cases where all the min-range targets happen to be on the opposite side of the boss.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/30/07 at 8:17 PM.
#777SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Northerner
The best analogy for a doomfire is still a heat-seeking missile with a short frontal cone of tracking. I have many, many times run a doomfire straight away from the middle all the way out until I get bored with it and hook back to where Archi is standing. It requires me to play chicken a lot (often staying at that "burning but not doomed yet" position) but I have never, ever lost one once it had lock on me in such a situation provided there was no one else in the frontal arc. You can even re-acquire a doomfire that you lost by getting in front of it again and turning it outwards but that's a dangerous game.

The problem lies in the frontal cone targeting as best I can tell. If there is me in front and close, I'll probably get kite control. If there is myself and a few others and even if they are many yards away, it seems like it will occasionally move off towards them regardless of what I do. That seems to be why moving the whole group has such a high success rate or at least that's it in my opinion.

That all said, we just raid-mark decursers and flow with it. It makes it much more difficult in some senses and we definitely have more doomfire issues than we might otherwise but it seems to work. Some people are good at kiting the dooms away, some not so much. We'll get some curl back and try to eat melee and that sucks. Hell, some people will eat dooms on occasion and we heal through it, even if grumbling about it.
#778SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3springwheat
The doomfires seem to spawn jut outside of max melee range. As long as I can hit Archimonde a newly spawned doomfire cannot hit me, even though I may appear engulfed in flames briefly I won't get the doomfire debuff.

Once they do spawn they always move away from him. If I'm not in melee range and one spawns between Archimonde and myself I'm a legitimate target and have to run out. The targetting from that point seems to be random selection of any target within a frontal cone. This is anecdotal, but Ive seen new doomfires sit stationary when there is no one in front of it. Im not sure if this is a bug or if the doomfires actually need a person to latch on to in a similar fashion to Buru or Thaladred.

In support of what Tyrian posted, the idiots that cannot grasp the concept of "turn 180Â° from the boss, run in a straight line" are the ones that screw over the raid. Trying to side step a doomfire when it turns toward you normally introduces new targets that it can latch on to. If it turns far enough, the MT and melee around Archimonde become valid targets and bad things can happen.
#779SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
This is anecdotal, but Ive seen new doomfires sit stationary when there is no one in front of it
Edit: I thought for sometime about your post and wanted to expand on what you said.

Sometimes doomfires seem to spawn and trail off by themself apparently following nobody. Usually it seems to happen when the below picture happens:

1--------------------2



--------BOSS fire===============>



3--------------------4

This freshly spawned fire doesnt have anyone in its frontal cone. Sometimes it will just head directly outwards. This somewhat contradicts earlier ideas that doomfires target the closest player at a minimum-range distance from the boss. It seems like sometimes doomfires arent even 'aware' of the raid unless they get an initial person in the frontal cone to lock onto.

Actually, Its almost like a doomfires have a combat system. This goes hand-in-hand with the Heatseaking Missile analogy. A doomfire automatically gets 'in combat' with everyone in its frontal cone and can decide to follow one or any of those people. If a doomfire cant get in combat because nobody is in its cone - it just trails off in what appears to be a 'random' direction, ignoring the raid unless somebody runs too close to it. This analogy could of course be wrong - but it would help explain many things:

- why melee/mt never get initial targeting by doomfires (not in frontal cone)
- why it usually follows an entire group successfully a long way out from the boss (its only in combat with that group in the frontal cone)
- why some doomfires just trail off 'randomly' and ignore the raid if nobody is in the frontal cone when it spawns (nobody got in combat with it)
- why some doomfires 'turn around' and head towards people that sidestepped it previously (they got in combat when they were in the frontal cone, even if they left the cone and it followed somebody else in the meantime)
- why the 4point strat is much more successful in doomfire control to the semicircle strat (one group gets in combat and move together to quarantine the doomfire, preventing other people getting in combat)

----

My analogy to describe Doomfire behaviour:

The doomfire is a Thaledred-type mob that only gets 'in combat' with everyone in its frontal cone and can follow any of them. Once in combat with that doomfire, you stay in combat until it despawns, regardless of whether you sidestep or leave the frontal cone.

Its therefore the responsibility of all the people who get in combat to make sure the cone is always 'aimed outwards' from the boss - so you can avoid getting other groups/melee/mt in combat or risk having it head towards them instead of you. In a 4-point strat, 5 people at a time (the 4 range groups) get in combat and run off together in an attempt to quarantine the doomfire and prevent spreading combat to other parts of the raid.

This also means that you should NEVER sidestep a doomfire that you got in combat with, even if it appears to be following someone else - because if your still in combat with it, it might turn around and come back for you and get other people in combat as well.

----

The more I think about it, the more that analogy very accurately describes the behaviour and movement of doomfires. Thinking about it this way, doomfires are like a plague and the 4-point group setup is a way to 'quarantine them by preventing minimal combat spreading'.
Last edited by Tyrian : 10/30/07 at 9:43 PM.

#782SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3

We've been using the 4-point strategy. We had a few hours working on him, and we had some kinks with where the groups were positioning themselves. But the doomfires were following people, and the fight seemed controllable. The doomfires were reacting as this thread described: like heat-seeking missiles.

After realizing that our positioning was off, I had high hopes that everything would fall into place on our next raid. Tonight we spent the whole night on him, and everyone was in their correct positions, sticking together as groups, and... ATTEMPTING to kite the doomfires away.

The doomfires simply did not follow people. They literally zig-zagged everywhere without any rhyme or reason. I watched a doomfire right on my tail veer off in a totally random direction, and there was NOBODY in that direction. It then wrapped right around to the melee. I saw that happen at least 3 or 4 times. When it *didn't* wrap around, it still did not follow us. It just kind of meandered on it's own path.

The only thing we did different was *fix* our positions (before, the groups were not properly at 90degree angles, but more clumped up). Also, this time our melee was in two groups to avoid having all of them airbursted at the same time.

Any ideas what was going on?

#783SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Raiste
We had similar experiences with doomfires on our 360 positionings. Sometimes doomfire would just take sharp turns and switch targets to people far away or just veer off into the open field and not even attempt to follow anyone. Although the heatseeking misslle discription seems to fit somewhat, I dont think it's the whole mechanic. There does seem to be a minor but significant random component to it. For us we decided that the 4 corners thing didn't work well for us as it thinned out healing/decursing coverage too much and we decided to go with 180 positioning and heal thru 1-2 people getting DF'd now and then. It worked much better for us and we got our first kill yesterday.

I think Archimonde more than any other fight is just something every guild needs to feel their way through. The mechanics are obvious after 3 attempts , but it takes 50 more worth of trial and error to see what does / doesn't work for your group.
#784SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3spiderella
Originally Posted by acote
ATTEMPTING to kite the doomfires away.
For what it's worth we don't ask people to kite doomfires away unless it's really, blatantly chasing them down like an episode of COPS. We did notice a change in this behavior of doomfires as they've changed over time - personally I think it's more deep breaths but some of our raiders swear they don't follow as predictably. Knowing when it's safe to strafe versus bailing away from Archimonde is equal parts knowing the fear cooldown and the black art of willing your raid to succeed.
#785SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
. It then wrapped right around to the melee. I saw that happen at least 3 or 4 times. When it *didn't* wrap around, it still did not follow us. It just kind of meandered on it's own path.
Realise that nothing you described here is inherantly 'bad' or raid-wiping on its own. Theres nothing wrong with a doomfire heading in the mele direction, if you see it happening and warn people in advance so they can prepare. In your case, you wouldve told the melee on vent to run off and they would all run away and wait until it despawns and is safe to return = no harm done.

ATTEMPTING to kite the doomfires away.
From reading your quote, it sounds like people need to realise doomfires can and will get messy at times - and this is normal - dont panic when they go in a bad direction - just warn the people its heading towards. Heres a good way to see it:

Ideal: Doomfire spawns and heads outwards in a perfect 150 yard straight line from archimonde and then despawns.

Reality: This isnt going to happen as much as youd like. The best you can try to do is try to 'pull it out' from archimonde for about 20-30 seconds , hopefully about 60-100 yards. At this point - even if it arcs or turns around youve done your job.

Dont have your raid go into archimonde attempts thinking you will turn all doomfires into perfect 150 yard straight lines and then panic when it doesnt happen. Therefore, prepare in advance ways to communicate fast and effectively when the doomfire hasnt moved in the direction you tried to take it. Having to scream on vent 'MELEE RUN, its turned around!' now and then, is a normal part of the fight.

In reference to your 'zig zag' comment - its normal for fires to create a whole mess on an entire side of archimonde, even if your groups are trying their best to pull them in a straight line away. However this quote is interesting..

, this time our melee was in two groups to avoid having all of them airbursted at the same time
How many melee do you have, enough to need to split into 2 groups O-O ?

In our setup there are only 7 people in melee range of archimonde and only 5 of them are actually melee dps. I never vary from this setup, I will not put more than 5 melee in an archimonde raid (the 5 melee always get a get a tremor totem to protect them) unless we can have some sort of fw protection for the 6th+ melee, which is rare. Its safer to put that FW on a healer instead of bringing a 6th+ melee dps. Lack of dps won't ordinarily wipe you... but lack of healing certainly can.

This is of course just what we do in our guild, others might operate very differently with regard to raid setup:

Only people in melee range of archimonde:
- 1 MT
- 1 Druid decurser (standing on the melee, but not in their group, usually has FW protection)
- 5 Melee dps (with a shaman always in their group , preferably dps enhancement shaman)

If you run with so many melee your trying to split them into two groups - you might be increasing the chance a doomfire comes towards the middle. After all, it does appear to have a random component on who it follows.

Therefore the less people in the middle the better (you want it to follow ranged/healers, not melee) Anyway that might not be the source of your problems.. but if you run with more than 5 melee (excluding mt/decurser) you might be creating a self-inflicted problem. The fight is about playing it safe - and you will make your raid alot safer if you limit the amount of melee you bring, in my opinion, as it will make doomfire control more manageable.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/05/07 at 11:45 AM.

#796SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Heres a WWS of a typical kill for us: Wow Web Stats

Ive noticed with our setup (one melee group) the 5 melee dps alone usually account for about 50-55% of total damage received to Archimonde. All ranged dps can be anywhere between 300-700 dps typically with DPSPresence time varying hugely (between 20-80%) = all obviously totally dependant on how many doomfires/airbursts their group had to deal with.

Im interested in what success various guilds have had in improving repeatability of Archimonde kills. Has anyone noticed a consistent improvement in the number of attempts its taken to get your guilds Archimonde kills weekly - as your guild members get more experience with the fight/strategy? Or do you find yourself often going backwards/stuck at a certain number of attempts/not improving or going round in circles.

For us (after 5 kills) the number of attempts to get a kill has been something like: 25 attempts, 21 attempts, 20 attempts, 9 attempts, 5 attempts. Some of the bad nights with higher attempts actually had better raid setup than lower attempt nights (more shamans) - but overall, looks like number of attempts is slowly dropping down as people familiarise themself with the fight more and more.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/07/07 at 9:19 PM.

#799SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Evy
Originally Posted by Vazu
Yeah. Our last kill we had our MT die at 15% health and two Rogues tanked (Evasion) him down to 10%. He enraged a few seconds after we went immune. It's been said before I know, but DPS is just not an important component of this fight at all. We've only killed him three times now, and we're improving, but it's perfectly normal for only our melee to be > 1k DPS right now. I think my best has been something like 750ish as Demonology with an Imp out.
Affliction tends to be better for Arch, at least from what I've noticed from our warlocks. It's probably just the fact that moving around doesn't drop the DPS of that spec too much, whereas it might with others.

But yea, overall melee tends to be very dominant on this fight unless there they get really unlucky with air bursts. Personally, as a rogue, I usually think of Arch as a DPS intensive encounter from my PoV, simply because safe fall and cloak of shadows nullify almost everything that are dangerous to the raid.

#801SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Evy
Originally Posted by Cybelirrae
Do you run with a shaman in the melee group, then? That is the only way I can see feeling pretty comfortable with all the fires that get fairly close to us as we dps him.
Yes. We get tremor instead of SoE from our enh shaman when the Fear cooldown is up. That plus a 2 minute trinket and CloS makes Doomfire almost always a nonissue, unless it's really stacking up near the hitbox.

We also have a resto druid primarily devoted to healing and decursing the melee, if that helps to answer your question.

#803SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Evy
I guess it really comes down to how many shamans you can afford to put in your raid. If you only have one or two, then they may be best suited for the MT healers and decursers. If you have any more, then the melee should definitely be able to take advantage of one, since they'll get, arguably, the best DPS boost.

#805SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Mearis
We killed it again yesterday, but dear god, this fight frustrates me like no other. It might be our incredibly paucity of shamans, but even with fear ward, that fight sucks complete ass.

What was even worst is that we had a ret paladin along who wasn't in the only melee tremor totem group and he died twice through no fault of his own because he'd get feared while in melee range and just end up dying to doomfires. We replaced him with a warlock and immediately killed him in two attempts.

Two questions then:
Does anyone know if there is a way to bring some melee DPS that are not backed with tremor totem without them being a liability? We have 1 enh shaman on most raids, and 1 resto shaman maybe 30% of the raids. Can a rogue reliably dps without tremor totem and getting killed?

We had a few ferals DPSing as well, but they could decurse and shift out + heal much more effectively than the ret paladin.

I heard rumours about waves of trash that spawn after Archimonde is dead. Where do they spawn? We tried killing a few of the NPC's from the undead base near the alliance base, but they didn't give faction or seem lootable.
#806SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Kalroth
Originally Posted by Mearis
Does anyone know if there is a way to bring some melee DPS that are not backed with tremor totem without them being a liability? We have 1 enh shaman on most raids, and 1 resto shaman maybe 30% of the raids. Can a rogue reliably dps without tremor totem and getting killed?
Undead rogues with the 2 minute PvP trinket can do reliable DPS. Those and dps warriors are the only ones that doesn't require a tremor totem.

As for the trash after Archimonde, I believe they removed those waves or at least removed trash drops from them.
#807SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Telani
Originally Posted by Kalroth
Undead rogues with the 2 minute PvP trinket can do reliable DPS. Those and dps warriors are the only ones that doesn't require a tremor totem.

As for the trash after Archimonde, I believe they removed those waves or at least removed trash drops from them.
Rogues period don't need tremor. We usually toss all the rogues and warriors in a group, having commanding+battle is pretty nice, and the combination of Cloak of Shadows, Vanish and PvP Trinket basically negates doomfire deaths.
#808SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Kalroth
Originally Posted by Telani
Rogues period don't need tremor. We usually toss all the rogues and warriors in a group, having commanding+battle is pretty nice, and the combination of Cloak of Shadows, Vanish and PvP Trinket basically negates doomfire deaths.
Almost yes, but not 100%. Melee will always be close to doomfires and "basically" is just not good enough. They need a 100% reliable way of breaking fear every 30-40 seconds.

Ranged got the option of moving really far away from doomfires, enough so they can run around feared for the full duration or at least until their fear can be dispelled. Melee doesn't have that option, they need to be able to handle the fear almost instantly. CloS doesn't help you one bit if you're feared into the doomfire eating multiple 2400 damage ticks, it's only good if you're also able to break the fear.
#809SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Akron

They don't anymore, as said in the "Hyjal trash" thread some pages behind. Which makes sense -- you just defeated the Burning Legion, why should more Undead waves spawn? The Undead base near Human base is only there for looks; in addition to having no loot/no rep they will also respawn very fast.
#810SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Mearis
Originally Posted by Akron

#811SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
Does anyone know if there is a way to bring some melee DPS that are not backed with tremor totem without them being a liability?
For a guild learning the fight, id say - Yes its possible to bring extra melee (that dont have tremor totem protection) , but do yourself a favour and dont.

If you absolutely must bring extra melee, I would tell them to run off in a 'safe direction' 10-15 seconds seconds before every fear is due, get feared - then return when its safe. Or they might want to try the stump-hump method.

But still, its much easier to just bring range classes instead - and limit melee to one group with tremor totem protection.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/09/07 at 9:42 AM.

#815SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Anonymity
My guild is currently working on Archimonde. We've put in about 10 hours or 3 full raids on him, coming out to around 80 total attempts. Our best attempt was 55%, and we've had him to the mid-60's about 3-4 other times. That's about where everything falls apart.

All 80 attempts, we have had four shaman. Yes, four. That's a tremor totem for almost every group! Everyone has either the 5 min or 2 min PvP trinket. We've all had ample practice on using the tears to reduce fall damage and on reacting to the doomfire and have gotten better at "kiting" it. We have one group of melee (4 rogues + enhancement shaman) and each of the remaining four groups stand on top of each other at each corner around Archimonde, forming a square. Each ranged group has 1-2 decursers and 2 healers.

I just can't pinpoint what our problem is. It seems to be something different every time. Early in last night's raid, the MT was dying because the healers weren't coordinating their fears (I guess). We fixed that and then people started dying to other random crap -- one time it would be because someone didn't get decursed in time, which normally isn't a problem. The next time someone would fail to use their tears properly. Then someone gets feared into fire. Nothing is consistent and it doesn't seem like there's a key issue that we can work on / talk about to fix our problems. It's different every single time. Usually these are just "getting to know the fight" concepts that people learn over time, but really, 12 hours? How much longer should it really take for people to start "getting" this fight?
#816SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Jelloshots
Originally Posted by Anonymity
My guild is currently working on Archimonde. We've put in about 10 hours or 3 full raids on him, coming out to around 80 total attempts. Our best attempt was 55%, and we've had him to the mid-60's about 3-4 other times. That's about where everything falls apart.

All 80 attempts, we have had four shaman. Yes, four. That's a tremor totem for almost every group! Everyone has either the 5 min or 2 min PvP trinket. We've all had ample practice on using the tears to reduce fall damage and on reacting to the doomfire and have gotten better at "kiting" it. We have one group of melee (4 rogues + enhancement shaman) and each of the remaining four groups stand on top of each other at each corner around Archimonde, forming a square. Each ranged group has 1-2 decursers and 2 healers.

I just can't pinpoint what our problem is. It seems to be something different every time. Early in last night's raid, the MT was dying because the healers weren't coordinating their fears (I guess). We fixed that and then people started dying to other random crap -- one time it would be because someone didn't get decursed in time, which normally isn't a problem. The next time someone would fail to use their tears properly. Then someone gets feared into fire. Nothing is consistent and it doesn't seem like there's a key issue that we can work on / talk about to fix our problems. It's different every single time. Usually these are just "getting to know the fight" concepts that people learn over time, but really, 12 hours? How much longer should it really take for people to start "getting" this fight?


Do your wipes always spiral out of control after the first soul charge? I think a key part to working this fight out is being able to recover from a single soul charge; everyone needs to know that it's coming, so they can do whatever it takes to survive it. Are people calling and healing through doomfires effectively? How is the raid positioned? If you have a number of people who are failing inconsistently, you might try the camps strategy. We settled on another strategy, because you run the risk of losing too many groups all at once, but I think it will provide more consistency than you're currently seeing. If you are using the groups strategy, there was some talk in this thread about it recently, but the key is making sure that the group does everything together. Put a mark on a leader, preferably a decurser or a healer, and make sure that they move closely together.
#817SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3â™¦ Anonymity
Originally Posted by Jelloshots
Do your wipes always spiral out of control after the first soul charge? I think a key part to working this fight out is being able to recover from a single soul charge; everyone needs to know that it's coming, so they can do whatever it takes to survive it. Are people calling and healing through doomfires effectively? How is the raid positioned? If you have a number of people who are failing inconsistently, you might try the camps strategy. We settled on another strategy, because you run the risk of losing too many groups all at once, but I think it will provide more consistency than you're currently seeing. If you are using the groups strategy, there was some talk in this thread about it recently, but the key is making sure that the group does everything together. Put a mark on a leader, preferably a decurser or a healer, and make sure that they move closely together.
For the most part, we can survive a single soul charge. We will call out when someone is low and when they die so the raid can be topped off and the healers can prepare. We have both wiped to and survived through a single soulcharge, once we even lived through two! That's just luck I suppose.

We are grouped up by our parties, forming a square around Archimonde, also known as the camp strategy I guess. There is a capitan for each group who is marked with a raid symbol and is responsible for notifying over vent what is happening with that group. This allows the healers who are still in the fight to realize, group 1 is running from doomfire, group 2 is flying in the air from air burst, group 3 is feared, group 4 better start using their big heals. We also announce when that group returns within range of Archimonde/the MT.
#818SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Khaen
To Anonymity.

At the risk of this sounding like a lame response (for which I can only apologise), a great deal of this fight is the mindset with which people go into it.
Perhaps it really needs to be iterated with your guild that the most important thing here is to not die? You mentioned that there is always something going wrong with someone dying. There is a significant element of randomness about this fight yes, but in my experience most of it comes from people simply watching out for any potential damage around them. Once they stop worrying about dps-ing Archimonde or topping meters, and start focusing more simply on their position, it does get noticeably easier.
Other than that, I can't find anything wrong with what you say you're doing, so I'd recommend you just keep trying and be patient. Again, there is an element of luck involved but I'd perhaps look to ensure everyone dumps any meters they have for this fight and just focus on doing absolutely anything they can to stay alive as that is what will win you the fight.

Also, I'd suggest you fix your profile Anonymity as soon as possible. Avoiding showing it is a fast track to infractions and a ban on this forum, I've noticed. Just a friendly suggestion.
#819SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Whitemane
And you need to drill into peoples heads that this fight really isn't all that random. Yes a lot of random things happen, but what they do to you isn't all that random and can for the most part be easily avoided. You can easily get caught in a circle of endless wiping with the general excuse of "Oh this fight is so fucking random". What happened is mostly one person or more not being careful and wiping the raid as a consequence.
#820SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Aciara
Originally Posted by Katherine
You've lost me on this... how does Vanish help with fear or the doomfire?
There is a cast time on fear. If you vanish while he is casting you won't get feared the same goes for feign death afaik. Also if your shaman drops his tremor totem in that bracket you'll instantly get out of the fear aswell (tremor ticks one second after being droped and then every 4? seconds afaik).


The other thing is surviving soulcharges is what makes rekilling this encounter easily doable. We've survived 7 deaths (not at once, but 1 charge after another) and went on to a kill. While still learning the encounter for us at least it was just a matter of drilling into peoples heads that living is important as well as people making the mistakes once (or some people more than that :x ).

/edit grammar.
#821SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Saabik
As several others have stated, try thinking about the fight more as vs environment than the actual boss. The key thought on everyones mind needs to be survival, not dps.

As for your retribution paladin, tell him to swap on heal gear and be in a no-tremor group with a priest. Alternate fear breaks with your pvp trinket and dispel the fears off the rest of the group - "Ghetto Tremor". You don't need exceptional healing or regen on this fight (for this role, that is).

Here is my terrible video of the ret "back up" healer, and our shaman-less group. Our mentality is simply "Take care of self, then contribute to raid". As you can see, most of the time we get airbursted together to avoid grip issues, and try to stick together.

YouTube - Archimonde Ret POV - Stump Hump


Regarding the point where "random" things happen to cause deaths, make sure everyone is doing everything in their power to avoid those deaths. If you get feared into a doomfire, you're PVP trinket better have been on cooldown. Even then, most doomfires can be avoided by standing away from them before a fear goes off. If you died to airburst/grip, you better have healthstoned/potted before you died. There have been countless times a simple healthstone/pot gave someone enough time to get a decurse after they were airbursted, and a decurser should be running to this person as well.

Using recount, we have a "competition" amongst decursers which gives a healthy urgency to the subject ;p It makes me cry when a mage finishes their fireball before they decide to decurse.
#822SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
All 80 attempts, we have had four shaman. Yes, four. That's a tremor totem for almost every group! Everyone has either the 5 min or 2 min PvP trinket. We've all had ample practice on using the tears to reduce fall damage and on reacting to the doomfire and have gotten better at "kiting" it. We have one group of melee (4 rogues + enhancement shaman) and each of the remaining four groups stand on top of each other at each corner around Archimonde, forming a square. Each ranged group has 1-2 decursers and 2 healers.

I just can't pinpoint what our problem is. It seems to be something different every time. Early in last night's raid, the MT was dying because the healers weren't coordinating their fears (I guess). We fixed that and then people started dying to other random crap -- one time it would be because someone didn't get decursed in time, which normally isn't a problem. The next time someone would fail to use their tears properly. Then someone gets feared into fire. Nothing is consistent and it doesn't seem like there's a key issue that we can work on / talk about to fix our problems. It's different every single time. Usually these are just "getting to know the fight" concepts that people learn over time, but really, 12 hours? How much longer should it really take for people to start "getting" this fight?
It sounds like you have the basic strat strong - but the problem is how you handle player deaths. As a raid leader, do you ask people on Archimonde 'How did you die?' after every attempt? If so they will usually say one of two things:

1 - "There was nothing I could do" and
2 - "It was just bad luck".

In my opinion, 9 out of 10 times - either of those reasons is a flat out lie, or bullshit. I put pressure on people who die during Archimonde raids and ask them to respond on vent (with everyone listening) to describe the situation they died. Then ill explain what they could have done better to prevent that happening next time. If you die on archimonde - you have a responsibility to let the raid know why - there is no escaping and pretending it didnt happen. Nobody likes dying and having to explain to the raid the silly mistakes they made - And dont even try the 'it was bad luck' bullshit, please, I wont buy it.

People who dont pot, or stand 5 yards from a doomfire and get feared into one will say theres nothing they can do and palm it off as 'bad luck'.. People might claim its bad luck after standing out of range of a decurser then getting feared and dying to the curse. People can say its also bad luck when they die from doomfire after having stayed close to archimonde trying to get a little more dps off before moving from it. Some people claim its bad luck if they dont have their pvp trinket up, because they used it the fear prior when they have absolutely no need to. Melee might claim its bad luck that a doomfire comes up behind them and kills them - when in reality somebody in the range groups should have just warned them on vent.

Do you use WWS? I always have a giggle when people who say 'Nothing I could do' are proved wrong with WWS... and never used a pot or healthstone - it happens more than we'd like to admit. WWS is a great tool for identifying problems like this. Like the above poster said, if you die you better have used a healthstone/healthpot first. Let people know you use WWS and will have a look at the end of night. Playeres have a responsibility for selfsurvival too with consumable usage - not just relying on healers.

If you have a solid strategy, first and foremost, there are very few situations where you can genuinely blame your death on 'bad luck' or 'random crap'.

We fixed that and then people started dying to other random crap
What attitude does your raid leader have when it comes to responding to players who answer 'Why did you die?' on Archimonde? From your above quote, if sounds as if your brushing it off as 'random crap' and somewhat acceptable. If you die - its probably your own fault (Whitemanes post above said it well). In fact I would settle to say 'You die = Your fault' for 90%+ of the time.

After reading your post on how you seem to be using a strong 4-point setup I would echo the other posters and question your raid players survival mentality. If the raid leader allowed poor play as an acceptable excuse for dying - then people dont have any compelling reason to improve, because they probably dont think its their fault in the first place (when it very likely could be).

When we learnt Archimonde, after every wipe and every stupid player death - I made it very clear people shouldnt blame 'the randomess of the fight' but instead look for what the player could have done to prevent or avoid the situation happening in the first place. If your guild goes into Archimonde with the 'oh its just so fucking random' attitude - your asking for problems - because its not.



PS: Are you using a retro druid standing on the melee btw? Thats an excellent way to boost your setup. That druid is responsible for mt/melee decurse and can keep heals on the MT when other groups have to run off or get airbursted away. However because hes in a very dangerous position (melee range) with no tremor totem (not in the melee group) - you need to take care of him well. Either FW rotation or have a ret pally in the melee group who can dispel him after every fear.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/09/07 at 6:59 PM.
#823SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3KamPa
"Other random crap" started dissapearing fairly quickly when I, as Raid Leader, decided to change groups on every try, making sure to see, what exactly is wrong on every corner(4 groups + melee for us). There is indeed plenty of things that can go wrong with people and going there myself and telling them when to move away, when to stay, all the simple things, helped out a lot. Shrugging it off as "random crap" made us wipe way longer than we should. Also, sometimes it's some minor things that people might not know, like being bit too far away from Archi as melee making you viable target for new DF, and which RL should know and tell. Once it becomes a habit for those people, you can work on another weak link.

Beside that, what helped us was communication betweem different groups. It's not enough to have group look after themselves, they must tell others what's happening. If Doomfire is heading back into melee, they must be warned. If it ignored your group and is heading for another one - say it. Communication is what makes a huge difference. Unless you have perfect 25 raiders who will always notice everything, there will be some situation where they will fail to see danger and need a quick yell to make them avoid it. It mostly affects melee, but sometimes it's also hard to notice new DF as ranged, if there is already one obstructing your vision.

Ranged got the option of moving really far away from doomfires, enough so they can run around feared for the full duration or at least until their fear can be dispelled. Melee doesn't have that option, they need to be able to handle the fear almost instantly. CloS doesn't help you one bit if you're feared into the doomfire eating multiple 2400 damage ticks, it's only good if you're also able to break the fear.

I guess it's highly dependent on the awareness of your melee, but I can count the number of melee doomfire deaths we've had on one hand. We've been killing him since June, and we've always put shamans with the healers/ranged. I guess it's just us making up for our sometimes sleeping ranged classes. Even though a rogue might be in more danger of getting doomfired, the penalty is much smaller than with a class that can't clear all debuffs.

#826SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Telani
