They're always on top, short of one kill where we got targeted with air burst until ~70%. We really don't find doomfires to be an issue either. Most of them can be sidestepped rather easily, and with the exception of fear/air burst we're on him the whole time.
#827SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Misao
Doomfire AI?
I have some questions about the nature of doomfire and its pathing. My shaman's guild is currently working on Archimonde. Part of our strategy involves "kiting" the doomfires away from the raid. We have a group at each of the 4 corners (NW, SW, NE, and SE) and melee under him (but far enough a way to not air burst the MT) If a fire spawns in NE corner, the NE group runs back (everyone) away from archimonde until the fire despawns. At first, I went along with the idea that the doomfires were like heat-seeking missles and would lock onto certain targets. But after spending 3 nights (2 of them full) on Archimonde, I've started questioning that assumption.

This is the post I made on the guild forums where I referenced this thread. I've cleaned it up to make it less argumentative. I apologize for the length:

Ok, after the last 2.5 nights we've spent on Archimonde, I'm really starting to doubt that these fires are 100% controllable. We've seen them go in straight lines, curves, circles, and hooks in situations where the "group in the cone" is there to grab it and times when it isn't.

If we're going on the cone theory, how does a fire "follow" a group, say...SW for about 10 yards, loop around, and then go right through the melee to the NE? There was somebody that said "oh, well you moved too far out of range of it so it targeted somebody else". So the closest people to it that its been following gets too far away, and therefore it goes for some target even farther away?

We said at one point, if it spawns right in front of you need to run backwards, not strafe to the side, but backwards with it. There were times when, even though the whole group ran together, the fire would change directions, either head off to no-man's-land or go back the way it came.

Then we're like "well, if you move out of the way really fast, it won't know you're there and keep going straight!" There was one instance with group 4 where the fire spawned by blank and went straight by her. Yet, it appeared that the fire came back after her and she got burned. We later blamed her for not running the fire away from Archimonde. Now, lets think about this. The fire goes straight on its merry way for about...oh...10 seconds...with no target, and then somehow decides to grab one? Lets say blank did get in its "cone". Why wouldn't it go for her immediately? Why would the fire go after nothing, and then something?

I think the reason it appears that the fire chases somebody has to do with people being too spread out at times. When we weren't together in our tight knit groups (which I wasn't always, I'll admit), there's a higher chance for the fire to path through a single person, and give reason for the vigilant observer to exclaim"see, look! It's following people!" when in fact its a simple issue of probability (more people occupying more space, thus, higher chance of fire going through one of said occupied spaces).

I read some parts of the EJ post. Somebody early on laughed at the notion that the fires were controllable. Post 129:


Originally Posted by Clandestine View Post
The Doomfire is pretty controllable, though - once you understand the basic ways it moves and seems to select targets. You can usually lead them away from the raid pretty successfully. You REALLY need to impress on people that it's much more important to lead their Doomfire away from the raid, taking themselves out of the fight for 30 seconds, than it is to let themselves get touched by it, taking a healer out of the fight effectively for 45 seconds.

There are random components in the fight, but it's really about controlling the chaos.

Purification Potions save lives.
The 2 bolded parts are absolutely ridiculous assertions.

There is NOTHING we can do about what direction Doomfire decides to take. None. If you think there is, please, show me FRAPS or something where you 100% of the time steer it where you want to. The simple fact is, it does what it wants, and the players HAVE NO CONTROL over it. You can run directly away from Arch, and the fire might follow you, or it might decide that it wants to loop around the Shadow Priest you just ran by, or any number of possible routes.

There is NOTHING we can do about when he feels like using his abilities, or on whom. Grip has a 50k(Anywhere) range, Fear has a 99yd range, and Air Burst has a 60yd (EL) range. Outranging is only really feasible with Air Burst, and, ironically, Air Burst is the only one that can really be controlled in the sense of how many people it hits.

So, we have 4 completely random abilities, and you're saying the fight is all about controlling these abilities? No, no I'm sorry, but that's simply false.

Survival is key, and pretty much the only thing that any participant in this encounter can hope to do. Stay near a shaman, stay near a healer, and for the love of all that's holy, don't get the stupid Doomfire debuff.
I make the same challenge. If these fires are really controllable, show me a video of people consistently guiding them away from the group. Like...how about a video where the fires never go through melee? Nobody would want to guide the fires through there, right? So a video like that shouldn't be hard to find!

Here's another post later on in the thread. I've bolded certain parts that I'm not sure about. Post 702:

Heres a test picture I made before we killed archimonde, when we were discussing positioning. Every guild uses different strats for group setup and positioning, as u can see we opted for a 4 point square around archimonde (group 5 is the melee group). This is what worked best for us - it may or may not work for your guild.

The trick is:

- when doomfire spawns that whole group runs in a straight line away from the boss as far as possible until the doomfire stops following you. Dont stop, dont try to sidestep it - the entire group keeps running in a straight line away as far as you can.

- each group is a fully self-sufficient unit - with its own healers and a decurser with a symbol. You always stay together: therefore you all get airbusted together (so nobody is ever out of range of their healer/decurser) and you ALL move together when a doomfire comes towards your group, regardless of which person in the group its actually following. Standing with your group is very high priority, so after any fears or situations where your positions get forcibly changed - moving back to your group decurser symbol is top priority.

This means that, even if the doomfire turns around and comes back for melee, by the time its back it will almost be close to despawning because it has a large travel time to 'snake back' before it reaches the melee. With good vent communication you will be able to alert your melee well in advance if this is happening so they can run off.

It almost always spawns (in my observations) and heads immediately outwards towards the closest ranged/healers for 10-15 seconds before theres a chance it will 'loop around' and chase melee. That 10-15 seconds is crucial as its the time you want to get it to move as far away (in that straight line) from the boss as you can.
This guy is saying that even if you run it back, it will sometimes loop around uncontrollably. What makes this happen? Is this a random element or the fire acting intelligently and picking another far off topic?

Last paragraph, he says that it heads outward immediately to the closest ranged/healers for 10/15 seconds. How does this explain fires going in straight lines or fires that go straight for awhile then decide to hook around? If these things are controllable from the getgo, they should stick with their targets and never look back.

All these theories about the doomfires being actual mobs with aggro tables or cones of aggro tables are, in my opinion, the BC equivalent of the wild beliefs about Onyxia's deepbreath. People who killed her for years had different theories on how the deep breath worked. Some said that it had to do with the amount of DPS you did to her, others said that by keeping lots of dots on her, she wouldn't breath. Finally, others would say it had to do with positioning, that if people "clumped up" she would blast you. Yet none of these theories, when executed could prevent deep breath, just like how all these theories about doomfire can't completely control their directions.

But here's my wild and crazy theory on doomfires, based on Occam's razor: The fires spawn, they make pretty designs in the ground, and then they despawn. Yes, they won't go through walls or in the water, but other then that, they go in random directions. I'm not saying because of this that there's nothing you can do about them, quite the opposite in fact. The fires, imo, are meant to be avoided (melee included), not somehow kited. You stick with your groups to prevent being too spread out and to prevent the chance of somebody getting burned, and you get out of the way of doomfire.
By posting this, I'm not trying to say that I think my theories on doomfire is correct and everyone else is wrong, but rather to illustrate the direction I'm coming from. Am I right about the nature of the doomfire or is there a flaw in my logic? Is the general consensus among the who post on these forums that the doomfires follow certain people or do the move in randomly generated paths? If it's the former, what evidence is there to support this?

Thank You
#828SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Whitemane
Doomfires partially track people. I only think they do when they spawn, they'll find someone and go in their general direction and then some kind of randomness kicks in and make them go do whatever they want.

They certainly don't track people, I've run away from several that just break off in some stupid direction where no people are to be found.
#829SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Misao
Originally Posted by Whitemane
Doomfires partially track people. I only think they do when they spawn, they'll find someone and go in their general direction and then some kind of randomness kicks in and make them go do whatever they want.

They certainly don't track people, I've run away from several that just break off in some stupid direction where no people are to be found.
You mean they'll aim for somebody when they spawn and then they'll go off on their own? For a period of time during our 1st or 2nd night, we decided to try a 3 group strategy (NW, SW, SE). On at least 2 occassions, a doomfire that spawned in the NE traveled in a straight line to the NE (or at least in a trajectory over 90 degrees off from any player). I considered the possibility of the "initial target and then randomness" theory at one point, but seeing those fires go absolutely nowhere made me think otherwise.

If a doomfire heads through one of your group's positions, what do you normally do? Do you have them make a 180 and run from Archimonde or do you have them go to another corner (i.e. fire in NE corner, NE group moves to North or East, etc)?
#830SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
The fires, imo, are meant to be avoided (melee included), not somehow kited. If these things are controllable from the getgo, they should stick with their targets and never look back.
I disagree, they are meant to be kited as much as possible - but this does not mean they follow you 100% of the time.

Doomfires (based on my observation) have a very strong 'follow a player' component but also have a 'go whatever direction I want' component and alternate between them at will. The trick is kiting them away as far as possible when they are in follow-a-player mode. The further you can pull a doomfire from the boss when its following a player, the less likely it'll cause problems when it decides to head in a random direction (as it will despawn before reaching anyone to cause problems)

The best analogy I have thought of for doomfire movement and behaviour is this:

Analogy to describe Doomfire behaviour:

1 = The doomfire is a Thaledred-type mob that only gets 'in combat' with everyone in its frontal cone and can follow any of them. Once in combat with that doomfire, you stay in combat until it despawns, regardless of whether you sidestep or leave the frontal cone.

2 = Doomfires can follow anyone 'in combat' but also can move in a random direction. If there are people in its frontal cone in that random direction, they will get in combat too.

Its therefore the responsibility of all the people who get in combat to make sure the cone is always 'aimed outwards' from the boss - so you can avoid getting other groups/melee/mt in combat or risk having it head towards them instead of you. In a 4-point strat, 5 people at a time (the 4 range groups) get in combat and run off together in an attempt to quarantine the doomfire and prevent spreading combat to other parts of the raid.

This also means that you should NEVER sidestep a doomfire that you got in combat with, even if it appears to be following someone else - because if your still in combat with it, it might turn around and come back for you and get other people in combat as well.
To respond to your other quote:

If a doomfire heads through one of your group's positions, what do you normally do? Do you have them make a 180 and run from Archimonde or do you have them go to another corner
180 and run off for as long as it follows you. Visually it looks like this:

Last edited by Tyrian : 11/11/07 at 1:14 AM.
#831SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		s[orc]ery
Doomfire is controllable. It follows someone then either changes targets or reaches a maximum range from Archimonde where it is forced to curve back.

If you can't see the pattern by now try having all players strafe the fire sideways instead of running backward on one attempt; and all of the fires will constantly curve inward into the raid.
The next attempt, have anyone who looks like the fire is chasing them run directly outward from Archimonde, and the Doomfires will travel in a straight line for a while then curve when it changes targets.

What seems painfully obvious is, a doomfire isn't going to travel in a straight line without a player in front of it. The doomfire pathing has boundaries and could target a player behind it (making it move in a large arc) and the AI adjusts, making look like it is targeting nothing. And yes the correct, minimum-risk method to deal with doomfire is to run outward from Archimonde until the fire curves away from you, then resume fighting.
Last edited by s[orc]ery : 11/11/07 at 1:15 AM.

Nobody has said you can make doomfires 100% do every exact thing and move every direction you want. Nobody will have a video of 50 doomfires following 50 groups in 50 perfect 150 yard lines and then despawning. Unfortunately, the fight isnt as clean as that - it gets messy at times because doomfires appear to have some random component as well.

Try the experiment the above poster suggested and the results should be convincing. Your not trying to make perfect straight-line doomfires here, your just trying to get them to move as far away from the boss as possible when they decide to follow a player (which isnt 100% of the time).

#833SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Misao

Like when it goes off in one direction (in almost a straight line) when there is no group anywhere) or when it targets people that were never in its "frontal cone".

When the doomfire appears to be following a group, and you have that group run it away from archimonde, at what point is it safe to make your way back? When it despawns or when its traveled x yards away and/or has traveled x amount of time away from the group?

I think another issue we had was with melee. Certain people believed that, with good kiting, you could prevent the doomfires from ever going into the melee. If I'm reading the above posters correctly, then there's no way to fully prevent this. You can try to reduce this chance by "kiting" the fires away, but they may just decide to change directions (either randomly or picking a new target), and its up to the melee to watch out for those doomfires. Is that correct?
#834SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3
Edited onPatch 2.2.3		Tyrian
If I'm reading the above posters correctly, then there's no way to fully prevent this. I think another issue we had was with melee. Certain people believed that, with good kiting, you could prevent the doomfires from ever going into the melee

You can try to reduce this chance by "kiting" the fires away, but they may just decide to change directions (either randomly or picking a new target), and its up to the melee to watch out for those doomfires. Is that correct?
In my experience, yes. Despite your best efforts, there will be times where a doomfire just doesnt seem to want to do what you want. However, you can minimise the amount of times doomfires go for melee with kiting and positioning - as other posters mentioned.

Thats all you really need. If you can get most doomfires to head outwards for 50+% of travel distance, your doing a good job. Realise that there can and will be times you will have to react fast and warn melee when things dont go as expected - its a normal part of the fight.

When the doomfire appears to be following a group, and you have that group run it away from archimonde, at what point is it safe to make your way back? When it despawns or when its traveled x yards away and/or has traveled x amount of time away from the group?
As a general guide id say: If a doomfire spawns and is obviously following your group - keep running for as long as it follows you - even if that means running 100-150+ yards from the boss.

If the doomfire starts to arc off after following you about 80 yards out (about half its total travel distance) and go somewhere else - you should be able to return to your original position (as the doomfire will despawn by the time it reaches you if it turned around)

If a doomfire spawns and only follows you a very short distance (eg 30 yards) then veers off, its probably best to stay back a few seconds and watch it carefully = chances are you will have to warn your melee group or an adjacent range group to move who might not see it coming. These are the dangerous ones and its probably just safer to stay away and wait until they despawn.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/11/07 at 3:10 AM.

#836SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Pyram
Too many healers that can't move. Remember Pallies and Shaman can only heal when they're standing still. This is a fight where standing still is pretty much the root of all problems. Stack up on Priests/Druids for HoTs. When an Air Burst hits a group, a Priest can CoH it back up in mid air before the group even lands. Doomfire itself is horrible for Pally healers. What you want is heavy HoTs on the recipient so the healers can set and forget not losing a healer altogether until Doomfire goes away. If you're going to stack non-moving healers, at least choose Shaman so that you can get a bunch of Tremor Totems going.

Honestly, I still think this fight is pretty broken and generally just not worth the time, but you can stack the fight in your favor at least.

#840SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Mearis
We tried the spreading out behind him strategy and found it worked much better for us, since we had a lot easier time making sure we always had enough healers in range to heal the tank and decursing was a lot cleaner.

My only complaint about the fight is how stupid fear as a mechanic is, expecially since this is a fight that encourages raid stacking to insane degreees. I can only imagine how trivial this fight is with 5 shamans, and 5 shamans per 25 man raid is much worst than 8 warriors per 40 man raid, expecially on alliance side.

A less stupid mechanic that doesn't punish you for stacking your raid would be nicer I guess.
#841SourcePosted on Patch 2.2.3Kasi
Oh we used the 180 degree strat too, with our feral tanking him up against the hill. As a person who was in the group alongside the mountains, I felt it had certain advantages. One is the presence of the tree to my right provided a shield at times. Second is the massive amount of doomfires that spawned on our group, ran straight up into the mountains and died there. The 180 strat though does make it very hard for anyone in the two middle groups (non mountain side ones) to heal the MT though. So focus more MT healers there and focus more melee healers in the middle groups.

#847SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Vihermaali
Doomfires never turn more than 90 degrees at time (or so says my experience). I always run in a direction 90 degrees (or more) when to their "current heading" is "0 degrees".

If doomfire follows you, dodge it. It doesn't matter if it follows you. Just dodge it again. As long as you don't close yourself in (should NOT happen) it doesn't matter where it goes or how long it follows you. I think 1 (or 2) healer(s) alone could keep tank up since Archimonde can't crush. Only thing to look out is that tank doesn't die during fears.

It's better to spread out evenly and focus on personal survival than do some fancy tricks.

I think there are max 3 doomfires up at any given time. If your side has 2-3 of them and it has boxed in people, the other 3 sides are completely free of doomfire. Thus it doesn't matter if few people are disabled by running around. Don't try to control doomfires. Unless someone gets grip, doomfire and airburst right after a fear (so no-one heals or decurses) and flies into well of eternity and thus gets a 30sec silence, they shouldn't die.
#848SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ zeidrich
I agree with recent posters.

At first, our strategy, coming from these boards was something to the effect of "The doomfires are controllable, you can kite them away, they should never hit melee. etc."

We used a 4-point strat, and tried to get everyone to kite doomfires. What ended up happening is doomfires would spawn between groups and start to curve. People would be running back from air burst and move the direction of the doomfires. The doomfires would just pick a direction no players were at, and start heading there. This resulted in less than "Perfectly controlled" doomfires.

But moreover, it led to people blaming doomfires for their deaths. If a doomfire looped around, rather than just deal with it, people started blaming kiters for themselves dying. If a doomfire hit melee, it was pretty much a wipe. People died a fair bit to doomfires. And a LOT of effort was expended trying, often in futility, to control the doomfires. And they weren't doing what was so often described in this thread.

When we moved our strategy from a kite-the-doomfire strategy, to a stay-alive strategy we did much better. We moved to a 180 degree layout, which meant that there is a lot more crosshealing available. In the 4 point strategy, each group was isolated. Which meant that if you got separated from your group, or your healer was overwhelmed, you had no backups. In the 180 degree strategy, group 2 could heal group 1,2 and 3 for instance, while group 3 could help with groups 2, 3 and 4.

Then doomfires became an annoyance rather than a death sentence. Sure, people got hit by a doomfire, and after reading this thread, you would start to believe that guilds do it only by nobody getting hit by doomfire at all. But they're easily healed through, and while everyone is doing their best to avoid the doomfires, if you do get it, it's no big deal. Increased crosshealing potential also meant that it is easier to keep everyone topped off. This in turn leads to being able to survive pretty much any solitary soul charge. Assuming you pop healthstones afterwards.

I think those 2 things, being able to survive through occasional doomfires, and being able to stop a chain reaction when someone does die, by being prepared for the soul charge, are really what allowed us to defeat this encounter. Not fancy doomfire kiting, or funky positioning. And I think because of that, I think the encounter becomes a lot less "random" and a lot more repeatable.
#849SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Tyrian
If doomfire follows you, dodge it. It doesn't matter if it follows you. Just dodge it again

Don't try to control doomfires
What you described is controlling doomfires. Unless your actively running towards melee/healers when you say 'dodge it' your attempting to move away from them in such a way that they won't endanger you and minimise effects to other people.

the 4 point strategy, each group was isolated. Which meant that if you got separated from your group, or your healer was overwhelmed,
Each ranged group has 2 healers. Since hitting doomfires is not too common, its hard for 2 healers (in a group of 5) to become overwhelmed. People ingroup shouldnt be the focus of heals, the MT should be. If your getting 4-5 people in a group doomfired at the same time, its not your 'overwhelmed healers' thats the problem - its the players who stood too close to the fire in the first place. You don't need cross healing, really, when everyone plays properly - because people ingroup should require very little healing (occasionally single doomfire, or 3k airburst = nothing for 2 healers to handle) and all the healing therefore is focused on the MT.

There is nothing 'fancy' about seeing a doomfire and kiting it away from archimonde/other raid members when its following you. Its common sense.
#850SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ zeidrich
There seems to be a common trend in this thread that doomfires can be caught, and pulled wherever and however anyone pleases. That you can magically "grab" a doomfire, and pull it directly away from archimonde, and that it works every time.

In my experience, and according to your post:
What you described is controlling doomfires. Unless your actively running towards melee/healers when you say 'dodge it' your attempting to move away from them in such a way that they won't endanger you and minimise effects to other people.
we agree on that.

I'm just trying to say that, don't expect nobody will get hit by a doomfire. I'm saying expect people to get hit by doomfire occasionally. Expect the doomfire to move incorrectly, despite best efforts to draw it away from Archimonde. And be ready to keep people alive when they get doomfire. Same with Soul Charge. It may happen. Be prepared.

All of this pandering to the crowd of people who can execute the strategy perfectly doesn't help a new guild learning the fight.

There is nothing 'fancy' about seeing a doomfire and kiting it outwards from archimonde when its following you. Its common sense, just worded very clearly. If kiting it away from archimonde is considered 'fancy' then whats considered normal? Kiting towards other players and your melee?
This is being patronizing. Obviously when a doomfire is following you kite it away from Archimonde. That is common sense, and that is not what I'm talking about. What I'm saying is when you're kiting it away and it decides to turn for no apparant reason, or maybe you get air bursted while you're kiting, or feared, or someone else runs too close and it changes target, or myriad other situations. The doomfire will curve, it may run over itself or another DF and look as though it's passed, and then seem to fork out of a different DF before people are expecting it.

I'm just saying be ready for when DF does retarded things. Or hell, when players do retarded things. Because nobody is perfect. And focus more on healing them up and keeping people alive, than playing the blame game when a doomfire arcs the wrong way for some unintelligible reason.

Yes, when a DF is heading towards you, run straight out from archimonde, I would never debate that. And if you can show me a video of doomfires following specific players in a straight line away from archimonde every go, and never hitting a person, I would be quite impressed. But realistically in my experience, at least learning, people get hit by it. And it's more important IMO to be prepared to keep people alive, than to rely on everyone to perfectly kite the fires. Best effort, yes. Perfection? no.
#851SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lujaar
Found this on wowhead: doomfire - Wowhead Search

Wowhead seems to think that the doomfires are invisible untargetable mobs.
#852SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
That fits what I described earlier, that doomfire is "A thaledred type mob that gets in combat with people in front of it and randomly Fixates any of them". When a doomfire first spawns you can actually see the burning mob for a second and the direction it heads - then it dissappears and you just see the normal flame-on-the-ground effect.

And if you can show me a video of doomfires following specific players in a straight line away from archimonde every go, and never hitting a person, I would be quite impressed. But realistically in my experience, at least learning, people get hit by it. And it's more important IMO to be prepared to keep people alive, than to rely on everyone to perfectly kite the fires. Best effort, yes. Perfection? no.
Where are people getting the idea that a 4-point strat means doomfires somehow become perfectly 100% controllable into perfect straight lines? There has not been a single poster in this thread who has ever said 'We did archimonde tonight and every doomfire was a perfect straight line 100% of the time - try our strat!'.

I think the misunderstanding comes from several posters who said, using 3/4point methods, things like 'our doomfire deaths went down a stunning amount' or 'doomfires are controllable' or 'removed doomfires as an issue from the fight completely' . This is no way means that suddenly all doomfires magically behaved exactly how they wanted, they still do have a random component and sometimes will cause problems - but overall - they can be managed more effectively.

They still arc, move around, create problems etc , regardless of strat - but if you successfully pull the doomfire 50+% of its travel distance directly out from archimonde it should despawn by the time it reaches anyone else - and thats what a 4point strat is good at.

All you really need to do is pull doomfires in a straight line when they follow you for, 50+% of their travel distance. The direction they head after that should be somewhat irrelevant (theyd despawn by the time they get to any other groups).
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/13/07 at 4:52 PM.
#853SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Kasi
What I think Thorene is trying to say is that we stopped caring about kiting doomfires. We just individually dealt with them. If they were following us, we ran away. But if a doomfire ran right past us, then we stayed in. Staying in or not staying in seemed to have little difference for us in if they curled or not. Either way, they still curled. So you had times where a doomfire had run past you but you were alongside it healing the tank. Now people might say that is dangerous and that you risk having doomfires cross the raid, but they already happened anyway even with the 4 strat and trying to stay together as a group and run away. The benefits to this was that it was a lot easier to keep up the melee if something happened and the MT deaths dropped a lot.
#854SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ zeidrich
Tyrian, I don't think I'm arguing with you. But given posts like Misao's on P34, and over the last few pages, there is a general sentiment that if someone is getting doomfire, it is a failure on the part of doomfire kiting.

When we started making progress was when we shifted the blame away from the doomfire kiting. We still attempted to draw the doomfires away when it targets you, rather than strafing or something which is going to ultimately cause more DF issues. But we focused on individual responsibility. If DF curves to melee, melee should move away. What melee should not do is throw up their hands and say "Oh, we got doomfired, it was the kiters fault." or "Oh, bad luck, DF went totally random and melee got doomfired". And if melee does get doomfired, then they use their tools to stay up. Fire pots, Health stones, CloS.

90% of the time if someone dies, it is their own fault. People have a LOT of tools to keep themselves alive in this fight.

My point is, if you're learning the fight, focus on survival foremost. If everyone can survive being hit by a doomfire occasionally, and everyone can survive taking a soul charge occasionally, then if something unpredictable happens, everyone can deal with it. Once the survival issue is sorted out, then worry about kiting patterns. Obviously we kite the doomfire away when it latches on to us. But when we moved the focus from how to kite the doomfire, to how to stay alive, we went from 2 minute wipes to 6+ minute wipes almost immediately, and then a kill shortly after.
#855SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Beats
Tyrian-

I have a few questions about the 4 corners strategy you use.

1. How close are these groups? We carry 3 shadow priests at most raids and I know they're going to want to mind flay (15 yds?). Or is it not even worth their dps/time to get that close?
2. What is the fewest number of healers you will see on your MT at any given moment? For instance if 3 groups are out due to "kiting" or blast, are you left with the resto druid in the middle and 2 healers from a corner group?
3. Shaman absolutely necessary in every corner group if we are horde? We typically raid with 3 resto shaman and an enhancement shaman...Though we do have another resto shaman keyed if we found it necessary.
4. I've seen you post that you don't 1 shot this boss...So what causes the bulk of your wipes?

After having been stuck on Kael for 2 months, we have enjoyed rather quick progress only raiding 3 nights a week, we've progressed to Archimonde and got Bloodboil last night(haven't tried RoS yet). We've spent less than 2.5 hours wiping on each encounter while enjoying a 1 shot on Kazrogal and 2-4 shots on every other boss other than Bloodboil. As raid leader, I'm looking for advice of what to set our guild up for for this boss.

Thanks in advance for your assistance.
#856SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Kink
Originally Posted by Beats
Tyrian-

I have a few questions about the 4 corners strategy you use.

1. How close are these groups? We carry 3 shadow priests at most raids and I know they're going to want to mind flay (15 yds?). Or is it not even worth their dps/time to get that close?
2. What is the fewest number of healers you will see on your MT at any given moment? For instance if 3 groups are out due to "kiting" or blast, are you left with the resto druid in the middle and 2 healers from a corner group?
3. Shaman absolutely necessary in every corner group if we are horde? We typically raid with 3 resto shaman and an enhancement shaman...Though we do have another resto shaman keyed if we found it necessary.
4. I've seen you post that you don't 1 shot this boss...So what causes the bulk of your wipes?

1. This fght is 100% about survival. The enrage is easily done. As he does not tend to chain cast doomfires, the Spriests can just go in after he casts a doomfire away from them.
2. We have had 1 healer for a short time and 2 healers usually on our MT. Depend son fears totem breaks etc. Archimonde hits fairly hard, but if people HoT up the MT before a fear and at least 1 person breaks it right away, you will be fine thanks to tremor totem breaks.
3. Not necessary for any corner at all. Our first kill was with 3 shaman, our last with 1.
4. You won't 1shot the boss because no matter what you do, doomfire has a random element. Someone might lag when clicking the tears of the goddess, so many things can happen to cause a single death and often a single death leads to more deaths which swiftly leads to a wipe.

However we have seen similar progress in our raids that you have in yours. We beat Archimonde on our second full day of tries (3hr raids). Since then we have one shot him twice and 2 shot him once. I dont know why, but this fight just was not difficult for us. However we also got stuck on Kael for ages. Short raid times with that trash respawn timer was brutal =/.

So it is not that you just will never one shot him. Its just that its not easy to. Just go in to the fight, have your decurses spread out. Have healers know what they have to do, who breaks fear etc and when. Have every person know what to do in case of a doomfire bearing down on them. Make sure they practice with the tears of the goddess off the cliffs near the woman who gives you the item. Bring consumeables, bring a fire prot potion couldron and hand out the pots and most importantly.. STAY ALIVE! You will probably find the fight like we did. Get the boss down to 60-80% on your first few tries. All you need to realise is that the first 10% is nearly the same as the middle 10% which is nearly the same as 30-20% etc. Nothing changes.
#857SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Northerner
I'll argue with you.

I am convinced that a doomfire is 100% controllable and yet the lack of raid control leads to other impressions. I have personally never, ever, lost a doomfire that had only me in the frontal arc (think old school frontal 60 degree arc from tabletop games) and when I was within 10 yards or so of the cone. Between the burning animation and the clearly safe range was where I lived. I kited them often and the *only* times I'd lose "lock" is when someone else at any range was in that arc. If I could get it out past the initial cluster of asshats, I was always gold and could take it as far as I'd like to.

What can I say? It's a hard to replicate situation but it always seemed stable to me. Zoom way the hell out though and see if it doesn't work for you.
#858SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Latito
Just wanted to comment on the fight using a Druid MT. My guild has killed Illidan 5 times now, with about 3 months of Archimonde experience. We generally run 4-6 priests, had 4 in the raid tonight. We tank a LOT of stuff with a druid.. generally saving our lone prot warrior for fights like Kael, Archimonde, RoS, Illidan, etc. Our feral MT has always wanted to tank the fights that were designated warrior-only (I woulda loved to be part of a no-warrior Kael kill just to say we did it) and tonight he got his chance.

First attempt.. about 15 seconds in he d/c'd. Nearly survived until he came back too.. I think a healer finally pulled aggro with dps just standing idle. Next attempt we get to 16% and a fear goes off with no fear ward up. Druid gets hit in the back, feared into a fire and hit in the back again.. it was definitely a preventable death in that it WAS healable.. but what do alliance guilds that have used a druid since day-1 do to counteract this[tank being feared]? Or was the 30-second fear ward just ALWAYS up.. no one ever missed it and screwed up?

We might go back to a warrior tanking, I don't know. Having a tank with 23k hp who gets hit for 5.5-6.5k is REALLY nice though.. a huge change from warriors with 21k hp taking 9k hits. Maybe just a little more coordination for our priests.. given that this was the first encounter they'd ever had fear ward for.

If your warrior is taking 9k hits from Archimonde then he isnt being debuffed properly.
#860SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Xantcha
Originally Posted by Latito

Basically, yes.
Fear Ward needs to be always up, before the fear-targetting change - if your tank got feared it basically means he runs over to the next on aggro (not-feared) and one shots them.
It wasn't really that hard with a 30 second FW.

I am convinced that a doomfire is 100% controllable and yet the lack of raid control leads to other impressions. I have personally never, ever, lost a doomfire that had only me in the frontal arc (think old school frontal 60 degree arc from tabletop games) and when I was within 10 yards or so of the cone. Between the burning animation and the clearly safe range was where I lived. I kited them often and the *only* times I'd lose "lock" is when someone else at any range was in that arc. If I could get it out past the initial cluster of asshats, I was always gold and could take it as far as I'd like to.

Not true for me. I have had a doomfire right on my ass with no one else was in that frontal cone and seen it change direction. We seriously tried to do this at the start with concentrated kiting groups, but it didn't work because of the kite not working properly and one other thing. That being if you kited it, well you ended up being on average further away from archimonde. This led to more tank deaths due to healers not being in range (we had to put 1-2 healers on top of melee to counter this) plus the dreaded thing of doomfire spawns where a group has just kited theirs way back, has nothing in their frontal cone and swerves into melee or crosses the field.
#863SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Beats
Here is what I suspect is the reason for the 4 corner strategy success. Spreading out, but grouping at the same time. You basically force 5 people to survive anytime there is an area in danger. Something that is much less coordinated (albeit still doable)on the "spread out and hope you get decursed and/or healed and/or not feared through a flame when there isn't a healer nearby" strat. (I know I'm oversimplifying it, but you understand what I'm saying.)

I have seen videos of alot of various styles and haven't seen a consistent "kiting" success. But I have seen that there is less flame cluster with the 4 corner successes. I can't explain why...I've just seen it help a little with making things less cluttered and chaotic.

As I set up my raid tonight and explain the strat(our first night of attempts will be tonight), I'll not mention anything about kiting the flames so people don't assume or even hope that we'll kite them away. I'll tell them that we can successfully kite 1 out of 10 away due to pure luck of the randomness. I'm pretty sure that we'll get at least one to straight out or at least away and probably more. But the main thing I'll preach to them is there is no guarantee on what the flames do, so figure out a way to protect yourself and stay alive..and the best way to do that is to hang with your group for healing and decursing.

As for "kiting"....sounds like it's something that should not be said...especially to a new/fragile raid...maybe it works, maybe it doesn't. Just figuring out ways to improve your survivability is the key imo.

I could be wrong and if we go to Hyjal tonight, I'll post my assessment of how things go.

(Still looking for answers from Tyrian to my post this morning)
#864SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
Tyrian-

I have a few questions about the 4 corners strategy you use.

1. How close are these groups? We carry 3 shadow priests at most raids and I know they're going to want to mind flay (15 yds?). Or is it not even worth their dps/time to get that close?
2. What is the fewest number of healers you will see on your MT at any given moment? For instance if 3 groups are out due to "kiting" or blast, are you left with the resto druid in the middle and 2 healers from a corner group?
3. Shaman absolutely necessary in every corner group if we are horde? We typically raid with 3 resto shaman and an enhancement shaman...Though we do have another resto shaman keyed if we found it necessary.
4. I've seen you post that you don't 1 shot this boss...So what causes the bulk of your wipes?
1) The groups are far apart on each of the four points and rarely get close enough to interact. Thus each group needs to be 100% fully self-sufficient with regards to heals/decursing etc. Our shadow priests usually dps in normal form the whole fight and never swap into shadow form.

The best thing to do is assess your raid comp then decide. If your healing is a little weak - tell them to stay in normal form and help heal+dps. Or you could ask them to wear full healing gear. We have all our restro druids in full healing gear in range groups on decurse/heal duty for this fight too.

2) Ya the restro druid + 2 on one side group is probably least - and should be enough. You might need to ask healers to trinket out of fears when this happens. Originally our rule was 'Never trinket out of a fear unless your in immediate danger' but after the patch we changed it slightly to 'healers can trinket out of a fear if its obvious theres not much MT healing at the time". Healers have to use common sense - if they can visably see that doomfirse have forced 50-75+% of the raid to run OOR of the MT, you might need to trinket. The best healers to do this are obviously Paladins, since they can trinket but still have DI shield invulernability up if they are in danger afterwards.

3) We've done it with 2 , 3 and 4 shamans. Obviously the more the better but having smart players is more important. We've had better Archimonde kills/raids with 2 shamans than we have had with 4 - simply because new players can mess up other parts of the fight. Still naturally, you want to bring as many shamans as you have available (as long as they dont lag/crater/die easily). So no - its not required on the outer corners. All you need to do is make sure that particular group without them knows they have to be extra careful and when a fear is incoming, they are at least 30-40+ yards away from any doomfires so if they get feared it will (Hopefully) run out by the time they run the travel distance towards one.

4) Most of our wipes are caused by the (Infuriating) stupid mistakes that just one person has to do each attempt to start the wipe chain (Crater, "oops, i laggged when I clicked my tear", stand near to a doomfire and get feared into it) Legitimate wipe reasons (parry gibbage and all healers feared/oor->mt dying) still come second to player-stupid mistakes causing wipes - at least for us anyway.

Hope that helps, anything else? Pls let us know how u went on ur initial attempts and what success/problems you had, im eager to hear


- The only change I made to our 4point strat for 2.3 in light of the FW change was this: The melee group now must have a Shaman+Pally in it(we used Ret, but holy/prot would be fine too)! I shifted one of the usual melee (Preferably fury warrior, because they can break their own fears) out of the melee-group to make room for him. Heres why we needed to do this..

The Resto druid standing on melee is very close to Archimonde, but not in a Shaman group and therefore has no Fear protection. This is a huge risk which needs to be fixed. There are a couple ways to do it but we did the following:
====
a - Melee Group Enhancement shaman gets a permenant FW rotation so he can Insta-tremor totem protect the melee group (and trinkets if theres no fw available)
b - FEAR - Tremor totem ticks and the melee group gets dispelled almost instantly.
c - Ret Pally (after being tremor totemed out of fear) immediately dispels the Restro Druid - who stands on the melee but isnt actually in a shaman group
d- Ret Pally attempts to dispel anyone else who is in range for the next few seconds , before returning to DPS.

B->D happens very fast (within 1-2 seconds) but basically its just a failsafe to keep your resto druid alive and works well if your Shaman/Pally have fast fingers. This fixes the melee-restro-druid fear problem quite well.

If you dont have a ret pally, you can just as easily put a Holy Paladin on the melee to do this job. But since a ret pally is dps, it works out well. (Assuming you have 8-9 good healers elsewhere) This would have the added bonus of him being able to get tremored out of feared to spam the MT. Yes, its not normal to have a DPS warrior kicked out of the melee group (And shoved into any random range groups) but it doesnt matter - as everyone said - Archimonde is not a dps fight so the usual dps-group-stacking rules dont apply.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/14/07 at 2:03 PM.
#865SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Sapp
Originally Posted by spartakos
They say the aggro loss when you are feared has changed. I have not tested it yet.
It stays.

If someone is over-topped the tank on threat but under the 10/30% pulling margin, the boss will re-evaluate based on threat and go kill that target rather than chase the feared tank.

They'll chase a feared tank instead of slaughtering people now though.

#868SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Whiteknight
Originally Posted by Beats
I have seen videos of alot of various styles and haven't seen a consistent "kiting" success. But I have seen that there is less flame cluster with the 4 corner successes. I can't explain why...I've just seen it help a little with making things less cluttered and chaotic.
There's a significant gotcha here - you need to verify the date the movie was made. Most Archimonde videos were taken prior to the patch which significantly increased the spawn rate of the doomfire. So a lot of vids will show significantly less doomfire junk just by virtue of being early kills.

Blizz took a good step in giving priests a universal Fear Ward -- is it so much to give druids a Shear Ward? (Sorry for the pun )

#872SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
Does the water in the river work the same way? We have been looking at setting it up with him ~20 yards away, with our main healers in the boat on the river, and having ranged/healers across the river in order to cut off the fires.
At the risk of saying the obvious - why bother - even if this works its clearly unintended and one of those things they will hotfix anyway. The intended design is having doomfires an important mechanic that need to be managed/avoided, not something you cut off with terrain/water/world tree and essentially remove them from the fight entirely. Itd be like Chrommaggus with the old LOS positioning which negated any affect his breaths had on the fight and being to dps the whole time whilst avoiding them.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/15/07 at 7:20 AM.
#873SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Myul

Using fear ward on a feral sounds like a very solid strat to me. Giving your tank a shaman with agi totem should push him over 50% dodge, compared with armor cap he shouldn't die regulary.

Well, we don't run with that much priests, leaving us only the warrior tanking way. Last week we advised our non-tremor groups (running with 2-3 shaman regulary) to run out of fear range with a fire near them and it really helped a lot. You will lose 1 decurse, heal and 2-3 dps for a while but the can't die to an unlucky doomfire/airburst combination. Of course, this makes the fight a bit longer, but we prefer the control.

#879SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Cadfael
Used to be with "the more, the merrier", ie 3 and above if possible. But with the changes to Fear Ward post 2.3 that's no longer so important, we just run away more instead of relying on an instant break by the Shaman.

Last kill on wednesday, we were 3 priests and we actually put FW on a holy priest who mass dispelled.

The big change for me seems to be that you just have to deal with Fear now, and can't nullify it on some groups anymore. However if you killed him before a few times, it's not that big of a deal, in my opinion.

It actually has a positive effect. People run away earlier and farther instead of standing still in place, which does help with doomfire paths and makes it less dangerous.

#885SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Mearis
Are you sure it wasn't one of your melees who moved too close and got the tanks air-bursted? That's quite common
#886SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
our MT got air burst
Remember - having agro on a mob doesnt necessarily mean you have the highest threat on it.

In your case, a melee had higher threat than the main tank, even if only by the slighest amount (101% - 109% of MT threat). Because the only person who cant get targeted from airbust is highest threat - this rogue became excempt from targetting and the MT suddenly became a legitimate target.

You don't want this to happen - you want to ensure that the current agro holder = main tank = highest person on threat for Archimonde. Usually this is easy, but if melee dps too hard - they will be able to mess things up.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/21/07 at 10:03 AM.

#892SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0lone

#893SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0KamPa
There's been no change. Once people focus on survival and get better at avoiding Doomfires, it's only natural that it seems much easier. Get some new ones who still have to learn it, and it will be just as difficult as it was in the past.
The things that changed is new Fear mechanics, Fear Ward for all priests and higher Decurse range. All in all, pretty trivial things.
#894SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
In both cases that seems pretty consistent with the time that you're in the air on a doomfire, depending on where you're getting burst into. In the first he seems to have used his tears, but it didn't activate before it killed him.
The player could have been lagging/spiked when theres an airbust? Since character position is client side he might have *appeared* to be dead mid-air, but the server actually had his character hit the ground (and die) at that moment. It would only take a second or two of lag to do this (because your character falls very fast), so you should check with that player if he experienced any lag/lockups around the time he got airbusted. Ill have a closer look at the wws after my raid.

got air burst as MT the other night, it was the first or second burst of the fight so it's possible someone was ahead of me in threat and hadn't pulled yet but I'd never had that happen before
If your the MT and you got targetted for an airbust, one of your players (usually the melee) is too high on threat -. Tell them to watch omen and hover around a much safer % to avoid spike agro (eg windfury crits) pushing them up over 100% of MT threat instantly. I believe most of our melee like to hover between 80-90% of MT threat for this reason. The reason it 'never happened before' is simply chance. Theres 24 people in the raid who can be targetted for airbust and the MT is 1 of them (when melee get higher threat). So its just a 1/24 chance your MT will actually be a target for airbust and thus isnt likely to happen that often, even if your melee get too high on threat - but it can happen.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/21/07 at 11:55 PM.
#895SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Quigon
Originally Posted by ozhanbnc
We finally started working on Archi last night and got it to 34% on our best attempt. But some strange thing has happened at 36%, our MT got air burst. Not a scenario where air burst is cast on melee and they did not react fast, MT is literally the target of the air burst, and he was clearly on top of aggro list.

Is this a known bug?
Is he acting like Capernican; sending a fireball after conflagrate? In archi's case, choosing MT as his next target to air burst after putting grip on an another player?
Assuming no one else was in range of him, and aggro was not an issue, then it was indeed a bug.

We have seen this bug once.

I was trying to anti-kite archimonde, standing right inside him, melee were far away from me, no one in range.

He targetted me for air burst. Roughly 10 people in the raid, spread out over 200 yards got hit by the 3000 damage from the air burst, but only I at the center of the boss got flung. We wiped cause I tried to intercept, and I got one of those "hey lets use the intercept cooldown up and go nowhere bugs". Was basically a lot of fun. I think Thezilch has this on a combat log somewhere if people (as always) don't believe this, until of course they see it themselves.

You will likely not see that bug again, and it was probably even more likely someone just ran into your MT, or aggro was a concern.

#897SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0sp00n
We haven't killed Archimonde yet so I wanted to ask for some help.
I didn't take part in the first two raids, only listened in teamspeak, so forgive me if I can't tell you all details.
However, on those two nights we tried the 'spread out' tactic, where the raid positioned itself in a circle all around Archimonde. It was a happy whipefeast, but they managed to get him down to like 26% in the second night (last try of course).

Now the next raid week, I take part in the encounter and I proposed to try the 4 corner strategy, which seems to have a great impact on survability and an increase on control over the random factors in the fight. However, in the two hours that were left on our schedule for that night (we are visiting him again tomorrow), it was a mere catastrophe. People still died, people still weren't decursed or healed, the doomfires went straight to the melees or from group 1 to group 2 etc.
Also there may have already been answered several of my questions in this thread, but with the changes done to the boss and a 36 pages thread, it is quite difficult to a) find the answer and b) be able to find out if it is not already outdated.

I'd like some advice for this tactis, as I feel the main problems were due to doomfire handling.
1) How far away from Archimonde do the ranged groups stand, before a doomfire spawns?
2) What angle do the doomfires have on for 'locking up' on one target? I've read 60Â° in this thread, and 60Â° basically means an isosceles triangle (sic?), which does leaves some unpopulated space between the groups, e.g. on certain spawn points, there is no player in range for the doomfire to lock on.
3) How tight together do the groups themselves position? All on top or more loosely (I proposed to stand almost on top of each other, but when I observed the groups more closely during these tries, I had to find out that they were more or less cluttered)?
4) Do you immediatley run away from the doofmire or do you wait until it has closed up a bit?

Some of co-officers stated that there is one major drawback of this tactis. Although it *should* encourage the dispellers/healers to focus solely on their own group, there are still some people (slackers) who just can't handle the simplest things (which exactly this is - dispel only your group, heal only your group (despite the main tank of course)). I appreciate all this, and I cannot understand how one could fail in doing so, but obviously there are a few people how are great in pushing one button for 5 minutes and are doing great on DPS, but when it comes to movement or fast reaction (decursing), they just fall behind.
And this is the key point in this tactic. If in one group, there is such a slacker as our decurser or primary healer, you have no backup. In the 'all around - wherever you like' tactic, most times there is an above-average player available to compensate the weakness of another player. In a four corner tactic, there isn't. If the decurser is brain-afk, simply lagging, and the player affected by the debuff also just stupid, it's a whipe. This is especially bad if you don't have enough players online to simply switch them and you have to stick to what's available.

The raid was terrifying. I don't know if it was due to that we were at the end of the night and were all a bit uncentrated (gone through all of Hyjal for the first time within one day, the raid was great up until Archimonde, all bosses were cleard on the first try), if it was the sudden change of tactics that overstrained our players, the not-so-optimal setup for Archimonde (a bit too less healers and two shamans), or if the players available simply sucked (which is someway possible, but seeing that we cleared all of the bosses without much problems in that night, kind of hard to believe).

Tomorrow we will have a full day available only for Archimonde, and I'd like to give some infos and tips before we try him, mainly the questions I asked above. After some tries I even ordered to melees to back off completely and assigned them to ranged groups, to maybe make it easier for the ranged groups to somehow control the doomfire, which didn't bring much success. They still went in circles, from group A to B, etc.


Thank you for help. I'm strongly suggesting tomorrow that we continue to train four corners, but if we don't see much improvement, there is not much we can do but to go back to the more chaotic spread out tactic, which I'd really dislike.
#898SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
who just can't handle the simplest things
The first thing you should do is remove these people from the raid. It might seem obvious, but running with 23 competant players is much better than running with 25 including 2 clueless players. There is no shame in saying 'Either improve or get out of the raid'. If you want to try to attempt archimonde with people who cant think or make the stupidiest of mistakes continually, then expect stupid wipes.

To answer your questions..

1 ) The range groups stand at max range from doomfires before they spawn. The exceptions to this might be shadow priests (who have to run in to fear ward) and mages (who might have to run in and help with a decurse).
2) Not sure
3) The groups are tight enough so that they all get airbusted together. Airbust is ~10 yard radius iirc, so everyone stands that close - just say to literally stand on top of each other, that makes it easiest to explain to your raid.
4) Run immediately if it spawns in front of you. After you start running turn around around and see if its following you - if not , it might be safe to return to your original position. Thats what we do anyway.

Although it *should* encourage the dispellers/healers to focus solely on their own group, there are still some people (slackers) who just can't handle the simplest things (which exactly this is - dispel only your group, heal only your group (despite the main tank of course)). I appreciate all this, and I cannot understand how one could fail in doing so, but obviously there are a few people how are great in pushing one button for 5 minutes and are doing great on DPS, but when it comes to movement or fast reaction (decursing), they just fall behind.
Just to re-iterate. No strategy is going to help you unless you first help yourself and first make sure you have competant players in the raid and remove the ones who just 'dont get it' after giving everyone a fair chance to learn and understand the strategy - then execute it.

Spread your competant players around and make sure each group leader with a symbol is a very competant player. Make sure your decursers and healers know exactly what role they have. Tell mages that all curses on their group should be dispelled within 1-2 seconds, sometimes before it even ticks once. Tell healers that anyone in their group who needs a heal is their top responsibility to top them up fast (then return to the MT). Tell players that get lost or easily confused with positioning that ALL the have to do is follow their group leader. If none of that helps - find another player and invite them to the raid instead.
Last edited by Tyrian : 11/25/07 at 1:38 AM.

#910SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
Has anyone ever experienced a doomfire that would spawn and immediately path into melee?
This is extremely rare, for us at least.

From observation it appears to be more likely to happen when the usually-closest range groups are currently far away (running from doomfire or just airbusted). If it happens 'every pull' then something is terribly wrong with the raid positioning and setup. I dont think the doomfire is actually going 'for the melee' but actually going for ranged/healers on the opposite side of Archimonde.

I think that when a doomfire spawns it targets a close-by person in a frontal cone initially, who is at a a minimum distance and travels towards them. All melee/mt are excluded from this initial targetting as they are within the minimum distance. So if a doomfire spawns and nobody is in front of it in this frontal cone (aka that group was just airbusted) it might instead target the closest person who is at least say 15 yards from Archimonde - on the opposite side. As it travels towards them it travels directly over the melee. So you could say the doomfire isnt actually going 'for the melee' but rather its going for the closest person on the opposite side of archimonde and the melee just happen to be in the way.

This would mean that melee/mt are never initial targets for a fresh doomfire spawn - but it doesnt mean a doomfire won't head over them upon spawning if the situation you described happens. However it should be a rare occurance.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/04/07 at 2:23 PM.
#911SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0taleden
Originally Posted by taybul
Has anyone ever experienced a doomfire that would spawn and immediately path into melee?
I've never seen this, but what I *have* seen and has given us plenty of trouble, is fires moving out toward some ranged, then losing their lock and choosing a new target on the other side of Archi, thus making a big circle around the melee, trapping them at the next fear, or else straight across the melee.

We've tried telling our ranged to never try to ditch the flame and just lead it straight away from Archi until it despawns, but this has its own problems: either the flame kiter goes alone, gets cursed and dies way out of range of decurses, or his whole group has to go with him, which takes them all out of the fight and then dps or healing is insufficient.

#919SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Vazu
Originally Posted by Krazen
Forgive me if this has been asked before, but I did a search through the thread.

Is Doomfire mitigatable through FR?
Once your raid believes in average ranged DPS with survival being the most important part of this fight, Doomfires should rarely be an issue anyway. I bring Greater Fire Protection potions (the ones people used for Rags) because they're much cheaper than Super Healing potions and really the only source of damage I need healing from ever. That's only in the very rare circumstances I am forced into a Doomfire w/o a trinket up. New Doomfire forms right after a Fear, etc. The FR pots are also immensely useful for Az'galor.
#920SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
I mentioned it a little earlier, but (for us) I expect a typical ranged DPS to do between 200-600 DPS on archimonde. Sometimes if your unlucky with doomfire/airbust, a DPS might do less damage than the protection warrior MT'ing = which is perfectly fine. Ive consistently seen in our setup (4 ranged + melee) that 50-60% of total damage to Archimonde comes from that single melee group. Our most recent Archimonde kill was 8 minutes (9 healers): Wow Web Stats

We actually use 6 melee + restro druid in centre. Five melee form a single group, this includes 3 rogues+ 1 shaman+ 1ret pally. There is also a fury warrior in the raid but he is in another group since he can break his own fear. When the melee group (aka ret pally) gets tremor totem'd out of fear, he immediately dispels the fear from the restro druid (whos in the MT group without a totem). If I didnt have the ret pally available for the raid I would put a holy paladin in the melee group to do the same job. The sequence of events (shaman tremor totem dispels ret paladin -> ret paladin dispels resto druid on melee) happens very fast, within 1-2 seconds.

As I explained to a new mage yesterday joining us for his first archimonde kill, "Our job is to dance with archimonde for 10 minutes, let the melee do the dps'.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/06/07 at 7:40 PM.

Does anybody tried Warlock's Detect invisibility ?
#922SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Klasto
I think for us the hardest part of learning the encounter was to survive through the doomfires, your dps has to learn that the dps isn't their first priority, survival is, we even had rogues who didn't go in for a minute to ensure their safety I believe.
#923SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Tacitus
Originally Posted by Vazu
Once your raid believes in average ranged DPS with survival being the most important part of this fight, Doomfires should rarely be an issue anyway. I bring Greater Fire Protection potions (the ones people used for Rags) because they're much cheaper than Super Healing potions and really the only source of damage I need healing from ever. That's only in the very rare circumstances I am forced into a Doomfire w/o a trinket up. New Doomfire forms right after a Fear, etc. The FR pots are also immensely useful for Az'galor.
So basically there's no way to do this fight with a Felguard out? Or without a severe headache and loss of DPS from moving the damn brainless demon every second?
#924SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Hop
Originally Posted by Tyrian
We actually use 6 melee + restro druid in centre. Five melee form a single group, this includes 3 rogues+ 1 shaman+ 1ret pally. There is also a fury warrior in the raid but he is in another group since he can break his own fear. When the melee group (aka ret pally) gets tremor totem'd out of fear, he immediately dispels the fear from the restro druid (whos in the MT group without a totem). If I didnt have the ret pally available for the raid I would put a holy paladin in the melee group to do the same job. The sequence of events (shaman tremor totem dispels ret paladin -> ret paladin dispels resto druid on melee) happens very fast, within 1-2 seconds.
That's a really interesting idea to put a resto druid in the middle. I've been tasked as a corner captain/decurser, but one of our problems is too little heals on the MT sometimes. Does having a resto druid in the middle give you raid-wide decursing and predictable/steady heals on the tanks?
#925SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
I've been tasked as a corner captain/decurser, but one of our problems is too little heals on the MT sometimes. Does having a resto druid in the middle give you raid-wide decursing and predictable/steady heals on the tanks?
Short answer = yes. Decrusing is still 'everyones responsibility' but the druid is the best person to do it , due to his central raid- positioning with the melee and being in range of alot more of the raid than one of the four corner groups (if you use a 4 point setup). The benefits to having a resto druid in the centre include:

- Melee always have a decurser in range , even when they get airbusted (since they get airbusted with the druid , who stands on top of them. This is good because you never know when mages/range groups have to run off or get airbusted away out of range)
- MT always has a decurser in range, regardless of whether mages have been airbusted/had to run off.
- Druids are excellent with hots to keep alive melee with multiple doomfires ticking if you have a nasty doomfire/fear
- Druid can keep constant hots on MT to help compensate for all the moving the other 7-8 healers have to do
- The druid is in the centre of the raid and thus in range of alot of the raid to help decurse/heal where needed, but his top priority is looking after melee/mt decursing and melee doomfire healing.

With all these benefits - I think its silly not to use a restro druid in the centre standing on the melee. I would suggest fear control as the way I mentioned a few posts up (ret/holy pally in melee group manually dispels resto druid).

Lastly, all the fear wards from the raid go onto the melee group Enhancement shaman. This ensures he can drop his tremor totem instantly when a fear goes off to tremor-dispel his ret paladin ASAP, who in turn gets the druid a split second later with a cleanse-dispel. If you decide to do this, make sure your paladin realises how important the need is to be FAST on the dispel, immediately as a fear goes off the Paladin needs to be spamming cleanse on the druid.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/07/07 at 6:02 AM.
#926SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Roywyn
Originally Posted by Bach
Is there a particular good mod out at the moment I should get my decursers to have installed for quickest decurse?
Decursive 2.0 - Decursive 2.0 -Ace2- | World of Warcraft @ Curse.com

It gives the decurser a little grid, curses peopple appear as bright red boxes (dark red if out of range), a left-click decurses them and interrupts your current cast to do so.
Might take you a day or two to get used to the change, but it's just plain awesome.
