So basically there's no way to do this fight with a Felguard out? Or without a severe headache and loss of DPS from moving the damn brainless demon every second?
Do your group a favour and give them blood pact
Pets are a very temporary thing on Archimonde, I'm happy if mine lasts 20 seconds!


Soul charges are still random, some go off immediately, some take a few second.
We just killed him with 8 people dieing in the fight - world first? *blush*
#927SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Vazu
Originally Posted by Tacitus
So basically there's no way to do this fight with a Felguard out? Or without a severe headache and loss of DPS from moving the damn brainless demon every second?
Felguards don't work on Archimonde. Who wants to heal a pet with the amount of stuff going on in this fight? Melee always end up eating Doomfires. Just not possible. I always use an Imp here. Ranged DPS are just not that important. Melee are the real winners (and good for them) here.
#928SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0constantius
We've spent 2 nights on Archimonde so far, with our best result being 39% using a 4-corners (sorta) strategy. Our melee are surviving fairly well at this point, and we're using what Fear Wards we have on our enh shaman, who cleanses his whole group.

Our doomfire control is absolute shite. I have no clue how it could be so bad, but it didn't matter what we did, or where ... doomfire would loop and twist and loop and come back in on the melee and basically screw us over in any circumstance it could.

We tried a couple of things:

1) Put all ranged behind Archimonde. In this case, fire spawned wherever, and looped in the area we had assigned. Rarely did it actually "aggro" on someone and kite out in a straight line ... most of the time it went 10' out, then cut back in and around and in fun heart-shaped patterns.
2) 4 corner strat. In this case, we found that the first 2-3 fires would always spawn behind the MT, blocking off one area. This group would move, and from there it was just fires all over the place, no reason. There was rarely more than 90 degrees free of fire at one point. I think we had up to 5 fires up at one point, just chain-spawning every 8 seconds.

Basically, what we want to know is ... (and I know this question has been addressed before in the thread, although no-one gave a definitive answer that I saw):

Is the doomfire in any way, shape, or form controllable? That is, does it spawn with guaranteed aggro on SOME ranged person, and can thus be kited for 10 seconds straight out, away from the boss? If so, does it spawn on the side of the boss that that person is on?

We've seen doomfire spawn behind the MT, loop around instantly, go through the melee and out the other side heading for someone random at the other side of the raid. We've seen it go straight out into nowhere-land with absolutely no target whatsoever, then pick a target 10 seconds later and start going straight for them. We've seen basically every combo possible.

I watched two videos; one by a guild on our server that seemed to go with the a semi-group strategy, and attempt to avoid the fires, and the second by Transcended, who either had some ninja-haxx-sk1lz, or were the luckiest people I've ever seen.

Can anyone explain why (video: Transcended Vs. Archimonde) over 80% of the fires spawning in this video spawn behind the MT, and wander off into that half of the map, where no-one is standing? I'd really love to be able to do this when we go back to play with Archimonde ...

We've got decursing under control, we've got melee group under control and they're doing nice dps. We've got tank healing mostly covered thanks to extra FWs and trinkets and pally bubbles. It's just the ranged dps and doomfires we cannot seem to solve.

Any suggestions?

As a complete aside, where does everyone tank him? We've been engaging from directly behind him, and tanking him about 15' from the stump back along the path toward where he spawns. This ends up leaving some healers in and amongst the trees over there, but provides a ton of space for the people behind him.
#929SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Cull
Regarding doomfire, my guild has always found it best to have everyone in that sector (We use 4 corners also) move straight back if a fire is moving towards them. By moving straight back it's almost guaranteed that fire will remain in a semi-straight line and will not twist and loop through your raid.

Do you lose out on a lot of healing and dps time by having an entire sector move back? Yes! But is worth it. The entire fight is about survivability and controlling doomfire properly will make for a much smoother kill.

As far as the 'AI' for the fires is concerned it seems to have some sort of set pattern after it chooses its initial random target. It will follow its initial random target until that person either runs in a new direction or dies. If the person who gets targeted off the start just runs straight back, the fire should follow them perfectly but if they decide to make an attempt to 'dodge' the doomfire it will instead choose a new target in it's vicinity. Which will lead to the fire looping happily through your raid.

Note: This is only from my experience and could be completely wrong .
#930SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Tyrian
It's just the ranged dps and doomfires we cannot seem to solve.
But thats the whole fight! Your constant use of 'behind' the MT leads me to believe your setting up your raid poorly - even if you are using '4 groups'. How exactly are there 4 groups positioned? It sounds like you have archimonde against the mountain with 4 groups like this:

---1
2
---boss
3
---4

The pic above is a bad 4-point setup open to many problems. Instead should try the setup below:

1-------2

--boss

3-------4

Try that instead. If you spread the raid/ranged/healers evenly around the boss, there is no 'behind' or 'in front of the mt' really - it doesnt matter where doomfires spawn as the raids effectively split up into 4 self-sufficient groups who can react and function independantly of each other.

You could not have '5 fires up at one point'. There are 2 doomfires up at a given time and the third doomfire spawns just as the first doomfire begins its despawn (which takes several seconds). So you really only have 2 active doomfires at a given time.

Is the doomfire in any way, shape, or form controllable?
Short Answer: Yes

Long Answer: Sortof. The doomfires appear to have a 'follow a player' component and a 'move in random direction' component and alternate between them at will. Thats why you see some doomfires obviously-following players and others mindlessly going off into the distance. You can, therefore, control the doomfires when they are following a player. You do this usually by kiting the doomfire away from archimonde (depending on your guilds strat) while it follows you.

Remember, NO STRAT can claim it has 100% control of doomfires and makes them all shoot off harmlessly in the distance, they do appear to have a random component in their movement too. No matter what strat you decide to run with, there will be times where a doomfire does something unexpected and might head towards other players. All you need to do is keep calm and immediately say on vent 'Group 4, watch out - doomfire coming from your left' - or similar - so they can move away safely.
#931SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0constantius
So do you have each sector clumped up completely? We were spreading out a little bit in some sectors to avoid sending multiple healers sailing into the distance; maybe that's part of the problem.

Has anyone successfully used a 4-corner strat that had people slightly spread out, or are all of them dependent on having all 5 people in that group clumped within 3' of each other?

As well, you most definitely *can* have more than 3 fires up at a time. I saw it tonight. Repeatedly. Maybe not 5 (one would be despawning), but there were at least 4 up on one of our wipes. We were seeing them spawn as often as every 6 seconds at times, which leads to a lot of fire and not much space to keep them in.

From conversation with one of the other guilds on our server that has killed him, current theory on Doomfire from them is that it can spawn any time he's not doing anything else, based off the GCD. So if he's casting Fear, or Grip, or Air Burst, he cannot cast Doomfire within 1.5 seconds of that. Other than that, it's completely random ... he uses the ability, when it's up, if he can. Here comes another fire.

Also, our 4-point strategy is just that ... 4 points. One group directly in front of Archimonde, one behind, one at his left, one at his right. It made a diamond shape, until fire distorted it.
#932SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
We were spreading out a little bit in some sectors to avoid sending multiple healers sailing into the distance; maybe that's part of the problem.
Well thats your problem. The idea of a 4-point strategy is 4 POINTS. Not four 'areas where groups spread out liberally' - 4 very defined points where the entire group stands together.

Four tight groups who together form a point spaced around Archimonde. That group stands together, on top of each other, runs out together when in danger, runs in together when safe, strafes together when necessary - and does everything else together.

Spreading out is what causes the problems. Of course, theres many ways to approach the fight and strat - other guilds do spread out - some stay compact, find what works for you. In my experience, sticking together is the key to doomfire management.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/08/07 at 4:59 AM.
#933SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0constantius
What about when it spawns (basically) halfway between two groups, and immediately cuts "sideways" toward a group, starting a loop early? Those were the worst we found ... (hard to draw a picture) ... it would spawn at Archimonde's front right, and go out about 5', then loop hard and start twisting and going nuts as it headed for the group (for example) behind him. No rhyme or reason. If it was headed for one of the groups in front of him, that would have made sense ... but it would twist immediately and head for someone behind him, despite having spawned directly in front.
#934SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Cull
Originally Posted by constantius
So do you have each sector clumped up completely? We were spreading out a little bit in some sectors to avoid sending multiple healers sailing into the distance; maybe that's part of the problem.
We try to promote spreading out in your sector as much as possible while still being in range of your decurser. This helps prevent entire groups from getting launched in the air at the same time. Also I hope your entire raid has at least 1 stack of Major Fire Protection Potions to use for when someone inevitably gets hit with doomfire.

The only thing I can think of is that someone was very close to him that was chosen as the random target then sidestepped the flame causing it to pursue someone else.
#936SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Tyrian
What about when it spawns (basically) halfway between two groups, and immediately cuts "sideways" toward a group, starting a loop early? Those were the worst we found ... (hard to draw a picture) ... it would spawn at Archimonde's front right, and go out about 5', then loop hard and start twisting and going nuts as it headed for the group (for example) behind him
The more important thing to remember is: nothing you describes is a legitimate reason to cause a wipe. If that doomfire was heading towards those players - simply warn them so they run off = simple. In our raids, its the responsibility of the Group closest to the doomfire to warn on vent when it changes direction and heads towards other unsuspecting groups.

Its easy to play devils advocate and say scenarios like "What if the doomfire spawns at A, cut across towards B but suddenly went to D and killed in everyone in its path". In reality - this only happened because of poor communication between players. The direction a doomfire moves shouldnt matter - as long as your raid communicates with each other well.
#937SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0constantius
The spreading out within the zones was the key problem, I think. I've drastically modified our strat, and I'm basically going to hammer the following mantra into our ranged dps' heads: "THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS. THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS. THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS." until they believe it. Right now, they seem to think they're heroes for dodging a doomfire and going back to dps'ing, not realizing that all they're doing is causing the doomfire to loop around and screw someone else. We have always had a very strong ranged dps crew who pride themselves on pushing up toward rogue range (rogues @ 1500, ranged @ 1350+ for our best), and they're going to have to learn that this is NOT a fight where they can do this.

Thanks for the help; I'll post again when we get back into Hyjal and have another shot at this punk. It's a frustrating fight so far; I can do my job flawlessly, avoid the fires, heal the tanks, and 2 random nubs will wipe the raid.

It seems to me like

- Archimonde chooses a random player not in melee range.
- A fire spawns on the same side as that player and heads towards them.
- If the player runs backwards, it just moves in a straight line.
- If the player runs sideways, the fire soon turns and becomes quite unpredictable.

it will probably stay as one of those things with a mystery element to it though, like onyxia deep breath :>

One thing I'm trying to figure out is this:

Wow Web Stats

Obviously a well geared and skilled guild that has farmed archi for months. They somehow managed with 7 healers, but what I find more remarkable is how many of their ranged have 90%+ dps uptime. How do you manage that while protecting yourself from fear > doomfire?

#941SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Myul
4 tremor totems, 2 cooldowns on your pvp trinket.

Only 4 people should need to really aware fear > doomfire, but you can easily manage to heal four people.

The key is experience in this fight. After some kills, you know how the fire spawns and moves around. Have group ts/vent channels for every tremor group and use the set_cameradistance 4 command if your system is able to manage it.

I'm wondering about the hunter "verdi" in this wws, the died at 4:20 but did allmost nothing (was afk?).
#942SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Vihermaali
Originally Posted by constantius
Is the doomfire in any way, shape, or form controllable?
I haven't found any need for doomfire control. Trying to control it will just mess you up. Don't bring too much melee and focus on individual survival, thats the best way to go. If you try to control doomfires, people will start assuming its not their job to dodge them. "They are supposed to be under control." Wrong, dingdingdingding!

Limiting peoples positions is actually one of worst things you can do, in my opinion. If someone is supposed to be with his group avoiding doomfires gets a lot harder.

In short, Archimonde tactics can be compressed into this: Spread people evenly around him and tell them to stay alive. It doesn't get more complicated than that.
Last edited by Vihermaali : 12/09/07 at 8:58 AM.
#943SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
In short, Archimonde tactics can be compressed into this: Spread people evenly around him and tell them to stay alive. It doesn't get more complicated than that
I disagree. Thats a poor way to see the fight - anyone can say 'tell them to stay alive' but you want to provide your raid with the best tools/strategy to make it easy to do so. And spreading out, we found - was the cause of many problems that made this more difficult. We found 4-point positioning superior mainly because it gives you a clear idea who and what your responsible for and will guarantee possible-death scenarios will not happen (eg being separated from healer/decurser).

Remember you can push things like 'individual survival' but its still a team effort to survive - as your survival needs other key people (healers/decursers) ready at a moments notice when things go bad. By just 'spreading out where you want' you have no guarantee who will/wont be in range. With tight-knit defined group positioning , you have more control.

However both methods (spreading out vs close-knit groups) can work fine depending on guild and player preference. Its just about finding out what your players are comfortable with.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/09/07 at 9:15 AM.
#944SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0constantius
My closest analogy for Archimonde in TBC is Gruul shatters.

I'll admit .... /cue "Give me the grace ..." ... our guild absolutely blows at shatters. Hard core suckitude. We basically couldn't deal with them, any way, any how. Every single shatter would result in minimum of 3 deaths. Some of our people are just really really bad at spatial awareness and moving AWAY from people (or things).

So we went with the assigned positions route, gave everyone a spot on the wall that could prevent them from being thrown, and made them go to "safe spots" before Grasp.

And it worked. Every time. It slowed down the kill, and we've never done faster than 9 growths (although we haven't done it with 25 mains since ... Hydross-era) ... but it's absolutely 100% controllable. If you die, it's because you're a moron, not because you had bad luck.

And that, to me, is just like Archimonde. By going with assigned group positions, with absolutely no spread-out, you control that uncontrollable factor. A doomfire in your "zone" (90 degrees, whatever)? Run away. Everyone. Your entire group. You're a self-sufficient little bundle of joy, and you run away from the boss like he has an infectious disease.

And your group lives. No-one gets stupid and runs the doomfire into another group. No-one stands so close to a doomfire that they get feared into it. You just run away.

"Spread out and live" only works with exceptional groups of people. You may not realize it, but if you do that kind of strat, you basically are depending on 25 people to not be morons for a period of 7-9 minutes. I hate depending on people that way ... it never ends well.
#945SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Duravi
The 4 point strat with people in the group running straight back when doomfire is headed that way gives u as much "control" as u are gonna get. I'd add one caveat tho, usually putting one MT healer in each group and having that healer stagger himself slightly from the other 4 players can be of some help (still in tremor totem range tho obviously). Usually our MT healer only run out with the group if it is apparent they have to to avoid the doomfire. The rest of the group should all be running out together even if its clear the fire isnt on them (i.e. say the fire is chasing the lock and the other players arent in its path, doesnt matter they should be going back as well).

IF YOU ARE NOT A MT HEALER OR MELEE YOU SHOULD ALMOST NEVER EVER BE DOOMFIRED. That is the most important point I think. When I say never I mean it, ur ranged can easily avoid standing near dfires before fear goes off and saving their ways to break fear ONLY for the times when it has to be broken to avoid running through one. One easy way to check who is sucking is to use recount and find the dmg from doomfires to each player after an attempt. Even if u have a called wipe and ppl suicide in them the suiciders only recieve their max health worth of the dmg and won't stand out, the noobs taking 10s of thousands of dmg from doomfires over the course of the fight will and I'd highly suggest swapping those people out for someone who doesnt suck. When we were first attempting this fight we had an entire raid night (4 hours) of wipes, the players (excluding mt healers and melee) who were good took ~1-2 doomfires over the course of the entire night if that gives u some idea about how often ur raid members should be getting doomfired.
#946SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Tyrian
One easy way to check who is sucking is to use recount and find the dmg from doomfires to each player after an attempt.
Thats a great idea. I did it a couple times on our first kills, basically pointing the finger over vent and saying 'why the hell are you taking so many doomfires' . It works too.

You can also use WWS after a night of attempts to analyse player performance. Taking in mind what the above poster said (people die in doomfires during wipes, so allow 1 tick/max health dam for that) you can learn a great deal about who seems to be just not playing-it-safe. On our last Archimonde kill (clean 7.5 minutes) this is who took doomfires:

Wow Web Stats

So you can see there were 28 doomfires over the course of the fight on 16 players. Only really the top three people there (who took 4, 3, 3 doomfires respectively) I would think to question after and find out if there was any problem they experienced. It was Povskis first night trying Archimonde but the pallys had done it before. However have the neat Bubble trick which they can use in emergencys - so I let them be a little more reckless sometimes when they want to stand in and heal the MT when required (eg if other mt healers have been airbust/run off from doomfire) if their bubble is not on cooldown, so even if they eat a doomfire they can just shield out of it.

I would love to see some WWS from other guilds showing how many doomfires your raid takes during the course of a kill.
#947SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Hodor
Heres the report from our MH clear last Wednesday (as a reference we are now at 5/5, 8/9): WWS

We use more like a four "splotches" strategy - we have four groups (2 healers, 3 DD per group) + melee (healed/decursed by a feral druid in heal equip). We generally try to stay close to each other in the groups, move together out of the paths of fires, etc, but we do not try to kite them or control them - if a fire comes in your direction it is your responsibility to evade it while staying close to a decurser (if you get completely cut off, join another group for a short time until the fires have despawned and your group can reform at the proper place again). We had bad experience with trying to kite them (groups stayed away to long kiting the fires, that the MT died several times, because almost all healers were moving/out of range. Using a pure point strategy (ie everyone clusters up and only moves when the guy with the symbol moves) also didn't work to well, as the reaction times were to slow.

The strategy obviously requires a lot of controlled communication over TeamSpeak - but thats what we have it for. We warn groups when a fire is closing in on them, we warn the melees/MT, we call out if somebody is burning, and so on. It also helped to remind people that the fight is not about DPSing, but about surviving.

I always have recount open and showing the deaths for the current fight - this way you see immediately who died and can (hopefully) remember their name and quickly look at why they died (ie no heals or too many fires). Though in one try we did get surprised by another heal-shaman on his first kill of Archimonde, when we all suddenly got a Soul-thingie with everyone alive - he had apparently used his ankh instantly and NS+HW himself up with no one noticing ^^

What works wonders:
/console set cameramaxrange 50

[Off Topic]How do you combine several reports in to one, so that you have all the Boss Tries/Kills in one Report, but seperated by Boss[/Off Topic]
#948SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Narishma
Originally Posted by dalien
I can confirm it. A couple weeks ago we had the death chain start around 20%, and had 4 people standing when he hit 10%. We burned him down to 7% in the next ~40 seconds and then he keeled over.

And yeah, the fight does seem a bit on the ridiculous side now, 30+ attempts to get him down again this week (although I'll concede some of those should've been kills if it weren't for mistakes).
Thought I'd add some weight to that theory. We got our first kill last night. Shit started hitting the fan around 18% I think it was, and we managed to zerg him down to 10% with MT dead. We had 5 people alive when Tyrande's shield was applied, and when was at 7%, he just died. Did his emotes and death animation etc.

We discussed it a bit afterwards, and it does seem like a move intended to retain some of the lore from WC3, Having the whisps kill him in the end. Have anyone actually wiped after shield got applied?
#949SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Kalroth

We've had kills where he was at 1% for more than twice as long as Vaelastrasz ever had.
#950SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Anthion
Originally Posted by constantius
I'm basically going to hammer the following mantra into our ranged dps' heads: "THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS. THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS. THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS." until they believe it.
Your mantra should be "STAY ALIVE. STAY ALIVE. STAY ALIVE." This fight is in no way a DPS race, it's a mini-survival marathon. We killed him once using the 4 point stratregy, and yes, if you are doing that it is helpful to have the group get airburst together to keep healers/decursers with them. Biggest problem for us with that strat was too many MT healers getting out of range while running straight out from doomfires.

We have since switched to tanking Archimonde at the mountain and have had better repeatability. This eliminates a decent amount of doomfires since they sometimes path up the mountain and are of no consequence to the raid.
#951SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
MT healers getting out of range
The wording some people use on Archimonde regarding healers confuses me. Do people assign specific dedicated-raid healers in some methods? I drilled into our healers that everyone is a mt healer, unless you had a specific person you needed to heal (eg someone in your group with doomfire dot).
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/10/07 at 10:57 AM.
#952SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Mearis
Tyrian, for what its worth, we tried the 4 point strategy, and we had huge issues with MT deaths. We switched to using an arc formation, with everyone spreading out behind him, and killed him quickly, and our last few kills have all been with a max of 3 attempts - our last attempt was a one shot with 5 or so completely new people in the fight, and one disconnect.

What was happening with the 4 point strategy for us was that one or two groups would be running from doomfires, one group would get airburst, and then a fear would land and the tank would die since too few healers would be in range.

Different guilds have different strengths, I understand the main strengths of the 4 point strategy, but at least for us, spreading out works very well, and we emphasize individual responsability on surviving. Don't insist that it is the best strategy and all others are inferior, as long as you kill the boss reliably with a good margin, then the strategy works.
#953SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â—Š Kasi
We had the same issue Mearis had. With the 4 point and the idea of being safe and moving doomfires away, the tank would get in too much danger, dip low and get killed. We put him up against the mountain now and the groups on the mountain sides can be pretty aggressive. It is more about personal responsibility though, which makes repeat kills sometimes hard to do. Last night we 2 shot him which was pretty fun. Even before 2.3 with using a bear tank with fear ward, the 4 point strategy would just get our tank killed most of the time.
#954SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Anthion
Originally Posted by Tyrian
The wording some people use on Archimonde regarding healers confuses me. Do people assign specific dedicated-raid healers in some methods? I drilled into our healers that everyone is a mt healer, unless you had a specific person you needed to heal (eg someone in your group with doomfire dot).
We assign MT healers and set up a trinket rotation to make sure at least 2 healers have PvP trinket on CD to break fear.
#955SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0andastra
We tank Archimonde probably 100 yards from the mountain (I'm not good at judging distances). Three ranged groups are spread out on the semi-circle in front of Archimonde. The melee and the warlock group (3 locks, 1 shaman, 1 druid) are behind him. The three ranged groups in front of Archimonde have assigned locations. The idea is to take some of the discipline of the 4-point strategy while lessening healer range issues on the MT. The three ranged groups, especially the middle one, have an easier time helping decurse/heal another group as well.

We still do the run out strategy on doomfires, but people have become better at knowing when it is safe to sidestep a doomfire and run back. We still have some retardation but we're killing Archimonde faster and lessening the MT gets gibbed issues we had.

For fear and doomfires, there's a timer on fear. If your trinket is down, position yourself a little bit away from the doomfires. You don't need to be extremely far away to not get feared into one. This is especially true for ranged dps.
#956SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â€¢ Acustar
We went back to Archi tonight for the first time in a few weeks (killed Illidan) and I had this happen:



Anyone ever have this happen, or know why this happened?
#957SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â€¢ Snowy
You have a 1% chance to fail a dispel I believe. It's actually surprising it doesn't pop up more often, but with multiple decursers people just may not notice since someone else is hitting it at the same time. Obviously it's much more noticable when you fail to dispel yourself!
#958SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0KamPa
Originally Posted by Tyrian
The wording some people use on Archimonde regarding healers confuses me. Do people assign specific dedicated-raid healers in some methods? I drilled into our healers that everyone is a mt healer, unless you had a specific person you needed to heal (eg someone in your group with doomfire dot).
If you have at least 2 priests in raid, you can have 1 healer immune to fear, makes him perfect for healing MT. Trinket and fear ward rotation is invaluable to prevent some nasty spikes during fear or when doomfires chase most healers away. I guess trinket rotation could work, but that just complicates things needlesly.
In our case, we use two such healers, they just stand between groups, strafe doomfires instead of running away and pretty much keep the tank alive no matter what, unless they get bursted. Also, we have druid standing together with melee, who is mostly decursing(feral), but can land some emergency heals on MT when needed.
"Everyone is MT healer" is nice in theory, but sometimes things go out of control, so we found it more effective to always have dedicated healers on tank.
#959SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0khel
The 4 points strategy with a resto druid being dispelled in the center strategy worked great for us and got him to 14% our first night of attempts. I think that I will take the suggestion in this thread though to jump the raid over a cliff inside MH over and over again until everyone makes it alive a few times in a row though. We controlled the doomfires for the most part (a few minor issues to work on with avoiding getting feared into the flames), and MT was staying alive. 2/3 of our wipes were from someone who "lagged" or used their pvp trinket instead of their tears when they got bursted.

4 points, 5 decursers, 7 healers + 2 hybrids healing (feral druid + prot paladin healed). I was pretty amazed that the final boss in MH seemed so easy to be honest. With a good raid setup then it is mostly a 5-8 minute long retard-check for your entire raid.
#960SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Saethar
Originally Posted by Tyrian
The wording some people use on Archimonde regarding healers confuses me. Do people assign specific dedicated-raid healers in some methods? I drilled into our healers that everyone is a mt healer, unless you had a specific person you needed to heal (eg someone in your group with doomfire dot).
I've always setup Archimonde the same way. I guess we are lucky to have 3 shaman in every raid though (2 resto, 1 enhance).

We have 1 melee group with the enhance shaman and 4 melee DPS.

We use a 4 point strategy. Each group has a group healer, a dispeller (3 mages and Feral druid), and a tank healer. So basically, we run 8 healers and use our Feral druid as a dispeller, freeing up our Resto druid for MT healing.

Both resto shaman heal their groups, and 2 priests take care of the other 2 groups. This leaves 2 Paladins, 1 Priest and 1 Resto druid MT healing. Since the 4 MT healers are in different groups, the chance of all 4 of them being out of range due to Doomfires is quite small. Group healers help on the MT if no one in their group requires attention.

The group healers and dispellers also keep an eye on the melee, and heal/dispel as required.

We've never needed to setup any Fear break rotations on MT healing, since 2 of the MT healers have a Tremor totem in their group, and everyone equips the PvP trinket in case of emergencies. If things get really hairy, our MT just blows Last Stand/Shield Wall to stay alive until healers are back on track.
#961SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Kabale
Our guild has finally downed Archimonde after taking a month break while focusing on BT.

We had gone from spreading everyone out to the 4-point strategy to finally getting the kill with a 3-point strategy. Personally, I don't really think the different strategies mattered - each have their merits and drawbacks - it was just a case of getting people to realise it's about survival and not dps. The more we wiped, the more people understood, basically.

I didn't enjoy getting feared, trinketting out, and finding myself falling through the ground at 20% though... Fortunately I didn't get cursed, wouldn't have minded getting air bursted back above ground though :p
#962SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Seneku
We initially went with the 4 points system as well but what we found was we kept having issues as 2-3 of the groups could be pretty much out of action at the same time. DPS was too low and healing always felt far too light as well regardless of how we spread out the healers.

Quick switch to the spread out around him positioning helped but then we ended up just going with everyone one spread out south of him except the MT positioning. This gave us by far the best DPS as less people needing to run constantly and ofc as a result the healing was a lot easier too, downed soon after those changes.
#963SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0cheebamonkey
This has probably been mentioned earlier on in the thread but for those who don't want to go back through searching, we've found that with the new change to Fear Ward placing a priest in your groups with no shaman and having them FW + Mass Dispell the group works amazingly well.
#964SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Beren
Originally Posted by khel;
I think that I will take the suggestion in this thread though to jump the raid over a cliff inside MH over and over again until everyone makes it alive a few times in a row though..
When we practiced like this (jump off the cliff till you take reliably take 0 damage), on our next run we had a lot of people crater because they were trying to take 0 damage. Their performance was very different with all the spell effects going off, etc. Lots of people gave me the "I swear I clicked before I hit the ground" speach.

So.....We went back to the cliff. But this time with the instruction to keep doing it until you can take a LITTLE damage every time reliably (like less than 1/10 your hp is a good target). This worked much better for us, and is now how we train all new people on when to click their tear.
#965SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0cheebamonkey
Originally Posted by Beren
When we practiced like this (jump off the cliff till you take reliably take 0 damage), on our next run we had a lot of people crater because they were trying to take 0 damage. Their performance was very different with all the spell effects going off, etc. Lots of people gave me the "I swear I clicked before I hit the ground" speach.

So.....We went back to the cliff. But this time with the instruction to keep doing it until you can take a LITTLE damage every time reliably (like less than 1/10 your hp is a good target). This worked much better for us, and is now how we train all new people on when to click their tear.
I tell my raid that idealy they should take 2-3k damage from fall damage each time.
#966SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Duravi
Too many MT healers being out of range is the one weakness with the 4 point strategy, and makes it essential for you to have a MT healer in each group. Even then there can still be problems, which is why I suggested staggering your MT healer slightly from his group and having him run back from doomfire only if he has to. Occasionally this can create a messy doomfire or two, but where as you can survive someone getting doomfired, or even worst case a soul charge, you cannot survive the MT dying and Archimonde does hit very hard. That said there still needs to be some intelligence applied by your MT healers; stand in range of tremor, dont stand near doomfires when a fear will go off soon, etc... Paladins and druids make great MT healers here because druids can still heal effectively well moving and paladins can bubble through a fire if too many other MT healers are currently out of range, they still need to play smart position wise though. One of our attempts not long after we began tracking doomfire damage had an MT healer (druid) taking over 200,000 damage from doomfires during just that one attempt. Yeah, lol.

As for groups
We use a 4 point strategy. Each group has a group healer, a dispeller (3 mages and Feral druid), and a tank healer. So basically, we run 8 healers and use our Feral druid as a dispeller, freeing up our Resto druid for MT healing.
is exactly the same for us except we also make sure every group has a shaman if possible. Oh and it sounded like decursing was not a problem for you, but if it ever becomes one it is usually because one or more of your decursers are terrible or their computer/connection is.
#967SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Saethar
Originally Posted by Duravi
Even then there can still be problems, which is why I suggested staggering your MT healer slightly from his group and having him run back from doomfire only if he has to.
From what I understand, you guys have 4 groups all standing on top of each other?

We simply use 4 groups that each go to a different side of Archimonde. People stay spread out on their side and don't remain clumped up. Make sure you're healing or DPSing from max range also to give yourself more time to react to newly spawned Doomfires.

I also put icons on all the dispellers, so people with Grip can quickly find a dispeller from another group if their dedicated mage/druid is out of range due to Doomfire or Air Burst. That groups healer can easily keep a Gripped player alive during the time it takes them to identify and run to another group and get dispelled.
#968SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Duravi
Saethar,
Not directly on top of each other (that used to be a good thing to do actually though before when you could get grip+burst) but all close enough to easily be in tremor range and to easily run together from an incoming doomfire. Originally we tried just assigning a direction like you are saying (i.e. N,S,W,E) but then you get alot more doomfires that circle around, where as with tighter groups for the most part as long as the whole group other than MT healer run out when a doomfire is chasing one of them you get mostly straight doomfires heading out. Also, well airburst may be annoying really the only people who it creates any danger for are MT healers or if someone is dumb enough to get your MT airbursted.

The icons on decursers is nice but assuming you have 5 decursers it is pretty unnecessary especially since 2.3 where mages can decurse from 40 yards now. We do not count the druid on MT healing as a decurser, usually we have 3 mages, one druid who is her groups patch healer, and a feral druid in with the melee. The feral druid will only decurse if the mage behind archimonde is running from a doomfire or airbursted since he obviously wont be able to reach the melee during that time. With a 40 yard range you can generally get anyone (it might make you have to just take a couple steps) in the groups adjacent to you in case their mage is airbursted. Doomfire wouldnt matter since the group runs together, the mage can decurse anyone in his group well they are running from it except possibly the MT healer since he will usually not run with the group, he should be easily reachable by the other two adjacent decursers though. That has worked very well for us, from attempt one decursing was never an issue. Between decursing and running out with my group from doomfires I don't get very much time to dps at all, and if your ranged are playing correctly they wont either. It's been said 1000 times already but THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS.
Last edited by Duravi : 12/12/07 at 5:32 PM.
#969SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Klasto
Originally Posted by Seneku
We initially went with the 4 points system as well but what we found was we kept having issues as 2-3 of the groups could be pretty much out of action at the same time. DPS was too low and healing always felt far too light as well regardless of how we spread out the healers.
We solved this issue by bringing more melee to raid, more than 5 preferred.Also I felt like healer communication is really important if you are using this tactic.

Also, well airburst may be annoying really the only people who it creates any danger for are MT healers or if someone is dumb enough to get your MT airbursted.

The icons on decursers is nice but assuming you have 5 decursers it is pretty unnecessary especially since 2.3 where mages can decurse from 40 yards now. We do not count the druid on MT healing as a decurser, usually we have 3 mages, one druid who is her groups patch healer, and a feral druid in with the melee. The feral druid will only decurse if the mage behind archimonde is running from a doomfire or airbursted since he obviously wont be able to reach the melee during that time. With a 40 yard range you can generally get anyone (it might make you have to just take a couple steps) in the groups adjacent to you in case their mage is airbursted. Doomfire wouldnt matter since the group runs together, the mage can decurse anyone in his group well they are running from it except possibly the MT healer since he will usually not run with the group, he should be easily reachable by the other two adjacent decursers though. That has worked very well for us, from attempt one decursing was never an issue. It's been said 1000 times already but THE MELEE KILL THE BOSS.

I've always drilled into people's heads that if a Doomfire gets anywhere near them, they need to turn and run. No strafing, no circling around- you go explore the mountains or go camping with your group for a little bit.

We assign people to sides, and generally they're all within their totem ranges and such, so it's worked for us. The icons on decursers are definitely not necessary, but do tend to come in handy.

And yeah, melee kill the boss. I just run around like a chicken with his head cut off for 6 or so minutes.

I really like the 4 points strat, but we are very melee heavy, and they are very bad at getting out of fires. Can you pull an azgalor and just let them live in it and get chain healed?

#973SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Klasto
I don't think you want to spend extra healing on something that is avoidable.We used a melee group of 5 in our first kill and the kill lasted 9 minutes and 56 seconds, that includes the last one minute.In the second kill we decided to use more melee to test it out and the difference was almost more than 2 minutes.

The thing about 4 point strat it seems for us is, that some of the groups don't do anything at all sometimes but run away, which is acceptable considering they survive and the main tank survives.Melee's job isn't really hard on this fight with berserker rages and cloak of shadows.Your enhancement shamans, your feral druids have to pull out early if it is a problem and you can always run to a "point" as a melee and get healed fully.I've heard on vent after one of the kills that one of our rogues didn't dps for more than a minute just to play it safe.

So i guess playing it safe, even for the melee is the key.Rogues, especially the undead ones are lovely in this fight, and yes even they wear their pvp medallions.And from my experience the fight goes shorter with 7-8 melee instead of 5 but that can be our people getting used to the fight as well.
#974SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Saethar
We pretty much always have 6 melee DPS for Archimonde. 2-3 rogues, 2-3 Warriors, 1 Enhancement Shaman. If a Doomfire is heading towards the melee, we call it out and they run away until it's gone.

Bringing extra melee would definitely make the fight go faster, but with 6 (including our OT warrior usually), we manage to drop him in a respectable 6-7 minutes with a 4 point strat.
#975SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach
Do they run to a specific spot, or just run in seperate directions? Same thing if it starts in the melee, just tell them to run out completely instead of trying to dodge it? Is it preferable if they stack on top of each other or spread out around his back?
#976SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Massael
From my experience melee can't really "stick together" if a doomfire happens to loop around Archi's legs or come at them they often just have to CloS/sprint/spread out as fast as possible to avoid getting hit. In some cases they can beeline together towards an opening - it's just not as easy as it may seem.

The hardest aspect of this fight for us is still doomfire curling, we are well aware of how the frontal cone targetting seems to work, and are quite effective at "kiting" doomfires, but still have a large number that spawn and start looping before they seem to have latched on to anyone. RNG I suppose, only possibility I have considered is that our positioning relative to the boss may be off (we use 4 corners), such that we're not lining the groups up with the locations where doomfire will generally spawn.
#977SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Karmen
We had our first night of attempts on him last night. Best we did was low 60's and high 50's with a lot of attempts that were basically over before they even started. Overall I think we probably had about 20 real attempts over a 4 hour period and in the end I think it was productive as we didn't have people cratering or running straight into doomfires on fears by the end of the night.

Our consistent issue though was MT healing. We had 9 healers in the raid and 5 decursers. We used a 4 point strategy and had 2 healers in each group with a resto in the melee group for tremor totem. I had instructed the groups to run straight away from Archimonde when a doomfire spawned in their area but because of airburst and the length of time it takes for a doomfire to despawn it seemed that all too often 3 of the 4 groups would be OOR. This seems to be a re-occuring theme yet I haven't really seen anyone talk about how they specifically addressed this issue other than saying that 3 healers are enough to keep up the MT. For whatever reason that didn't seem to be the case for us. Any thoughts on this issue?

I think if we get that cleaned up we realistically could by our next raid as our best attempts almost always ended with a MT death rather than soul charge issues.
#978SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Saethar
Originally Posted by Lambach
Do they run to a specific spot, or just run in seperate directions? Same thing if it starts in the melee, just tell them to run out completely instead of trying to dodge it? Is it preferable if they stack on top of each other or spread out around his back?
They basically just run wherever is safe. Also, Doomfires can't spawn directly on melee, as they spawn about 20 yards from Archimonde.


Originally Posted by Karmen
This seems to be a re-occuring theme yet I haven't really seen anyone talk about how they specifically addressed this issue other than saying that 3 healers are enough to keep up the MT. For whatever reason that didn't seem to be the case for us. Any thoughts on this issue?
We always use 4 healers on the MT, with the 4 group healers helping if they're available. The only thing we really setup for MT healing is making sure that all 4 dedicated MT healers are in different groups.
#979SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0giansm
Originally Posted by Karmen
Our consistent issue though was MT healing. We had 9 healers in the raid and 5 decursers. We used a 4 point strategy and had 2 healers in each group with a resto in the melee group for tremor totem. I had instructed the groups to run straight away from Archimonde when a doomfire spawned in their area but because of airburst and the length of time it takes for a doomfire to despawn it seemed that all too often 3 of the 4 groups would be OOR. This seems to be a re-occuring theme yet I haven't really seen anyone talk about how they specifically addressed this issue other than saying that 3 healers are enough to keep up the MT. For whatever reason that didn't seem to be the case for us. Any thoughts on this issue?
Our solution is basically to abandon a grouping strategy, and just spread out with massive use of vent by the healers and decursers. Our vent during Archimonde is a constant stream of things like "I'm cut off" (meaning a healer is blocked by fire from the MT), "I can't decurse Warlock X" (a decurser is out of range) and "I can't heal Hunter Y" (a healer notices that hunter has a doomfire dot but is out of healing range). Often one of these things will be followed very quickly by "I'm on MT", "I got Warlock X", or "I got Hunter Y" and everyone knows not to worry about it. If nobody calls it out, that poor warlock or hunter pops a pot or healthstone and tries to run closer to someone that can help him. If too many healers call that they're cut off then the MT knows to be really twitchy with shieldwall, last stand, and healthstone.

As far as the specifics of our healing, we use our fear wards on healers and normally have two tremor totems, one in the melee group and one in a healer group. We have a resto druid stand with the melee so he can decurse anyone in range of the boss and heal the MT. Most of the MT healing comes from the druid and a couple of paladins, although everyone heals him to a degree. Make sure the boss is being debuffed and your tank is buffed (demo shout, thunderclap, ironshield). Try to keep up Earth Shield and Prayer of Mending whenever possible. The fight has been very repeatable for us, after our first kill we usually only wipe if someone screws up a tear click or if the MT misses a stance dance.
#980SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0KamPa
Originally Posted by Karmen
Our consistent issue though was MT healing. We had 9 healers in the raid and 5 decursers. We used a 4 point strategy and had 2 healers in each group with a resto in the melee group for tremor totem. I had instructed the groups to run straight away from Archimonde when a doomfire spawned in their area but because of airburst and the length of time it takes for a doomfire to despawn it seemed that all too often 3 of the 4 groups would be OOR. This seems to be a re-occuring theme yet I haven't really seen anyone talk about how they specifically addressed this issue other than saying that 3 healers are enough to keep up the MT. For whatever reason that didn't seem to be the case for us. Any thoughts on this issue?
We use 2 healers that aren't with any of 4 groups and just stand somewhere "in between". (there's also a feral druid decursing/healing melee, but can't really consider him MT healer, just some small LBs) They do not run away from Doomfires, just sidestep them and are Fear Warded. With 2 Fear Wards, one person is pretty much immune to Fear, if you have 4, that's 2 people. In case you're limited to just 2, one can dispel the other, and then they both heal MT(not to mention they can get Tremors, just in case). Keep in mind, those 2 healers shouldn't stand too close to each other, so they don't get bursted at same time or have to avoid same Doomfire. At absolute worst it means that there's at least one healer on MT during Fear - spamming max rank heals should be enough.

Obviously, 2 minute Trinket is mandatory, it also helps if at least one of those healers is a Paladin, as he can bubble out of some nastier situations. I prefer being second myself, as I have full control on my own Fear Ward, plus it's always some hots/instants on tank if I have to run. Now, if you do not have a single priest in raid, than it might be somewhat tricky to do it our way But then again, that would mean you have different issues than just MT healing.

Also, sidestepping Doomfires instead of "luring" it away from Archimonde isn't really a big issue - sure it might form some pretty circles around those healers, but as long as they are immune to fears, it doesn't matter. Just make sure no one stands too close to them so they won't get Bursted by other people.
#981SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
Our consistent issue though was MT healing. We had 9 healers in the raid and 5 decursers.
Do you have WWS of the kill? After our MT died on a few learning attempts with new people I did a healing breakdown on them and found out they were healing group members/melee more than they healed the MT. After I told them the MT is top priority unless there was something else in-group like doomfire that needed attention, the MT healing improved.

If you could provide a WWS of your attempts for the night we could see what the healers were healing.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/14/07 at 1:44 AM.
#982SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Grapes
My guild has been wiping on him for the past 2 weeks, for our 1st night we tried spreading method around him in 180 degree, it did not really work well with massive amts of deaths from airburst n doomfire and our best try got him to like 78% before calling the night off.

That night I skimmed through this entire thread and found the 4 corner strat quite promising for the potential to keep doomfire "ezmode" ie. whole grp just run in n out to avoid fire and get airbursted together. So we end up tryin this 4corner strat for the next 3 nights but we encountered similar issues with MT kept dying when 2grps got cut off by doomfire and another grp got airbursted.

To fix the MT dying issue, we tried many different positioning tweaks on the 4corner strat:

1. Putting a healer between each of the 4 groups
2. Putting 3 groups above boss and spreading 3-4healers below him
3. Tried the strafe around and stay in range method using 4corners so we do not have like too many healers out of range

But ultimately the tweakings were not effective as our MT continued to die and the best try we got him was 15% where I died from fire and chained soul charges to the raid and had another 30% n 40% wipe but basically those are the only attempts that went below 50% out of 100 plus attempts.

My raid is now in a dilema, is there any other way to do this fight in a 4corner strat and reliably down him every week or do we have to totally change strat to the spreading method and go through another series of wipes to get used to spreading. As of my post, my raid is kinda used to clumping and having a cluster leader to shout out move in n out when doomfire comes and we probably gona take abit of tries to get used to spreading n pple being aware of doomfire.

We are really out of ideas atm and would really appreciate some help from pple who hav done him every week using 4corners. How do u assign the healers, which healer gets fearwarded, when should the healers top up their own grp and focus on MT, and how do ur healers coordinate when there are unlucky combos like airburst on 1 MT healer n 2 others being chased by doomfire?

This is the wws for the latest night we spent on him Wow Web Stats
There are 4 MT healers assigned to solely just heal him and 4 healers in each corner and 1 druid near the melee.
After looking through the wws, I realised that the raid healers are not healing enough on our tank, any suggestions to allow the raid healers in the 4 corners to stay in to pop heals on tank when there is a doomfire in their sector and the dpsers etc are running out from the fire? Would clumping the dpsers up in each corner and making their healer stay like 15yards away from them viable?

Added another 2 wws Wow Web Stats http://wowwebstats.com/pnqtvgvquvzmg

#983SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Krazen
Originally Posted by Grapes

There are 4 MT healers assigned to solely just heal him and 4 healers in each corner and 1 druid near the melee.
After looking through the wws, I realised that the raid healers are not healing enough on our tank, any suggestions to allow the raid healers in the 4 corners to stay in to pop heals on tank when there is a doomfire in their sector and the dpsers etc are running out from the fire?
