#984SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Massael
The one change we made which helped a lot was to put the MT in a different position relative to the melee, with CoH priests in two groups adjacent, like this:

G1 G4


Me. XX MT


G2 G3


CoH priests are in groups 1 and 2.

Your melee have their backs facing the water, with CoH priests able to help keep them up, and HoT the MT both those melee heal groups had mages in them to decurse melee as soon as they got a grip. We just found that this positioning really helped us ensure that melee didn't die, once other healers had the opportunity to stop "saving the melee" they could focus more on MT healing and we downed him 2 attempts later.
#985SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Asheneyes
Grapes,

I think it's difficult to give good advice for Archimonde besides the usual positioning tips. Healing on this fight is annoying to say the least, at least in my personal experience. There's nothing more frustrating than watching the MT dip lower and lower while being chased by a doomfire and finally running back into range only to be airbursted immediately into the Hyjal suburbs again. The fight's a bit stupid like that.

But when your MT keeps dying and we can assume that the MT is doing the usual to keep himself alive as long as possible it's unfortunately mostly on your healers. Keep in mind that there's a certain randomness to the fight, even when people play very well the RNG can throw some stuff at you which will cause a wipe. Being successful on Archimonde is mostly about reducing the RNG's ability to screw around with you.

So. First of all, a couple things you really need to make clear to people.

Archimonde's not a DPS race. It's a survival fight. Everytime a DPS class takes an unnecessary risk which leads to damage that's a heal which is not landing on the MT. In an ideal situation, nobody in the raid should take any damage besides the MT and those who get cursed etc. While this is clearly not a possible scenario the goal's to achieve something close to above.

When damage is being taken, your raiders need to understand that they're a little bit self reliant. That means that they need to be prepared to use appropriate pots, it means that they need to be aware of their surroundings and be close to a healer and decurser. It means bandaging when standing around 70+ yards from Archimonde with no doomfire in sight.

Also, and while that might be difficult to do in small raids especially, identify those who constantly eat doomfires or crater or somehow die. Deaths happen, and sometimes even twice in a row, but if you've got some people who absolutely cannot perform adequately on Archimonde then let them sit out. You'll save twentyfour other people a lot of headaches by doing that.

Your healers should understand that even when there're designated MT and raid healers everybody with a heal button should at least keep an eye on the MT and be ready to help out if needed. Get a macro/vent arrangement where MT healers notify other healers when they can't heal the MT for whatever reason. Get those healers with tremor totem shamans. Get them the low cooldown pvp trinket to get out of fear. Use fearward if you've got a few. Maybe even setup a rotation so there's two healers breaking out of fear at all times (a somewhat soso working thing imho but hey).

And finally make the healers job easier a bit by not allowing other people to cluster closely to them to avoid airburst unless you use the 1 group 1 airburst strategy of course.

Just hang in there. If you got him to 15 percent you can get him to 10 percent. Be mindful of the time you attempt Archimonde, don't try him at the end of a raid night when everybody's tired and lacks attention span. Go in fresh on a new raid night if you can. Also, take some breaks in between attempts, he's got no trash to clear after all.

Good luck.
#986SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Massael
I should mention that we did a training attempt that our MT actually came up with the idea for, which was absolutely amazing for getting people into the right mindset.

Have all your ranged DPS put on stam/pvp gear (this is wise anyway), then engage the boss with explicit instructions that no one but melee is allowed to DPS. Ranged have only one job, staying alive, and DPS is expressly prohibited. We told them to just stay alive, we lasted until just before the enrage timer ran out that attempt, and it was a few attempts later where we downed him. In one attempt we really managed to train people to focus on clicking tears at the right time, being proactive in avoiding doomfires, and also at communicating. Once communication and individual responsibility have been worked out, you're very close to a kill - just wait it out.
#987SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		SikYi
Firstly, i am from the same guild as grapes.

I want to elaborate more on what grapes said and what is the difference with our strat from the strat in EJ with the 4 corners method I will it list out as follows

1) Referencing from post #739 under archimonde thread, Tyrian of Blackrock, the difference between our 4 corners and the picture is that we position ourself slightly near the mountain which is located top right of the picture near the tree trunk location. Moreover, the area is quite small and not many areas to run. Lets say for instance the doomfire chased a person towards the hill, does anyone noticed that the doomfire will change it direction if the person is standing on top of the hill ? However we do encounter several times when a person is behind the tree and the doomfire is aiming at him, it sort of change target and treat as if the current target isn't in line of sight. Is there any relevant post that i might have miss out regarding the doomfire and those people who are standing on the hill ?

2) Does having a druid in melee group rather then he standing 20 yards away from Main Tank really helps to lighten the burden on the healers ? Reason why he isn't standing in the melee group is because he usually gets feared into doomfire and it turns up healing the druid rather then healing main tank.

3) During our first few tries, we split the 8 healers into the 4 cluster groups and 1 into the melee group and they will move out if they are being chased by doomfire. The problem with this strategy is that if one being chased by doomfire and another being airbursted which doesn't solve the MT from dying. How do most of you guys resolve this problem?

In the end we tried to split the healers into 1 per cluster and 4 healers standing in the middle of each groups but the doomfire caused more havoc n thus cutting off healers n the MT death issue was not resolved
Last edited by SikYi : 12/18/07 at 5:18 AM.
#988SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Vonwen
I'd say Archimonde is a fight where each guild will have its own strategy, based on the lineup, the strengths and weaknesses of the members, the number of healers... There is no perfect strategy that works for everyone, due to the silly randomness. But there are advice that can be given.

What I did after some wipes was to make 2 groups, one small group with 3 pallys, 1 shaman and 1 mage, which is facing Archimonde (thus closer from the MT), and is completely alone. The 3 pallys of course heal the MT, and of course try to spread out as far as they stay in range of the totems. The chaman only heals this group so that the workload remains quite low, even if all of them are under doomfire. The tremor totem minimalizes the fear uptime, and if not proccing soon enough, they can rotate bubble/dispel. The mage only decurses this group. The other group is spread on a 180 angle behind Archimonde, with 4 other decursers (usually 3 more mages and 1 resto druid), each decurser being assigned to a specific angle, and marked by a raid icon.

This has some advantages, and drawbacks. The 3 paladins care only about the MT and are not tempted to heal anyone else, or even themselves (except an instant heal coming back from air burst). The lack of healing on the MT is immediately notified in case of an air burst, which is a clear signal for the other healers to help out. They just say "air burst on pal #" and the help arrives. As 3 paladins may be not enough to heal the MT, the resto druid keeps his hots on him, bursting when needed, and healing the raid/decursing when it's quieter. The drawback is that, if they are somehow too close from each other, they may all be air bursted at the same time. It's a matter of practice. The second drawback is that the shaman may have troubles to heal himself if all the group is doomfired. It's quite rare though.

Besides this, having a lot of shamans is a huge help, we did our first kill with 5 (1 enhance, 4 resto), we usually kill him with 4, and always have at least 3. Pvp trinkets and smart group optimization are also a big help. For instance, the fury warrior won't need a tremor totem, so he should be placed in a group with no shaman, preferably in the MT group, even if there's a dps loss. Frost mages (it does help if your mages have troubles with the fight) also are less dependant to the tremor totem, and warlocks can drain life to stay alive while waiting for some heal. BM hunters can also be immune to fear, if they manage to keep their pet alive.

Fear wards are useful on healers, especially priests who can dispel other fears (and they really should do so, especially the shadow priests). Fire cauldron can also help when trying the boss. Anyone being in danger should use HS + healing pot, you should be careful to this (you can see it with a death log like Recount or Assessment), most people die because they forget/don't want to use potions. Make everyone use the tear of the goddess before the pull, as some people argue that they cratered because the spell animation froze their game (believe it or not, but this can be prevented). And as said before, if you notice anyone repeatedly lagging out, dying stupidly or making big mistakes (like air bursting the MT), you really should sit him out for the good of the raid.

PS : even if it's not a dps fight, the shorter it is, the less randomness you undergo. People should absolutely not take risks, but they must go all out as soon as they can. Mages and rogues are very useful here, as rogues aren't too disturbed by the doomfire, and mages (while also decursing) have a great mobility, can cross doomfires to reposition into a safer spot, and can blink immediately when air bursted, even being able to choose where to land.
Last edited by Vonwen : 12/18/07 at 8:15 AM.
#989SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0amethyst
Originally Posted by Massael
I should mention that we did a training attempt that our MT actually came up with the idea for, which was absolutely amazing for getting people into the right mindset.

Have all your ranged DPS put on stam/pvp gear (this is wise anyway), then engage the boss with explicit instructions that no one but melee is allowed to DPS. Ranged have only one job, staying alive, and DPS is expressly prohibited. We told them to just stay alive, we lasted until just before the enrage timer ran out that attempt, and it was a few attempts later where we downed him. In one attempt we really managed to train people to focus on clicking tears at the right time, being proactive in avoiding doomfires, and also at communicating. Once communication and individual responsibility have been worked out, you're very close to a kill - just wait it out.
We did something similar, way back when we were learning him. Although there was some, "WTF? Waste a proper go?" I am of the opinion that it really taught people a LOT about positioning, when they're not checking cast bars, spell rotations, cooldowns etc.
#990SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Yaelle
Looking back on 7 Archimonde kills (without any of them being 1st try kills)

- I personally think it's great for learning the encounter, spending at least one of many tries on survival (we didn't do this, but I still think it's a great idea).

- By learning you'll improve your survival on this encounter and countering soul charges works towards that as well.
The two elements on their own work towards each other until you reach the point where you kill Archimonde.

On an individual base, people will try and explain why they really had no chance, but very often the mistake did happen long before they unintentionally got theirselves into that situation they couldn't counter as it occurred.

We had one kill with 7 dead people, so learning to counter a soul charge was part of our progress on this encounter.
#991SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Alefa
@Grapes,SikYi

My guild also initially had problems with the 4 group postitioning, but after trying the all the different basic strategies decided it was best for us.

We put a dedicated paladin to stand on the melee and try to focus on the MT. Considering the chances of having 3 groups incapable of healing (1 air burst, 1 doomfire, 1 running back from either one), having that 5th spot that only has to worry about a small chance of air burst (well, with rogues vanishing that is) or a looping doomfire helps immensely. I've definitely kept the tank up by myself quite a few times while the rest of the raid was busy, and without a doubt it has helped quite a lot for MT or melee healing. I can also keep tabs on the melee dps, which helps you avoid a doomfire + burst out of range melee death. Even if I eat a burst, it means that there should be 2 raged groups capable of continuing.

The main issues I find with being in the melee group is that I often spend quite a bit of time not doing anything after a burst, simply because of having a doomfire spawn in front of me as I run back. That, and there's been a wipe or two that the tank has died probably because I was more focused on getting back then healing first, figuring that it was better to get into position first. The dead zone of where the doomfires has to be crossed pretty carefully; there's no stopping after you get within 25yards of arch or so. I don't believe these problems outweigh the positive, though, as it still provides another group for a healer to stand in that doesn't take away from the 4 corners.

Between the pvp trinket and bubble, along with a tremor totem (our MT group is normally MT,rogue,war, shaman, me) the only real time I'll eat a doomfire is either from a stupid mistake on my part or a looping doomfire after wasting a bubble. Even if I do get an unlucky doomfire, a druid can toss hots on me and I'm at least getting a decent amount of mana back from spiritual attunement.


Each healer has to go into the fight with the thought that they are the only one healing the tank at any time, assuming they don't need to heal through any other raid damage. That said, every memeber of the raid needs to realize that any damage they take is taking away a healer's attention on the MT. Once the raid got used to not getting hit by doomfire as much, we had a lot more constant attention on the MT, and it became quite rare to have a MT death be the reason for a wipe.

I'm not 100% sure, but I also believe the 2 healers in each of our groups try to spread out a bit, to lower the chance of having a burst or doomfire make them both run away. With the increased decurse range, you gain quite a bit of leeway to have groups spread out a bit. There's been a few situations where we've had one healer in the group that was out of the cone of a doomfire, or out of the range of a burst and was capable of staying on the MT.

Anyhow, in terms of group and healer composition, 2 healers on each corner (one corner with one good healer if you run with 8), fear wards on priests or druids (curse + fear is a pretty nasty combo, it's enough to kill someone if nobody is capable of healing or decursing them in time), and try to just keep hots and spot heal on the people who get doomfired to keep them up. As long as you can get a good amount of hots on someone there's really no pressing need to keep them topped off, as long as they're above 80% or so they should be fine. MT always takes priority when there's no realistic danger to anyone, and just in general the fight isn't very demanding on mana as long as you have a SP. Also, with mobs that do slow, large attacks, there's no reason not to overheal if you feel the swingtimer coming back up.

People also need to realize that their PvP trinket is there for running-into-doomfire emergenices only (minus healing emergencies, of course), not to up their position on the meters. Actually in general the meters really don't matter, so much of this fight is so relative that the damage meters are more or less meaningless.

Being calm and attentive is the most important part of the fight; to make sure that there's no doomfires in the immediate area before a fear, to make sure that the raid stays healed along with MT attention, and that people can at least try to realize when other groups are just getting destroyed and they have to pick up for their healers on the tank. The fight's self-reliance is quite similar to c'thun; jobs regulated to 4 groups of 5, but every memeber of those groups must pay attention all the time, and should even be capable of overextending themselves to other groups as needed.
#992SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Tyrian
2) Does having a druid in melee group rather then he standing 20 yards away from Main Tank really helps to lighten the burden on the healers ? Reason why he isn't standing in the melee group is because he usually gets feared into doomfire and it turns up healing the druid rather then healing main tank.
I think you missed a key part here. The druid who stands with the melee must get some sort of fear protection or a strategy to deal with fear - and he doesnt necessarily need to be in the melee group to achieve that. If they arent in the melee group, someone IN the melee group can dispel them when fear comes. We use a ret pally to do this, but you could put a holy pally in the group for same effect. Refer to posts on the previous pages for more detailed explanation of this. The sequences of events is this:

Fear wards on melee shaman -> fear -> ret/holy pally gets tremor totem dispel -> ret/holy pally dispells druid. This all happens within 1-2 seconds, before your druid is in any danger. It might sound complicated but its all very easy and happens fast, providing your shaman/paladin know what they're doing.
#993SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Kyuki
quick question I havnt found an answer for yet. Is it still 10% everyone gets shielded up and you go take him down?

I've heard some people say it's 20% nowadays..
#994SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Yaelle
Originally Posted by Kyuki
quick question I havnt found an answer for yet. Is it still 10% everyone gets shielded up and you go take him down?

I've heard some people say it's 20% nowadays..
When we killed him yesterday, we still had to get him to 10%.
#995SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Kyuki
Thanks.
#996SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0rayijin
3rd kill for us last night, was the 5th attempt of the night I believe.

My mantra on this fight is "personal accountability". The people who typically die on this fight in my guild are ranged DPS and healers who aren't paying attention. Having the majority of our locks/mages being undead with a pvp trinket there's really no excuse to ever get feared into a doomfire. We made it very clear that getting hit by a doomfire if you have trinket or wotf up means you are not doing your job. Getting hit by a doomfire when not feared is grounds for an immediate raid kick. Excuses are not acceptable, everyone needs to be doing everything they can to avoid doomfire. On top of that, if you messed up and got hit, you MUST use a consumable to stay alive. If combat logs revealed that someone got hit by a doomfire then did not even use a healthstone/potion (doing everything they can to stay alive), they were immediately docked dkp.

Personal accountability is the only way to do this fight. Our second kill was done with 23 due to a lack of replacements for people we had to kick from the raid. However, once people got the message that dying for any reason was completely unacceptable, they played much more cautiously, resulting in clean, easy kills.

I also stole another quote from previously in this thread: "Melee dps's the boss. Melee dps's the boss. Melee dps's the boss. Range, stay alive." Once again, it's all about making sure everyone has their priorities straight.

Does this post seem repetitive? There is a reason for this, it's the best way to teach your players. Constantly remind them about their priority - stay alive. Don't get hit by doomfire. If you get hit, it's because you weren't playing perfectly. Play better next time. Surviving this fight it 100% based on your personal skill level. Don't accept excuses. Don't get hit by doomfire. Melee dps's the boss. You are personally responsible for your own survival.
#997SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Solomir
What are your guys' policies on rebirths, soulstones, and ankhs? Last night, we had a 11% wipe after the tank died at ~14%. I was the only shaman that ankhed and that was after sitting for about 20 seconds determining if it was worth it.

Is the risk of causing more cascading deaths worth the ressurection of a healer or a melee dps?
#998SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0rayijin
Originally Posted by Solomir
What are your guys' policies on rebirths, soulstones, and ankhs? Last night, we had a 11% wipe after the tank died at ~14%. I was the only shaman that ankhed and that was after sitting for about 20 seconds determining if it was worth it.

Is the risk of causing more cascading deaths worth the ressurection of a healer or a melee dps?
The only way you could be killed instantly after ressing is if you got immediately air bursted (by someone standing near you), you ressed in a doomfire (stupidity), or you get hit by a soul charge (stupidity). While getting air bursted by someone else isn't stupidity, it is preventable with the application of some brain cells. Hence if done wisely, there is zero chance of causing "cascading deaths" simply by taking a res.

Assuming you are not killed instantly upon ressing, you can pop a consumable, or if you're a shaman, NS heal yourself. This will take you out of the danger zone of "insta-death". A bandage or another healer afterwards will bring you up to a high HP level. There is zero risk of dying if battle resses/ankhs/soulstones are done properly.

I believe like many others in this thread that all deaths on this fight are 100% preventable through skill. The real question is, if you died in the first place, it means you messed up: Would you mess up again?
#999SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Baalzaman
A little trick we have found invaluable for preventing wipes on Archimonde - Flask of Petrification.

If all else fails, if a Doomfire or a Grip is ticking on you and there is no way you are going to be able to save yourself (pot/HS or other 'oh-shit' abilities are on cooldown or out of range of healers/decursers or whatever) hit this.

It will take you out of the game for 1 minute and remove all buffs but if the choice is between living and dying then this works. Cheaper than wiping your raid too
#1000SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Joy
Originally Posted by SikYi
Firstly, i am from the same guild as grapes.

I want to elaborate more on what grapes said and what is the difference with our strat from the strat in EJ with the 4 corners method I will it list out as follows

1) Referencing from post #739 under archimonde thread, Tyrian of Blackrock, the difference between our 4 corners and the picture is that we position ourself slightly near the mountain which is located top right of the picture near the tree trunk location. Moreover, the area is quite small and not many areas to run. Lets say for instance the doomfire chased a person towards the hill, does anyone noticed that the doomfire will change it direction if the person is standing on top of the hill ? However we do encounter several times when a person is behind the tree and the doomfire is aiming at him, it sort of change target and treat as if the current target isn't in line of sight. Is there any relevant post that i might have miss out regarding the doomfire and those people who are standing on the hill ?

2) Does having a druid in melee group rather then he standing 20 yards away from Main Tank really helps to lighten the burden on the healers ? Reason why he isn't standing in the melee group is because he usually gets feared into doomfire and it turns up healing the druid rather then healing main tank.

3) During our first few tries, we split the 8 healers into the 4 cluster groups and 1 into the melee group and they will move out if they are being chased by doomfire. The problem with this strategy is that if one being chased by doomfire and another being airbursted which doesn't solve the MT from dying. How do most of you guys resolve this problem?

In the end we tried to split the healers into 1 per cluster and 4 healers standing in the middle of each groups but the doomfire caused more havoc n thus cutting off healers n the MT death issue was not resolved

Most of your questions have been answered a couple of suggestions I would make that I haven't seen so far:

Make sure your MT healers communicate with the raid, we have been using 4pt for months and don't have problems with MT deaths because the healers yell out when multiple are airburst/ or out of range 'cause of doomfires. This gives 'raid' healers plenty of time to get a heal in or gives the tank himself warning to HS/LS/SW/Trinket, hell a shadow priest might be in range to shield.

That being said your WWS shows 10 healers so there should really be no problem assigning 5 healers full time on the tank and as long as they are near a decurser they can be independent of groups and minimize the risk of multiple getting hit by the same burst.

Melee, melee, melee. But support your Melee. Have 2 priests communicate with your melee groups Shaman so that he is constantly fear warded or has his PvP trinket available. A Shaman breaking/being immune to fear and manually using grounding is much better than waiting for up to 4.99*s on a pulse (Also means he can have SoE down the whole fight). It will remove the chance of melee getting feared in to doomfire and it will give them 30+ extra seconds of DPS over the fight.
#1001SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Grapes
Originally Posted by Tyrian
I think you missed a key part here. The druid who stands with the melee must get some sort of fear protection or a strategy to deal with fear - and he doesnt necessarily need to be in the melee group to achieve that. If they arent in the melee group, someone IN the melee group can dispel them when fear comes. We use a ret pally to do this, but you could put a holy pally in the group for same effect. Refer to posts on the previous pages for more detailed explanation of this. The sequences of events is this:

Fear wards on melee shaman -> fear -> ret/holy pally gets tremor totem dispel -> ret/holy pally dispells druid. This all happens within 1-2 seconds, before your druid is in any danger. It might sound complicated but its all very easy and happens fast, providing your shaman/paladin know what they're doing.

I think this would be the critical issue for my guild here, we initially had a restore druid in the melee group for decurse and MT healing duty but he kept dying from doomfire. (We did not fw him or fw the enhance shammy who died alot also in his group)

So we end up trying to put healers in between the 4 points but they mostly got chased by doomfire/unlucky airburst combos and as a result too many healers got cut off and MT died very often.

I think we might revert back to the original 4point strat posted way back in this thread on page 30 with 2healers per group and maybe 1-2more in melee group WITH fear protection full time. With this setup, even with 2groups being chased by doomfire and 1 getting airbursted, there is still another group with and the melee group within range totalling up to 3-4 healers being able to get on the MT immediately.

Coupled with the MT healers using vent more actively to communicate as mentioned by Joy and having the entire raid take minimal damage from proper doomfire control, I think the chances of success will be increased. Thx for the various advices given. Cheers.
#1002SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Vonwen
I really don't get why you love melee so much on this boss. They are indeed less vulnerable than ranged to doomfires, but will very often get air bursted. The rogues have useful timers but they might want to save them for a worst case scenario, instead of using them to gain mobility.

If I look at my Archimonde kill yesterday, I end up first on damage as well as on dispel. Much like every week. If I had an advise to give about the lineup, it would be to stack chamans and mages as much as possible. A good mage just can't die here, he provides decursing and will have a dps activity much higher than other classes who have no other way of coping with the air burst than just running, and hoping not to be prevented from getting back by a doomfire.

Anyway, this is a quite fun event, it just requires a lot of attention, but I'd say it's still less difficult than Illidari Council. Just remember that the more you dps, the less you will face stupid deaths.
#1003SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Viv
Originally Posted by Baalzaman
A little trick we have found invaluable for preventing wipes on Archimonde - Flask of Petrification.

If all else fails, if a Doomfire or a Grip is ticking on you and there is no way you are going to be able to save yourself (pot/HS or other 'oh-shit' abilities are on cooldown or out of range of healers/decursers or whatever) hit this.

It will take you out of the game for 1 minute and remove all buffs but if the choice is between living and dying then this works. Cheaper than wiping your raid too
Brilliant
Can you still be targeted by airburst while petrified?
#1004SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0amethyst

DPS warrior can have almost 100% dps uptime on Archimonde and I regularly top damage done in this fight by a significant margin.

Fear? Zerker rage.
Airburst? Intercept.

Pure sword to legs action for a warrior. That's why they're good on this fight.

Every melee class has its strength and weaknesses on Archimonde, but I still highly doubt they own so much (or maybe consider changing your mages).
#1006SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0rayijin
Originally Posted by Vonwen
Yeah well ok, I thought mostly of rogues, and also shamans/druids ;p But yes you got a point about the fury warrior, it's just not so easy to stack, I believe most guilds have one, maybe two ;p They're still taking more damage from the fire if they fuck up, and have no survival timer to use in this case, making them more fragile than rogues. Every melee class has its strength and weaknesses on Archimonde, but I still highly doubt they own so much (or maybe consider changing your mages).
Warriors have defensive stance and high HP pools to start with to survive doomfire. It doesn't hit melee unless it loops completely around anyways, and you'll be in range of nearly every healer.

Intercept assures near 100% dps uptime on the boss (it does bug/resist sometimes though, meaning you have to run back).

Our kills have always been 2 rogues at the top, followed by me (arms for the first kill, tanked the 2nd kill, prot dps for 3rd kill).

Still, I wouldn't suggest more than 4-5 melee dps, simply because you'd get more air bursts on them, even when spread into 2 groups.

Highest dps? Your most skilled player, but if you use a strat like ours where the range's first priority is to avoid doomfire and decurse, some type of melee.

#1008SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
He would have to be using a 'spread out all around Arch, dodge doomfires' strat to be that high on dps. Either that or his melee are terrible. The results sound impressive, but they come with a cost you didnt mention - its risky for range to try do that much dps - especially for players new to the fight or who haven't been farming Archimonde. Guilds that are learning the fight probably shouldnt try to copy you.

I dont think theres any need for range to dps much. Our melee (3 rogues, shaman, ret pally, fury warrior) account for ~60% of total damage to archimonde on a typical fight, theres just no need for anyone else to take any risks to push some extra dps - he'll still die well before the enrage. But again, if your guild is advanced and players know the fight in and out - people can afford to try new things like that

To repeat a comment earlier: Our mages (and other ranged dps arent much higher) usually do ~300-600 dps on archimonde and sometimes will do less damage than the protection warrior mt'ing him. Perfect! As long as they stay alive and decurse the whole time - they did their job. Archimonde will still die in 7-8 minutes regardless.

Melee dps the boss -> Range dance around Archimonde -> 6-10 minutes later, he falls over and dies.

#1009SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Jalhar
Originally Posted by Vonwen
Yeah well ok, I thought mostly of rogues, and also shamans/druids ;p But yes you got a point about the fury warrior, it's just not so easy to stack, I believe most guilds have one, maybe two ;p They're still taking more damage from the fire if they fuck up, and have no survival timer to use in this case, making them more fragile than rogues. Every melee class has its strength and weaknesses on Archimonde, but I still highly doubt they own so much (or maybe consider changing your mages).
Or maybe you should consider changing your melees ? ^^
95% of the players here confirm the fact that melees kill Archimonde, you are probably the exception that confirms the rule.

We often bring 1 group of melees for Archimonde, 2 rogues, 2 warrs and 1 enhancement shammy, all in the same group. They do around 60% of the damage if not more, all over 1k dps, sometimes reaching 1.3k+. Tremor totem pretty much annihilates the fear for rogues, CloS allow rogues to get rid of doomfire, and warriors take it very rarely. Only the shaman may require a bit more healing (especially if he lands grounding instead of tremor as our did last night ).

As for the fact they'll get air bursted more, air burst being random and having a casting time allowing players to spread a bit before it lands, I don't see why it would be the case. And even if air burst, sprint or intercept back.

As for mages being top dps, that means you use a very risky strat, unless you take 5+ mages. Dispells should be done by mages primary, as druids are quite busy healing and hotting what they can - and there is no way a mage can be top dps using so many GCD on decursing unless other dps classes don't do their job properly (I don't think a mage can beat a good affliction warlock as well for example)

Ironically though, I find it much more enjoyable playing archimonde on my mage as someone who just runs around decursing and watching doomfires - its the first real fight where dps doesnt matter, why not enjoy it?

But alot of new guilds come to this thread asking 'Whats the best way to learn/attempt archimonde?' or "How to we make our strat as safe/retard-proof as possible' and they need to take comments like that with a grain of salt.

#1011SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Latcho
It ist our 3rd week now, and the best try was 17% in the first week, we didnt get pass 50% in the second and now 11% last week. Its a really anoying fight, we didnt use a 4-point strategy, more a random spread-out of people, with 4 mt
healers(mostly 2 paladin/2 priests) behind the mt and 5 raidhealers, while everyone will spread in a semi-circle behind him. We had in the first trys only 3 decursers(1 Druid/2 Mages) but now we have 3 Mages/1 Druid all the time. We got about 3-4 shamans(1 enhancer/1 elemental/2 restoration). The rest of the raid setup is mostly 3-4 warlocks/1-2 hunters/4 melees.

We have only the mt healers fearwarded(works fine, we have mostly 2 holy priests/3 shadows) and with the pvp insignia we dont really have problems with the fear. I`m the mt and stance dance ist not a problem. Our main problem is the doomfire and the fact that mt healers have to run at a point to avoid df. Thats why in these <20% trys the mt mostly dies. Our tank position is about 40 yards from the mountain(buff spot). Im thinking to try out the 4-point strategy, but i dont know how much will that take until we are at this point what we reached now. In the description the 4-p strategy is very nice to read but im not so sure if that will work so fine for us.

Another problem is, the trys we make are very unrealiable: 1 try= 40%, then 5-6 trys with 90/80/90 and so on. I really don't want to get the kill in a "lucky try" and every weak afterwards to hope again. So do you have any ideas that would help us, or should we just try the 4-p strategy?
#1012SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Dustwhisper
3p strategy, 4p strategy or cone strategy.. It all comes down to the same things: Quick and stable healing, fast decurse, no stupid airburst deaths and correct handling of fires and fears.

Quick and stable healing?
- Make sure that enough healers at any time can reach the tank which usually means make sure noone is stupid enough to drag a doomfire all around the place effectivly blocking healers. Also hots (gogo restodruids here) are awesome.

Fast decurse?
- Good positioning by mages is key to that, if more than 1 group can decurse their own group AND reach the melee/tanks it's very good.

Airbursts?
- Use tear sooner than later..

Doomfires?
- Lead them away from raid and be adaptive in where you stand, you can shift the position of a group based on doomfire so as it can still dps boss and heal mt.

Fears?
- Trinket/WOTF/Totem/Fearward. With all those things you shouldn't really have much problems with fears. The easiest way is of course to have a shaman in each group that is lightning quick and have ace timing on putting down the totem so it pulses with the fear-cast, fearward can save the tank. Always make sure to top of tank before fear aswell.
#1013SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Vonwen
We never tried the 4p strategy, I think (as I did in my first post on this thread) that every raid will eventually come up with a strategy that works, regarding the lineup, the individuals strengths and weaknesses and the personnality of the raid leader.

Basically, we raid Archimonde with 4 mages when we can, 3 if we can't. 1 resto druid, rarely 2 (mainly because we only have one very active, having 2 druids would definately help on him), all the decursers are wisely spread and marked with a raid icon, so that we never lose time running after people, especially (and I want to stress on this point) with the new 40 yards decurse range, which helps a lot. Groups try to stay together, around the totem (when there's a totem), and don't hesitate to move if the position has too much fire on it.

What about melees then ? Well, they do not indeed try to spread and avoid the air burst, because doing so might endanger the MT if someone fucks up (and it happens, if noone ever fucks up Archimonde would be easier than Rage ), or on the other hand might run into a fire behind, which is also not suitable. So yes their dps is limited by their uptime, whereas mages basically only lose some GCDs decursing and blinking through fires. On the last kill, I ended up first on dispels with a total of 10, I believe the fight lasted around 6 minutes, the second was the druid with 9, and a mage with 8. It's not THAT much, 10 GCDs are worth 15 seconds of casting, and the time lost by people running back after an air burst is much more than that (even for a fury warrior I think).

Affli locks should do great also, it's just that when we don't have 5 chamans, they are in the MT groups, first for imping him, second because they are much less vulnerable to fire than other classes, being healed more efficientely and being able to drain life while waiting for some healing.

To the one who said your mages do 300-600 dps, well that seems very low to me, it's important to survive, but my credo is that the more you dps, the less it lasts, and my experience as a raid leader is that something will _always_ happen, sooner or later. If you dps a lot, that eliminates the later. Last time I killed it, Assessment told me around 1000 dps, which is still quite low for a mage, but there's not much reasons to do less, of course except if you're being really unlucky with fires.

When a friend trying this boss asks me for advice, there are just few basic things I can tell : focus on survival, adapt the strategy and positions to your very particular raid, and try to shorten the fight as much as possible, as long as you're not jeopardizing your survival.
#1014SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Jalhar
Besides Vonwen, there is a high difference between dps and damage done, as some mods calculate the dps according to your activity. So you can have 1k dps, if you spend half of the fight running around decursing and avoiding doomfire, you'll have less damage done than the warrior with 800 dps who has 90% dps uptime. All our mages are around 1k dps on Archimonde, but with perhaps half the damage done by melees, who have 90+% dps uptime. (I'm sorry, but melee have higher dps uptime on this boss than ranged if both play well - mages have to stand still to dps, and they'll HAVE to move to avoid doomfire or to go decursing the guy who got air burst or whatever, whereas the melees can just keep dpsing moving around Archimonde to avoid doomfires).

Of course, if you don't give totems to your melees, nothing I can do about that =)
#1015SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Vonwen
Yep yep I know how the mods work :p Well I guess each raid has its particularities ;p Our melee group is usually rogue*3 + enhance chaman + feral. If we have enough totems, we switch the feral with a fury warrior (or we just add him if we only have 2 rogues). But mages being able to output some good dps isn't the main reason why you want some, it's basically because decurse (win) + blink (more win) + maybe frost (super win although less dps). They just own the survivability contest within the ranged dps if they are not too dumb, and allow your druids to focus on the healing. Well at least if works for us

#1016SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach
Whew, so basically 3 days on this guy so far...and it keeps getting more frustrating. We've been working with a 4 point strat. The first hour or so of each night is people remembering what they are doing. Few deaths to craters, few deaths to doomfire, few deaths to curses. Then we get that out of the way. Then for the next few hours we die to a couple of different things. The worst thing we are dealing with is MT death. At some point during the fight, 2 groups are out with fire, one group got airbursted and the last group just cant hold the MT up. Usually the first time this happens he uses his tricks to stay alive,t hen it happens again at some point and he dies.


It seems like if we got luckky he might die, but itd be purely up to chance. Using a 3 point strat only seems to aggravate this too many people being out of the fight issue. So, my only other option is to try a cone strat, and I havnt been able to find too much information on it. I've looked around for vids, and most i find for cone strat seem to be before the doomfire change. Are peopel still using cone strat still? Below I'll list my few fears and some questions I have about it.

Do people dodge doomfire or run out? It seems that straight up dodging doomfire is easy for some and hard for others, if its coming near you do you just run away like 4 points? Or try to swerve sideways a bit and dodge it? My other possible solution is that everyone in that area runs back until you figure out who its targetting, and then that person keeps running back.

In the case of that person running back, how do you handle decurse for him? Does it become an issue to the point that a mage runs back with him? Or is it really not so bad?

Is it safer to have the MT's back to the group, or have him on the opposite side? Bosskillers screams that you must have the MT face the boss away from the raid....but I cant find a logical reason for that, and it seems if the melee is opposite the rest of the raid, that theyd get doomfire trailed to them less often.

Positioning. If we have him near the mountain, does the mountain kill doomfires? If we place him near the lake(not close enough for him to get angry and nuke the raid obviously), do people use it to get doomfire off them? Is that a useful strat at all for people to run and take a swim? Are they easily healable there?

I think thats everything, long boring day at work today with not much to do, so I'll be trying to think of any other questions I have.

#1020SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Jalhar
Originally Posted by Vonwen
Yep yep I know how the mods work :p Well I guess each raid has its particularities ;p Our melee group is usually rogue*3 + enhance chaman + feral. If we have enough totems, we switch the feral with a fury warrior (or we just add him if we only have 2 rogues). But mages being able to output some good dps isn't the main reason why you want some, it's basically because decurse (win) + blink (more win) + maybe frost (super win although less dps). They just own the survivability contest within the ranged dps if they are not too dumb, are allow your druids to focus on the healing. Well at least if works for us
Oh, I don't argue on the fact that mages are one of the best classes to take for Archimonde (on paar with druids, and ofc around 10 000 miles behind shamans, we did it once with 2 shammies - never again), I just highly doubt that mages can be top damage done on Archimonde on a regular basis (ie. in more than a few guilds and more than once)

About the MT dying problem, are you sure druids and priests do whatever they can to keep hots ticking on the main tank, especially before a fear ?

I usually tell paladins to focus on the main tank, shamans to heal the melees and their groups, and druids and priests to heal their groups + hotting the MT. In this fight, because players have to move a lot, they also must be very flexible in their tasks : every healer is at some point a tank healer or a group healer, and each healer should always keep an eye on the MT (the use of /focus is very useful).

We use a 4 points strategy for the initial minute, after that doomfires usually break our setup and each group lives his own "life" around his decurser, with some interactions with groups in range of heals & decursers.

Tell your MT to not to be shy on cooldowns, he has a lot and some are usable more than once. Shit will happen, especially during your first kills, and he'll have to live a few seconds on his own (be it someone dying, a whole group feared in doomfire, etc). Communication between the healers and the MT is very important so the tank can be prepared .

#1023SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Zindel
Originally Posted by Lambach
Wow Web Stats

This is the second half of the 2nd night. None of our usual WWS'ers were there last night.

MT is in full t5 sans hat, which he replaced with the chicken hat out of ZA. He's using ZA boots, Kaz' sheild, and autoblocker and moroe's for trinkets, he logged out after switching to pvp, so his armory wouldnt be too helpful.

Edit: MT is usually incredibly good at surviving, but we are getting stuck with fire groups out for pretty extended periods of time, and an airbursted team is out for at least 10 seconds while running back.
There are a lot of things you could do to improve your tank's mitigation.

- Avoidance wins on Archimonde, assuming you can keep 20k hp or more. If you look at the report I linked above, it shows me having avoided 72.7% of Archimonde's attacks, while Athen avoided 56% in that last pull. He took less damage per hit but I'm assuming that's because of lack of curse of recklessness on Archimonde. I'd get rid of the autobuckler for another avoidance trinket too.

- Shaman in the tank group, we usually have the tank/elemental shaman/3 healers in one group until we outgeared the fight. Grace of Air is a good bit of dodge, tremor to break fears on healers, and a resto druid here allows more healing on the tank.

- Ancestral Fortitude uptime. There's enough downtime for healer shamans that they can proc it on the tank using rank 1 LHW, 25% armor is huge.

- Cooldowns. Assuming scarab/moroe's, you'll be able to pop one cooldown every fear for 7 fears in a row. Usually you'll dodge/parry enough hits that you don't need cooldowns, but having scarab (3min cd) moroes (2min cd) last stand (8min cd) shield wall (30min cd) means you should have enough cooldowns to survive bad fears and bad airbursts.
Last edited by Zindel : 12/20/07 at 1:23 PM.
#1024SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach

Our healer shaman(xmas month has us down to one atm) rarely has any downtime. And if hes running out to avoid doomfire, ancestral is going to completely fall off. Although I imagine with him and 2 priests, its up fairly often just from normal spells.

Often if this synched witih fear, he'd blow CD's but it was already GG because of his lack of previous heals.

I dont mean to sound unnapreciative with that last bit, just wasn't really the issue we were having. Just seemed that there was a high chance for many healers to be out of range a fair portion of the time.

Edit: Perhaps however you work that shaman +3 healer group is the solution.
#1025SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Noressa

Since the fear is cleansable, just have 1-2 cleansers and have them in the totem group, they can cleanse it from others if it's an issue.
#1026SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach

#1027SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Zindel
The tank doesn't need tremor, just GoA. Tremor can be dropped down at the back for the healers.

I can't imagine having only 1-2 out of 8 healers in range of the tank for any extended period of time, though. Perhaps it's more of a problem of positioning the healers more. We use 4 points to start the fight. The 8 healers are spread 2 healer in each spot (we used to have 3 healers in the mt group, 2 healers in other 2 groups, and 1 healer in the last group without tremor). Usually one, maybe two, sides get rocked by fires and whatnot. But that still leaves 4 healers free to heal the tank at any given moment.

I recall a few of our wipes happening because the three healers in the tank group stood next to each other and got air bursted together. I'd emphasize spreading out especially for healers, it's bad to have more than one healer get hit by airbursted if it can be easily prevented by moving a few yards away from the air bursted target before hand.

Our tank deaths were during fears until we fixed them with proper use of tremors, I assumed you had the same problems.

Edit: The tank group was elemental shaman/tank/3 healers, not resto shaman. Was a typo.
#1028SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Noressa
Hm, we run with a 3 point strat, 1 healer in the middle and a couple healers with each side group. That way there's always the middle healer with the tank (unless airburst) and then ~2 minimum from 1 of the side groups. All 3 groups are never running away since the doomfires are "confined" to the 3 points we give them, there isn't much room for them to spread out. The middle healer is a druid so swiftmend and NS are available for spike healing fast and we've rarely needed more. Then again, we usually run really healer heavy due to who is online and can keep themselves alive well. (9-10 healers for our kills.)
#1029SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach
Hmm...
We were having issues the first day with the airburst. One player in the group would get airbursted, then might get a curse, and die on the way back. (could be fixed by the mage running back for sure, but some nubbery was happening). Or the decurser got airbursted, and while running back someone in teh group got it and took massive dmg. Or sometimes the group was spread out and got seperated by fire pretty badly.

To counter this each team stayed on top of each other so they got airbursted all together, and could decurse on the run back. Found a couple vids where they used that so it seemed a viable option.

Would you suggest a more liberal spreading out, and decurser on that side(or other sides?) just pick up the slack? Should only one person be getting hit with airbursts per group(except melee of course)?
#1030SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Noressa
We keep everyone on top of each other, and the whole group on the decurser. If someone gets airburst, the whole group runs in for a group hug. You ~can not~ be separated from a decurser. If you die to grip it's your fault from being too far from a decurser. It's not a dps race, don't die from falling, let your decurser keep you in range so they can do their job. This prevented some deaths for us. Yes, you miss out on a few precious seconds of DPS, but unless you're melee, it's no real loss.
#1031SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Baalzaman
We have killed Archimonde 4 times now, 2 shotted him this week.

Our strategy is 4 point, with each groups decurser being marked with a raid icon. Each group is instructed to stack on their decurser at all times.

If a doomfire spawns in your quarter the entire group runs way. If a group member gets airburst the entire group gets punted. The idea behind this is so that no matter what the group sticks together, doesn't get spread out so no-one is ever out of range of decursing and heals.

Key point with this strategy is make sure that at least one person in each group is a loudmouth on vent/teamspeak. That person needs to be yelling at his group to run away when a doomfire is heading their way and do so consistently and _early_.

Archimonde is all about communication and staying alive. DPS is secondary
#1032SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach
Thanks but that is exactly what I outlined in my question, and is already exactly what we are doing, and it isnt working.
#1033SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Noressa
Where is it failing though? If everyone is getting airburst with their decurser, is that an issue? Is it people failing on tears? Is it too many healers airburst and tanks dying? At what point is it failing? 4 point strat failed for us because too many groups got divided by doomfires, so we controlled that a bit more and it worked. What's the thing killing your groups? Chain reactions from soul charges aside.
#1034SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Lambach

Whew, so basically 3 days on this guy so far...and it keeps getting more frustrating. We've been working with a 4 point strat. The first hour or so of each night is people remembering what they are doing. Few deaths to craters, few deaths to doomfire, few deaths to curses. Then we get that out of the way. Then for the next few hours we die to a couple of different things. The worst thing we are dealing with is MT death. At some point during the fight, 2 groups are out with fire, one group got airbursted and the last group just cant hold the MT up. Usually the first time this happens he uses his tricks to stay alive,t hen it happens again at some point and he dies.

#1035SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Karmen
We have about a day and a half work in on him so far so I can't say with certainty that what we are doing is better. But the first day we did have an issue with the MT dying, it pretty much ended every attempt we had. What we ended up doing is having basically every hybrid in the raid throw on their healing gear. The 8 normal healers in the raid had the sole job of healing the MT, the 3-4 hybrids that we had were solely responsible for their group. We only had 2 shamans in the raid so we also had our shadow priests dps out of shadow form so they could mass dispel the fears quicker. Lastly we also adjusted the 4 point positioning a bit by using only 180-270 degrees of the circle around Archimonde. This allows for more cross-healing and it seemed more healers closer to the MT at all times as the 2 groups that were about even with Archimonde could run away from the doomfire yet still be in range of the tank.

We did not have a single attempt after those changes end because of the MT dying. The only issue now is that when a soul charge goes off there is a 3 second stun and people were getting overrun by the doomfire while stunned. So basically once we get people better prepared for soul charges we should be able to down him, hopefully tonight.
#1036SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0â™¦ Noressa
Lambach, part of the issue is that the "best" varies from guild to guild, so the most we can offer is what works for us, what failed for us and let people glean what they can for them. The later bosses have a few "set" things (avoid doomfire, don't die from fall damage) but everything else is completely open. That's why a lot of what you will see is re-hashing. Yes, I read your original post and the follow up posts. If you'll notice I added new information of what we do (again, this is just what worked for us, every guild is different.) We stack more healers, have more healers per group and 1 healer with 2 instants in the middle. I'm sorry that it doesn't give you a specific answer, but people can only offer you the information they have available.

Summary:
1) There is always 1 group in range of the tank, I'd expect this to hold true for 3 or 4 point strategies. There are typically 2-3 healers per group.
2) There is always 1 healer with melee for decursing and healing on the MT.
3) Healing is honestly very light in this fight. If people are taking doomfire, they're not running enough.
4) Keep a decurser always around your groups. 40 yard range means no one should die to Grip.
5) Track decursers (WWS, Recount) and make sure people aren't trying to sneak in DPS when people are dying to grip. Decursing is a higher priority.
6) Cratering. There is no excuse. Give people a deadline to learn it, then replace them. There is no reason for someone to crater. Jump off cliffs and learn your latency to avoid "lag".

You mention different things, I can't imagine what those would be. If you have good magic decursers, put at least one in a tremor group and have them cleanse other healers who are feared, this should mitigate your tanks spikes during fears. Other then that it's just practice.
#1037SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
That night melee was getting doomfired a lot probably once an attempt or so, at least. People were really bad at letting melee know it was creeping up on them.
Stop worrying about your MT healing until you fix this.

Communication for doomfires and avoiding them is directly related to MT healing. If people get doomfires because the raid 'sucks at communication' then all those heals diverted off the MT to them will increase the chance your MT will die. Thats not the healers fault, its the dps's. That fury warrior, who ate 16 doomfires - hes a good example of the problem guilds need to fix before they question their healers. Either the communication needs to be better to warn melee or the players themself are just too slow or too busy dpsing to notice doomfires around them (big no no).

So if your MT dies thru lack of heals, its not necessarily a healer problem - it could very well be a dps-arent-avoiding-doomfires-enough problem.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/21/07 at 7:26 AM.
#1038SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Yaelle
Absolutely true. Also I think Archimonde is a lot about mistakes happening and getting in bad situations later.
Often someone will tell you, how he had no chance of avoiding being killed but his mistake or from someone else happened a lot earlier.
#1039SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
Often someone will tell you, how he had no chance of avoiding being killed but his mistake or from someone else happened a lot earlier.
"It was bad luck" and "There was nothing I can do". How many times have raid leaders heard someone say either or both of those lines after their death?

Most of the time, people who say one of those are either wrong - or flat out lying.

#1040SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Kirion
If you are using 4 point tactic and you have problems with tank healing, bring 9 healers and spread them better between groups. Also ask tank to use avoidance gear. We had same problem in past.
#1041SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Yaelle
During an evening on Archimonde (8 kills and haven't one shot him yet although we do clear Hyjal in one evening) I VERY rarely get doom-fired.

In reaction to mistakes that will make you, or someone else pay later, pay attention to what can/will be happening in the near future (fear cool down, uptime of PvP-trinket or abilities you might have).

Bad luck is, when he and his abilities seem to after you most of the time and you spend more time on counter reacting than anything else.

- If I get airbursted I look at that fear cool down and decide whether it's better to stay away and save that trinket cool down. The only time I can do decent dps is when that trinket is up, not worrying about fear. When he does fear I can get lucky and resist (which as a feral Druid happens a lot) or just don't get feared near some fire.

- As soon as I used the insignia I switch to "extremely careful-mode" for as long as its on cool down and move to a safe location 10 seconds before fear cool down wears off.

This is not really meant to be as guidance, only as example, that upon strategies, while learning Archimonde, raid members will develop class-specific behaviors of their own, all of which will improve progress on him.

Later we got pretty cool about soulcharges as well.... a total of 7 dead on one kill still seems pretty much insane to me.
#1042SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Vandermonde
What have people found best works for catching your high liability members up to the norm? Is it effective to assign people doing really poorly a swimming buddy that seems to be having more success to follow around, or do the differences produced by fear resists and fear run direction make that implausible? I don't think there's anything more that can be said in terms of "this fight is entirely about staying alive; you cannot realistically hit the enrage if you stay alive; it is mostly your responsibility to keep yourself alive" than has already been repeated several times. Obviously people are going to learn sooner or later, but what incentives, comments, or instructions have you had the most success in speeding up the process with?

At what point do you just sit a piece of dps with/without a replacement?
#1043SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Covertghost
What do you mean, if he craters twice, sit him if it's for a first kill.

Make sure you let him know how the mechanics work, give him practice with tear on the large hill. But this fight is all about survivability. How long you can survive without a heal, do you have the situational awareness to avoid fires, and see when they're about to hit you is the crux of this fight.
#1044SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0hellenkeller
When we were learning the fight, we spent the first night wiping to doomfires and shoddy movement. As Tyrian said, a lot of people told our raid leaders that there was "nothing they could do" to prevent their death. We needed to create an attitude adjustment within the raid. The second night of attempts, we told the group that every death was avoidable, and they needed to treat them as such. They needed to do everything in their power to stay alive. For example, a rogue using COS to DPS and then getting doomfired 30 seconds later was an avoidable death, because he used his cooldown in a frivolous manner rather than using his cooldowns defensively. The same applied to PvP trinket usage, and various other examples. Try to stress the fact that death can always be prevented, and lay into people who die. It might facilitate better results.
#1045SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Tyrian
Obviously people are going to learn sooner or later, but what incentives, comments, or instructions have you had the most success in speeding up the process with?
When we learnt the fight I asked every person who died first (and second) on vent to explain in detail (to the whole raid listening) what killed them after the wipe. With 25 people listening closely, would you be a little embarrassed to admit to them that you died stupidly by saying "I cratered" or "I was feared into a doomfire and forgot to trinket "? Make it policy to ask the first death player on vent to explain how they died and talk about ways they could have avoided it.

The other thing is for your raid leaders to realise 'It was bad luck' and 'there was nothing I could do' are not acceptable excuses for dying - they are simply a coverup for player mistakes almost all the time. Let the raid know that almost all deaths on Archimonde are the result of a player mistake. If your raid and raid leader believe Archimonde is just 'a luck fight' then expect lots of bad luck.

Use WWS: Upload your full night of attempts and check which players used 'Super Healing Potions', 'Healthstones' and 'Purification potions' and 'Fire Protection Potions'. You could reward those players who do but more importantly - tell people that these pots should always be used if you risk dying. Also check on WWS who received the doomfire debuffs.

I read another poster say he used bonus DKP for every soul charge they recovered from. I think this is a great idea, but we don't use DKP to try it If your using dkp, you could also setup bonuses for all players that receive less than X number of doomfires for a night of attempts. Make sure you tell players not to suicide in them during wipes if you try this. If you gave an attractive DKP bonus for everyone who averaged less than X doomfires per Y attempts - im sure it would be a nice incentive to people to avoid them just that little bit more.

Also, if theres people that just cant learn the fight in a reasonable time - tell them they will have to sit out. Dont put 24 people through the pain of stupid wipes because nobodys got the guts to sit that 1 bad player out.
Last edited by Tyrian : 12/23/07 at 5:59 AM.
#1046SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0hellenkeller
We ended up giving negative DKP to everyone who cratered; that seemed to do the trick and cause people to use Tears of the Goddess early, rather than at the last minute, risking death. We have one shot Archi two weeks in a row now, the 4 corner strategy really holds people accountable and facilitates the learning process. If someone gets separated from his group and dies, it is his fault. Make sure your raiders know that every time they die first, it is their fault, and have them explain their death.

The fight is just an accountability check. If everyone stays in their group and uses cooldown defensively, the learning curve isn't very severe.
#1047SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Krazen
Originally Posted by Tyrian

Use WWS: Upload your full night of attempts and check which players used 'Super Healing Potions', 'Healthstones' and 'Purification potions' and 'Fire Protection Potions'. You could reward those players who do but more importantly - tell people that these pots should always be used if you risk dying. Also check on WWS who received the doomfire debuffs.
This helps a lot IMO. To repeat a comment made earlier in the thread, everyone who dies first (other than possibly the MT) better have used a healthstone and potion first, or they have a lot of explaining to do.
#1048SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0
Edited onPatch 2.3.0		Beats
We use the 4 point strategy and have a couple kills under out belt with last week being a one shot (even had 1 Soul Charge).

We had to spend about 2 full raids worth of time on him to get him down and the turning point was when I, as raid leader, told everyone to not dps and just see if we can get to the 10 minute enrage. I wanted people to understand that surviving is the most important thing....even though I had said it a million times, it didn't register with some people for some reason. After it appeared we could survive doomfires and air bursts and everything else, we had "light dps" attempts and killed him 3-4 pulls later.

Here are some of the keys to us killing him:
1-Full healthstones, Fire protection potions, Health potions, PVP Trinket---all necessary 100% of attempts...People need to learn to find ways to save their own ass at all costs.
2-Shadow priests in healing gear and normal form only putting their DOTs up when it is "safe" to...Their fear wards and HOTs are more important here...If they're in MF'ing, they're going to wipe you....THIS ISN'T A DPS RACE. Tell your shadow priests they are healers first and foremost and then putting occasional DOTs up if everyone around them is topped off.
3-Communication is so incredibly important...if there is a doomfire even looking like it might go near melee, let them know way early. You have to promote an aura of paranoia in everyone's head.
4-We've yet to even come close to the enrage and 75-80% of our dps is from melee. Ranged groups job(s) is to stay alive and try to "kite" the doomfires away.(Though it doesn't seem that the "kiting" works, melee can tell the difference of when ranged groups are side stepping doomfires or running/kiting them far away....Seriously)
5-Soul Charge does not mean you're going to wipe...If someone dies, keep vent calm and immediately tell everyone to make sure everyone else is topped off and prepare to heal immediately after the Soul Charge/silence. Our first kill had 3 Soul Charges and wasn't all that crazy even. It's just a matter of your healers being ready and no one panicing and being ready to heal themself with potion/healstones/bandages...whatever it takes.
6-FAST decursing. There is no reason that curses should tick more than once on anyone in your raid. No excuses here. If you have a decurser that fails consistantly, then find a way to replace them. This isn't a fight you can "carry" a bad player...especially in such a key position. Our mages and moonkin are typically well under Main Tank dps because their primary responsibility is to decurse.

Most importantly, do attempts with zero dps until everyone can survive until the enrage timer. This will help your healers the most because healing on the main tank can be tricky if multiple groups are "out." Once you can make it 10 minutes, add in melee dps and "light" ranged dps...You'll see him going down that night.
Last edited by Beats : 12/30/07 at 12:33 PM.
#1049SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Malrix
Originally Posted by Lambach
Quoted from my original post above. I'm really happy that people are trying to help me out and give advice, but not reading any of my original questions and just rehashing how you do things is confusing at best.
My advice would be to just give up on kiting the fire. Reliably kiting the fire is sketchy at best. I would still use a 3 or 4 points strat (just to keep people near de-cursers and healers and tremor totems) but tell the groups to just avoid Doomfires as best they can and if separated get back together asap. (We usually mark the mages/resto druids to help them stay together). This will also increase DPS on him by a noticeable margin.

On a possibly unrelated note: We had to pry away from our mentality the preservation of group synergy in order to distribute tremor totems, de-cursers and healers. Trying to keep shadow priests with casters and dps warriors with enhancement shamans is nice if you can swing it, but giving each point the people it needs and keeping healers un-feared was a higher priority. Convert group synergy into survival groups instead of DPS/heal maxing groups.

We use 4 point tactic but till now i don't think everyone still not gets it after 1 night of whiping so now my question is kind when ever a doomfire spawns and well its in a range pretty close to you but isnt moving yet or not moving towards you yet should you still already run? And we have had our melee dps get doomfire ofcourse we already had a kind of bad start due to not enough people and ending up taking 8 melee so we had 1 group less of 4 point tactic, is this a misake that it pretty much started/came at melee is our melee standing wrong or is our MT tanking him wrong?
