Would appreciate some tips on how others dealed with these problems. Thanks in advance.
#1051SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.0Penguin
1. MT should never be airburst. Ever. No excuse.

2. Living takes priority over everything. If a Doomfire looks like it's even remotely close to you, move. If the fear is almost up, and there's a Doomfire within running distance, move or be ready to break the fear with something.

3. Lots of melee is ok, as long as they know how to stay alive. Having them clumped at the back of the mob means they'll be spending more time airburst than the rest of the raid, but there's not much to be done about that.
#1052SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Emtee
Should I spread melee more, if so in what kind of way?

I know MT shouldn't get Airbursts, but I still don't get why he got it. Some people in our guild aren't really honest, about saying who did what or why they died.
#1053SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Vidofnir
Yesterday we killed Archimonde after about 2 months (although we did focus on Black Temple, and only had 5-6 nights of solid attempts on Archimonde himself, so it's not as bad as it sounds). The kill was made using a tactic completely new to us, and it worked out perfectly for us.

Before yesterday we always used the four point tactic. Now we had a kind of two point tactic. Archimonde is tanked in the middle of the big field, and west and east of him are two big groups with healers and decursers spread out between the groups. The big difference is that the two groups dont clump up like you do with the 4 point strategy. They spread out like a big "wall" west and east of the boss. Almost all fires went for someone in those groups, and almost none at all for the melee. Big plus about this strategy is that not 5 players get air burst at the same time, but only 2-3. The ones that get "targetted" by the Doomfire run back in a straight line, and so do the players close the person running backwards. This proved out to be very efficient, and the flames could be kited almost perfectly for some reason.

First few attempts we had no healer in melee range, but we changed that after 2 attempts. We used a Holy priest in melee range focussing on the main tank and nothing else. The reason for using a Holy priest is simple: Binding Heal. In case he gets the Doomfire DOT he can Renew himself and heal the MT and himself with Binding Heal, so the MT keeps recieving heals even while he's healing himself. He himself and a shadowpriest could keep him out of fears almost permanently with Fear Ward and Trinket.

We had Shadowpriests out of Shadowform, so they can not only dispell fears but also emergency heal. The 2 Shadowpriests did less than 500 DPS, but they saved quite some lives.

We have a lack of Shamans, so we chose not to have a Shaman for the melee, since they have enough abilities to break fear (Trinket, Cloak of Shadows, Beserker Rage, Divine Shield). They lose some DPS because they won't get any totems, but in the end Archimonde was on 10% after 7,5 minute. So DPS was not really a problem.

When a Fear is incoming, every moves away from any fires at least 30 yards. If they get feared and run towards a fire, they use their trinket or get dispelled. Trinkets are not for "Fear soon, im gonna stay right next to this pretty fire and pop my trinket immediately". Its for emergency use only.



To Emtee: If you have your MT getting airburst than either the Melee is to close to him, or people are running like chickens from flames. Tell them to turn around and move in a straight line backwards when a fire is following them. Not running around the boss, and definately not near the MT.
#1054SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2seped
Originally Posted by Penguin
1. MT should never be airburst. Ever. No excuse.
While I agree, and it's only ever happened to me twice, both times were fully survivable. Sure it shouldn't happen, but if it does you click your tears.

3. Lots of melee is ok, as long as they know how to stay alive. Having them clumped at the back of the mob means they'll be spending more time airburst than the rest of the raid, but there's not much to be done about that.
We've had good luck with splitting the melee into two groups, if I'm tanking at 6 o clock they are at 2:30 and 9:30 about. (just enough to be sure to avoid parry gibbing the tank)
#1055SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2aadric
We spent about 3 hours on Archimonde yesterday. All were no-DPS attempts. We had spent a few hours on him a few weeks ago. We seem to run into two major problems:

1.) The Shaman's tremor totem does not dispel fear 1 second after cast. It does so instantly and then doesn't tick again for 4-5 seconds. We tested this in the Nagrand arena. This means the Shaman cannot drop the totem reactively when they see the cast bar. Since the fear ward change, are people doing fear ward rotations? The melee is so close to the fire spawn that any amount of time feared results in many dots.

2.) When the doomfire curves, it usually results in not one but two groups having to move. If both groups are standing far enough from the doomfire not to get feared into it, they are out of range of the tank. If both active fires do this, it is very easy for all 4 groups being affected by this, leaving only melee healers in range of the tank (and still at the mercy of air burst).
#1056SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2
Edited onPatch 2.3.2		Ragnor
9/10 times if a doomfire curves early it's because the "initial' target's whole group didn't lead it away properly. You generally only see doomfires curving from one group to another or to the melee when people are being cocky/dumb and trying to sidestep the doomfire instead of the whole group running directly out and away.

Regarding fear, you don't stand within 15 yards of a doomfire when fear cd is coming up and everyone wears their pvp trinket.

When it's all working properly with a 4 point strat only 1-2 of the melee should get ever the doomfire dot and only really once during the fight.
Last edited by Ragnor : 01/10/08 at 10:28 PM.
#1057SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Tyrian
.) The Shaman's tremor totem does not dispel fear 1 second after cast. It does so instantly and then doesn't tick again for 4-5 seconds. We tested this in the Nagrand arena. This means the Shaman cannot drop the totem reactively when they see the cast bar. Since the fear ward change, are people doing fear ward rotations? The melee is so close to the fire spawn that any amount of time feared results in many dots.
Thats why your melee group/enhancement shaman should be the recipiant of a full Fear Ward rotation. If you've only got 3 priests in the raid, give all the fear wards to the melee shaman. Then he can place his tremor totem reactively the moment after a fear is cast.

The other heal/elemental shamans dont need FW, as players in their group can simply move 30-40 yards/~4-6 sec worth of running-time away from doomfires before a fear anyway, which should be standard practise for the rest of the raid.

2.) When the doomfire curves, it usually results in not one but two groups having to move. If both groups are standing far enough from the doomfire not to get feared into it, they are out of range of the tank. If both active fires do this, it is very easy for all 4 groups being affected by this, leaving only melee healers in range of the tank (and still at the mercy of air burst).
With more practise (as players understand positioning/how to move when a doomfire comes near you) this should become less of a problem.
#1058SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Vazu
Originally Posted by aadric
We spent about 3 hours on Archimonde yesterday. All were no-DPS attempts. We had spent a few hours on him a few weeks ago. We seem to run into two major problems:

1.) The Shaman's tremor totem does not dispel fear 1 second after cast. It does so instantly and then doesn't tick again for 4-5 seconds. We tested this in the Nagrand arena. This means the Shaman cannot drop the totem reactively when they see the cast bar. Since the fear ward change, are people doing fear ward rotations? The melee is so close to the fire spawn that any amount of time feared results in many dots.

2.) When the doomfire curves, it usually results in not one but two groups having to move. If both groups are standing far enough from the doomfire not to get feared into it, they are out of range of the tank. If both active fires do this, it is very easy for all 4 groups being affected by this, leaving only melee healers in range of the tank (and still at the mercy of air burst).
1. Stop relying on Tremor Totems to bail you out. Just stay away from Doomfire before potential Fears. Make sure everyone has DBM or a similar boss mod. Have your raid leader call out "Fear anytime." That's your raid's que to check their surroundings. If ranged DPS do their jobs, healers can focus on calling out Air Bursts, healing the MT and melee. Make sure people in your raid are wearing 2 minute PVP trinkets. I won't say it's a "must", but it makes a big difference, especially for healers.

2. You can have an entire group out of healing range of the MT and be fine. The healing strategy here is really communication. We call out on Vent "So-and-so away" when our healers can't get back to the MT or when they get Air Bursted. It communicates urgency for the remaining healers to step their game up and pay extra attention to the MT. This is again why ranged DPS need to be very self sufficient in not taking Doomfires.
#1059SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2BoinKlasik
Originally Posted by Tyrian
Thats why your melee group/enhancement shaman should be the recipiant of a full Fear Ward rotation. If you've only got 3 priests in the raid, give all the fear wards to the melee shaman. Then he can place his tremor totem reactively the moment after a fear is cast.

The other heal/elemental shamans dont need FW, as players in their group can simply move 30-40 yards/~4-6 sec worth of running-time away from doomfires before a fear anyway, which should be standard practise for the rest of the raid.
Our guild does not give me a fear ward and typically what happens is that I will keep a tremor up at all possible times (there are truly sometimes where I was locked out of the middle for 2 minutes) and let the rogues take care of themselves (warriors can dance all fears and the healing/feral druid in the group can heal themselves through a bad fire), they have so many more abilites to counteract the doomfire than I do. If they get a back tick or their trinket is on cooldown they can cloak anyway. It is possible to still have melee that don't get killed by doomfires constantly, but it requires them to be paying more attention than the ranged (as always.) In my personal case the general rule of thumb is that if my trinket isnt up, I am already running out of the middle 5s before fear for the safety of the logs.

That said, I would love to be the target of a fear ward rotation anyway, but it is entirely possible to do it without one. Tremor totems in this manner are largely about luck, sometimes it will tick nearly instantly, sometimes you will have to wait the full 5s pulse, the best any shaman can do is make it ALWAYS a 3.5 second break (instantly drop at the cast of a fear + no lag + instant reaction times.) I also tinkered with seeing if the first tick was delayed in any way but was also unable to break a fear with my totem during a warlock fear cast.
#1060SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2
Edited onPatch 2.3.2		Tyrian
That said, I would love to be the target of a fear ward rotation anyway, but it is entirely possible to do it without one.
Nobody disputes that - but much of the Archimonde fight is about minimising potential risks. Is it possible to do it without FW's on melee-group shaman? Yes. Is it a smart thing to do? No.

Melee having to be at the mercy of the '5 second tremor tick' when doomfires are literally behind them is just asking for trouble. Yes, rogues have good survival tricks in case things go wrong - but you want to minimise the number of potential times something can go wrong which force people to use abilities like Cloak of Shadows. Knowing theres a risky/dangerous situatiaon and having the mentality 'well rogues can just cloak if needed' is like trying to fill a leaking bucket. Fix the real problem first.
Last edited by Tyrian : 01/13/08 at 10:37 AM.
#1061SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2etalon
we killed Archimonde yesterday evening with a feral druid tanking, with 3 priests rotating fear ward on him. (he had to use his pvp trinket like 2-3 times)
#1062SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2â™¦ Quigon
Originally Posted by Tyrian
Nobody disputes that - but much of the Archimonde fight is about minimising potential risks. Is it possible to do it without FW's on melee-group shaman? Yes. Is it a smart thing to do? No.

Melee having to be at the mercy of the '5 second tremor tick' when doomfires are literally behind them is just asking for trouble. Yes, rogues have good survival tricks in case things go wrong - but you want to minimise the number of potential times something can go wrong which force people to use abilities like Cloak of Shadows. Knowing theres a risky/dangerous situatiaon and having the mentality 'well rogues can just cloak if needed' is like trying to fill a leaking bucket. Fix the real problem first.
I think most people forget this in the constant epeen waving contest - or perhaps just in being naturally argumentative.
If we were perfect, no one would ever wipe - and we wouldn't even have this thread.

You minimize risk by weighting your circumstances - fear ward helps you out a lot if used appropriately.

This is the entire idea behind min/maxing.

You can get away with hybrid setups, or something in-between, but that doesn't mean that you should - or rather that it is the path of least resistance.

I'm sure people have beaten archimonde with 0 fear wards, 0 shamans, maybe no warriors, and 6 healers. But the last thing we need is to discuss the merits of doing that. Why would you do that unless you didn't have a choice?
#1063SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2aadric
We'll be using a Fear Ward rotation this week. Leaving the melee to their own devices sounds great when its all Warriors and Rogues, but we have at least 1 feral, 1 paladin, and 1 resto in melee range. We use a method described in this thread of having a Paladin in the totem group, then dispelling the resto druid.

No one really answered my second question, but I think the answer is that we simply need to be more aggressively positioned when his Fear is on cooldown, then resume cautious positioning about 10 seconds before the cooldown is up. We were being extra cautious the entire time, which resulted in more groups being outside of healing range then were probably necessary.
#1064SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Zealoz
Originally Posted by Tyrian
Thats why your melee group/enhancement shaman should be the recipiant of a full Fear Ward rotation. If you've only got 3 priests in the raid, give all the fear wards to the melee shaman. Then he can place his tremor totem reactively the moment after a fear is cast.
We just started this encounter last night and after about 10 wipes we decided to retire for the evening. What I can say is that Tremor Totem CAN be a viable tool for this encounter if utilized properly. Dropping the Totem as Archie casts Fear will not help much if at all. The Fear spell is a 1.5 second cast. The totem doesn't "PULSE" (IE dispel fear) until after 4 seconds. If you drop it as he's casting, your group is going to be feared for 2.5 seconds. Which in a fight like this is an eternity. If, as a Shaman, you can time your totem right, meaning when you see the BW warning "Fear Cooldown over" drop your Tremor Totem then. Your group will stand a better chance at getting the fear dispelled almost immediately. There were several instances where, when I timed my Totem dropping right, the melee group was feared for less than a second.

The last few attempts we also, as a melee group, stood right under Archies rear end. Within the raid target circle to be exact. And while I thought that "Hey this might not be a good idea because of the possibility of MT getting Air bursted", it proved to be beneficial in that none of the doomfires hit us. Granted they were all around us and one poorly timed Fear would have ended our DPS, which made it all that more important to make sure Totem Pulsing was spot on. We ran with 3 UD Rogues (PvP trinket WotF, TT), Me, Orc Enhancement Shaman (PvP Trinket, TT), and a Fury Tauren WAR (IMMUNITY FTW). I got Air bursted once during that strat, but the MT didn't.
#1065SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Kasi
I don't know if thats really viable, because the fear cooldown is over just means he can use fear now. It doesn't mean he will use fear now. It is variable. Which means dropping it could mean the next fear breaks instantly. It could also mean that its a 4 second tremor. If the timing was precise than the fight could be handled easily. But it can't be. Which means yeah, use tremor as a backup. You just move away from flames. The advantage of tremor is not that it takes away fear, it just means the groups with it can get back to healing the MT quicker because they're not mindlessly running around for a huge amount of time.
#1066SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Larisroth
Just got our first kill last night, and thanks to all of those here for suggestions and information. This is more an execution fight than anything else, so it can be difficult to see that you are actually making progress.

Your fear wards should go on those people who can make the best use of them. In our case because we had a lot of melee dps (6.5) we had 11 people in the centre (split across 2 positions to minimise collective air bursts) and used the fear wards on the MT group resto shaman, who dropped the totem to cleanse the fear from a resto druid, a feral druid in hybrid gear and a holy paladin. That gave us enough healing to heal through what doomfire that managed to hit on the rest of the melee (We had a couple of doomfires charge through the melee area on the kill). That way we could still preserve our standard melee dps group.
#1067SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2
Edited onPatch 2.3.2		Valjean
Awright, my turn to ask for advice.

We got him down to 21% and then had a cascasding soulcharge on 3 healers.

We use the 4 point strategy. Each group is self-sufficient, healer/decurser. The exception is group 2 (melee). We have a resto druid from group 1 stand with group 2 to decurse them.

1 MT - Prot War
6 Melee (2 rog, 1 druid, 1 ret paladin, 1 feral druid, 1 enh shaman)
10 healers (3 shamans, 2 priests, 2 resto druids, 3 paladins)
2 hunters, 3-4 mages, 1 shadow priest, 1 warlock, 2 hunters.

Group 1= MT, mage, resto druid (decurse group 2, sits with group 2), holy priest (MT Healer), holy paladin(MT Healer).
Group 2= Melee Rogue, Rogue, Ret Paladin, Fury Warrior, Enh Shaman
Group 3 = Holy priest (MT healer), Mage, Resto Shaman, Hunter, Holy Paladin (MT Healer)
Group 4 = Shadow priest, Mage, Resto Shaman, Hunter, Holy Paladin (MT Healer)
Group 5 = Resto Shaman (heals melee), Mage, Resto Druid, Feral Druid, Warlock


So here's the problem.

Group 5 and 3 are getting hit with a lot of doomfires. When they have a doomfire on them, they have to run parallel to the mountain, but for some reason or another, they still end up getting hit with a lot of doomfires. They just don't have enough room to move. Group 1 and 4 don't have this problem because they don't have to run parallel to either mountain.

I just don't know why group 5 had so much problem with doomfire.

Group 1's biggest problem is since they didn't have a tremor totem, if they got feared + cursed, they were pretty much guaranteed to die. I'm not sure about the best way to address that.

This is the positioning diagram we use.

We initially tanked him right around the stumps, but we found they ended up blocking doomfire and making it do weird things. Once we moved him closer to the mountains, doomfire was easier to manage, except for group 5.



And here's the log from tonight. Arctia is the resto shaman in group 5. He was pretty high on doomfires. His job was tougher because I assigned him to be the melee DPS healer as well. Bizzara was the resto druid in group 5, and he too was getting hit a lot.

#1068SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2
Edited onPatch 2.3.2		Tyrian
Group 5 and 3 are getting hit with a lot of doomfires. When they have a doomfire on them, they have to run parallel to the mountain, but for some reason or another, they still end up getting hit with a lot of doomfires. They just don't have enough room to move. Group 1 and 4 don't have this problem because they don't have to run parallel to either mountain.

I just don't know why group 5 had so much problem with doomfire.
If your ingame position is just like your picture, your putting him a little too close to the mountain, cramping some groups and group 5 almost can get cornered/trapped. Heres a pic to show how much easier the run path is for Group 1/4 if you shift the whole raid to the left. They basically run back to the mountain then parallel along it - shouldnt be a problem at all.



Im not sure if you posted your wws report so people could comment on it - but out of curiousity I had a little look anyway at some key indicators on Archimonde and thought id comment - I hope you dont mind. Your WWS records 21 attempts.

- Doomfires: Looking at who takes doomfire damage over the course of those attempts we get this: Wow Web Stats . Fifteen people took more than 25 doomfires each (Yes I know people sometimes suicide in them in wipes, but still thats more doomfires than attempts) while the top 2 paladins took ~33 - something is wrong there. Were the top doomfire-paladins in group 5?

- Healthstones: For the entire night of 21 attempts, 13 people used less than 5 healthstones and 8 people only used one healthstone - in twenty one attempts. Wow Web Stats . If survival is the key - people are being way too light in their healthstone usage and selfsurvival consumables. I can see on your WWS you only have one warlock in the raid - so that might limit the number of healthstones you had available between attempts a bit, so lets check the next two major pots to see if people compensate for a lack of available healthstones with other means (which they should)

- Super Healing Potions Usage: For the Entire night of attempts, only 9 people used a Super healing potion. Only two people used more than two over the course of the night. Thats not good.

- Fire protection potion usage: Wow Web Stats 10 people used fire pots over the night, but only two people used more than 3. If people used Healing potions instead itd be ok, but that wasnt happening.

- Purification (self-decurse) potion usage: WWS Loading... 5 people used decurse pots over the night

===

So while we can look into your positioning and strat to make it easier for groups to avoid doomfire - your bigger problem is players simply arent trying hard enough to stay alive. Nobody can really say that, in 21 attempts while you learn the fight, using one super healing potion or one healthstone is accepable. I count about 7 attempts you had where over 1 million damage was done to the boss - surely all 7 of those attempts were worth potting to attempt to stay alive or recover from soul charges? Looks like people potted maybe for one of them , two at most. Make sure players know that using consumables and pots to stay alive isnt 'nice', its a requirement for the fight. Check WWS after and point fingers and ask questions at players who seem to be slacking.

If people dont want to pot in the first place when they are in danger, your going to keep wiping - regardless of where you decide to tank the boss. However if you can get the boss to 21%, a kill should be forthcoming. Whether its easily repeatable the following week - is another story
Last edited by Tyrian : 01/15/08 at 11:17 AM.
#1069SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Zedd
We Killed him last night on our 2nd full night on him(8 hours total spend), Thanks for all advice
#1070SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Masimo
1st Kill Strats
After reading this forum for hours or end and applying the tips here, we got our first Archimonde kill after only 3 hours of attempts on our first night. I appreciate all the people who took their time to post strats in here, and for the guilds who are upcoming on him I'd like to highlight the ideas that were incredibly useful.

1. We ran a 4 point strategy and positioned him the same as Tyrian posted above.

2. We raid with a lot of shamans in general (Enh sham and 3 restos as is a lot of raid healing in BC encounters). Therefore we had totems in 4 of the five groups.

3. Group without the totem were filled with Undead classes w/ 2 min pvp trinkets.

4. Fear wards were used to bail us out of bad situations. Ie. Someone got cut off by a doomfire or somehow ended up surrounded by them, they could call out for a fear ward to prevent getting feared into a doomfire if their CD's for breaking the fear were down. Fear wards are a life saver, going forward I'm going to ask our raiders to shout out when they need the fear ward so they can avoid a wipe. We need to utlize this more going forward.

5. For MT healing, it was never an issue. 1 resto druid keeping up HoTs, 1 holy paly and 1 holy priest all in different groups. Arch never came close to killing me as the whole night I never died to cause a wipe. At one point reading I thought since Arch couldn't crush a druid would be a good choice to tank the fight, but imo Az'galor output more damage than Arch does. Arch's attacks on me were easy to heal as he didn't have much burst capability. I was stacked in pure stam/avoidance gear, and no TPS gear.

6. Other groups helped each other out by letting them know ahead of time doomfire was coming for them. As MT I tried like hell to see doomfires coming to the melee from behind them to try and help them out.

Doomfires did get hectic but we will be able to work on that. I cannot stress enough how important it is to have the groups run away from the doomfires when the fear is incoming, as the totems were a huge help BUT are not the end all be all. However, they do help you save your CD when they pulse at the right time.

His abilities are very easy to survive and avoid. I understand our kill is nothing like pre-nerfed Arch, but once again thanks forf the tips guys.
#1071SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Valjean
Originally Posted by Tyrian

Thank you very much for that analysis Tyrian, it's given me and my guild a lot to think about.

Part of reason people didn't pot/hs a lot is that most of the people who took damage were either melee, or in groups 1 or 5 in our original diagram. (Or NE and NW corners, assuming world tree is W) For example, Davidthorne was the warrior in melee group, and he took 15 FR pots, according to WWS. But I was in group 4, and I took almost no damage. I think I only got hit by doomfire once, so my healthstone was never consumed.

This does indicate to me that I can drop one healer and go 9 healer instead of 10 healer. ee

I think if we move further away from the mountain as you suggest, group 1+5 (the sides closest to the mountain), should have fewer problems with doomfire. Those two groups probably took over 60% of the heals for the fight. My only concern is that the stump in the middle can still make doomfire act even more erratic by blocking it.

Also, I decided that the MT group, since it doesn't have a tremor totem, will have all high-survival or fear-breaking classes. Which means moving the fury warrior from melee group to tank group. We had too many problems with tank group getting feared + cursed and no way to break it. I figure MT, DPS War, paladin, frost mage, warlock should be a good MT group.

As for purification pots, my raiders said that the pots got resisted a lot, and preferred to use FR or health pots intead.

Hopefully we'll get to Archimonde in time tonight to try out the positioning you suggested. Otherwise tomorrow for sure.

He said it was difficult for him at times because he had to go in closer than his group did, making it harder for him to consistently break their fears. It also made it harder for him to consistently heal the melee group. I think the only thing I can tell him to do is just have his entire group come in closer.

MT healers said it was easier for them to get hit by doomfire vs the rest of their group, because they had to be closer to the MT than the rest of their group in order to keep up heals.

#1075SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2
Edited onPatch 2.3.2		Tyrian
What happened next was that the server came down hard on them about their use of a certain Log to exploit the fight, which they adamantly defended that they were in fact being creative and not exploitive in anyway.
Its an exploit.

If people want to argue over semantics, its a unintended way of doing the fight - clearly not the way the designers wanted (regardless of whether the so-called gm used the specific word 'exploit'). People are meant to be having doomfires them harass them during the fight - not have archimonde in the middle of a massive 200 yard field just to huddle up on/behind a tiny log to trivialise that mechanic. Its like the original tank spot for Archimonde (underwater, below the world tree), you could call it 'creative' if you really want to - but it was obviously unintended and fixed when word got out.

#1080SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2

Definitely an exploit, back in naxx days, there were some safe spots on Heigan that you could use to avoid the dance, they gave some warnings to guilds exploiting it and fixed it some patch later. They don't bother hotfixing those tho it seems, since you still need to get to archimonde, tank him, and do some stuff. It's an exploit, but hardly gamebreaking. You could argue that archimonde is supposed to be real hard or something, but he's been nerfed so much, we killed him in 4tries, without any specific positionning strat. You can easily heal 4-5people taking doomfires for the whole fight with HoTs, plus the tank and the curse first ticks.

#1083SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Moogul
Originally Posted by Daboran
but it's trivial if we all stand on one spot and line-of-sight his main raid-killing ability - that's not an exploit at all is it? /sarcasm
I'd like to see a video of a guild killing Chromaggus without Line-of-sighting his main raid-killing ability.

Yes, this appears like an exploit, but LoS is a game mechanic which Blizzard has used in boss fights before.
#1084SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Pariah
That said, Doomfire is not an ability you line of sight like the Chrommagus breath was. There are abilities that can be LoS'd and for that reason you position bosses in the pull area for it. Doomfire doesnt get LoS'd, it gets kited away, I dont seem the two abilities as comparable.
#1085SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2â€¢ Maledict
That's incorrect. Blizzard has always been very particular about how LoS works in raid bosses.

i) If you can hit the boss and the boss can't hit you, it's an exploit. (Archimonde)

ii) If you can't hit the boss and he can't hit you, it's not an exploit (Firemaw, Chromagus).

Indeed, on Chromagus if you did hit him through the walls it made you vulnerable to his breaths, so it was clearly designed with that in mind. For Arhcimonde however, you are making yourself immune to this doomfires without interfering with your own ability to hit him in any way.

I am curious how the raid isn't destroyed by airbursts however. (cannot download file).
#1086SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Valjean
2nd night, 20 wipes. :-(

13% wipe too. That's right. We hit 13% with 23 up and hit the enrage timer.

Not enough DPS due to:

1) Not enough shamans meant dps groups were extra paranoid about being near doomfire or other groups before fears
We've been doing this with 4 shamans, we were down to 3 last night (2 at some points), and learning this fight is really challenging without shamans. I did almost no dps because I wanted to make sure I didn't get feared/doomfired (and I still screwed up a few times).

2) The shamans we did have blew heroims in the wrong groups (blowing it on a healer group vs melee group, for example).

This is a video one of our resto shamans made of our 13% wipe.. He was in the melee group for decursing.

YouTube - MB vs Archimonde

It was frustrating, and after that it was hard to get people to focus again. We're going to take a break, let people get some consumables and farm and go back on Monday.

Wow Web Stats - Wowwebstats of our 13% wipe.

Just looking at the logs, I'm still seeing a lot of what Tyrian posted, which is people aren't surviving. A lot of the people who got doomfired didn't pop healthstones or FR pots. I think healers in particular were lazy, assuming they can heal themselves through it. We also had paladins/mages pop their shields/blocks at the first tick of a doomfire instead of saving it for being feared into a doomfire or some other oh shit.

And finally, a huge problem, healers weren't focused enough. Looking at the logs, I assigned 4 MT healers and 5 raid healers But the MT healers took a ton of damage. Most of them healed themselves for about 10% of the amount they healed the MT. One even wasted time healing a pet. Only one MT healer focused on healing the MT, the others were pretty much cross-healing like mad.

At this point, I don't think there's any more strategy or tips I can tell people except do your own job and stop trying to do other peoples' jobs.

Here's hoping for Monday.
#1087SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2rayijin
Valjean: Keep at it, you're on track to get it your next raid.

Suggestion: If you get to a minute left and are just short dps, have your healers dps, and have your tank blow last stand/trinkets/shield wall. I did this on our second archi kill when we had 10 healers in the raid and they got to spam smite for 30 secs, allowing us to barely beat the enrage timer.

If you can hit the enrage timer, you have beaten the part of the fight that's hard: not dying. As your players get more comfortable at not dying, their dps will increase.

You could also try dropping a healer or two - it looks like two of your pallies decided to drop themselves before the halfway point of the fight anyways.

I'm also trying to figure out how the shadowpriest did that little damage with such a high % of presence.

#1089SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Daboran
If you are short on Shaman:

Make sure the melee dps group gets one and put your Resto Druid in that group for it too.
Put any "spare" dps Warriors in any group you like. Fear shouldnt ever be an issue for them and if they are good they can Intercept out of the Air Burst too - they will take the damage but can get straight back to the boss without the knockback. this helps DPS a huge amount (much more than "optimizing" their group at the expense of others). We don't particularly optimize his group, but our Fury Warrior tops dps on this fight every single time.
Set up a Fear Ward rotation on the MT so that he doesnt have to worry about stance-dancing or rely on the Shaman totem as a backup.

We got our first kill with a single Shaman. Yes it's easier with more, but focus on the classes that really NEED a totem i.e classes/races that only have the PvP trinket to break Fear.
It's also worth mentioning to your Shaman that Archimonde will never Fear while someone is Airbursted, at least in our experience - knowing this, totem-dropping becomes a lot easier.
#1090SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Insanelogic
Archimonde down! I think it took us 4 nights and 70ish pulls. Had to be pretty tough about sitting the people who couldn't avoid Doomfire, but in the end we didn't have to kick anyone or recruit. Thanks for the great advice in this thread.

#1094SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Healium

I stay out of shadowform and fearward my groups healer, I also wear the BT neck piece for extra SR and tend to resist a lot of the fears and can dispel others quickly in range. We tend to be priest heavy with 2-3 SPs and 2-3 holy, so there are a lot of fearwards to go around.

Our guild was a little stuck on archimonde and tried the log strategy but the melee had a horrible time staying alive with it, it seems to almost favor stacking ranged behind the log with little to no melee. After two hours of attempts, we went back to a 4-pt strategy and got a kill in 3 pulls.

Personally, it felt better getting the kill without using an environmental shield. If the log is removed, we know we have a strategy that will hold up.
#1095SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Bullshot

#1096SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2â—Š Kalman
There's no reason to stay out of shadowform just to fearward. Go in with fear ward up; when the cooldown is over, fearward yourself and then go back into shadowform. You really should not be having mana issues on Archimonde, given the amount of time you'll be spending not casting, even with the dropping form every 3 minutes.

(A good trick, if you don't have a tremor in a group, is to have a fearwarded priest time a mass dispel to go off right after fear. We run with enough shamans it isn't typically an issue, but it's been helpful at times.)

#1098SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2â€¢ Yessia
Originally Posted by Valjean
I'd like to get some more advice.

We've had situation where melee gets airbursted, and right before they're running back into melee range, a doomfire spawns around them and gets trailed to the MT.

Our melee do a good job of watching nearby when they land, but they tell me that if the doomfire spawns right as they're getting back into his hitbox, there's nothing they can do about it. It's a rare occurence, but it's happened enough where I've flipped out on them a few times.

If this just a luck of the draw situation where we'd have to heal the MT through?
I'm pretty sure that almost all doomfires are avoidable. There are many occasions where I'll be up near the melee and a doomfire spawns right on me, but as long as I stop whatever I'm doing and quickly strafe out of it I avoid taking damage/getting the debuff.

Does that mean it's possible for melee to take 0 doomfires? Maybe, but in our 2 kills and 100+ attempts it hasn't happened . I will say though that for the most part the only melee that still get doomfired consistently are the ones we know to be a little slow(not just this encounter but in general as player). Make sure melee are communicating with each other, our melee almost always call out every doomfire that spawns somewhat near them.

As for the MT getting doomfired, just have him back up/side step a little and tell him to let the melee know he's moving the boss.

#1104SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Caligula
My suggestion:

/console CameraDistanceMaxFactor 4

This will allow you to zoom out about 3x as far as the default zoom.

Move out of the way of the incoming Doomfires. Don't just stand there and take them.
#1105SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2rayijin
DPS warriors are one of the easiest classes to survive with on this fight. This is what makes it easy to stay alive:

1) Can reliably break every fear (never, ever get feared into doomfire)
2) Can (usually) intercept after air bursts, meaning you rarely get far away from the raid
3) Are standing in the middle (read: in range of every healer/decurser at all times)
4) Cannot get hit by doomfires unless they loop around completely (if you stand close enough to the boss and/or watch for spawns, you won't get hit)
5) If you do get hit by a doomfire that loops all the way around, you can instantly mitigate a large amount of damage by going to defensive stance and eating a healthstone/pot if needed.

If you're getting grip and it's not being dispelled immediately while standing in range of every decurser in the raid, that's not your fault. The only thing you can do to play better is avoid doomfires, which should be easy.
#1106SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Sepulture
We've been working on this guy now since mid December. As the MT, I am getting bored to tears with the fight-pun sort of intended I suppose. I can execute this fight with my eyes closed, never get feared, and trinket my way through rough spots without having to think about it. I feel like I'm farming MC for bindings here at this point.

Our problem is with the rest of our raid. We are playing on a backwater expansion server; we are the only guild in BT and MHJ, and many of our raiders should probably be playing Hello Kitty Island Adventure.

We use a 4 corners strategy that is well defined and quite standard. We use 4 ranged groups with 2 healers per group where possible. Hopefully we have a shaman in each group, and if not a priest for fearward/mass dispel. Still, we consistently lose people to doomfire and cratering. We have never gotten this guy past 40%. We made it to the enrage timer once when I yelled a lot and instructed people to not dps at all. We have probably put in between 150 and 250 tries over the last month or so. We have thoroughly researched the fight. Everyone has been told ad nauseam about running directly away from Archimonde at the first sight of nearby doomfire, as well as everything else that they should be doing.

Well, I've had it so I wrote up these rules. Can you suggest any revisions that could make the policy more effective? Are they too brutal/not brutal enough?

New Archimonde Rules

Every time we attempt Archimonde, we will now make a note any time someone dies early. Here are the rules associated with dying early on this encounter.

Cratering
1) If you crater, you will get a second chance.
2) If you crater twice, you will be removed from the raid for the night.
3) If you crater repeatedly on different nights, you will be blacklisted from the Archimonde fight until it's on farm status.

We will keep a "crater list" for this purpose. We will run with under 25 if necessary. If too many people crater twice, and we can no longer make attempts, the raid will either be called or redirected to another instance.

We will recruit a replacement for anyone who is blacklisted from cratering. Falling on trees is not an excuse, you should be looking down and hitting the tear early if you are falling on top of wooded areas.

Doomfire
1) If you die early from doomfire once, you get a second chance.
2) If you die early from doomfire twice, you are removed from the raid for the night.
3) If you die from doomfire twice on multiple nights, you will be blacklisted from the Archimonde fight until it is on farm status.

We will keep a "doomfire list". If you die from doomfire, you should consider equipping stamina gear and chugging fire protection pots every 2 minutes. Note: You can use flasks of petrification to not get blacklisted from doomfire. If you are too lazy to get petrification pots, or too slow to use them, that's not our problem. As with cratering, anyone who doomfired themselves repeatedly will be recruited over.

2 Minute PvP Trinket
It's now required. If you don't have one, you are now a second stringer for the Archimonde fight and will get last dibs on loot from the encounter regardless of your dkp.

Purification Potions, Flasks of Petrification, Fire Protection Pots or Healing Pots
These are all required. If you failed to bring any of these items, people who did win Archimonde loot over you regardless of your dkp.

Putting in your time
Just like on Kael'thas, the people who put in the most effort and do a good job on Archimonde will become first stringers. People who half ass the encounter, crater, get doomfired, or come unprepared will be recruited over.
#1107SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2â™¦ zeidrich
I would say ease up on the trinket requirement. It's nice to have, but by no means a necessity. I would never bench someone who has proven themselves to be good at surviving on the fight just because they didn't have the 2 minute trinket.

If they're dying, then it doesn't matter if they have the 2 minute trinket or not.

Your potion requirement seems really high too. Then again, if you carry them and don't use them, it doesn't cost anything.

I typically only end up using a healthstone or two in case I get air burst while low health.

In your situation I would definitely say your focus should be on keeping alive more than anything (obviously).

Hammer into people's heads that if you're near a doomfire when a fear is coming, and you don't have a way to break fear, or remove the doomfire, then get the hell away from it. Even if it puts you out of position.

Get your cleansers to help cleanse other groups when necessary. Your raiders should be moving away from doomfire at all costs. Occasionally that will mean they get separated from their groups, and thus decursers. This means they need coverage from another group's decurser.

Cratering is unacceptable, and there's not much you can do about it other than removing people who consistently do it. Some people take a few tries to be comfortable using it. Make those people practice off a cliff or something. It is different of course getting flung up than it is jumping down. I normally do it more based off timing now than visual queues, since sometimes it's hard to see your character, but you know that if you hit the tears x seconds after the apex of your jump you should be fine anywhere.

Also keep a positive outlook. It sounds like you're being pretty harsh, which is understandable, it's a frustrating fight. But a lot of it is about confidence in the fight. You sound like you're pretty close to it, and once you get him down the first time, he becomes immensly easier, despite the fact that you WILL wipe again on him on subsequent resets.

If your raid can get him to 40%, they can get him to 10%. There is nothing different about the first 60% from the last 30%. It is just more of the same. It's just about maintaining that focus the entire time.
#1108SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.2Beren
Originally Posted by xtreat
Ok i am a a fury warrior and i am having a hell of a time staying alive while fighting this guy. It seems the fires are swooping in on melee and while the rogues CoS and the healers keep themselves and attempt to keep me up i am burning away. If i get airburst or grip its game over for me.
First of all, why are you dying to air burst? That makes no sense.

2nd of all, make sure your decursers know who is responsible for melee decursing.

3rd. Really, if you are paying attention for incoming doomfires(ie panning the camera arround, and LOOKING for them) you should never ever be hit by one as a dps warrior. Stop looking at your buttons, and start looking at your environment.

Communication can help with a lot of these issues. Ranged people warning the melee that a rogue Doomfire is inc can provide a critical warning. Melee people who get gripped speaking up in vent can help make decursers aware. Healing groups getting cut off by doomfires and letting the rest of the raid know can help let other healers know when they need to steo up, etc. Its a fight where good communication can really help things out.

Yes, melee dps really do dominate the meters on this fight. But, if your melee doesnt pay attention, and healers need to stop healing the MT to heal dumb dps who cant/arent avoiding doomfires then you put your MT at tremendous risk.

God no - it should be a requirement. It might not be a 'necessity' for experienced players - but you'd be silly (while your learning the fight) to make wearing this optional.

#1113SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3rayijin
Originally Posted by Amonra
I would say that a flask of petrification seems pretty excessive.

Fine if people want to bring one to avoid getting blacklisted for doomfire problems, but making it a requirement seems over the top.
It's not excessive, here's why:

The fight is 100% about personal accountability. If you die, it's your fault. Putting this clause in there basically means there can be no excuse. You COULD have survived if you were overprepared - or if you simply paid attention.

Excuses are the guild killer. Personal accountability is the Archimonde killer.
#1114SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3plebsy
Our guild has been attempting Archimonde over the last few weeks with relatively little success (best attempt ~50%). We have adopted the 4-point strategy described at several points in this thread. We are finding that we can broadly put our wipes into three broad strategies:

-personal stupidity (cratering/feared into doomfires/other reckless acts)
-doomfires into melee
-tank deaths when all the healers are in transit.

We're working on the first. Dealing with the 2nd is proving a challenge, largely because the inflexibility of the fight and its chaotic nature makes it difficult to pin down exactly what is causing doomfires to run through Archimonde or around and into the melee. We've drilled into ranged groups that they must mouse turn and run radially away from Archimonde, yet melee still get hit on a regular basis.

My questions are really these: is it the ranged that are doing something wrong, or is it that the melee need to be sharper to avoid incoming doomfires? Even with perfect ranged execution, should we expect some doomfires in the melee? Is it realistic to expect that the only time melee get hit with doomfire is when they are feared (which an appropriate Fear Ward rotation + tremor should solve)?
#1115SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Sonrisa
There will be doomfires going for your melee no matter what you do. What we do is the groups call out when their doomfires turn early and is headig towards melee/another group so they can watch out and try to move away in time. Fear to doomfire on melee is going to happen too. Rogues can CoS it though and not all of the melee should be getting doomfire either so you can heal through it easily.

Also when there is 5 secs left for fear I warn everyone of the incoming fear, if it takes time before it gets cast I keep repeating it, watch out for the fear. What people do is try to stay at least 25-30 yd away from all doomfires when the fear is coming. This greatly helps reduce the doomfire dmg on ranged if not completly on some groups.
#1116SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Tyrian
My questions are really these: is it the ranged that are doing something wrong, or is it that the melee need to be sharper to avoid incoming doomfires? Even with perfect ranged execution, should we expect some doomfires in the melee? Is it realistic to expect that the only time melee get hit with doomfire is when they are feared (which an appropriate Fear Ward rotation + tremor should solve)?
It could be because ranged are looping/sidestepping - or it could be simply because the doomfire decided to go for melee. You really have to be in the actual fight watching to see how it happens, but its not necessarily anyones fault. No matter what strat you have, some doomfires will refuse to follow the people you want (the range groups) and instead might go towards melee.

doomfires into melee
The only two tools you need to deal with this effectively are"

- Fear warded shaman in melee group, who knows what hes doing. (Yes, im aware its possible to do the fight without this, but realistically = youd be stupid to try, if your learning the fight)
- Good communication on vent. Range groups should announce immediately when a doomfire appears to turn and head towards melee. Then they run off until its safe to return, if they are slow and die in the doomfire behind them (which was warned prior on vent), they messed up.

#1120SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Sepulture
Originally Posted by Figrond
Quick question for the more experienced:

We just started on Arch using the Stump strategy and it seems to me that it causes more harm than good as raid is forced into too small an area. Assuming we swtich to a 3/4 point strategy, my only question is about the pull (hard to see on many videos). Do you have groups come in from their sides, or does everyone go in on mass and then make their way out to their points?

Any pull advice would be gratefully received.

Cheers

Fig
Here is a good way to pull:

1) Have your entire raid get on their horse
2) Have the MT run in first.
3) MT runs mounted to his tank spot.
4) MT uses bloodrage to break his mount when near the final position (for snap aggro off that stupid mage who firewarded and pulled aggro), uses an avoidance trinket, then uses demo/TC.

This method is pretty much foolproof. I'd highly recommend 4, the avoidance trinket is really helpful because you are unlikely to get many heals in the first 5-10 seconds.

We also experimented with the stump strategy. We found 4 corners to be easier and more repeatable.

We found the key to this fight is this: make sure each of your four corners runs out IMMEDIATELY and directly away from Archimonde at the first sign of doomfire.

Tell them this before every pull: "You know how fast you have to move out of the flamestrike on Kael'thas? That's not fast enough. You cannot wait at all when running away from doomfire."

Use a "crater" and "doomfire" list and make sure you use the language "blacklist". People will start following your strategy. If you are having stupid deaths, it's because people aren't being held accountable.

1) Get recount
2) scroll to "deaths"
3) Select the fight where the player died early
4) See the last 15 seconds-was it cratering? Was there ANY doomfire damage in the last 15 seconds of their life?
5) If 4 = yes, put them on a publicly posted list.
6) If they crater twice or doomfire twice, sit them out. If they do it two raids in a row, blacklist them until farm status.

Worked for us like magic, and we didn't have to blacklist anyone. No one was ever sat out. The fear motivated people to follow orders and pay attention and we got him within 8 tries after hundreds of wipes.

Yeah, we assume causality here, but it sure seemed like the list was the thing that worked for us.
Last edited by Sepulture : 01/23/08 at 12:50 PM.
#1121SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Buiden
Originally Posted by Tyrian
- Fear warded shaman in melee group, who knows what hes doing. (Yes, im aware its possible to do the fight without this, but realistically = youd be stupid to try, if your learning the fight)
Melee have plenty of tools to deal with doomfire on their own, whether it is breaking their own fear as a warrior, or cloaking it off as a rogue, therefore placing a shaman with fear ward as highest priority on the melee should be lower priority than you state. Yeah it is nice to have a shaman with the melee, and we always do, but fear warding them shouldn't be a priority.

I find that it is much more important to break out people who can heal the quickest so we always have priests fearward the shaman they are grouped with, or themselves and then they dispel people.

Obviously more than one strategy works, it is just my experience that the quicker we get the healers unfeared the smoother our runs go from every standpoint.
#1122SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Silverstorm
We generally have 4-5 priests available (3 holy, 2 shadow), so setting up a FW rotation on two of the holy priests is the easiest thing for us to do. Both of those priests, in turn, have macros to dispel another healer. With the 3 minute cooldown on Fear ward, 2 FW + PvP trinket = 3 out of 4 fears that are easily avoided. The 4th one should be avoidable.

Plebys, melee just have to be aware. Doomfires will circle around to them. They can generally avoid fears through totems/berserker rage. Ranged should assist in letting them know, but the melee CANNOT rely on ranged to warn them. Zoom out the camera with the macro posted, then look around. You don't have to have the camera on your target to do DPS.

It's my understanding of the tremor totem that it can be dropped during Archimonde's cast of Fear, and will pulse after the cast is finished, which almost instantly frees the group. Is that correct?
#1123SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Silverstorm
It's my understanding of the tremor totem that it can be dropped during Archimonde's cast of Fear, and will pulse after the cast is finished, which almost instantly frees the group. Is that correct?
Our shamans were saying that it will definitely tick during the fear, but likely 3secs after the fear started, which might put you out of range, or not make it very useful. Might as well just drop tremor during the fight and keep it refreshed, and there's a chance it'll tick right after the fear.

On our last kill we had 2 of our dps warriors die to doomfires at 60%, our hunter die in the first 10secs(grip+airburst away from the raid while running in and MDing tank), our tank got airbursted away from the raid and still managed to get a kill. 8-9 healers seem to help a lot for this fight to counter the mistakes, as long as archimonde isn't a bitch when it comes to his soul charges.
#1124SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Buiden
Another thing I haven't noticed much talk of his his fear timer. A few patches back they changed the timer to be more consistent but we've had some ridiculously long periods without fear. For instance this week he didn't fear for 2 full minutes and was at 60% before the FIRST fear. Another run someone died right about when fear was going to go off. About 20 seconds later he finally used the soul charge... fear coming soon right? Nope. 30 more seconds he finally did his fear, almost a minute after when he should have.
#1125SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Zaq
We actually Fw our tank. It may make the shamans more essential, but we have a solid group of them. It really lets the tank worry about other things instead of holding off for the fear cast. It's just another option now.
#1126SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Tehehe
Originally Posted by Zaq
We actually Fw our tank. It may make the shamans more essential, but we have a solid group of them. It really lets the tank worry about other things instead of holding off for the fear cast. It's just another option now.
This is really a waste unless you are using a druid or paladin tank. The tank has pretty much nothing to do on this fight but build threat and use survival cooldowns/trinkets. Watching the fear timer and dancing the fear should be immensely easy for any tank that's in a position to be tanking Archimonde.
#1127SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3rayijin
Originally Posted by Tehehe
This is really a waste unless you are using a druid or paladin tank. The tank has pretty much nothing to do on this fight but build threat and use survival cooldowns/trinkets. Watching the fear timer and dancing the fear should be immensely easy for any tank that's in a position to be tanking Archimonde.
If you don't notice the fear in order to zerker rage, what are the odds you also won't react fast enough to stop attacking and prevent a possible parry-gib?

If your MT is this bad, I pity your guild.

Constructive suggestion: a priest FWing himself then dispelling the tank would be a better option.
#1128SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Caligula
I like to FW myself and dispel healers and anyone else that I can nearby, especially those heading towards Doomfires. It's probably preference but I think it's better than using FW on a healer who probably wont have any time to dispel anyone. I've saved quite a few people from being feared into a doomfire this way (or at least saved them use of their trinket). And FW on the tank seems pretty wasteful if it's a warrior. FW would have a much greater benefit on anyone else in the raid, especially a healer.
#1129SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3nataku
Originally Posted by Caligula
I like to FW myself and dispel healers and anyone else that I can nearby, especially those heading towards Doomfires. It's probably preference but I think it's better than using FW on a healer who probably wont have any time to dispel anyone. I've saved quite a few people from being feared into a doomfire this way (or at least saved them use of their trinket). And FW on the tank seems pretty wasteful if it's a warrior. FW would have a much greater benefit on anyone else in the raid, especially a healer.
I tend to do the same, sometimes acting like a mini tremor totem when I have FW up by starting to cast a Mass Dispel on a group of people when I see Archimonde casting Fear.
#1130SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3aadric
We finally killed him this week. 24-manned him on the 4th attempt.

We made a few final tweaks last week and this week. After having more or less successfully stressed the importance of not dying, we then stressed the importance of not getting the debuff in the first place, as it is a significant drain on healers attention.

We also had almost all the healers play more aggressively. If a healer's trinket is up, and they are not actively kiting a fire, they position themselves in range of the tank regardless of fires. They have to react quickly if they get the Grip. It is extremely common to have 3 groups our of range of the tank due to fires. With another tank getting airburst, that leaves only 2 healers to heal the tank (and their own group). Tying healers to groups just wasn't cutting it.
#1131SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Greymist1
Originally Posted by Tyrian
The only two tools you need to deal with this effectively are"

- Fear warded shaman in melee group, who knows what hes doing. (Yes, im aware its possible to do the fight without this, but realistically = youd be stupid to try, if your learning the fight)
- Good communication on vent. Range groups should announce immediately when a doomfire appears to turn and head towards melee. Then they run off until its safe to return, if they are slow and die in the doomfire behind them (which was warned prior on vent), they messed up.
You forgot (IMO, anyways):

- Have melee zoom their cameras all the way out, and watch for doomfire their own damn selves.


I'm not running down communication. A timely "Melee watch out doomfire!" is always welcome. But when the raid fails to announce, you can save yourself anyways, given a wide view portal and the presence of mind to avoid hyperfocusing on DPS. Archimonde rewards raids which have 25 players who do whatever's needed to maximize their personal situational awareness.
#1132SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3cyp
Hello
I have a question about Archimondes main tank gear.
First, let me describe our situation. We've started MH/BT 3 weeks ago and so far we're at 4/5 MH and 4/9 BT. Obviously our next target is Archimonde.
The thing is, we had really bad luck with drops and so far our MT is sporting the Supremus xbow and Teron pants as his only t6 loots. Is he able to tank Archimonde without the risk of being gibbed in ~2 seconds?
Here's his armory: http://eu.wowarmory.com/character-sh...azzak&n=tankeh
#1133SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Yoma
Originally Posted by cyp
Hello
I have a question about Archimondes main tank gear.
[...]
Is he able to tank Archimonde without the risk of being gibbed in ~2 seconds?
Here's his armory: The World of Warcraft Armory
Archimonde can and will hit like a truck, especially during the fear phases, so you will want to have a tank capable of tanking Kael'thas (21k HP and up). And do your healers a favor and give them a buffer to react properly, even if some of them are feared.
Note that I have only killed Archmonde three times yet, but with 3 different MTs. So, in my experience high stamina combined with an on-click avoidance trinket (for your average 'oh-shit' moments) works best. At least, it did for us.

We had a few MT's quit when we first got to Archimonde a few months back and our MT for the first few kills was far less geared than your tank. You will be fine as long as the healers are really keeping an eye on him.
#1135SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Gneek
I haven't heard anything about this yet so I thought I'd share:
During tonight's attempt, I (rogue) happened to vanish while air burst was being cast on me and the result was more than pleasant. Since Archimonde lost his target, he stopped casting it all together and went back to meleeing our MT.

It's my theory that any ability that can drop a mob's target will stop Archimonde from airbursting that particular player and everyone in the aoe's range. It *confirmed* works for Vanish. Very possibly works for Feign Death as well.

Hope it can prevent some deaths =).
#1136SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Vidofnir
Originally Posted by Gneek
I haven't heard anything about this yet so I thought I'd share:
During tonight's attempt, I (rogue) happened to vanish while air burst was being cast on me and the result was more than pleasant. Since Archimonde lost his target, he stopped casting it all together and went back to meleeing our MT.

It's my theory that any ability that can drop a mob's target will stop Archimonde from airbursting that particular player and everyone in the aoe's range. It *confirmed* works for Vanish. Very possibly works for Feign Death as well.

Hope it can prevent some deaths =).
This indeed works with Vanish. Skilled players can do it, while not-so-skilled players are just too slow for it. I'm guessing it also works for Feign Death, since it has exactly the same effect as Vanish except with a different animation: entirely removing you from the Boss' threat list.

On the other hand you saying "Hope it can prevent some deaths =)" worries me. Do you mean you have people dying to Air Burst?
#1137SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Daboran
Originally Posted by Gneek
I haven't heard anything about this yet so I thought I'd share:
During tonight's attempt, I (rogue) happened to vanish while air burst was being cast on me and the result was more than pleasant. Since Archimonde lost his target, he stopped casting it all together and went back to meleeing our MT.

It's my theory that any ability that can drop a mob's target will stop Archimonde from airbursting that particular player and everyone in the aoe's range. It *confirmed* works for Vanish. Very possibly works for Feign Death as well.

Hope it can prevent some deaths =).
A possible side-effect of this is that over the course of the fight you will get more Fears instead. From experience Archimonde will not cast Fear if someone is affected by Airburst, which accounts for the long delays occasionally once his timer for casting it is up.

Not a great difference admittedly, but a difference nonetheless and I'd count Fear as potentially a lot more dangerous than Airburst.
#1138SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Mearis
Originally Posted by Caligula
I like to FW myself and dispel healers and anyone else that I can nearby, especially those heading towards Doomfires. It's probably preference but I think it's better than using FW on a healer who probably wont have any time to dispel anyone. I've saved quite a few people from being feared into a doomfire this way (or at least saved them use of their trinket). And FW on the tank seems pretty wasteful if it's a warrior. FW would have a much greater benefit on anyone else in the raid, especially a healer.
I fear ward myself, then when fear is off cooldown, I completely stop dpsing and hover my finger over the mass dispell button. I wait for fear to start casting, it casts in exactly 1.5 seconds, and start casting mass dispell immediately - you can land the mass dispell .1 second after the fear lands if you time it right.

For example, during our last Archimonde kill:


22:59'21.978	Hyvis is afflicted by Fear
22:59'22.375	Mearis performs Mass Dispel
22:59'22.375	Mearis performs Mass Dispel
22:59'22.375	Mearis performs Mass Dispel
22:59'22.375	Mearis performs Mass Dispel
22:59'22.375	Mearis performs Mass Dispel
22:59'22.386	Mearis performs Mass Dispel on Misi
22:59'22.386	Mearis performs Mass Dispel on Elusive
22:59'22.419	Mearis performs Mass Dispel on Saladin
22:59'22.419	Mearis performs Mass Dispel on Hyvis
I landed a mass dispell roughly .3 seconds after fear had landed on 4 healers. Survival > all - as a shadowpriest mass dispell is incredible on that fight.
#1139SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3constantius
The idea about using Mass Dispel is a good one, but only really works if you go with a 4-corners (or 3-corners or some variant) strat. You require that everyone in your party be within 25 yards of you, which is not such a guaranteed thing on Archimonde.

I personally never "eat" a fear -- between WotF, Fear Ward, and my 2-minute pvp trinket, I break every single one. This means that I can play it a little more risky, stand a little closer to fires (and usually thus closer to the MT), help out with healing on every transition, and, most importantly, dispel. I get off 2-3 dispels per fear on average, usually on other healers who are around me, or people who are running straight toward fires.

It can also be a game-saving performance if you happen to see someone with Doomfire on them start running under the effects of a fear. If you dispel them, they can then pot, healthstone, ice block, etc. to save themselves. If you let them run away from you while feared, then either you are taking responsibility for their healing (as a healer, that is), or you really don't care about the raid.

It's not only priests who can remove fear, either -- it's dispellable by paladins as well, although ours don't tend to do it, instead leaving it to the priests and spamming heals on the MT.
#1140SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Mearis
Originally Posted by constantius
The idea about using Mass Dispel is a good one, but only really works if you go with a 4-corners (or 3-corners or some variant) strat. You require that everyone in your party be within 25 yards of you, which is not such a guaranteed thing on Archimonde.
Not at all, we use a spreading out strategy. I just position myself so that I can mass-dispell the maximum number of people - I make sure I am near the healers, the healers can stay wherever they want, it is my job to be near them and dispell them.
#1141SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3â—Š Fellwraith
Originally Posted by cyp
Hello
I have a question about Archimondes main tank gear.
First, let me describe our situation. We've started MH/BT 3 weeks ago and so far we're at 4/5 MH and 4/9 BT. Obviously our next target is Archimonde.
The thing is, we had really bad luck with drops and so far our MT is sporting the Supremus xbow and Teron pants as his only t6 loots. Is he able to tank Archimonde without the risk of being gibbed in ~2 seconds?
Here's his armory: The World of Warcraft Armory
He should be fine, we killed him when I was wearing similar gear.

He needs to chainchug ironshields, keep up demo shout and thunderclap. If you can tank Azgalor, you should be able to tank Archimonde, the damage is similar and you will have the similar healing interruption issues. Your healers will need to communicate if they're out of range so he knows when to pre-emptively use his trinkets.

I'd also suggest swapping pepe's shroud for the phoenix wing cloak if he has one. You don't need to worry as much about threat generation in this fight, so the +hit is an unnecessary luxury.

Armor and avoidance are as important as HP in this fight. Don't sacrifice either of them for more stamina like you would with Kael.
#1142SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Lansky
Originally Posted by Gneek
I haven't heard anything about this yet so I thought I'd share:
During tonight's attempt, I (rogue) happened to vanish while air burst was being cast on me and the result was more than pleasant. Since Archimonde lost his target, he stopped casting it all together and went back to meleeing our MT.

It's my theory that any ability that can drop a mob's target will stop Archimonde from airbursting that particular player and everyone in the aoe's range. It *confirmed* works for Vanish. Very possibly works for Feign Death as well.

Hope it can prevent some deaths =).
This has been part of our melee strategy since our first night of attempts basically. 2 camps of people stand in melee range behind Archimonde - rogues and not rogues. If they are paying attention your rogues will never get burst out of dps'ing, which can improve raid damage quite a bit. Also warrior can intercept back to him after being burst but the timing on this seems to be tougher to execute. All in all our only melee members that are normally burst and not dps'ing are the enchancement shaman.
#1143SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Cathela
Originally Posted by Fellwraith
He needs to chainchug ironshields, keep up demo shout and thunderclap.
Bolded for emphasis. We got our first kill last night after ~140 total attempts. Once the healers learned the basic survival skills, our biggest cause of tank death by far was dropped Tclaps and Demo Shouts (and tank death was the cause of roughly 1/3 of our wipes.)

The tank has a lot to deal with, so if you don't have a DPS warrior to help out with these, you might consider having one of the warlocks put up CoW to make your tank's life a little easier (and just eat the dps loss).

EDIT: And also, thanks to everyone who's posted in this thread. The advice here helped us a lot in getting our kill.
#1144SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3â€¢ goss
Originally Posted by Cathela
The tank has a lot to deal with, so if you don't have a DPS warrior to help out with these, you might consider having one of the warlocks put up CoW to make your tank's life a little easier (and just eat the dps loss).
MT really doesn't have a lot to deal with. Fight is threat insensitive, Archi doesn't crush so a missed shield block isn't the end of the world, and the tank rarely has to move. He should be able to keep both debuffs up fine, and is significantly more reliable than any DPS warrior or warlock who simply may not be near Archi at any given time.
#1145SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Mearis
Originally Posted by goss
MT really doesn't have a lot to deal with. Fight is threat insensitive, Archi doesn't crush so a missed shield block isn't the end of the world, and the tank rarely has to move. He should be able to keep both debuffs up fine, and is significantly more reliable than any DPS warrior or warlock who simply may not be near Archi at any given time.
Agreed, main tank has the easiest job by far on this fight. Threat is completely trivial, he doesn't crush, he has to fear ward a slow casting fear that no longer wipes aggro so...
#1146SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Shadorn
Our raid had the first night of attempts (around 20-25) on this encounter just recently, with the best attempt being stable to about 53% before a few errors by ranged and healers. Finished up on 48% from what I recall, but that doesnt really count

If I may, just after clarification on a few points: we currently have only 2 locks on our roster, so as far as curses go (keeping in mind we're still learning the encounter), and considering that we carry a maximum of 4 rogues, 1 critkitty and 1 enh shaman (and for arguments sake an average of 2 hunters); should we look at using CoRex and CoWeak in tandem, as opposed to the staple CoS / CoE? Or, is CoRex best left alone, for a combination of say CoS / CoWeak?

For rogues; is priority #1 for CloS considered to be air burst, even when learning the fight, or should it be saved for Grips / Doomfires? From what I observed, while most of the doomfires were avoided by melee, there seemed to be 1-2 players per attempt getting the debuff. Something that never really occured to me would be the viability of having the rogues all stand on eachother, with the remaining warrior/shaman/druid out of range as far as air burst is concerned; that's definately something we'll work on for this weeks attempts.

Any advice appreciated, thanks in advance.
#1147SourcePosted on Patch 2.3.3Castafoo
Originally Posted by Shadorn
Our raid had the first night of attempts (around 20-25) on this encounter just recently, with the best attempt being stable to about 53% before a few errors by ranged and healers. Finished up on 48% from what I recall, but that doesnt really count

If I may, just after clarification on a few points: we currently have only 2 locks on our roster, so as far as curses go (keeping in mind we're still learning the encounter), and considering that we carry a maximum of 4 rogues, 1 critkitty and 1 enh shaman (and for arguments sake an average of 2 hunters); should we look at using CoRex and CoWeak in tandem, as opposed to the staple CoS / CoE? Or, is CoRex best left alone, for a combination of say CoS / CoWeak?

For rogues; is priority #1 for CloS considered to be air burst, even when learning the fight, or should it be saved for Grips / Doomfires? From what I observed, while most of the doomfires were avoided by melee, there seemed to be 1-2 players per attempt getting the debuff. Something that never really occured to me would be the viability of having the rogues all stand on eachother, with the remaining warrior/shaman/druid out of range as far as air burst is concerned; that's definately something we'll work on for this weeks attempts.

Any advice appreciated, thanks in advance.
Considering melee DPS is usually the bulk of the damage dealt to Archimonde, it would be wise to use Curse of Recklessness. We typically use Curse of Recklessness almost always, even if we only have one or two locks on any given boss encounter. Your second curse would depend on the number of fire/frost damage dealers versus shadow/arcane damage dealers. However, given the nature of the fight I think Shadows would be the superior choice since Warlocks and Shadow Priests can do damage on the run. I don't believe Curse of Weakness stacks with Demoralizing Shout, so I wouldn't ever bother using it.

I'm not a rogue, but I imagine our rogues like to save CloS for "Oh crap!" moments. Personally I don't see the point in using it on air burst, it's not very difficult to use tears correctly.

Hope that helps.
